With hymns and songs from across Scotland.;"Claire McCollum explores Edinburgh and discovers the rich Christian heritage of Scotland’s capital. On a history tour
column6: Claire hears about individuals through the ages who
column7: inspired by their faith
column8: had an impact on Scotland and the world. She also visits Polwarth Parish Church on the banks of the Union Canal and takes a trip on the church’s brand-new canal boat!

column1: Gemma Hunt is in neighbouring Glasgow to meet a Christian using music to break down barriers by setting up a record label to nurture the talent of ex-prisoners. And Claire hears about the faith of one of Scotland’s and Edinburgh’s most celebrated sporting heroes
column2: Eric Liddell. His Olympic triumphs were immortalised in the Oscar-winning film Chariots of Fire
column3: but Eric was initially a rugby star and gained his first Scotland cap exactly 100 years ago. On the rugby pitches of the University of Edinburgh
column4: Eric’s niece tells the story of his life as a sportsman and as a missionary.

column1: A phenomenon known as ‘Peatlemania’ has recently taken hold of the nation. Fisherman Calum ‘Boydie’ Macleod
column3: and delivery driver Uilleam ‘Uilly’ Macleod - together as Peat & Diesel - have taken the Highland music scene by storm
column4: capturing the country’s imagination through their infectious music and unique tales of island life.

column1: Just one year after their first ever gig in a well known Lewis pub
column2: Peat & Diesel sold out the iconic Glasgow Barrowlands. Follow the band through this musical documentation of one of their biggest gigs yet
column3: which sees them play classics from their albums Uptown Fank and Light my Byre
column4: including the Western Isles anthem that catapulted them to fame.

column7: breathtaking and bonkers – this festival is a Scandi party paradise.;"For his final Extreme Festivals adventure of the year
column8: Chris Stark travels to the edge of the Arctic Circle to experience the Norwegian wonder that is Træna.

column1: Only accessible by boat
column2: the remote islands of Træna sees a small fishing community of hundreds become thousands when it transforms every summer into a Scandi party paradise with endless sunlight.

column1: Chris completes his epic journey on a sailing boat racing to the festival
column2: before meeting his fierce festival friends Ragna and Mira (AKA bad girl Norweigian rap duo KUUK).

column1: 29;29;Soul America;Series 1: 3. Sweet Love;How
column3: bedroom soul was born to soften soul's hard edges.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08qz2rl.jpg;BBC
column5: TV
column6: Soul America
column7: Series 1: 3. Sweet Love;How
column8: in the 70s and 80s
column9: bedroom soul was born to soften soul's hard edges.;How
column10: in the 70s and 80s
column11: a second coming of soul men offered a black female audience slow jams and sexual healing.;"How
column12: in the 70s and 80s
column13: a second coming of soul men
column14: led by Teddy Pendergrass
column15: Marvin Gaye and Luther Vandross
column16: offered a black female audience slow jams and sexual healing.

column1: In the early 70s
column2: Memphis was the capital of gospel-infused soul music
column3: thanks to two key labels. One was Stax
column4: the other was Hi Records - a high church of soul presided over by Al Green whose Let’s Stay Together pre-figured a new type of soul man
column5: one who would come to dominate the 70s - a sensitive lover man.

column1: In Philadelphia
column2: a new record label was born that would also soften soul’s hard edges. Philadelphia International Records was home to Harold Melvin and the Bluenotes
column3: from whose ranks Teddy Pendergrass would emerge. PIR was also home to the O’Jays
column4: who embodied Philadelphia’s message of love and togetherness.

column1: Fresh from the monumental success of What’s Going On
column2: Marvin Gaye went to work on his follow-up
column3: shifting focus from the streets to the bedroom with Let’s Get It On. Bedroom soul was also epitomised by the sensitive
column5: whose deep baritone put both black and white audiences in the mood.

column1: In the mid-70s
column2: disco became a lucrative sideline for female singers who delivered first-hand songs about love
column3: loss and empowerment such as Candi Staton’s Young Hearts Run Free
column4: whilst Millie Jackson did what the soul men did
column5: only more so
column6: telling it like it was.

column1: This episode also looks at the Quiet Storm radio format
column2: conceived by billionaire entrepreneur Cathy Hughes
column3: targeted at a black female audience. The title was borrowed from Smokey Robinson’s 1975 album of laid-back soul ballads
column4: and the genre helped make stars of artists such as Peabo Bryson
column5: whose smooth ballads led the listener discretely to the bedroom door.

column1: The tragic death of Marvin Gaye
column2: on the back of his biggest success - Sexual Healing - and the paralysis of Teddy Pendergrass seemed like bad omens for soul in the 80s. But one artist filled the gap. New York-born Luther Vandross started out as one of the most in-demand backing vocalists before redefining soul with Never Too Much. Luther may have been the 80s soul king
column3: but he did not rule alone. Anita Baker was the queen. Her 1986 hit album Rapture pursued a similar
column4: contemporary yet retro take on soul.

column1: However
column2: Luther couldn’t hold back the tide forever. The birth of hip hop as a political force and the arrival of MTV closed the door on soul
column3: ushering in a new era for black music. The soul epoch may have been over
column4: but the music never went away and
column5: from time to time
column6: it resurfaces in all its glory.

column1: With The O’Jays
column5: Jerry Cummings
column6: Charles Hodges
column7: Candi Staton
column8: Peabo Bryson
column9: Millie Jackson and Cathy Hughes. Expert analysis from Mark Anthony Neal
column10: David Ritz and Nelson George.

column8: Krept and Konan set the final challenge for the artists: they must perform their final bars on Kenny Allstar’s legendary 1Xtra show. ;"It’s the final episode of The Rap Game UK and the last chance for the five artists to impress Krept
column9: Konan and DJ Target in their battle for the £20k music prize.

column1: It’s been a tough contest for the MCs
column2: and their hard work culminates in one final challenge - performing their final bars on Kenny Allstar’s legendary 1Xtra show.

column1: The artists begin the episode by meeting Krept
column2: Konan and Target in a series of one-to-ones with no topic off limits. After bidding farewell to their Manchester penthouse
column3: the MCs return to their hometowns for inspiration in writing their final bars on this year’s series.

column1: Later
column3: the artists record their tracks for Kenny Allstar’s BBC Radio 1Xtra show. There’s no room for nerves as the MCs showcase their rap skills for the last time. They also then face tough and probing questions from a panel of renowned interviewers as they look back over the previous five episodes. Will any of the artists wilt under the glare of a media grilling?

column1: As the final performances are broadcast on the radio
column3: Konan and DJ Target hear them for the first time

column5: Let's Spend the Night Together and Get Off of My Cloud through the late 60s and early 70s era of prolific song writing when the band were knocking out a classic album every other year and offering up such classics as Honky Tonk Women and Gimme Shelter.

column1: 55;55;Boy George and Culture Club: Karma to Calamity;None;Film about Culture Club's 2014 reunion
column2: as they record a new album and tour the UK and US.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p02kbskm.jpg;BBC
column5: Boy George and Culture Club: Karma to Calamity;Film about Culture Club's 2014 reunion
column6: as they record a new album and tour the UK and US.;Documentary about Culture Club's 2014 reunion
column7: as they record a new album and embark on a UK and US tour
column8: seen through the prism of the band's sometimes troubled past.;"In the early 1980s
column9: Culture Club was one of the biggest bands in the world
column10: selling 150 million records worldwide. Formed in London
column11: the band was comprised of Boy George on vocals
column12: Mikey Craig on bass
column13: Roy Hay on guitar and keyboards and Jon Moss on drums. As well as their UK success
column14: the band was huge in the USA - notching up ten top 40 hits. Being part of Band Aid cemented them as stalwarts of the 80s
column15: a band that broke down barriers and left a huge legacy for the stars that came later
column16: before they disbanded in 1986.

column1: However
column2: they are a band with a past as colourful as their music. George had a secret affair with his drummer Jon Moss and when they acrimoniously split
column3: the band fell apart and George descended into heroin addiction. Over the years there have been numerous failed attempts to reunite the band.

column1: In 2014 Culture Club decided to come back together to record a new album and embark on a UK and US tour. Director Mike Nicholls has unique access
column2: following the band as they first meet in George's London home to write new material. However
column3: it's not long before creative differences and tensions from their past begin to emerge. Faultlines develop further when the band travel to Spain to record the new album
column4: spending two weeks working and living together in a remote recording studio.

column1: As the band return to London to prepare for the tour
column2: they suffer a Twitter mauling after their first big public performance on Strictly Come Dancing. Relations are even more strained when George and the band sign to separate managers and a sudden illness threatens the whole reunion.

column1: The film looks at the band's troubled past
column4: and reveals the personalities behind one of the most iconic bands of all time.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;Contains strong language.;2015;59;music

column5: Welcome to the World of George the Poet;A mix of poetry
column6: music and conversation exploring what rap can teach us about education.;A mix of poetry
column7: music and conversation exploring what rap can teach us about education
column8: from the BBC's Radio Theatre.;Award-winning podcaster and spoken word artist George the Poet comes to the BBC’s own Radio Theatre for a one-off live show exploring what rap can teach us about education. For George
column9: rap was always a vehicle for knowledge. But it isn’t always taken seriously by an establishment that often sees it as unconstructive. Rap was an essential part of George’s own development as a poet
column10: and studying sociology at Cambridge University allowed him to look more closely at what rap can do for marginalised communities. This show charts George’s own story of education – his evolution from Grime MC to Cambridge student to spoken word artist – and pays homage to the rap music that shaped him and his peers. George brings a number of friends to the stage to explore what rap can teach us about education.;Entertainment;BBC RADIO FOUR;False;2019;72;music

column1: 81;81;Lindisfarne’s Geordie Genius: The Alan Hull Story;None;Sam Fender traces the career of fellow Geordie music legend - Alan Hull of Lindisfarne.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b4kn7x.jpg;BBC
column4: Lindisfarne’s Geordie Genius: The Alan Hull Story;Sam Fender traces the career of fellow Geordie music legend - Alan Hull of Lindisfarne.;Sam Fender goes in search of his hero - Alan Hull of Lindisfarne. Hull wrote hit songs such as Lady Eleanor and Fog on the Tyne. With contributions from Sting
column5: Elvis Costello and Dave Stewart.;"Brit Award winner Sam Fender goes in search of a musical hero from another era - the late
column6: great
column7: Alan Hull of Lindisfarne. Sam is amazed how few people
column8: outside of his native north east
column9: know much about his hero’s work. He’s now on a mission to win back Hull’s place in music history.

column1: In this film
column2: he traces the career of the man whose words and music put Newcastle and supergroup Lindisfarne on the musical map in the 1970s. Alan continued to write classic songs until his early death in 1995. He spoke of love and life
column3: championed the underdog and the misunderstood
column4: and celebrated working-class people and his hometown - both of which he loved with a passion. Alan lived and wrote through turbulent times - writing eloquently about the troubles in Northern Ireland
column5: the Falklands War and the miners’ strike.

column1: Sam digs out great archive interviews
column4: family and bandmates who knew Alan Hull best. Sam also hears from top stars like Sting
column5: Elvis Costello
column6: Mark Knopfler
column7: Dave Stewart and Peter Gabriel. All were huge fans of songs such as Lady Eleanor
column8: Fog on the Tyne
column9: Winter Song
column10: Clear White Light and Run For Home. But he also finds that Alan inspired an entire new generation of musicians like Kay Greyson: a young rapper from Tyneside. To his surprise
column11: Sam discovers ‘Hully’ also took the lead role in an acclaimed BBC TV primetime drama. He reveals a complex man - a political animal
column12: a drinker and an agitator

column1: 83;83;Krept and Konan: We Are England;None;Rappers Krept and Konan explore Englishness while creating a Euros football anthem.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09kbnm3.jpg;BBC
column4: Krept and Konan: We Are England;Rappers Krept and Konan explore Englishness while creating a Euros football anthem.;Rappers Krept and Konan explore Englishness as they create a football anthem for the Euros
column5: seeking advice from England players
column6: manager Gareth Southgate and fellow rap artists.;"As we emerge into the sunlight from the long shadow of lockdown
column7: the UEFA Euros Tournament in June is one of the world’s most highly anticipated sporting events. And
column8: with the final on 11 July taking place on the hallowed turf of Wembley
column9: football really is coming home this summer.

column1: In We Are England
column3: two of the UK’s most talented and successful rap artists
column4: are setting out to mark what is sure to be a huge shared cultural moment by making a track to celebrate the England football team. But first they need to investigate what Englishness actually means in 2021. It’s never been a simple question for those of non-white British heritage
column5: but it’s a question they’ll need to tackle if they are going to create an authentic track to celebrate the national squad.

column1: Because instead of the traditional cheesy sing-along
column2: featuring a former soap actor or long-retired left-back
column3: Krept and Konan are going to create an anthem for our times: representing the modern diversity and forward-looking culture in which our chart-topping rap stars and the young stars of the England team are cut from the same cloth. Rap culture is the culture of young Britain
column4: and today’s top-tier teams now move to a whole different beat than they did when the Three Lions anthem of Euros 96 had them tapping their toes in the changing rooms and their fans chanting on the terraces. The lifestyle
column5: attitude
column6: slang and swagger of rap culture is replicated in the national football team – itself now one of the youngest and most diverse it has ever been – and many of the country’s biggest rappers came up honing their football skills and their rap lyrics on our city streets and in the ‘cages’ of the UK’s estates
column7: just as top footballers grew up surrounded by hip hop culture
column8: looking up to rap stars.

column1: So if they’re going to create a track to celebrate the pride of a new nation
column2: it’s these stories that Krept and Konan want to tell
column4: aspirational culture they want to reflect. On their journey into exploring national identity
column5: they hit the road
column6: striking out beyond the streets of the capital as they get to know the England squad
column7: meeting players including Everton’s Dominic Calvert-Lewin
column8: Aston Villa’s Tyrone Mings and West Ham’s Declan Rice as well as retired Lioness legend
column9: Eni Aluko. They also seek advice from fellow artists including chart-topping Manchester rapper Aitch who they meet at Old Trafford
column10: and west London rapper Big Zuu as they watch some football anthems from days gone by to see just how much our national culture has changed. They also go to St George’s Park
column11: home of the England team
column12: where they get an exclusive audience with England manager Gareth Southgate to find out what ingredients he’d like to see making it into the final song.";Sport;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2021;57;music

column7: delayed for a full year
column8: will see three exceptional musicians compete for one of music’s most coveted titles. The finalists have had to wait for their moment in the spotlight
column9: but it’s certain that the brilliance of the music-making will be even more special as the twenty-second edition of the contest reaches its much anticipated conclusion.

column1: The grand final takes place at the Bridgewater Hall
column3: where each finalist will perform a full concerto with the BBC Philharmonic Orchestra and celebrated British conductor Mark Wigglesworth. Presenters Anna Lapwood
column4: Josie d’Arby and Jess Gillam – herself a finalist in 2016 – are on hand to guide you through proceedings. Joining Anna with expert analysis is the 1980 winner of the title
column5: oboist and conductor Nicholas Daniel.

column1: A judging panel featuring some of the UK’s leading musical figures is tasked with making what is always a difficult decision. They are clarinettist and composer Mark Simpson
column2: winner of BBC Young Musician in 2006
column5: principal conductor of the BBC National Orchestra of Wales
column6: Ryan Bancroft
column7: award-winning composer and performer Errollyn Wallen
column8: MBE
column9: and returning to chair the jury
column10: the chief executive of performance venue Saffron Hall
column11: Angela Dixon.

column1: As well as the performances by the three finalists
column2: we will also see a return to the competition for a very special performance by the 2018 winner

column1: Who will follow in her footsteps? All will be revealed at the end of what promises to be a thrilling finale to BBC Young Musician 2020.

86;86;Tangled Up with Dylan: The Ballad of AJ Weberman;None;Documentary chronicling the life, times and crimes of Bob Dylan obsessive AJ Weberman.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09htx2m.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Tangled Up with Dylan: The Ballad of AJ Weberman;Documentary chronicling the life, times and crimes of Bob Dylan obsessive AJ Weberman.;Documentary chronicling the life, times and crimes of Bob Dylan obsessive AJ Weberman, who spent years rooting through Dylan's rubbish to try to gain insight into his life.;Documentary chronicling the life
column2: times and crimes of notorious Bob Dylan obsessive and garbology inventor AJ Weberman. It's an irreverent and witty exploration into one man's obsessions
column3: a bohemian life lived on the New York fringes and a uniquely twisted take on the American dream.

column1: Bob Dylan once said 'I don't think I'm gonna be really understood until maybe 100 years from now'. Author of the Dylan To English Dictionary
column2: a Dylanologist and originator of garbology (the practice of rooting through rubbish in order to gain insight into prominent people's lives)
column3: Weberman has made it his life's work to understand Dylan.

column1: At times both hilarious and disturbing
column2: the film is not only a great companion piece to Scorsese's No Direction Home but an interesting observation on our unbalanced desires to know more about celebrities and how far we are willing to go to get that information or even become a part of their lives.

column1: Weberman does not see himself as a stalker and insists that Dylan should be grateful that he is around: 'how was I to know I would have been to Dylan what Verlaine was to Rimbaud'. It's hard to see this as a tale of poet and critic
column2: but rather a look at the bizarre relationship between the obsessed and the object of his obsession and how it can completely take over a man's life.

column1: Beginning in the 1960s when Dylan was at the height of his early fame and regarded as something close to a prophet or a seer by the American counter-culture
column2: Weberman has sought to try and climb inside Dylan's head by going through his rubbish. Back then he pursued his obsession relentlessly.

column1: An amusing telephone conversation between Weberman and Dylan
column3: punctuates the film in the form of animations
column4: creating connections between Weberman's past and present.

column1: The film also features an unforgettable cast of supporting characters close to Weberman
column2: including New York street singer David Peel
column3: former child dancer Jay Byrd and Aaron Kay aka 'The Pieman'
column4: and enjoys a vivid Americana soundtrack performed by cast members
column5: adding an extra veneer of strangeness to Weberman and his universe.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;Contains strong language.;2011;76;music

column1: 95;95;Listening through the Lens: The Christopher Nupen Films;None;A film about Christopher Nupen
column2: a pioneering director of films about classical music.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xh28z.jpg;BBC
column5: Listening through the Lens: The Christopher Nupen Films;A film about Christopher Nupen
column6: a pioneering director of films about classical music.;Documentary about Christopher Nupen
column7: a pioneering film director who championed classical music on television
column8: seizing upon his unique access to a golden generation of musicians.;"A tribute to Christopher Nupen
column9: who became Britain’s first independent television producer in the 1960s at the dawn of the documentary era. It is also the story of how the talents of a golden generation of artists were forever preserved on film. Nupen came from an unlikely background in South Africa and ‘ticked none of the boxes’
column10: but seizing upon the emerging camera technology and his unique access
column11: he filmed classical music in a completely new and intimate way that broke down the barriers between artists and their public. As a result
column12: this documentary is also an important story about the history of music on television and the great artists who collaborated on the films.

column1: Now 86
column2: Nupen reflects on 75 productions about artists and composers spanning more than 50 years. His body of work convincingly enforces his conviction that television is capable of remembering artists in a way that no other medium can equal. Oxford philosopher and historian Sir Isaiah Berlin described Nupen’s films as being ‘at just about the highest level which television is capable of reaching’.

column1: The programme cherry-picks examples of Christopher Nupen’s best work between 1966 and 2017. When he started
column2: he instinctively blended documentary and musical performance to create a new genre of film. He filmed musicians at close quarters in their natural environment
column3: where they have most to offer. Television picked up the exuberant spirit of the new generation and carried it far and wide. The effects were dramatic and brought countless numbers of people to music for the first time.

column1: A musician himself
column2: Nupen’s musical friends were among the most-renowned artists of the 20th and 21st centuries. Capturing their unique talents on film
column3: we relive sublime historical moments with the likes of Daniel Barenboim
column5: Andrès Segovia
column6: John Williams
column7: Nathan Milstein
column8: Placido Domingo
column9: Itzhak Perlman
column10: Jacqueline du Pré
column11: Vladimir Ashkenazy
column12: Evgeny Kissin and Daniil Trifonov.

column1: This episode focuses on 1999. The full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement is stalled over the issue of decommissioning. The Ulster Unionist Party insists there must be decommissioning of IRA weapons before a power-sharing executive can be set up.
Despite the Good Friday Agreement there are a number of violent incidents
column2: including the murder of former IRA man turned informer Eamon Collins and civil rights lawyer Rosemary Nelson. A number of deadlines set by the British and Irish governments for the establishment of the executive pass without success.

column1: However in November
column2: thanks to Senator George Mitchell’s review of the agreement
column3: the Ulster Unionists agree to enter government before any decommissioning takes place. A power-sharing executive is finally established and devolved government is returned to Northern Ireland.";History;BBC TWO NORTHERN IRELAND DIGITAL;False;2019;29;music

column7: from tavern songs to sacred music and stage works.;Charles Hazlewood explores the lives of great composers. Seminal figure Henry Purcell is celebrated
column8: from his tavern songs to sacred music and stage works.;"In this series
column9: conductor Charles Hazlewood explores the development of British music through the lives
column10: times and works of four great composers
column11: each with a major anniversary in 2009.

column1: The first programme celebrates the music of Henry Purcell
column2: one of the most seminal but mysterious figures of British musical history. Charles investigates what life would have been like for a composer in 17th-century London through a wide range of Purcell's music
column3: from the vast but often overlooked output of tavern songs to his glorious sacred music and pioneering stage works such as Dido and Aeneas. He discovers how Purcell's work is still central to British life today
column4: visiting the Grenadier Guards at Wellington Barracks and attending the Service of Remembrance at the Cenotaph.

column1: Few bands have undergone such radical musical and personal change. The band evolved from the 60s British blues boom to perfect a US West Coast sound that saw them sell 40 million copies of the album Rumours.
However

column7: including the role Britain played in paving the way for their success.;"Between 1989 and 1994
column8: Nirvana introduced a new and exciting brand of rock music to the UK – one that changed the musical landscape and influenced a generation of British youth.

column1: Thirty years on since the release of their seminal album Nevermind
column2: this documentary examines the special relationship between Nirvana and the UK – including the role Britain played in paving the way for their global success.

column1: Featuring rare and unseen archive footage - as well as home movies shot by the band themselves - the film charts Nirvana’s rise from their very first British tour
column2: performing in pubs and tiny gig venues
column3: through to legendary (and infamous) TV appearances on The Word and Top of the Pops that helped cement their status as one of the biggest rock bands on the planet
column4: taking ‘grunge culture’ from the underground to the mainstream.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains strong language.;2021;59;music

column1: 124;124;Llangollen;2021;Josie D’Arby presents highlights from the 2021 Llangollen Eisteddfod.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09qftn6.jpg;BBC
column5: 2021;Josie D’Arby presents highlights from the 2021 Llangollen Eisteddfod.;Highlights from the 2021 Llangollen Eisteddfod as Josie D’Arby introduces new commissions from Paul Mealor
column6: Catrin Finch and renowned artist Luke Jerram.;"Josie D’Arby presents highlights from the 2021 Llangollen Eisteddfod.

column1: This year’s events in Llangollen combine new commissions from Catrin Finch and Paul Mealor
column2: performed both online and in the famous pavilion
column3: with a remarkable artwork that decorates the old bridge at the heart of the town. It climaxes in possibly the biggest musical event in Wales since the pandemic began.

column1: The international performers may not be able to travel to Llangollen this year
column2: but a new dance track has been created by singer-songwriter Lily Beau and rapper Magugu. Shared on TikTok
column3: it invites dancers the world over to take part.

column1: Catrin Finch has been working on a new commission combining harp with Indian tabla percussion and traditional wooden flutes. Add in beatboxer Mr Phormula and the Cardiff Oasis refugee choir
column2: and the result is a piece that reflects the international outlook of the eisteddfod.

column1: Luke Jerman is an internationally renowned visual artist whose projects have included a giant slide in Bristol and a huge replica of the moon – now he takes on the medieval bridge at the heart of Llangollen.

Composer Paul Mealor has been working with the writer Mererid Hopwood on a piece for orchestra and chorus on the theme of tangefedd (peace). It’s a work that reflects the original spirit of the Eisteddfod
column2: which was set up to unite nations through music and dance following the Second World War. More than 100 socially distanced singers take part
column3: drawn from several of the choirs that have won at Llangollen in the past. For many
column4: it will be their first chance to sing together and perform since the Covid pandemic started
column5: and it promises to be an emotional occasion.";Music;BBC TWO WALES DIGITAL;False;2021;39;music;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09qftn6.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09qftn6.jpg;josie ’ arby present highlight 2021 llangollen eisteddfod year ’ event llangollen combine new commission catrin finch paul mealor performed online famous pavilion remarkable artwork decorates old bridge heart town climax possibly biggest musical event wale since pandemic began international performer may able travel llangollen year new dance track created singersongwriter lily beau rapper magugu shared tiktok invite dancer world take part catrin finch working new commission combining harp indian tabla percussion traditional wooden flute add beatboxer mr phormula cardiff oasis refugee choir result piece reflects international outlook eisteddfod luke jerman internationally renowned visual artist whose project included giant slide bristol huge replica moon – take medieval bridge heart llangollen composer paul mealor working writer mererid hopwood piece orchestra chorus theme tangefedd peace ’ work reflects original spirit eisteddfod set unite nation music dance following second world war 100 socially distanced singer take part drawn several choir llangollen past many first chance sing together perform since covid pandemic started promise emotional occasion;19

column1: 127;127;Arlo Parks: A Popstar in a Pandemic;None;How does an up and coming artist survive a global pandemic and release a debut album?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p094nssf.jpg;BBC
column4: Arlo Parks: A Popstar in a Pandemic;How does an up and coming artist survive a global pandemic and release a debut album?;At the start of 2020
column5: BBC Radio 1 gave Arlo Parks a camera
column6: to capture an exciting new artist making their debut album. No one could have predicted how the story would unfold.;"At the start of 2020
column7: BBC Radio 1 gave Arlo Parks a video camera
column8: to capture behind the scenes of a new
column9: exciting artist during the making of their debut album. No one could have predicted how the story would unfold.

column1: In March 2020
column2: Arlo Parks was on her first headline tour of the UK when Covid-19 brought the country to a halt. Her remaining shows were cancelled and no longer able to perform
column3: she went back to living at home with her parents in London. She began to grieve for the year she had lost
column4: sometimes not leaving the house for days. Until
column5: she decided she needed to change her perspective.

column1: Determined not to be defeated by the circumstances
column2: Arlo Parks put a plan together and began writing her debut album
column3: connecting with other artists and fans online and as restrictions began to ease
column4: she flourished even further. She collaborated with some of her favourite singers and performed in two Live Lounges in lockdown. She crafted album artwork and even went to sing on a stripped back Pyramid Stage in Glastonbury.

column1: Trad music show presented by Julie Fowlis. Ceòl aig Baile brings old and new musical friends together to create music and perform intimate concerts at venues in hot-spot areas for traditional music around Scotland.
Filmed at Armadale Castle & Gardens
column2: this programme spotlights a mix of new music and standout collaborations by some of the best traditional musicians with connections to the Isle of Skye. Included are performances of a selection of Gaelic songs by Mary Ann Kennedy and Anne Martin
column3: as well as local instrumental music and dance from Angus MacKenzie
column5: Sophie Stephenson and Murdo Cameron. Skye-based band Da Birlinn reveal musical bonds between Skye and Shetland.

Told entirely through interviews with the maestro
column5: the film starts with his earliest musical experiences as a child piano prodigy in Buenos Aires
column6: before following his meteoric rise to fame
column7: including his encounters with other musical giants such as Nadia Boulanger and Arthur Rubinstein
column8: who gave the 14-year-old Daniel his first vodka and cigar!

column1: We also learn of Barenboim’s move to Israel when he was a teenager
column2: where he lived a double life as a musical genius and an ordinary schoolboy. He then talks with unusual intimacy about his relationship with cellist Jacqueline du Pré and her long battle with multiple sclerosis. The film also charts Barenboim’s stellar career as an orchestral conductor
column3: his move into opera and the founding of the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra with Edward Said.

column5: TV
column6: Carole King: Natural Woman;The story of Carole King
column7: including her upbringing
column8: musical success and eco-activism.;Documentary telling the story of Carole King's Brooklyn upbringing
column9: her songwriting success with Gerry Goffin
column10: her time as an LA singer-songwriter and her more recent eco-activism.;"Documentary telling
column11: in her own words
column12: the story of Carole King's upbringing in Brooklyn and the subsequent success that she had as half of husband-and-wife songwriting team Goffin and King for Aldon Music on Broadway.

column1: It was during this era in the early 1960s that they created a string of pop hits such as Take Good Care of My Baby for Bobby Vee
column2: The Locomotion for Little Eva and Will You Love Me Tomorrow for the Shirelles
column3: which became the first number one hit by a black American girl group. They also wrote the era-defining Up on the Roof for the Drifters and the magnificent Natural Woman for Aretha Franklin.

column1: By 1970 Carole was divorced from songwriting partner Gerry Goffin and had moved to Los Angeles. It was here that she created her classic solo album Tapestry
column2: packed with delightful tunes but also
column5: very much sung from the heart. The album included It's Too Late
column6: I Feel the Earth Move and You've Got a Friend and held the record for the most weeks at number one by a solo female artist for nearly 20 years. It became a trusted part of everyone's record collection and has sold over 25 million copies to date.

column1: The film features some wonderful unseen material and home movies
column2: and narrates her life as an acclaimed singer-songwriter. To date
column3: more than 400 of her compositions have been recorded by over 1
column5: resulting in 100 hit singles.

column1: More recently
column3: Carole was the first woman to be awarded the prestigious Gershwin Prize for Popular Song by the Library of Congress for her songwriting
column5: which tells her life story during the Goffin and King era
column6: has received rave reviews. And in 2015
column7: Carole was a recipient of the Kennedy Center Honors
column8: celebrating her lifetime artistic achievements.

column1: Nowadays Carole King would see herself as an environmental activist as much as a songwriter
column2: and she is to be found constantly lobbying congress in defence of the wildlife and ecosystems of her beloved Idaho.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;52;music

column1: 142;142;Marianne and Leonard: Words of Love;None;The beautiful yet tragic love story between Leonard Cohen and his muse Marianne Ihlen.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07x0h42.jpg;BBC
column4: Marianne and Leonard: Words of Love;The beautiful yet tragic love story between Leonard Cohen and his muse Marianne Ihlen.;The beautiful yet tragic love story of Leonard Cohen and his Norwegian muse Marianne Ihlen
column5: following their relationship from the early days on Hydra to Leonard becoming a successful musician.;"The beautiful yet tragic love story between Leonard Cohen and his Norwegian muse Marianne Ihlen. Their love began on the idyllic Greek island of Hydra in 1960 as part of a bohemian community of foreign artists
column6: writers
column7: and musicians. This film follows their relationship
column8: from the early days on Hydra
column9: a humble time of 'free love' and open marriage
column10: to how their love evolved when Leonard became a successful musician.

column1: It was on Hydra in 1968 that director Nick Broomfield
column3: first met Marianne Ihlen. Marianne introduced him to Leonard Cohen’s music and also encouraged Broomfield to make his first film. She was an enormous influence on him. Marianne and Leonard's was a love story that would continue for the rest of their lives. Along the way the film tells of the tragedy that befell those that could not survive the beauty of Hydra
column4: the highs and lows of Leonard's career

column4: The Rapper Who Chopped His Penis Off;Wu-Tang Clan-affiliated rapper Christ Bearer’s drug-induced mental health crisis.;An intimate and at times harrowing portrait of a rapper from the male-dominated
column5: bravado-soaked
column6: hip hop industry
column7: who made an almost fatal decision.;"Christ Bearer
column8: aka Andre Johnson
column9: was headline news in just about every publication during April 2014.

column1: He went from being an underground Wu-Tang Clan affiliated rapper to a humorous
column2: worldwide tabloid sensation overnight: the wacky story of the rapper who cut his own penis off and jumped from a two story balcony.

column1: Harassed by the media while recovering in hospital
column2: his suffering was overlooked until months later
column3: when it emerged that Andre had been under the influence of PCP among other drugs
column4: and had been suffering from severe depression.

column1: The act was in fact a reaction to the downward spiral of dark and destructive thoughts he was experiencing as a result of a far from perfect family life.
This documentary hears from a number of Andre’s friends
column3: offering a first hand look at how difficult mental health issues can be to address in such a macho industry as Hip Hop.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains very strong language and upsetting scenes.;2017;18;music

column1: 150;150;Billie: In Search of Billie Holiday;None;Documentary showcasing American legend Billie Holiday.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p099j0b3.jpg;BBC
column4: Billie: In Search of Billie Holiday;Documentary showcasing American legend Billie Holiday.;Documentary showcasing American legend Billie Holiday
column5: capturing her depths and complexity through the voices of those who knew her best.;"Billie Holiday
column6: known one of the greatest voices of all time as well as a woman of breathtaking talent and global popularity
column7: was a figure of controversy throughout her short life - a black woman in a white man’s world
column8: a victim and a rebel. Her infamous Strange Fruit
column9: the first protest song of the civil rights movement
column10: earned her powerful enemies. She was also an enigma
column11: her telling of her own life story a mix of half truths and free-form improvisations.

column1: Then
column2: in the late 1960s journalist Linda Lipnack Kuehl set out to write the definitive biography of Billie. Over the next decade
column3: she tracked down and tape-recorded interviews with the extraordinary characters that populated the iconic singer’s short

column1: Raw
column3: these incredible testimonies ranged from musical greats like Charles Mingus
column5: Sylvia Syms and Count Basie to her cousin
column6: schoolfriends
column7: lovers
column8: lawyers
column9: pimps and even the FBI agents who arrested her. But Linda’s book was never finished
column10: and the tapes remained unplayed – until now.

column1: With unprecedented and exclusive access to Linda's astonishing 200 hours of never-before-heard interviews
column2: this documentary showcases an American legend
column3: capturing her depths and complexity through the voices of those who knew her best. Painstakingly restored with footage and stills colourised by one of the world's leading colour artists
column4: it is an arresting and powerful tale of one of the greatest singers who ever lived
column5: and of Linda Lipnack Kuehl
column6: the woman who would sacrifice her life in trying to tell it.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains very strong language.;2021;90;music

column10: La Bohème
column11: performed at the Royal Opera House
column12: Covent Garden.

column1: Ever since its premiere in Turin in 1896
column2: La bohème has been a huge hit with audiences across the world. Within two years
column3: it had been seen in Buenos Aires
column5: Prague
column6: Berlin
column7: Manchester and beyond. With over 500 performances chalked up at Covent Garden alone
column8: this opera is one of the most popular and enduring in the repertoire.

column1: In this performance from 2020
column2: Sonya Yoncheva stars as the doomed seamstress Mimì
column4: who falls in love with her at first sight. Simona Mihai and Andrzej Filonczyk perform the roles of the on-off lovers
column5: Musetta and Marcello.

column1: Richard Jones’s period production brings to life the garret flats and shopping arcades of 19th-century Paris
column3: pitting the rags of the bohemians against the riches of the swanky shopping arcades and restaurants of the French capital.

column1: Poverty and passion collide in a story of friendship and fellowship
column2: love and loss. Featuring some of Puccini’s best-loved music
column3: this performance is conducted by Emmanuel Villaume.";Music;BBC FOUR;False;2021;119;music;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b8qj7f.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b8qj7f.jpg;puccini ’ operatic masterpiece la bohème performed royal opera house covent garden ever since premiere turin 1896 la bohème huge hit audience across world within two year seen buenos aire los angeles prague berlin manchester beyond 500 performance chalked covent garden alone opera one popular enduring repertoire performance 2020 sonya yoncheva star doomed seamstress mimì charles castronovo rodolfo fall love first sight simona mihai andrzej filonczyk perform role onoff lover musetta marcello richard jones ’ period production brings life garret flat shopping arcade 19thcentury paris design stewart laing pitting rag bohemian rich swanky shopping arcade restaurant french capital poverty passion collide story friendship fellowship love loss featuring puccini ’ bestloved music performance conducted emmanuel villaume;19

column1: 159;159;Nile Rodgers: How to Make It in the Music Business;Series 1: Episode 3;Nile shows us how he has adapted to the new musical landscape and digital media.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bkcj8d.jpg;BBC
column4: Nile Rodgers: How to Make It in the Music Business
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;Nile shows us how he has adapted to the new musical landscape and digital media.;Nile shows us how he has adapted to the new musical landscape and has collaborated with a diverse range of musicians - Daft Punk
column6: Laura Mvula
column7: Keith Urban
column8: Avicii and John Newman.;"The final part is almost entirely set in the landscape of the music world today - a world that is near unrecognisable from the one Nile started out in over 40 years ago.

column1: Technology and digital media have revolutionised how we hear music. Digital platforms like YouTube
column3: Apple Music and others make music instantly available to everyone. Computers and the internet have changed how music is written and composed and
column5: artists can communicate directly with their fans - they can even release their music to them with a single tweet.

column1: Nile shows us how he has adapted to this new world and why he wants to be a part of it. We discover how
column3: he has collaborated with a more diverse range of musicians on a greater variety of music than ever before.

column1: The first collaboration we hear about is Get Lucky with Daft Punk
column2: which became a Grammy-award-winning international hit. Later
column3: we have contributions from singer-songwriter Laura Mvula
column4: who won a Novello award this year for her album The Dreaming Room which Nile worked on. We hear from top country music star Keith Urban - they were both nominated last year at the Country Music Awards. And from Swedish DJ and composer Avicii
column5: who plays to audiences of tens of thousands around the world
column6: we discover the closeness of their musical relationship and learn about their working methods. We discover how Nile's contribution to singer John Newman's song Give Me Your Love came about.

column1: In what is the 40th anniversary of Nile's band Chic
column2: we see him on stage in Glasgow
column3: and at the end of the film Nile reveals that he has just finished recording a new song. Called I Believe In Music
column4: this at present unreleased song sums up Nile's personal philosophy toward the art form that has dominated his life. This film has exclusive access to that song.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;False;2017;59;music

column2: a mother and an international pop star

column4: launching an acting career and being a first-time mum.

column1: The film observes Paloma’s life both front and backstage in the midst of this pivotal year for her career. We see her struggling with choices every mum will be familiar with
column2: whilst embarking on enormous career challenges in a cut-throat business. Paloma not only returns to work after having her baby
column3: but also to huge expectations to break Australia and America.

column1: A familiar presence on the London underground circuit for several years
column2: Paloma Faith eventually broke into the mainstream thanks to her ultra-flamboyant theatrical style and retro-soul sound. Born in Hackney to a Spanish father and English mother
column3: at the age of 18 she made her debut on the cabaret scene
column4: singing in a covers band called Paloma and the Penetrators
column5: before performing as a magician’s assistant and appearing in a burlesque troupe. After turning down an opportunity to join Amy Winehouse’s band
column6: she began writing and performing her own songs
column7: and soon earned a reputation as one of London’s most exciting and flamboyant live acts.

column1: She hit the big time in 2009 after releasing her first album
column2: which reached number two in the UK and went platinum within weeks of release. Since then
column3: she has sold well over a million records
column5: each of which went double platinum and reached number one in the album charts. She is a household name in Britain
column6: having been a judge on The Voice and having had roles in numerous television series and films. Now
column7: after returning to work following the birth
column8: she will star as the villain in a new Batman TV series
column9: write and launch her fifth album
column10: and
column11: she hopes
column12: crack America – all while being a working mum.

column1: 185;185;Blackburn Sings Christmas with Gareth Malone;None;Gareth Malone travels to Blackburn to stage a Christmas concert.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bbnvz2.jpg;BBC

column6: to stage a concert with local musical talent that brings the whole town together.;"In this seasonal special
column7: choirmaster Gareth Malone heads to Blackburn
column8: one of the areas of the country hardest hit by Covid-19
column9: to create a concert that celebrates the work of NHS staff and the community spirit of the town.

column1: In the Royal Blackburn Hospital and the surrounding town
column2: Gareth comes across a wealth of amateur musical talent. Working with them to devise and rehearse musical performances that reflect their experiences over the last year
column3: he uncovers a range of moving stories about how the town has pulled together through the pandemic.

column1: In the hospital
column2: Gareth meets porter Stephen. Before the pandemic
column4: but when all of the music venues in the area closed because of lockdown
column5: he found himself in need of work and decided to take a job at the hospital. As a cleaner and porter during the height of the pandemic
column6: Stephen found he was able to bring comfort to patients through his singing. Even now
column7: with music venues open again
column8: Stephen continues to work at the hospital
column9: and the performance he devises with Gareth will beam his talent out across the town.

column1: Then there’s Tanviha
column2: a local mother who found herself in critical care at the hospital when she contracted Covid-19 last year. At eight months pregnant
column3: she had to give birth by caesarean before being put into an induced coma. Through the care of the hospital staff
column4: Tanviha pulled through and was able to be reunited with her husband Tabraiz
column5: baby son Kameel and her three-year-old daughter Sonum. Her moving and uplifting story will culminate in a family song at the concert.

column1: Other performers include local pub landlady
column3: who helps Gareth lead a special singalong in the town square
column5: who’ve helped to compose an original song
column6: and ambulance driver Justin
column7: whose powerful voice leads a new interpretation of Good King Wenceslas.

column1: The final concert is an emotional thank you to the local hospital
column2: an uplifting celebration of community and a chance to bring some festive joy to the nation.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;music

column1: 195;195;Defending Digga D;None;Following rapper Digga D as he is released from a 15-month stint in prison.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08yzfws.jpg;BBC
column4: Defending Digga D;Following rapper Digga D as he is released from a 15-month stint in prison.;Following rapper Digga D as he is released from a 15-month stint in prison. He is intent on making a success of his music career
column5: but that’s not straightforward.;"Twenty-year-old Digga D is one of the biggest up-and-coming drill artists in the UK. He’s on the brink of stardom
column6: with his singles getting millions of views online. But he has also been jailed for violent disorder. This film follows him as he is released from a 15-month stint in prison
column7: at a pivotal moment in his life. He is intent on making a success of his music career
column8: but that’s not straightforward.

column1: Digga D is one of the first musicians in British history to be given a criminal behaviour order that controls his creative output. It means he is not allowed to release any music
column3: without telling the police. If the music breaches the terms of his CBO – for example 'inciting or encouraging violence'
column4: they can take it down and arrest him.

column1: The police say they target drill because it promotes and causes violence
column2: but the genre’s supporters call this censorship and say that the art simply reflects real life. Digga’s situation
column4: embodies this dilemma. His next moves could redefine his life
column5: and his music
column6: forever. A year after his social media accounts stopped
column7: a year after his last music video
column8: his last post and his last tweet
column9: Digga is coming back. This film tells the story of how he manages that
column10: and who is helping him. His lawyer Cecilia has been defending him for years. She is doing all she can to enable him to make music
column11: despite his restrictions. But with his music so rigorously policed
column12: can he do that and secure his future?

column1: Digga has everything to fight for – and everything to lose.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2020;58;music

column1: Don and Phil Everly's love of music began as children
column2: encouraged by their father Ike. Little Donnie and Baby Boy Phil sang on Ike's early morning radio shows in Iowa.

column1: After leaving school
column2: the brothers moved to Nashville where
column3: under the wing of Ike Everly's friend
column4: the highly talented musician Chet Atkins
column5: Don and Phil signed with Cadence Records. They exploded onto the music scene in 1957 with Bye Bye Love
column6: written by Boudleaux and Felice Bryant.

column1: After Bye Bye Love came other hits
column3: followed by the worldwide smash hit All I Have to Do Is Dream and a long string of other great songs which also became hits.
the brothers were lured away from Cadence to Warner Bros with a $1
column5: 000 contract. Their biggest hit followed
column6: the self-penned Cathy's Clown
column7: which sold 8 million copies. Remaining at Warner Bros for most of the 60s
column8: they had further success with Walk Right Back

column1: 200;200;Fake or Fortune?;Series 9: 4. A King’s Last Supper;Could a picture bought online for £50 be a missing 18th-century work by Benjamin West?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09py56p.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 9: 4. A King’s Last Supper;Could a picture bought online for £50 be a missing 18th-century work by Benjamin West?;Anglesey farmer Huw Lewis bought a small painting depicting the Last Supper for £50 on the internet. Can the team prove it’s an eighteenth-century work by the artist Benjamin West?;"The team head to the beautiful island of Anglesey at the northernmost tip of Wales
column6: where Huw Lewis has a sheep farm. Huw  frequently spends his evenings scouring the internet for art bargains and was trawling through eBay when he came across a small
column7: unattributed oil sketch of Jesus and the apostles at the Last Supper. He immediately sensed it was something special and was amazed when nobody bid against him. He secured it for just £50. He later learned that it had been in the seller’s family for decades
column8: and they had assumed it to be practically worthless.

column1: After doing some online research of his own
column2: Huw thought he might have identified the artist as Benjamin West. Born in Pennsylvania
column3: West left America in his twenties and settled in Britain
column4: where he quickly found fame and fortune. By the late eighteenth century
column5: he was one of the most celebrated artists of the day
column6: renowned for the bold storytelling of his history paintings. Perhaps his biggest fan was King George III
column7: who made West his official history painter. Together they aimed to bring about a magnificent new era in British art.

column1: Huw’s picture is an unusual one
column2: as it is a small canvas that appears to be semi-finished. It’s partly painted in oils
column4: black lines delineating the figures. After examining the picture closely
column5: Philip is intrigued by it but is also worried by its condition. It appears to have been scrubbed in places
column6: and layers of dirt have built up over the years. There’s also no signature
column7: which
column8: given West was very good at promoting himself and his work
column9: is concerning. But Fiona discovers that Benjamin West was commissioned by King George III to paint two paintings of the Last Supper for chapels at Windsor Castle
column10: and at the Royal Academy of Arts she discovers that one of the preparatory sketches for those paintings hasn’t been seen for a century. Could it be that Huw’s internet bargain is the missing West sketch?

column1: Forensic science will be key
column2: as a genuine eighteenth-century picture could reveal some more unusual ingredients
column3: and West was known to experiment with paints. At her laboratory in the Courtauld Institute of Art
column4: Professor Aviva Burnstock examines the picture and reveals some surprising details that the naked eye would never see.

column1: But this proves to be one of the team’s most difficult investigations. As well as the worrying condition of the picture
column2: they face a provenance trail that should stretch back more than two hundred years. There’s also the added challenge of doing research in the midst of lockdown. With the odds so stacked against them
column3: can they prove that Huw’s internet bargain is actually a long-lost work fit for a king?";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2021;59;arts

column4: Firestarter: The Story of Bangarra;How an Indigenous Australian dance group became a cultural powerhouse.;Documentary that recounts how three young brothers turned an Indigenous Australian dance group into a First Nations cultural powerhouse.;"Marking the thirtieth birthday in 2019 of Bangarra Dance Theatre – an Indigenous Australian and Torres Strait Islander organisation
column5: and one of Australia's leading performing arts companies – Firestarter takes audiences on a tour of Bangarra’s birth and spectacular growth. It presents its founders and tells the story of how three young Indigenous Australian brothers – Stephen
column6: David and Russell Page – turned the newly born dance group into a First Nations cultural powerhouse.

column1: Through the eyes of the brothers and company alumni
column2: Firestarter explores the loss and reclaiming of culture
column3: the burden of intergenerational trauma and – crucially – the power of art as a messenger for social change and healing.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;Contains some strong language.;2022;58;arts

But these strategic seats of power had to become palaces to impress monarchs such as Elizabeth I.;Sam Willis explores how
column2: by the Wars of the Roses
column3: castles were under attack from a new threat - the cannon - but survived into the Tudor era only to find their whole purpose challenged. What had once been strategic seats of power now had to keep up with the fickle fashions of the court and become palaces to impress monarchs such as Elizabeth I.

column1: Just as castles seemed to have lost their defensive function
column2: the English Civil War erupted. The legacy of that tumultuous period resulted in castles no longer being associated with protection. Rather
column3: their ruins took on a unique appeal
column4: embodying a nostalgia for an age of chivalry that became a powerful part of the national psyche.";History;BBC FOUR;False;2014;59;arts

Although their conversation covers much about the author's influences and ambitions - with the notable exception of any mention of his time as a spy - much of the interview looks at the modern phenomenon of the secret service agent as a hero.

column1: In a revealing insight
column2: le Carre explains that his dislike of James Bond stems from the fact that Bond doesn't exist in a political context
column3: making him more of an ""international gangster"" than a spy. Although Malcolm Muggeridge talks about his own
column5: period of spying
column6: John le Carre remains close-lipped about his (much more extensive) career in espionage. Le Carre (real name David Cornwell) began working for MI5 in 1952 and transferred to MI6 in 1960. There he remained until 1964
column7: when a combination of Kim Philby's defection
column8: which exposed many British agents
column9: and his own growing success as a novelist caused him to leave the secret service. Le Carre remained secretive about his former career for many decades.";Arts;BBC WEBONLY;False;1966;30;arts

column1: Bridget Riley has been challenging our perception through painting for over 60 years
column2: with radical work that has transformed how we look at art and invites us to feel with our eyes.

column1: With simple black and white geometric shapes
column2: repeated curves of colour or an array of muted dots
column4: shimmers and - in some cases - unsettles.

column1: At the age of 90
column2: Bridget Riley shows no signs of stopping. Her paintings command millions at auction
column3: she has won prestigious awards and honours
column5: paint
column6: publish and exhibit around the world.

column1: BBC cameras have filmed with Riley over the past few years in two of her studios
column3: where she spent the Second World War
column4: and at the National Gallery in London during the installation of her enormous mural there in 2018.

column1: In a rare and revealing interview with Kirsty Wark
column2: Riley dispels the numerous misconceptions which have followed her throughout her career. Many consider her as a poster girl for the Swinging 60s
column3: while others hail her as a titan of abstract art. However
column4: Riley considers herself a traditional painter who has merely picked up the baton from those who have gone before her
column5: such as Leonardo da Vinci

column8: considering a range of very different works that have challenged the political and social status quo
column9: expressing opinions and attitudes that many have wanted to silence - and even erase.

column1: She examines artwork ranging from the etchings of Otto Dix
column3: to the paintings of artist and gay activist Derek Jarman and the now famous (or infamous) statue of Edmund Colston. She considers the challenges of the representation of religious images from England to West Africa

column1: 237;237;Nature and Us: A History through Art;Series 1: Episode 3;James Fox explores our relationship with nature across the last hundred years.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xt337.jpg;BBC
column4: Nature and Us: A History through Art
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;James Fox explores our relationship with nature across the last hundred years.;James Fox uses art to explore the relationship between humans and nature across the last hundred years.;"In the concluding episode of the series
column6: James explores how the art of the last hundred years reflects how we swapped nature for progress in the first half of the 20th century before rediscovering its beauty in the decades following the Second World War
column7: and how today’s artists are re-imagining our future relationship with nature.

column1: The film begins in the first decades of the 20th century
column3: intent on conquering nature. In the art of Piet Mondrian
column4: James explores how an artist who began life as a landscape painter gradually leaves nature behind
column5: tidying up the messy reality of nature into abstract lines. We meet Chinese artist Yang Yongliang on the streets of New York
column6: whose sprawling digital landscapes ask questions about our drive for rapid urbanisation.

column1: James continues to explore this story through the images of one of the best photographers of the last century – and one of its most brilliant women - Margaret Bourke-White. In 1930
column2: she was the first professional western photographer to be allowed into the Soviet Union
column3: where she captured the rapid transformation of the country from being largely rural into a modern
column4: industrial state. James moves on to explore how the destructive power of the atomic age both terrified and inspired artists in the 1940s and 1950s
column5: from painters like Bittinger to the world of sci-fi films.

column1: We then see the arrival of a new kind of art – land art. In the late 60s and 70s
column2: a growing number of artists left the city and started working not only in nature but with it. We meet two contemporary land artists based in New Zealand: Philippa Jones and Martin Hill
column3: who use natural materials to create sculptures in the landscapes of New Zealand’s South Island. And finally
column4: we explore how artist collective Random International are using technology to explore our future relationship with nature – through a series of mesmerising art works.

column1: James finishes the episode and the series asking questions of the interviewees who have appeared across the series. How do they see our future relationship with nature?
He concludes that on the long journey we humans have been on since our beginnings
column2: artists have played a vital role not only in reflecting but also shaping our attitudes to nature. They’ve helped us understand its intricacy
column4: and now – when the entire planet seems under threat – they can help us forge a new relationship with it.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;False;2021;59;arts

column1: 239;239;Civilisations;Series 1: 9. The Vital Spark;Simon Schama explores the fate of art in the machine- and profit-driven world.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jx3bd.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 9. The Vital Spark;Simon Schama explores the fate of art in the machine- and profit-driven world.;Documentary. Simon Schama explores the fate of art in the machine- and profit-driven world
column6: looking at the rise of art as a tradeable commodity.;"Simon Schama begins Civilisations with this premise: that it is in art - the play of the creative imagination - that humanity expresses its most essential self: the power to break the tyranny of the humdrum
column7: the grind of everyday. Art makes life worth living and is the great window into human potential. And societies become civilised to the extent that they take culture as seriously as the prosecution of power or the accumulation of wealth. But in the century of total war and industrial slaughter
column8: was (and is) that enough?

column1: The cause of humanity went up in the smoke of the Nazi crematoria. Horror and terror brushed beauty aside and stamped on its pretensions. In the modern world
column2: art has become increasingly commodified. Simon's last programme explores the fate of art in the machine- and profit-driven world. It looks at the rise of art as a tradeable commodity and turns on one central question. Should art create a realm separate from the modern world
column3: a place where we can escape and pull the ladder up after us? Or should it plunge headlong into the chaos and cacophony while transforming the way we see it and live in it?

column1: Using the works of both dead and contemporary artists of the 20th and 21st centuries
column2: Simon seeks answers to these profound questions. His conclusion is imbued with hope: despite all the travails of the present
column4: art still offers civilisation an insight into the incomprehensibility of the world and a way to transcend its horrors with the enduring creativity of the human spirit.";History;BBC TWO;Contains adult themes.;2018;59;arts

column6: novelists and poets.;"To mark the 250th anniversary of the birth of Sir Walter Scott
column7: author Damian Barr goes in search of the legacy and lasting influence of one of Scotland’s great historical figures
column8: novelists and poets.

column1: From the huge Scott monument on Princes Street Edinburgh
column2: to Smailholm Tower in the Borders
column3: from Loch Katrine - the setting for his most famous poem - The Lady of the Lake - to Doune Castle
column4: a setting which continues to inspire historical novelists to this day - Damian takes us on a personal journey to discover the truth about the man
column5: his world and his work.

column1: With contributions from world experts: professor Alison Lumsden
column2: Aberdeen University; novelist James Robertson; author of Scott-land Stuart Kelly and Abbotsford curator

column1: In Search of Sir Walter Scott reveals the long lasting influence of Scott and his writing
column2: his political campaigning and his role in creating a version of Scotland we are still living with today.

243;243;The Story of Welsh Art;Series 1: Episode 3;Artists working in the 20th century found new and radical ways to portray Wales.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p097j38s.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, The Story of Welsh Art, Series 1: Episode 3;Artists working in the 20th century found new and radical ways to portray Wales.;As the 20th century dawned, artists found radical new ways to depict Wales, pushing themselves to extremes and redefining what art could be.;In this final episode
column2: Huw Stephens’s journey begins at the dawn of the 20th century with the artists who broke with tradition and depicted Wales in radical new ways. In Snowdonia
column3: he learns how Augustus John and JD Innes led the way
column4: obsessively painting the landscape with a freedom and vibrancy that still dazzles today. Equally bold was the work of Gwen John
column5: whose work is in complete contrast to that of her brother Augustus. At the National Museum Wales in Cardiff
column6: Huw discovers how she used light and tone to paint delicate and hypnotic portraits and interior scenes.

column1: Between the wars
column2: industrial south Wales produced some of the most powerful art of the century. Huw discovers how the work of Evan Walters and Cedric Morris is steeped in their experience of mining communities and the desperate poverty they endured. The lives of striking miners were rarely reflected in art
column3: but Walters’s 1926 portrait of his friend William Hopkins captured his subject with dignity and honesty.

column1: Travelling north
column2: Huw heads out to Bardsey Island off the Llyn Peninsula
column3: a place he first visited as a teenager. The landscape of Wales has long been a source of inspiration for artists and in the 1940s Brenda Chamberlain moved to Bardsey to immerse herself in its isolation. Inside the picturesque cottage where she lived
column4: Huw sees her sketches of island life that she drew on the walls ‘as if they were a giant sketchbook’. At the same time
column5: Kyffin Williams was painting the distinctive
column6: dramatic landscapes of north Wales
column7: establishing himself as the most popular Welsh artist of the 20th century.

column1: Contemporary art in Wales reflects a post-devolution self-confidence that allows it to look both back and forward. In Swansea
column2: Huw meets Daniel Trivedy and learns how his award-winning work Welsh Emergency Blanket took the patterns of traditional Welsh blankets and printed them on to the silver foil coverings given to refugees rescued from the sea. For his final stop
column3: Huw visits Colwyn Bay where he meets internationally renowned artist Bedwyr Williams
column4: whose work draws heavily on Welsh art history using humour and irreverence. It is a unique history
column5: Bedwyr concludes
column6: and one that makes him excited to be living and working in north Wales.";Arts;BBC TWO WALES DIGITAL;False;2021;59;arts

column3: Purgatory (Purgatorio: Love) and the Afterlife (Paradiso: Poema Sacro). Along the way
column4: the poet encounters characters such as Ulysses
column5: Virgil
column6: Satan and adulterous lovers Paolo and Francesca.

column1: This exciting new piece crosses boundaries between abstract and narrative dance

column3: the stage is brought to life with designs by Tacita Dean and lighting designers Lucy Carter and Simon Bennison. Dramaturg Uzma Hameed completes the creative team that illuminates the extraordinary vision of Dante.

column1: 245;245;Meet You at the Hippos;None;Mark Bonnar explores the street sculpture of the Scottish new towns in which he grew up.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b716g8.jpg;BBC
column4: Meet You at the Hippos;Mark Bonnar explores the street sculpture of the Scottish new towns in which he grew up.;Mark Bonnar returns to the Scottish new towns in which he grew up to explore the street sculpture made by artists such as his dad.;"Actor Mark Bonnar is on a mission to understand more about the Scottish new towns in which he grew up
column5: exploring the street sculpture made by artists such as his dad in the 60s
column6: 70s and 80s. He discovers why the new towns are there and how they enticed people out of the bigger cities
column7: and uncovers the surprising ways in which public art changed the new towns and the new towns changed public art.

column1: Mark's father
column3: made sculptures that stand to this day on the streets of Glenrothes
column4: East Kilbride and the Scottish new town that never was
column5: Stonehouse. These new towns employed town artists to make artworks in the very housing precincts the new residents were moving into.

column1: Stan Bonnar was the first assistant to seminal town artist David Harding in Glenrothes in the early 70s
column2: then became town artist himself at East Kilbride and Stonehouse Development Corporation later on in the decade. His first new town artwork was the concrete hippos that have stalked Glenrothes for almost 50 years.

column1: Scotland’s new town artists were at the forefront of a shift in thinking that changed the relationship between art and public places. Rather than plinths and bronze likenesses of dead soldiers and politicians
column2: this art would be found in playgrounds
column5: and could be seen out of people’s living room windows. The environment and surroundings of the work were seen as part of the art itself
column6: the context in which the sculptures stand being part of what they have to say. The new town art was there for everyone
column7: designed to define the places it was made and to mean something to the people who lived alongside it.

column1: Mark uncovers the relationship between the new towns and their art
column2: tracing a legacy of the approach taken by the development corporations and revealing the impact of the town artists’ work in the communities they were made for. Across Scotland
column5: Cumbernauld
column6: Livingston and Glenrothes
column7: Mark travels to talk with former town artists such as David Harding
column8: Malcolm Robertson
column9: Mary Bourne and Denis Barns
column10: and to learn about Brian Miller. On his travels
column11: he finds out how some work has survived
column12: some has been damaged and some lost. This journey takes Mark closer to an understanding of his father’s approach to art and helps him grasp the context and legacy of the towns
column13: the artists and their work.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;Contains some strong language.;2021;58;arts

260;260;Britain's Lost Masterpieces;Series 5: 3. Glasgow;Technical problems frustrate Bendor and Emma’s investigation of a 300-year-old portrait.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bm1qx6.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 5: 3. Glasgow;Technical problems frustrate Bendor and Emma’s investigation of a 300-year-old portrait.;Technical difficulties frustrate Bendor’s attempt to uncover who painted an unfinished portrait in a Glasgow museum. Emma reveals the true identity of the sitter after 300 years.;"Britain’s premier art detectives
column6: Bendor Grosvenor and Emma Dabiri
column7: are on the hunt to find and restore one of the nation’s great lost masterpieces. Can a mysterious painting of a beautiful society woman really be by the celebrated artist Joshua Reynolds? And which celebrity playwright will lead them from Rome to Bath to London’s Royal Academy? With a fascinating treasure hunt into the art of the Georgians and a very modern 21st-century digital restoration
column8: the results are truly spectacular.

column1: Bendor traces the remarkable life of Sir Joshua from humble beginnings in the West Country to reach the pinnacle of the artistic establishment
column2: becoming the first president of the Royal Academy and the country's most respected authority on art. In Rome
column3: Bendor explores how Reynolds developed his style
column5: and visiting the home of a private collector
column6: he looks at a little-known self-portrait by Reynolds. Bendor explains why he believes it to be the greatest self-portrait ever made by a British artist
column7: with virtuoso brushwork and a fluidity that gives it a remarkably modern appeal. Intensely personal and sympathetic
column8: it was painted when Reynolds was at the height of his success
column9: wealthy enough to buy a large house in the centre of London
column10: lavishly furnished and adapted for his own needs. Bendor is also pleased to see the picture has many similarities to the portrait of Elizabeth Linley.

column1: Emma explores the story of the man who donated the picture
column3: a wealthy businessman whose passion for art saw him amass an outstanding collection
column4: which he left to the city of Glasgow.

column1: Reynolds's achievements culminated with his presidency of the newly created Royal Academy of the Arts
column2: a position he made his own and which gave him an authority to promote his own opinions about painting. The suite of rooms at Somerset House in the Strand
column3: where the academy was originally housed
column4: have recently been restored. Bendor visits it to get a taste of the spaces that would have been familiar to Reynolds
column5: including the Great Room
column6: where the tradition of the Summer Exhibition was born under Sir Joshua.

column1: At the restoration studio
column2: the portrait itself has been subject to close scrutiny. At some point in the last few years
column3: the surface of the painting had been coated with a thick varnish
column4: which has now discoloured and darkened. However
column5: Reynolds's unorthodox painting methods
column6: often using wax instead of oil to mix his paints
column7: mean it must undergo stringent technical analysis to ensure it is safe to clean it. It soon becomes clear it will be impossible to restore the picture
column8: which Bendor feels will damage the prospects of a favourable verdict from the Reynolds expert
column9: Martin Postle.

column1: Emma investigates the brief and tragic life of the woman who has always been the accepted subject of the picture
column3: she became a celebrity singer performing in her hometown of Bath from the age of nine. In her teens
column4: she was regarded as a great beauty and suffered frequent but unwelcome attention from suitors. She eloped and married the playwright and politician Richard Brindsley Sheridan
column5: and found herself at the centre of a constitutional crisis before her tragic early death at the age of 37. Emma is puzzled to know what evidence there is that the portrait is really Elizabeth
column6: as there have been doubts expressed in the past. When she looks at some of Reynolds's vivid and insightful portraits of female celebrities from the Georgian era
column7: she is surprised when she uncovers the true identity of the sitter in our portrait.

column1: To give a sense of how the portrait would look if it had been possible to clean it
column2: and to give his case a boost
column3: Bendor creates a three-dimensional digital facsimile using laser scanning techniques and high-resolution re-colourisation. The portrait is returned to Glasgow for the verdict to be revealed.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;False;2022;59;arts

column1: A documentary on the work of Derick Thomson

column6: such as the role of the Gaelic language
