column8: use the sci-fi genre.;An exploration – from Jean-Michel Basquiat to Grace Jones – of how black artists use the sci-fi genre to examine black history and imagine new
column9: alternative futures.;"The arc of black history shares an uncanny resemblance to the plot points of classic sci-fi including ‘alien’ abduction
column10: enslavement and rebellion. It’s this unlikely relationship that provides the inspiration for Afrofuturism
column11: the broad cultural trend that encompasses works by Jean-Michel Basquiat to Grace Jones
column12: Solange Knowles and Sun Ra. In this film
column13: we meet
column14: see and hear from artists across three continents who each
column15: in their own way
column16: explore the Afrofuture to look at the horrors of the black past and imagine alternative futures.

column1: The mysterious yet influential Detroit techno duo
column4: a site of death and destruction during the African slave trade and reclaim it as a place of creation and beauty. Through a series of releases from the late 1990s through the early 2000s
column5: they envisage the unborn children of enslaved pregnant women
column6: thrown overboard during the Middle Passage to the Americas
column7: adapting to breathe under water and thrive in a Black Atlantis. The mythos is vividly brought to life by the Drexciyan collaborator and graphic artist Abdul Qadim Haqq as a thriving
column8: technological undersea world.

column1: Visual artist Ellen Gallagher similarly transforms the violence of the ocean into rebirth and renewal. Her film Osedax
column3: is an imaginative retelling of how the skeletal remains of dead whales sustain new life in the curious form of the bone-devouring worm of the title. Whereas for artist Hew Locke
column4: as well as the ocean itself
column5: it’s the Atlantic’s coastal fringes that inspire his world of bricolage phantoms
column6: plucked from the ghost stories of a Guyanese childhood.

column1: The Afrofuture is perhaps most commonly imagined through the rubric of outer space
column2: thanks in no small part to avant-garde jazz musician and poet Sun Ra.  Born in the southern US in the early 20th century
column4: claiming to have been teleported to Saturn. As with funk pioneer
column5: George Clinton
column6: who describes a similar close encounter with extraterrestrials
column7: Ra’s identification with an alien presence can be read as more than simple escapism. It’s also a biting satire on the alienating experience of being black in America. For Ra
column8: space is also an alternate destiny for black people
column9: as the title of his 1973 Afrofuturist feature film Space is the Place insists.

column1: Reaching beyond these fictional ‘Afronauts’ is the conceptual artist Tavares Strachan. His performance piece
column4: sees Strachan visit the famous Russian space centre to undergo the same rigorous – and often tortuous – training of the Cosmonauts. Strachan likens one of the exercises
column5: which measures our capacity to withstand disorientation and gravitational stress
column6: to his impoverished upbringing in The Bahamas.

column1: The film concludes with an exploration of the idea of double consciousness. Coined in the early 20th century by WEB Du Bois
column3: double-consciousness describes how black people in western societies see themselves twice over. Through their lived experience but also how they’re perceived within a dominant white culture.

column1: Curator and writer Ekow Eshun traces uses of the idea through Ralph Ellison’s lauded mid-20th-century novel Invisible Man
column2: and painter Kerry James Marshall’s image of the same title
column3: right up to the Black Lives Matter movement. Predicated upon recordings of anti-black violence often captured through digital tech
column4: Eshun argues these ‘expose’ a double consciousness at work
column5: the world as experienced and seen through black eyes
column6: laid bare for all to witness.

column8: whose work has been shaped by her family’s farming traditions and by overcoming a tragic accident that befell them a decade ago.

column1: The programme considers her rural upbringing and the influence living and working on a farm that claimed the lives of her father and two brothers has had on her art. Her strength of character and her strong faith have been tested repeatedly since her family was rocked by tragedy in 2012
column2: when her father Noel and brothers Graham and Nevin died in a single
column3: devastating incident on their farm. This programme looks at how Emma has tried to cope with such a traumatic loss and what impact it has had on her art
column4: as well as revealing the family’s story since then.

column1: Nevin was well known as a professional rugby player with Ulster
column2: and Emma reflects on how their similar outgoing personalities and careers in the public eye were at odds with the traditions of their close-knit and private rural family. Emma explores how her work conveys the juxtaposition between traditional pastoral landscapes and the realities of farming the land as seen through the eyes of those who live and work on it. She reflects on resilience and surviving loss and considers wider themes such as how grief and trauma can be reflected in and processed through making art.";Documentary;BBC ONE NORTHERN IRELAND;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2022;29;arts

column7: retracing the route of the transatlantic slave trade.;"Performance artist Selina Thompson recreates her award-winning dramatic monologue about a journey she made by cargo ship to retrace the triangular route of the transatlantic slave trade. Poetic and deeply personal
column8: Salt is part testimony
column9: part performance and part excavation of collective memory through archive and music.

column1: Throughout the film
column2: Thompson explores her painfully difficult but ultimately redemptive exploration of the Atlantic triangle
column4: takes us on a cathartic pilgrimage through grief
column5: race and identity. Darkly comic in places but also intensely sad
column6: Salt is Thompson’s deeply human response to being both British and a descendant of a people enslaved by the British.

column1: Central to Salt is Thompson’s physical performance of her monologue. She plays a character
column3: who pounds great rocks of salt
column4: tells profound stories and makes wry observations. The Woman allows Thompson’s particular journey and personal experience to hold a greater resonance
column5: representing the afterlife of slavery and colonialism.

column1: The salt the Woman breaks down into manageable pieces embodies that shared experience – the labour of negotiating racism
column4: the healing. The salt is also of the sea
column5: itself a character in the piece that plays witness to the atrocities of the Middle Passage.

column1: Complementing Thompson’s performance is a revealing
column2: unflinchingly honest and at times humorous interview conducted by Afua Hirsch.

column1: Thompson describes her journey
column2: reflecting on the feelings and thoughts that defined her experience at the time
column3: as well as her meditations now
column4: five years after the original journey. She is an exceptional storyteller and her candidness
column5: vivid powers of description and facility with language give Salt a raw and powerful intimacy.

column1: Recalled in distinct chapters
column2: Thompson’s journey takes her by sea from Belgium to Ghana
column3: on to Jamaica and finally back across the Atlantic to Europe. She set out on this extraordinary journey not to try to experience the horror of the Middle Passage
column5: to commemorate the dead. Part way through her journey
column6: that grieving process takes on an additional significance with the death of her beloved grandmother.

column1: In exploring the past and its lasting legacy
column2: Thompson is also looking for new definitions of home on the three continents she visits
column3: having been told variously her whole life that all of them and none of them were home.

column1: Footage of James Baldwin and Stuart Hall
column2: who themselves grappled with this history and its afterlife
column3: speaks to the inspiration and comfort Thompson drew from the black cultural archive and its distinct and rigorous legacy.

column1: In Europe
column3: she examines what it means to be black in a country that must grapple with its leading role in
column5: both slavery and colonialism. Her first sea voyage
column6: where she encounters toxic racism and the abuse of power
column7: becomes a contemporary replica of empire.

column1: In Ghana
column2: she explores the complexities of grief and remembrance
column3: and what it means to commemorate a history and a people defined by absence. On her journey between Africa and the Caribbean
column4: she confronts her own privilege and power
column5: granted to her by her British passport.

column1: In Jamaica
column2: the country of her grandparents’ birth
column3: she reflects on the nature of diasporic identity
column4: on an island where most people’s ancestors came from somewhere else. On the final leg of her journey
column5: overwhelmed by the weight of history and its ongoing legacy
column6: she reaches a point of crisis
column7: but ultimately
column8: she does find home. Her long journey back into the past allows her
column9: at last
column10: to go forwards
column11: as she closes with the quiet demand that we reckon with the past so that we can all do the same.

column1: Salt is a deeply moving account of a young woman grappling with the afterlife of slavery and colonialism. The artist in Thompson creates a performance that somehow makes the overwhelming and unsurmountable bearable for her. Steeped in anger but delivered with the lightest of touches
column2: Salt in its essence is about love and family
column4: chosen through adoption or simply the bonds inherent within the black community. In exposing her pain
column5: and her path towards healing

column11: a master bead maker
column12: crafts a traditional Maasai wedding necklace.;"For the Maasai people of the Great Rift Valley
column13: beaded jewellery is of great ceremonial significance. The Maasai are a semi-nomadic tribal group who inhabit much of Kenya and Tanzania. Many Maasai people continue to live traditional
column14: pastoral lives. While the men tend to their cattle
column15: Maasai women care for children
column16: maintain the village buildings
column17: and craft intricate
column18: colourful beaded items. Necklaces
column19: bracelets and headpieces are used in Maasai weddings and coming-of-age ceremonies
column20: but they are also enormously popular with non-Maasai Kenyans and tourists. Over the past few decades
column21: tourist interest in Maasai beads has allowed Maasai women to earn their own money for the first time.

column1: This episode follows Jane Semanto
column3: as she crafts a traditional Maasai wedding necklace. Like many Maasai
column4: Jane lives a modern life in Nairobi but retains a deep knowledge and reverence for her tribal heritage. The Maasai use beads to signify social and marital status. Colours also hold special importance
column5: signifying elements of the Rift Valley landscape
column6: as well as valued Maasai character traits such as bravery and friendship. During the film
column7: Jane leaves her Nairobi studio to visit her Maasai friends who live a more traditional rural existence. We discover how
column8: for them
column9: bead making not only gives them an income and independence from their husbands
column10: it also fosters a sense of female solidarity.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;False;2020;28;arts

column6: JMW Turner.;"Art historian Leslie Primo examines six decades of BBC archive to explore what makes JMW Turner such a beloved name in British art. Almost everyone has good things to say about Turner - after all
column7: he’s responsible for some of Britain’s greatest artistic treasures
column8: like The Fighting Temeraire
column9: and Rain
column10: Steam and Speed. But exactly what makes him great is where opinions can differ.

column1: Leslie discovers the TV art historians behind each theory. Was Turner great because he reinvented landscape painting
column2: because he was a radical whose work marked the beginning of modern painting
column3: or because he captured the extraordinary march of the industrial revolution? Through the archives
column5: Simon Schama
column6: Andrew Graham-Dixon and Kenneth Clarke.

column1: Leslie also finds that the disputed nature of Turner’s brilliance has made for some entertaining film-making
column2: from a frock-coat- and powdered-wig-loaded reconstruction of his humble origins as the son of a barber in London’s Covent Garden
column3: to modern art historian Tim Marlow lashing himself to a mast in the middle of a choppy ocean to recreate Turner’s inspiration for Fishermen at Sea.

Rare archive combines with performances from the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra.;"Scotland has always been intensely proud of its landscape. But at the same time
column5: Scotland has always done its natural world grave harm. As the Cop26 conference on climate change approaches in Glasgow
column6: BBC Scotland’s Changing Landscapes meditates upon the care and carelessness we’ve brought to bear on the environment.

column1: In this 60-minute film
column2: Scotland’s film and video archives from the last 100 years illustrate the story of this contradiction. The words of poets
column4: journalists and travellers - read by some of Scotland’s most famous voices - are combined with the voices of ordinary folk from our archival store; people whose relationship with land and nature is as varied as folk always are.

column1: It is their workplace
column2: the place where they take their leisure
column3: the place where they go to shoot the carefully curated stocks of deer and grouse. We see how very deep we have mined and drilled in search of coal and oil – and how far we have hiked and biked in search of solitude and beauty. We learn that the damage done has always been at the back of our minds
column4: at the very least since the 1930s.

column1: Driving the film is BBC Scotland’s Scottish Symphony Orchestra performing a carefully selected soundtrack of work by Scottish composers old and new
column2: featuring pieces by one of Scotland’s oldest living composers
column5: Jay Capperauld. We hear from some of the finest of Scotland’s folk musicians
column6: Julie Fowlis and Kris Drever
column7: who remind us that Scotland’s relationship with nature has been in many ways like a bad romance.

column1: Our narrators read passages from a wide range of sources. We hear words from Scotland’s newly appointed makar
column3: and passages from poets such as Edwin Muir
column5: Edwin Morgan
column6: Magi Gibson
column7: Don Paterson and Robert Burns – evocations of Scotland’s landscapes
column8: both rural and urban. We also hear from travel writers and journalists
column9: old biographies of Osgood Mackenzie and excerpts of the ecologist Fraser Darling’s 1930s report on the Scottish Highlands: ‘they are a wet desert'.

column5: TV
column6: Eye of the Storm;One of Scotland’s finest landscape artists
column7: eyesight failing
column8: attempts one last painting.;Renowned landscape painter James Morrison struggles with the loss of his sight in a poignant account of a creative mind dealing with the physical frailties that catch up with all.;"Renowned landscape painter James Morrison faces his greatest challenge. His eyesight is fading fast
column9: and he has one more painting to complete. From his studio just outside Montrose
column10: Morrison can hear the crashing North Sea. On the wall is a drawing of Mickey Mouse that he completed when he was eight years old
column11: at the outset of World War II.

column1: ‘My sight has deteriorated quite badly
column2: ’ Morrison admits. ‘And the very thought of coming in here and not being able to pick up a brush and do something with it really terrifies me.’ Nevertheless he has agreed to let film-maker Anthony Baxter follow him as he picks up the brushes again at the age of 85 after being sidelined by a series of operations. And while doing so
column3: he reflects on an extraordinary artistic life.

column1: Eye of the Storm is a fascinating exploration of what it means to be a landscape painter. It is also the poignant and universal story of a creative mind dealing with his own mortality
column2: and the physical frailties that catch up with all of us. The film movingly intertwines Morrison’s struggle with old age
column3: with his lively views as a much younger painter
column4: captured in remarkable archive filmed more than 50 years ago. Pivotal moments in Morrison’s career are also brought vividly to life by Scottish animator Catriona Black. Indeed
column5: her own journey to understand Morrison’s artistic genius
column6: in order to do justice to it in the film
column7: represents a story within a story in this multi-layered and visually stunning documentary.

column1: As Morrison begins painting again
column2: he is particularly troubled by the fact that – on doctor’s orders – he can’t paint outside. His lifelong compulsion to paint what he sees
column4: has taken him around the world – from Africa to Paris to Greenland.

column1: Morrison explains that it all started in Glasgow. Son of a shipyard pipefitter
column2: Morrison entered the famous Glasgow School of Art in 1950. While other students embraced the overtly political and abstract art then fashionable
column3: Morrison was attracted to the landscape painters of a different era such as Claude Lorrain
column4: Jean-François Millet and Scotland’s own Horatio McCulloch.

column1: Morrison’s first major subjects were the crumbling Glasgow tenements
column2: home to thousands of working-class families soon to be relocated to the outskirts of the city. Though painted without people
column3: Morrison’s haunting paintings are memorials to a lost way of life
column4: and would find their place in major museums. And his concern with documenting fleeting
column5: disappearing worlds would become a recurring feature of his work.

column1: Morrison’s work then underwent a dramatic shift when he moved to the tiny fishing village Catterline in north east Scotland in 1959. Here
column2: Morrison effectively established what would become a famed artists’ colony
column3: along with painter Joan Eardley. As he views archive from the time
column4: which he has not seen in half a century
column5: Morrison relives his artistic and personal friendship with the woman who some consider the greatest Scottish artist of the 20th century. While Eardley became beloved for her portraits of children
column6: Morrison never painted the human figure. Instead
column7: he focused on the skies and landscape of Angus and the Mearns that would become a distinctive feature of his work. Morrison’s quest for meaning in the landscape took him
column8: ultimately
column9: to the least populated part of the planet – the high arctic reaches of Canada and Greenland.

column1: ‘I had no idea what I was getting into
column4: which includes hair-raising flights over glaciers and arctic bison
column5: and a confrontation with a polar bear
column6: all the result of his determination to paint the vanishing arctic wilderness.

column1: As Morrison returns to his studio to paint
column2: there is a sense of time running out. His memory is now failing as well
column3: and he needs to refer to a piece of paper in his pocket to remember the director’s name.

column1: A new solo exhibition of his work in Edinburgh – his twenty-fifth – is soon to be mounted at The Scottish Gallery. Despite his worsening sight
column2: Morrison has promised the organisers one last work.

column1: As he shuffles through half a dozen different pairs of glasses
column2: he expresses his frustration at not being able to focus his eyes on the canvas properly. But as he begins painting on a pristine white board
column3: he miraculously summons up the energy of the brash young painter he once was
column4: his brush flashing across the canvas
column5: leaving behind great waves of lapis lazuli.

column1: As the film – and Morrison’s own artistic journey – draws to a close
column2: there is a final moment of poignant triumph in Edinburgh. The first case of Covid in the UK is still a few weeks away. As the artist arrives at what will be his last solo exhibition
column3: his wheelchair guided by his daughter Judith
column4: as he greets his great grandson and a host of admirers
column5: Morrison learns that one of his final paintings – Dark Landscape – has already sold. James Morrison would die
column6: a few months later
column7: at the age of 88.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;78;arts

He goes on a journey with blind comedian Jamie MacDonald to see how blind artists achieve their vision.;"Jamie O’Leary has terrible sight
column5: and is now facing eye surgery that could potentially lead to sight loss. A television director for almost 20 years
column6: Jamie has produced groundbreaking programmes that take a fresh look at disability
column7: as well as making popular travelogue shows with some of the UK’s funniest talent
column8: including Karl Pilkington
column9: Romesh Ranganathan and Katherine Ryan.

column1: At this pivotal point in his life
column2: O’Leary wants to explore how people cope with sight loss and how blind artists achieve their creative vision of a world they see from a unique perspective. So he has hooked up with blind observational comedian Jamie MacDonald to bring light and shade to facing the condition. Together
column3: they’re on a blind-leading-the-nearly-blind mission to uncover and collaborate with the best blind creative talent.";Film;BBC TWO;Contains strong language.;2021;59;arts

column1: 311;311;Branagh: bringing Belfast home;None;"Sir Kenneth Branagh is profiled as his Oscar-tipped new film Belfast is released here.
;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bhph85.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Branagh: bringing Belfast home;Sir Kenneth Branagh is profiled as his Oscar-tipped new film Belfast is released here.
;New film Belfast is Sir Kenneth Branagh’s account of his childhood in the early years of the Troubles. Tipped for Oscar glory and now released here
column2: we speak to the man behind it.

column1: ;New film Belfast sees Sir Kenneth Branagh return to the city of his childhood. It is an autobiographical exploration of the value of family life in the face of the gathering storm that became the Troubles - one which led to him leaving the city.
Sir Kenneth became a household name while still in his 20s for his acclaimed work as an actor and director who breathed new life into the plays of Shakespeare. Later
column2: he spread his wings as a writer and director of feature films. By his own admission
column3: he has come a long way from Belfast - yet his new film sees him return to his formative years in the city with the meticulous monochrome recreation of the tightly-packed streets he knew so well. The film’s cast includes Dame Judi Dench
column5: Ciaran Hinds
column6: Catriona Balfe and newcomer Jude Hill.

column1: Sir Kenneth talks at length about his new film - what drove him to write it
column2: working with the actors and even his refusal to water down the Belfast accent for international distribution. He also discusses his own childhood experiences of being caught up in rioting as both bystander and participant
column3: his parents’ zest for life and how leaving the city left a deep mark on him.";Arts;BBC ONE NORTHERN IRELAND;False;2022;29;arts;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bhph85.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bhph85.jpg;new film belfast see sir kenneth branagh return city childhood autobiographical exploration value family life face gathering storm became trouble one led leaving city sir kenneth became household name still 20 acclaimed work actor director breathed new life play shakespeare later spread wing writer director feature film admission come long way belfast yet new film see return formative year city meticulous monochrome recreation tightlypacked street knew well film ’ cast includes dame judi dench jamie dornan ciaran hind catriona balfe newcomer jude hill sir kenneth talk length new film drove write working actor even refusal water belfast accent international distribution also discus childhood experience caught rioting bystander participant parent ’ zest life leaving city left deep mark;1

column3: ask why albums still matter and consider the future of the album.

column1: 314;314;Inside America's Treasure House: The Met;Series 1: Episode 3;As the Met faces a Covid cash crisis
column5: Inside Americas Treasure House: The Met
column6: Series 1: Episode 3;As the Met faces a Covid cash crisis
column7: friends and donors rally round.;With a cash crisis
column8: restrictions on visitor numbers and exhibitions
column9: a new roof to pay for
column10: and an imminent election causing alarm
column11: friends and donors rally round to save the Met.;"Autumn
column12: 2020. The Met is open
column13: but in a safe and very limited way. Visitor income helps keep the museum running
column14: so times are hard. Since it was founded
column15: like so many US arts institutions
column16: the Metropolitan has largely been funded by benefactors. We visit Clyde B Jones III
column17: the executive matching modern donors to exhibitions and events as the economy tanks.

column1: Jones explains how hard it is to keep up the social links that the system depends on. He has
column3: found it possible to drum up millions of dollars for the imminent remodelling of the Arts of Africa
column4: Oceania and the Americas galleries. Currently
column5: the need to shade the massive south-facing glass wall that illuminates the rooms means artefacts are not shown to their best advantage. Now he must find the funds to replace those walls.

column1: Some give money
column2: but others donate items from their own collections. We meet curator Jaysen Dobney of the musical instruments department as a rock musician and long-term patron asks for help with his problem
column3: a collection of 403 guitars. Dobney is only too happy to have a promised gift of a 60s Gibson Les Paul TV Special.

column1: Every department is currently calling on its supporters. In Textile Conservation
column2: Head Curator Janina Poskrobko makes breakfast for a visiting professor. We've been with her since dawn
column4: saying her prayers. She must find the money for an unfunded project - the rescue of an Ottoman robe. We observe as she subtly raises the issue while showing him a Renaissance cape. The professor is a textile expert and passionate supporter. Might he dig deep?

column1: The Costume Institute is normally funded by stars who pay to attend the famous Met Gala fashion event
column2: but this year they're economising. The 2020 Ball is cancelled
column3: so 2019's proceeds must be used carefully. We follow the building of About Time as the set undergoes construction and the garments are installed.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: fashionable friends are stepping up. In Detroit
column3: America's most flamboyant private collector of couture
column5: opens her home
column6: and her heart
column7: to explain why the Met is so important to her - and why last year she donated 160 garments amassed over seven decades of collecting.

column1: In London
column2: we are with top-end cobbler Georgina Goodman
column3: who has just taken a call from the Met
column4: asking for help bolstering their huge accessories archive. In the mid-2000s
column5: Goodman attracted the attention of couturier Alexander McQueen. Packing up her sketches
column6: the designer reveals how she was charged with interpreting Lee McQueen's footwear visions
column7: including the iconic armadillo shoe. The Met has a pair
column8: but is keen to acquire Goodman's original sketches.

column1: As Covid keeps visitor numbers low
column2: every ticket purchased helps keep the lights on and the building open. With no tourist trade
column3: the Met is back to where it began in 1870
column4: catering for locals. Citizens are not obliged to pay for entry into the museum
column5: but Naqiya Hussein has bought two tickets. She's joining the many young people
column6: newly unlocked but making only tentative outings
column7: on a Met Date. Her scientist beau Cyril and she enjoy the tranquillity of solitude in her favourite galleries
column8: though the camera is ever present. A date here is a litmus test of love. If the million objects on display can't spark a conversation
column9: it's never going to work.

column1: Perhaps the greatest donation is a lifetime of work at the Met - or the possibility at least. We are with Vietnamese-American student Kevin Pham as he visits the medieval department at the Met Cloisters in northern Manhattan. He's one of 120 postgraduate interns
column2: paid through a new $5M donation to study with a view to a possible career in the museum. The Met wants to build a new and diverse staff
column3: and must succeed if it is to remain relevant. As Kevin says
column4: the museum can't be the preserve of bearded old white men.

column1: At Halloween
column2: About Time opens. The annual Costume Institute show is always a blockbuster that draws in the crowds
column3: and now the stakes are high. The newly reopened Met must show that it is still the place for fashion as art. This anniversary year
column5: packed with black garments from across 150 years
column6: points to objects that are timeless in an industry now driven by constant change. We're with fashionistas as they thrill to the show
column7: noting that even on a budget
column8: Curator Andrew Bolton has managed to make a splash.

column1: Philanthropy has always kept the Met alive and vibrant
column2: and as the nights draw in
column3: there's disquiet about the upcoming US election and its effect on giving. A change of administration
column4: or the return of President Trump
column5: might warp the delicate web of tax breaks and write-offs that underpin the whole arts world. With the fall-out of Covid and the tumult of Black Lives Matter in mind
column6: CEO Dan Weiss gives a dark assessment of America's contribution to history. And on the night of the election itself
column7: Head of Communications Ken Weine worries about money
column8: staff and the fate of culture itself.";Arts;BBC FOUR;False;2021;59;arts

column1: When Aiysha gets injured during a hunt

column1: Gnu still has to cross the river

column3: he faces a suicidal drop from sheer cliffs to the river below

column1: As Ray travels through the cold high mountain Great Basin desert and the hot Sonoran desert of southern Arizona
column2: he discovers how their hostile geography and rich geology shaped the stories of fortune hunting and lawlessness in the Wild West
column3: and were the setting for the last wars between the US Army and the Apache warrior tribes.

column1: Ray's journey begins in Monument Valley
column2: whose dramatic desert landscape has become synonymous with the Wild West years. He explores how plants and animals survive in this waterless climate and how the Navajo Indian people adapted to the conditions. In Tucson
column3: he meets up with desert coroners Bruce Anderson and Robin Reineke
column4: who show him how the desert still kills people today.

column1: He explores how the Apache adapted their warfare methods to the desert and how the US cavalry struggled in the hot arid landscape. In Tombstone
column2: he gets to grips with the myths around lawmakers and lawlessness and how it flourished in the remote desert regions of the Old West. He discovers how this forbidding landscape was the perfect refuge for bandits and pursues the outlaw trail to Butch Cassidy's hideout at Robber's Roost. His journey ends with the story of Geronimo's surrender which marked the end of the Indian Wars

column1: 337;337;Attenborough's Wonder of Song;None;David Attenborough chooses seven of the most remarkable animal songs found in nature.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b963xq.jpg;BBC
column4: Attenboroughs Wonder of Song;David Attenborough chooses seven of the most remarkable animal songs found in nature.;David Attenborough chooses seven of the most remarkable animal songs found in nature and explores the significance of these songs in the lives of their species.;"Sir David Attenborough chooses his favourite recordings from the natural world that have revolutionised our understanding of song. Each one - from the song of the largest lemur to the song of the humpback whale to the song of the lyrebird - was recorded in his lifetime.

column1: When Sir David was born
column2: the science of song had already been transformed by Charles Darwin’s theory of sexual selection: singing is dangerous as it reveals the singer’s location to predators
column3: but it also offers the male a huge reward
column4: the chance to attract a female and pass on genes to the next generation. Hence males sing and females don't.

column1: Today
column2: new science in the field of birdsong is transforming those long-held ideas. Scientists are discovering that
column4: in the majority of all songbird species
column5: females sing - and it is only now they are being properly heard. Through this revelation and others
column6: we can understand that animal songs are marvelous examples of the spectacular survival strategies that species have developed in order to stay alive. ";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2022;58;science-and-nature

column1: 338;338;Extinction: The Facts;None;Sir David Attenborough investigates the loss of biodiversity happening around us.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08qy6lp.jpg;BBC
column4: Extinction: The Facts;Sir David Attenborough investigates the loss of biodiversity happening around us.;With a million species at risk of extinction
column5: David Attenborough explores how this crisis of biodiversity has consequences for us all
column6: including putting us at greater risk of pandemic diseases.;"With a million species at risk of extinction
column7: Sir David Attenborough explores how this crisis of biodiversity has consequences for us all
column8: threatening food and water security
column9: undermining our ability to control our climate and even putting us at greater risk of pandemic diseases.

column1: Extinction is now happening up to 100 times faster than the natural evolutionary rate
column2: but the issue is about more than the loss of individual species. Everything in the natural world is connected in networks that support the whole of life on earth
column4: and we are losing many of the benefits that nature provides to us. The loss of insects is threatening the pollination of crops
column5: while the loss of biodiversity in the soil also threatens plants growth. Plants underpin many of the things that we need
column6: and yet one in four is now threatened with extinction.

column1: Last year
column2: a UN report identified the key drivers of biodiversity loss
column4: climate change and pollution. But the single biggest driver of biodiversity loss is the destruction of natural habitats.   Seventy-five per cent of Earth's land surface (where not covered by ice) has been changed by humans
column5: much of it for agriculture
column6: and as consumers we may unwittingly be contributing towards the loss of species through what we buy in the supermarket.

column1: Our destructive relationship with the natural world isn’t just putting the ecosystems that we rely on at risk. Human activities like the trade in animals and the destruction of habitats drive the emergence of diseases.   Disease ecologists believe that if we continue on this pathway
column2: this year’s pandemic will not be a one-off event.   ";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2020;58;science-and-nature

column2: the Aberdeenshire coast to the islands of Argyll - each episode sees Calum embark on a distinctive journey that allows him opportunities to capture special images of places and his travels.

column1: His mode of travel is as varied as the locations
column2: all the while keeping his keen photographer’s eye peeled for evocative shots employing different photographic techniques.

column1: 341;341;The Chronicles of Strangford;Series 1: 4. Summer;It’s summer - sailing regattas and long days stretching to glorious sunsets.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bh1pnh.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 4. Summer;It’s summer - sailing regattas and long days stretching to glorious sunsets.;It’s summer
column6: a season of long evenings and dawn choruses. Mark listens for the elusive yellowhammer
column7: Katy finds healthy barn owl chicks
column8: and Kenny wins the centenary sailing race.;"It is summer
column9: and humans and birds flock to the lough to enjoy its unspoilt beauty and unique habitats.

column1: At Slievemoyle farm
column2: Mark McCormick from the RSPB is camping out for a dawn chorus survey. Coming home and working with nature has helped him get over PTSD from witnessing the Westminster Bridge terror attacks. He is hoping he will hear the distinctive call of the endangered yellowhammer.

column1: Summers on Strangford Lough mean long evenings stretching into glorious sunsets. The Crawford family enjoy an evening picnic
column3: four generations of the Murray family take the St Brendan out for an evening of fishing.

column1: Summer is regatta season on the lough
column2: and a big moment for Kenny Smyth and his River-class sailing boat Laragh. It’s 100 years since the Rivers were built
column3: and Kenny is hoping to wrestle the series race trophy from his brother Graham.

column1: Away from the buzz of summer activities
column2: Katy Bell is hoping to find healthy barn owl chicks. Wet and extremely hot weather has meant most of the sites have failed this year
column3: but a new site may have some healthy chicks.

column1: Out on the lough
column2: wildfowl expert Kerry Mackie is counting greylag geese. It is important to monitor the populations as they can cause problems for farmers. Carrying out the counts reminds him of his deep family connections to the lough and a lifetime of memories.

column1: Kieron Black is also out
column2: snorkeling and remembering his father Brian. He would try to fill every day with experiences
column3: something Kieron also tries to do as he loses himself in the otherworldly surroundings of the lough’s sea bed.";Nature;BBC ONE NORTHERN IRELAND;False;2022;29;science-and-nature

column1: 342;342;The Sky at Night;Dark Skies;The Sky at Night team explore how light pollution impacts the beauty of the night sky.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09lkk39.jpg;BBC
column5: Dark Skies;The Sky at Night team explore how light pollution impacts the beauty of the night sky.;The Sky at Night team explore how light pollution impacts the beauty of the night sky
column6: animal behaviour and human health
column7: and what might be done to mitigate its harmful effects.;"Dr Maggie Aderin-Pocock and Professor Chris Lintott visit the Van Gogh Immersive Experience to seek inspiration in one of the world’s most famous works of art
column8: Starry Night. How can we mitigate the effects of light pollution so that the beauty of the night sky captured by Van Gogh might be preserved in the real world for future generations?

column1: Images and data from satellites have made it easy for us to visualise the extent of the growing effects of light pollution around the world
column2: but speaking with Professor Kevin Gaston from the University of Exeter
column3: Chris discovers that our current estimates show that global light pollution could be much worse than past data suggests. Without satellites capable of analysing the light emitted from the now-popular bluer LED lighting
column4: he estimates that the true levels of light pollution could be around 200% more than was previously thought. Kevin and Chris discuss how light pollution is not just a problem for astronomers but can have devastating effects on animal behaviour and human health.

column1: Pete Lawrence visits one of the few places in the UK where you might still be able to catch a glimpse of the Milky Way. In Moore’s Reserve
column3: Pete meets up with Dark Skies Officer and South Down National Park ranger Dan Oakley
column4: whose public outreach and passion for astronomy helped to get Dark Sky Reserve status for the area. Together they talk about the way towns and cities might change to help create more dark sky areas for the public to enjoy.

column1: In contrast
column2: atop Television Centre in London - one of the country’s brightest cities – Chris joins the Baker Street Irregular Astronomers under a bright city night sky. The group demonstrate some tips and tricks to show us that
column4: you can still view and image some spectacular night sky objects.

column1: And finally
column2: Maggie looks at the latest risk to clear views of the night sky
column3: mega-constellations and how satellite streaks that were once a novelty and easy to avoid are now becoming a nuisance to researchers and astronomers in many disciplines. Speaking to Tim Stevenson from the Square Kilometre Array Observatory
column4: they discuss how mega-constellations disrupt radio telescopes that rely on a particular waveband to help their research of everything from galaxy formations and the chemical markers of life in the universe.";Science;BBC FOUR;False;2022;29;science-and-nature

column1: 343;343;Life Story;7. The Full Circle;Highlights programme showcasing the most spectacular stories from the series.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0276zg5.jpg;BBC
column5: 7. The Full Circle;Highlights programme showcasing the most spectacular stories from the series.;Highlights programme compiled from the Life Story series presented by David Attenborough
column6: exploring every stage of life in the natural world.;"In this highlights programme compiled from the recent Life Story series
column7: David Attenborough brings us the universal story that unites each of us with every animal on the planet
column8: the story of the greatest of all adventures - the journey through life. For each stage of life we see the most spectacular
column9: beautiful or dramatic stories from the Life Story series.

column1: The journey begins with one of the most talked-about sequences - flightless barnacle goose chicks making an extraordinary leap down a cliff face from the ledge where they hatched. Newly independent arctic foxes travel great distances across the frozen
column3: learning how to catch prey. They leap high into the air and plunge nose-first into the snow to catch the lemmings living underneath.

column1: In pursuit of a home
column2: tropical hermit crabs do something seen nowhere else in nature. They form an orderly queue
column4: smallest at the back. It's a housing chain. When the chain is complete there is a mass swap as each crab moves into the newly vacated shell ahead of it in the line. In meerkat society
column5: a youngster must quickly learn how to defend home and family from snakes. In a spectacular showdown between the meerkat clan and a venomous cobra
column6: the youngsters learn a vital life lesson.

column1: In a sequence that has since gone viral across the globe
column3: drab male puffer fish creates the most complex and beautiful structure made by any animal on earth. He builds a spectacular submarine 'crop circle' in the sand to attract a female's attention. Parenthood for a mother zebra involves a life-and-death choice on where to cross the river during migration.

column1: In a touching final scene
column2: elephants delicately stroke the bones of an ancestor.";Nature;BBC TWO;False;2015;58;science-and-nature

column1: 345;345;Restoring the Earth: The Age of Nature;Series 1: 3. Changing;"Global warming is changing our planet fast
column2: but we’re learning ways to help us manage it.

column1: ;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xgj46.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Restoring the Earth: The Age of Nature, Series 1: 3. Changing;Global warming is changing our planet fast
column2: but we’re learning ways to help us manage it.

column1: ;Documentary series about nature's resilience. Global warming is changing our planet faster than ever before, but we’re also increasing our understanding of nature to help us manage it.;We visit Bhutan
column4: Australia and Indonesia to learn just how much carbon can be stored by nature. By restoring forests
column5: mangroves
column6: seagrass meadows
column7: and most importantly biodiversity
column8: we can help nature draw down the excess carbon from the atmosphere and slow climate change.

column1: From the tropical island of Borneo to the ice sheets of Antarctica
column2: global warming is changing our planet faster than ever before
column3: but we’re also increasing our understanding of the potential for nature to help us manage it.";Nature;BBC FOUR;False;2021;52;science-and-nature

column1: 346;346;Chris Packham's Animal Einsteins;Series 1: 6. Travellers;Chris discovers the cleverest animal travellers and how they find their way.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p097ck2k.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 6. Travellers;Chris discovers the cleverest animal travellers and how they find their way.;Chris discovers the cleverest animal travellers and how they find their way
column6: from deer with mental maps
column7: blue whales planning routes
column8: and dung beetles navigating by the stars.;"Chris Packham discovers the clever methods that animals use to travel from A to B and how they find their way. Whether it is a local trip to find food or an epic journey to reach a safe place to breed
column9: every traveller must work out where to go and the most energy-efficient way to get there.

column1: Now
column2: the latest scientific research is helping uncover just how they do it
column3: from creating mental maps of their environment to planning their route with precision. We are only starting to understand how these intelligent travellers get around successfully
column4: but by studying their movements we may also learn valuable insights that could help us
column5: like ways to manage crowd safety and to how to tackle cancer more effectively.

column1: Chris begins by meeting Bertie and Baxter
column2: two beautiful Bactrian camels that demonstrate how they are perfectly adapted to trekking across harsh deserts. With long eyelashes and special eyelids to keep out sand
column3: broad feet so they do not sink
column4: and the ability to go without water for up to a week
column5: these camels can cover 25 miles a day
column6: and helped humans travel and trade for thousands of years.

column1: In America
column2: Rhiannon Jakopak from the University of Wyoming is part of a research team collaring and tracking mule deer across the state. They are finding that mule deer are constantly collecting details about the environment and their position within it
column3: allowing them to learn migration routes passed down the generations
column4: and even occasionally learning their own new routes.

column1: Some ocean migrants are also showing impressive brainpower
column2: as Dr Briana Abhrams from the University of Washington has discovered. Her research has shown blue whales use their memories to migrate
column3: letting them predict where and when there will be a steady supply of food all along the west coast of North America
column5: 000-mile-long migration.

column1: Elephants have a reputation for never forgetting
column2: and it seems their memory can help them find valuable resources. Sophie Sadera is a safari guide in the Maasai Mara National Reserve and she knows first-hand how elephants use the same pathways every year as they travel to find water. During times of drought matriarchs can use their memory of water sources they have visited in the past to ensure their herd’s survival.

column1: But you do not need to have a big brain to find your way around. The green and black poison dart frog lives in the rainforests of South America and is a master of mental maps. Brand new science has shown this tiny amphibian has got the mind to remember the structure of a rainforest
column3: enabling them to transport their tadpoles to water sources within this dynamic environment.

column1: Exciting new research by Rickesh Patel
column2: from the University of Maryland Baltimore County
column3: has revealed an excellent underwater navigator. By constantly monitoring the turns they take and the distance they travel
column4: mantis shrimp can find their way back to their home. This suggests they use a navigational strategy called path integration. They are currently the only underwater animal that we know of that is able to do this.

column1: Professor Marie Dacke
column3: has been studying dung beetles in South Africa for over 20 years
column4: and her research has discovered that these insects have the remarkable ability to navigate at night using the light of the Milky Way.

column1: Some animal travellers use the most surprising ways to get around
column2: and new science by the University of Bristol has shown how spiders can fly. By detecting static electricity in the air
column3: they float along on silk lines. They have been found an impressive 1
column5: and up to two-and-a-half miles high in the air.

column1: But they are not the only surprising flyer
column2: the Paradise Tree Snake can cover almost 100 metres in a single glide. Now
column4: new research has revealed the science behind how they can glide and land safely.

column1: Some of the most exciting discoveries are coming from studying how animals travel en masse. Dr Iain Couzin
column2: from the Max Planck Institute in Germany
column3: is showing that bird flocks and fish shoals tap into a 'group mind' influencing how they travel. Their behaviour may hold answers to some human problems
column4: like how to manage crowd safety and even new ways to treat cancer.

column1: Chris takes us on a trip into the remarkable world of animal travel. By getting up close and personal with some of the nature’s best travellers
column2: Chris reveals the remarkable intelligence these Animal Einsteins use to journey around our planet.";Nature;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 347;347;Planet Earth II;6. Cities;Cities can be worlds of surprising opportunity for animals.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jv3xx.jpg;BBC
column5: 6. Cities;Cities can be worlds of surprising opportunity for animals.;Cities can be worlds of surprising opportunity for animals
column6: from the leopards prowling the streets of Mumbai to the peregrine falcons hunting amongst New York's skyscrapers.;"Cities are growing at a faster rate than any other habitat on Earth. They may seem an unlikely place for animals to thrive
column7: but they can be a world of surprising opportunity. Leopards prowl the streets of Mumbai
column8: peregrine falcons hunt amongst New York's skyscrapers
column9: and a million starlings perform spectacular aerial dances over Rome.

column1: In Jodhpur
column2: langurs are revered as religious deities and in Harar
column3: locals live in harmony with wild hyenas. Many animals

column5: a new species of the plant-eating titanosaur.;"David Attenborough tells the story of the discovery and reconstruction in Argentina of the world's largest-known dinosaur
column6: a brand new species of titanosaur. Measuring 37m long - close to four London buses put end to end - and weighing 70 metric tons
column7: it now holds the record as the biggest animal ever to walk the earth.

column2: a shepherd spotted the tip of a gigantic fossil bone sticking out of a rock in La Flecha Farm in the Chubut Province in the Argentinian desert. Palaeontologists soon uncovered a massive 2.4m long thigh bone (femur)
column3: the largest ever found. By the end of the dig they had uncovered more than 220 bones. As the programme reveals
column4: these all belong to a new species of the giant plant-eating titanosaur.

column1: Filmed over the next two years
column2: the documentary follows the twists and turns of this forensic investigation. Attenborough witnesses the uncovering and examination of these stupendous fossils and the dramatic construction of the complete skeleton. And using state-of-the-art graphics
column3: the film also reveals the internal secrets of this dinosaur and what it means to be a giant.";Science & Nature;BBC ONE;False;2016;58;science-and-nature

column6: exploring the rugged coast of Cumbria and learning how central the county is to many challenges facing Britain.;"Simon explores the wild and rugged coast of Cumbria and learns how central the county is to many of the challenges facing Britain.

column1: The Lake District National Park includes a beautiful stretch of Cumbria’s coast
column2: where rare natterjack toads inhabit a spectacular sand dune landscape. But this rugged wilderness sits in the shadows of Sellafield
column3: the most hazardous industrial site in western Europe
column4: which is home to hundreds of aging and disused nuclear facilities - including the largest single stockpile of plutonium on the planet.

column1: At a brand new training facility
column2: Simon meets members of the Civil Nuclear Constabulary
column3: an elite unit of armed police that is the UK’s first line of defence against an attack at a nuclear site. He is also given rare access to Sellafield’s aging facilities and some of the men and women tasked with clearing and securing over half a century of Britain’s nuclear waste.

column1: Further down the coast
column2: Simon heads out to sea to visit a much less controversial part of Cumbria’s ‘Energy Coast’ – the second biggest offshore wind farm on earth. But greener energy alone won’t reduce carbon emissions enough to prevent global warming. Vast areas of the Lake District are boggy peatlands. Peat is dense
column3: wet organic matter that stores enormous quantities of carbon. Simon heads up into the fells above Coniston to see a large project that is aiming to prevent the release of carbon from peatlands
column4: reversing this process to restore the land to its former boggy glory.

column1: At the end of his travels through Cumbria
column3: a shepherd and bestselling author who believes that farming could be the solution to many of our national problems
column4: from the loss of wildlife to climate change. His vision of ‘regenerative farming’
column5: where farmers work with the natural world to produce food
column6: is increasingly seen as one answer to the decline of rural communities and the degradation of the natural world.";Nature;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 367;367;The Forest;Series 1: Episode 6;Tree planter Alastair Livingstone restocks a recently felled site with sycamore and oak.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0blzvxd.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 6;Tree planter Alastair Livingstone restocks a recently felled site with sycamore and oak.;Mark Bonnar narrates a series revealing the world of Galloway Forest. John Coughtrie and Archie McNeillie prepare safe standing places for the crowds at the Galloway Hills Rally.;"Mark Bonnar narrates a series revealing the hidden world of Galloway Forest
column6: the country's largest afforested area. Join the amazing men and women who live and work in the place known as Scotland's 'Highlands in the Lowlands'
column7: where 600
column8: 000 tonnes of timber are produced every year.

column1: The Galloway Hills Rally draws crowds of visitors to the Forest Park. To make sure spectators have the best and safest view
column2: John 'Cool' Coughtrie and his Recreation Team boss Archie McNeillie spend the days leading up to the race preparing safe places for them to stand along the route. Reigning champion and local legend Jock Armstrong hopes to defend his title. On the day of the rally
column3: a troop of the event's safety marshalls are on duty and Archie too keeps a watchful eye over proceedings. Jock
column5: thinks of nothing but the finish line.

column1: At Penninghame
column2: tree planter Alastair Livingstone restocks a recently felled site with sycamore and oak. The Forestry Commission plant 4.5 million trees a year and Alastair has single-handedly planted over a million
column3: proudly offsetting his carbon footprint many times over. Wildlife ranger Grant Carson is on a stalk. Trees are the Forestry Commission's valuable asset
column4: and his task is to manage the numbers of thousands of deer that roam the Forest Park in an effort to stop them from damaging the recently planted trees. Having worked for 43 years as a forester
column5: Jim Burns has sophisticated tree-felling machines operating in the forest.";Nature;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2018;29;science-and-nature

column1: 368;368;Horizon;2021: 1. Horizon Special: The Vaccine;The extraordinary inside story of the vaccine scientists who took on Covid-19 - and won.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09l3fpy.jpg;BBC
column5: 2021: 1. Horizon Special: The Vaccine;The extraordinary inside story of the vaccine scientists who took on Covid-19 - and won.;With unique access to five vaccine teams around the globe
column6: this is the extraordinary inside story of the unprecedented quest to develop and make vaccines to fight Covid-19.;"The extraordinary inside story of the biggest scientific challenge of our age – following a small band of vaccine scientists around the world who took on Covid-19 and ultimately delivered the weapon to beat it.

column1: As news of the coronavirus broke around the globe
column2: a small group of scientists jumped into action to tackle one of the greatest medical challenges of our time: to create a vaccine against a virus no-one had ever seen before and to do so in record time

column1: 369;369;The People v Climate Change;None;Meet the ordinary Brits who will help decide how Britain solves the climate crisis.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09h8xzd.jpg;BBC
column4: The People v Climate Change;Meet the ordinary Brits who will help decide how Britain solves the climate crisis.;Meet the 108 ordinary Brits who Sir David Attenborough says we should listen to. This warm and honest documentary reveals how everyday people feel about the climate crisis.;"Britain has made big promises about reducing our impact on the planet
column5: but getting there means huge changes to our everyday lives. In this surprising and funny documentary
column6: we follow members of the UK’s first ever Citizen's Assembly on Climate Change
column7: where 108 ordinary Brits are tasked with deciding what we should do to meet our climate change goals.

column1: Organised by Parliament
column2: this historic event sees members of the public grapple with big questions about our future. As the assembly members learn the science of climate change from experts and hear Sir David Attenborough thank them for giving up their time for this task
column3: they begin to realise the huge significance of the decisions they must make.

column1: The film follows seven assembly members from all over the UK
column2: who each bring their own perspective to the climate change debate. Sue
column4: is shocked to learn the science of climate change
column5: and when floods hit the UK - and the south west in particular - she begins to understand how close to home these issues can be and resolves to make personal changes.

column1: British Gas employee Marc from Newcastle is enthusiastic about taking part in the assembly
column2: but is worried about losing his job in the transition to green energy
column3: while 27-year-old postal worker Amy is unsettled when she learns the environmental impact of the coal fire she heats her home with. We also meet retired printer Richard
column4: who is sceptical about climate change and reluctant to accept many of the proposals put forward in the assembly. But when his own health deteriorates
column5: he is forced to re-examine the impact of dirty air on all our lives.

column1: Through this cast of warm
column3: we understand the challenge we all face in the effort to reduce climate change and start to see what the future might look like in a greener world.";Nature;BBC WEBONLY;False;2021;63;science-and-nature

column1: 370;370;The Psychedelic Drug Trial;None;Can psychedelic drugs and psychological support help tackle depression?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09hcm8f.jpg;BBC
column4: The Psychedelic Drug Trial;Can psychedelic drugs and psychological support help tackle depression?;With exclusive access to a ground-breaking trial
column5: this film asks if psychedelic drugs combined with psychological support can help tackle one of the biggest medical challenges we face – depression.;"The Psychedelic Drug Trial has exclusive access to a ground-breaking new trial at Imperial College London. The trial sees
column6: for the first time ever under controlled conditions
column7: a psychedelic drug tested head-to-head against a standard antidepressant as a treatment for depression.

column1: The film follows a pioneering team of scientists and psychotherapists
column3: Dr Robin Carhart-Harris and Dr Rosalind Watts
column4: as they compare the effects of psilocybin (the active ingredient of magic mushrooms) with an antidepressant (an SSRI called escitalopram) on a small group of participants with clinical depression. This is scientific research at its most cutting edge. With over seven million people being prescribed antidepressants each year in England alone
column5: this drug trial is an important milestone in understanding a completely different treatment for depression.

column1: Filmed over 16 months
column2: this film explores both the immediate and long-term impacts of the trial on the lives of participants. It investigates whether psychedelic drugs combined with psychological support could help tackle one of the biggest medical challenges faced today and what it takes to conduct research in uncharted scientific territory.

column1: How do psychedelic drugs measure up against the industry-standard antidepressants that have been popular since the 1990s? The empirical results of the trial are explored alongside the participants’ powerful lived experience.";Science;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 371;371;Fred Dibnah's Building of Britain;6. Victorian Splendour;Fred looks at how steam-powered machinery facilitated the construction of Eastnor Castle.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bj1b4f.jpg;BBC
column5: 6. Victorian Splendour;Fred looks at how steam-powered machinery facilitated the construction of Eastnor Castle.;Series in which Fred Dibnah explores the engineering skills that went into the building of Britain. This edition is devoted to 19th-century achievements.;"In the final programme of the series uncovering the construction and engineering skills that went into the building of Britain
column6: Fred Dibnah indulges his personal passion for the achievements of the builders of the 19th century.

column1: At Eastnor Castle in Herefordshire
column2: a young architect called Robert Smirke was commissioned to build a grand house that was as big and impressive as a great medieval castle. As Fred demonstrates
column3: steam-powered machinery made this possible in a fraction of the time - if not the cost - involved originally.

column1: Eastnor also provides an introduction to the work of architect and designer Augustus Welby Pugin
column2: who was inspired by medieval Gothic architecture. At St Giles in Cheadle
column4: Fred examines one of Pugin's best Gothic works
column5: achieved thanks to one of the finest teams of craftsmen that have ever been seen in the building of Britain. The building with which Pugin is most commonly associated is the Palace of Westminster
column6: where he worked alongside fellow architect Sir Charles Barry. Fred reveals how the two men came up with a building that matched the medieval Westminster Abbey next door
column7: as well as demonstrating how the builders overcame the challenges posed by the riverbank location.

column1: Fred's final stop on this epic journey sees him scaling the heights again
column2: this time inside the Westminster clock tower - the one we call Big Ben - where he reveals what makes the country's best-known clock tick to time and how the huge bell was originally constructed.";Science;BBC TWO;False;2002;29;science-and-nature

column1: 372;372;Human Universe;5. What Is Our Future?;Professor Brian Cox concludes his exploration of our place in the universe.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xh6pz.jpg;BBC
column5: 5. What Is Our Future?;Professor Brian Cox concludes his exploration of our place in the universe.;Professor Brian Cox examines what lies ahead for humankind. On Svalbard
column6: he gains access to civilisation's greatest treasure
column7: buried deep in the permafrost.;"Professor Brian Cox concludes his exploration of our place in the universe by asking what next for the ape that went to space.

column1: In northern Spain
column2: he begins in a cave that was once home to our distant ancestors. Here
column3: he discovers some of the earliest art in the universe - a child's hand painted onto the wall that has remained intact for around 40
column4: 000 years. That child - if raised today - would be just as bright and just as capable as any modern child. Yet its vision of the future would be very different to ours.

column1: To understand what sets us apart
column2: Brian heads to the Arctic. In Svalbard
column3: he joins a group of people who are celebrating the midsummer sun. At these latitudes
column4: the sun doesn't set for weeks on end. Brian shows how science is able to precisely predict the future passage of our star in ways our ancestors could not have imagined. The difference is that science has given us a vision of the deep future. It has shown us that we live in a clockwork universe where planets turn around stars in predictable orbits
column5: stars around galaxies and the galaxies themselves are all falling through a probably infinite universe.

column1: But powerful as science is at predicting the motion of the heavens
column2: our future is far from certain. In Florida
column3: Brian joins the latest efforts to protect Earth from potential catastrophic events. He joins a team of Nasa astronauts who are training for a future mission to an asteroid - should we ever discover one coming our way - under 30 feet of water in a submerged laboratory that simulates space. It is just one example of how
column5: space exploration may well be vital. It is a view shared by Apollo 16 astronaut Charlie Duke
column6: who tells Brian what it was like to escape the confines of the planet. It is a dream that both Nasa and now commercial companies share as they race to get humans back into deep space.

column1: But space travel
column2: like every leap our civilisation has ever made
column4: scientists are hard at work attempting to safeguard our future. At the National Ignition Facility in California
column5: Brian witnesses the world's most successful fusion experiment in action. He believes that if their mission succeeds
column6: our civilisation will have unlocked a way to the stars that will not destroy the planet in the process.

column1: Brian concludes by returning to the top of the world in Svalbard
column2: where he gains access to our civilisation's greatest treasure
column3: locked away in a vault buried deep in the permafrost.";Science;BBC FOUR;False;2014;58;science-and-nature

column1: 373;373;The Mating Game;Series 1: 5. Against All Odds;Animals facing the greatest odds have the most extraordinary mating strategies of all.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09x58x9.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 5. Against All Odds;Animals facing the greatest odds have the most extraordinary mating strategies of all.;All life is driven by the need to breed. Yet for a few
column6: the odds of success are overwhelmingly against them
column7: and these animals have adopted the most extraordinary mating strategies of all.;"One basic need connects all life on earth - the need to breed. But for a few creatures
column8: the odds of success are overwhelmingly stacked against them. Some must find a partner when there are none to be found
column9: while others must find a way to succeed without breeding at all. And some must try to adapt in a world unrecognisable from when they were born. These are animals that have evolved some of the most extraordinary mating strategies of all
column10: and now they face a new challenge in the most successful breeder of all: us.

column1: The deep ocean is home to perhaps the most bizarre mating game of all. It’s the largest and least populated habitat on earth
column2: and most of the creatures here spend their lives alone and in total darkness. So when a male fan-tailed anglerfish is lucky enough to stumble across a female
column3: he clings on for dear life - and that ends up being the price he pays
column4: as his body fuses with hers and his sole purpose becomes the fertilisation of her eggs. He gives so much of himself to her that when she dies
column5: so will he.

column1: Toad-headed agamas spend their lives on the sand dunes of southern Russia. They need burrows in which to lay their eggs
column2: but this isn’t easy when their homes can be swallowed up before their eyes in the ever-shifting sands. Meanwhile
column4: finding a place to breed isn’t so much of a problem
column5: but finding a partner is a real struggle. Laysan pair for life
column6: but when there are not enough males to go around
column7: different tactics are required. And for another iconic bird
column8: an abundance of males leads to perhaps the most remarkable strategy of all. On the plains of Texas
column9: dominant wild turkey males are aided by their less impressive brothers
column10: who will help to keep rival males at bay whilst the top turkey secures as many mates as possible.

column1: In North America
column2: thousands of creatures have been hiding underground for 17 years for their chance to play the mating game. Periodical cicadas emerge from the ground in immense swarms to overwhelm predators and ensure the next generation of ground-dwellers. But a lot can change in so long a time
column3: and their parents could not have predicted how different the world would be for their offspring nor the challenges they would face in this brave new world.

column1: This is just one of the ways in which the breeding success of humans is impacting the natural mating game of others. As a consequence of our success
column2: we face a mass extinction event like no other in human history. But there is hope. Scientific breakthroughs have led to extraordinary solutions in helping other species to reproduce. In a United States federal government facility in Colorado
column3: an incredibly precious animal may be the key to secure the future of her species. And the successful conservation of perhaps the most iconic endangered animal on the planet
column5: has proved that humans can be a force for good.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2021;58;science-and-nature

column1: 375;375;Grand Tours of Scotland's Lochs;Series 4: 6. The Forgotten Lands;Paul explores the lochs of Morvern and Lochaber.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p05d762d.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 4: 6. The Forgotten Lands;Paul explores the lochs of Morvern and Lochaber.;Paul explores the lochs of Morvern. He discovers the devil in a fossil
column6: dabbles in art and then learns how to make Jacobite bank notes
column7: before climbing to a loch that never was.;"Paul explores the forgotten lands of Morvern. On the shores of Loch Aline
column8: he sees the devil in a fossil and then plunges deep underground to discover an unlikely connection between sand and WW2. Above Loch Arienas
column9: he hears the moving testimony of a family who were cleared from the land in the 19th century. Paul then has an al fresco art lesson and tries to paint the scene.

column1: At Fort William
column2: he paces the ruins of the original fort and learns that the town that now surrounds it was once known as Maryburgh. Following a Jacobite theme
column3: Paul encounters the Strange Plate and discovers the secrets of Jacobite paper money. Journey’s end is a 'loch that never was' beneath the magnificent 300ft Steall Falls.

column1:
;Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;29;science-and-nature, lifestyle, history, documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p05d762d.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p05d762d.jpg;paul explores forgotten land morvern shore loch aline see devil fossil plunge deep underground discover unlikely connection sand ww2 loch arienas hears moving testimony family cleared land 19th century paul al fresco art lesson try paint scene fort william pace ruin original fort learns town surround known maryburgh following jacobite theme paul encounter strange plate discovers secret jacobite paper money journey ’ end loch never beneath magnificent 300ft steall fall;9
376;376;Inside the Factory;Series 6: 10. Vacuums;Gregg Wallace visits a factory that makes 1.2 million vacuum cleaners every year.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09232d3.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Inside the Factory, Series 6: 10. Vacuums;Gregg Wallace visits a factory that makes 1.2 million vacuum cleaners every year.;Gregg Wallace visits a huge vacuum cleaner factory in the heart of Somerset and follows their biggest seller
column2: the Henry vacuum cleaner in bright red.

column1: ;Gregg Wallace visits a huge vacuum cleaner factory in the heart of Somerset. This 32-acre site is a hive of activity where 1.2 million vacuums are made every year. Gregg is following their biggest seller
column2: the Henry vacuum cleaner in bright red.

column1: He starts with head of operations Stuart Cochrane
column2: who is taking delivery of 25 tonnes of clear polypropylene pellets. They are transported to the factory floor via a spaghetti junction of pipes and then mixed with a red colouring agent. A massive moulding machine heats the plastic pellets and forces them into a drum-shaped mould under 300 tonnes of clamp pressure
column3: the equivalent weight of 24 London buses. There are 47 of these huge moulding machines in the factory
column5: 000 vacuums every day.

column1: Next
column2: Gregg’s vacuum needs a bit of personality. The famous smile was drawn on for the first time as a joke by an employee at a trade show
column3: but it attracted so much attention that it quickly became a permanent fixture. It is created using a process called PAD printing. Silicone pads are dipped in ink and pressed onto the surface of the moulded plastic ‘face’ to create the eyes and smile
column4: after which it is cured under heat to dry the ink.

column1: With the drum and face moulded and printed
column2: and wheels made from moulded recycled plastic
column3: the bottom half of the vacuum is assembled in less than a minute. Timing is crucial - the drum is still hot from the moulding machine
column4: so the wheels must be slotted in before the plastic cools and shrinks.

column1: Now for the top half of the vacuum cleaner
column2: which starts with a moulded motor housing. The motor needs power
column3: so Gregg meets with wiring section manager Nathan Bandy at the loom assembly station. Nathan explains that the wiring loom is a cluster of cables that connect to the on/off switch

column1: With so many electrical and mechanical parts in each vacuum
column2: the factory has its own on-site testing centre. Gregg can’t quite believe his eyes
column4: they are being put through their paces. It is like a torture chamber for vacuum cleaners!

column1: Back at the factory
column2: the top half of Gregg’s vacuum is coming together
column3: and the shiny top cover is emerging from another moulding machine.

column1: Next
column2: Gregg is sent off in search of a set of ‘wands’ for his vacuum
column3: and project manager Roy Poole has the magic touch. The wands start life as 422mm stainless steel tubes which are fed into a machine that reduces one end by 1mm and stretches the other by 1.75
column4: so they will slot neatly together to form a solid link between the brushes and the hose.

column1: At last
column2: the components can be brought together at the final assembly station
column3: and it happens fast! The lower housing forms the base
column4: then the motor with a jacket of acoustic wrap. The upper motor housing drops in on top with the reeler and ten-metre-long cable coming in above
column5: before it is all finished off with the shiny cover. The machine is plugged in and powered up to check the suction reaches a precise 225 millibar. Gregg is stunned to see that all the components come together in less than 30 seconds
column6: before they’re checked
column7: boxed up and sent to the dispatch area.

column1: 377;377;Wonders of the Celtic Deep;Series 1: Episode 4;This episode looks at some of the biggest marine environment challenges and issues today.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xhyf5.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 4;This episode looks at some of the biggest marine environment challenges and issues today.;Presented by Dame Sian Phillips
column6: this episode looks at some of the biggest challenges and issues facing the marine environment in Wales and the rest of the world today.;"Presented by Welsh acting legend Dame Sian Phillips
column7: this final episode in the series looks at some of the biggest challenges and issues facing the marine environment in Wales and the rest of the world today. We meet the conservation heroes from across Wales
column8: each doing their bit in many ways
column9: to help marine conservation and promote the importance of the ocean: from fishermen sacrificing profits in return for sustainability and a plastic-waste campaigner who paddleboarded around Wales to raise awareness about the pollution of our oceans to a group of underwater scuba-diving litter-pickers and a surfer who uses the sea to help people with mental health issues.

column1: Many are also working directly to save marine wildlife
column2: including a highly successful breeding programme to bring seahorses back to Welsh waters and remarkable organisations rescuing Atlantic grey seals and stranded whales. When the tide goes out
column3: one group of young enthusiasts undertakes important species counts on Welsh shores
column4: and another young marine biologist heads out to sea using a bait camera to film shark and other exciting species
column5: which he records and then shares with the world via social media.

column1: We also join the remarkable world-leading Welsh Seagrass Project
column2: led by a passionate scientist who is trying to plant a million seeds in Dale in Pembrokeshire. Seagrass is a hugely important marine environment. It acts as a nursery environment for animals and stores huge amounts of carbon dioxide - but seagrass has been disappearing across the world due to human activity.";Nature;BBC ONE WALES;False;2021;58;science-and-nature
