column1: 378;378;Neutrino: Hunting the Ghost Particle;None;The astonishing quest to detect and decode the most elusive particle in the universe.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09vxjrs.jpg;BBC
column4: Neutrino: Hunting the Ghost Particle;The astonishing quest to detect and decode the most elusive particle in the universe.;The astonishing tale of how scientists have battled against the odds to detect and decode the neutrino - the strangest
column5: most elusive particle in the universe.;"This is an astonishing tale of perseverance and ingenuity that reveals how scientists have battled against the odds for almost a century to detect and decode the neutrino
column6: the smallest and strangest particle of matter in the universe.

column1: Inside the world-renowned physics laboratory Fermilab
column2: a team of scientists are constructing an audacious experiment to hunt for a mysterious new ‘ghost’ neutrino. If they find it
column3: this could transform our understanding of the nature and fabric of our universe. The problem is
column4: these tiny particles are almost impossible to detect.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: physicists conduct experiments in some of the most extreme environments on the planet: from deep mine shafts in South Dakota to vast ice fields at the South Pole. In these unlikely places supersized neutrino detectors hope to unlock the universe’s deepest secrets. Could neutrinos overturn the most precise theory of particle physics that humans have ever written down? Could they even be a link to a hidden realm of new particles that permeate the cosmos – so called dark matter? Scientists at Fermilab are edging towards the truth.";Science;BBC FOUR;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 379;379;Animal Babies;1. Safari Babies;Young animals struggle to overcome challenges on the African savannah.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p049tgdb.jpg;BBC
column5: 1. Safari Babies;Young animals struggle to overcome challenges on the African savannah.;Documentary following young animals as they take their first steps and face their earliest challenges. This episode follows creatures on the great plains of Africa.;"The great plains of Africa are home to some of the most iconic animals on the planet. Growing up here means safari babies face immense challenges that will really test them. With the largest herds on the planet all competing for the same food
column6: and dangerous predators round every corner
column7: the African savannah is a hugely competitive place.

column1: This film follows animals including the newly born elephant calf who
column3: has become separated from the safety of the herd. She must battle against scorching heat to search for the rest of the family. Even predators are having a hard time - six adorable cheetah cubs are chased from a kill by vultures
column4: and now they need to start to learn to hunt for themselves. Elsewhere
column5: a young zebra foal has to cross the treacherous waters of a crocodile-infested river - despite her still-wobbly legs.

column1: They are all setting out on their own adventures
column2: and must learn fast if they're going to make it to adulthood.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2016;58;science-and-nature

column4: Inside Chernobyls Mega Tomb;The construction of a structure to entomb the ruins of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.;Documentary which follows the construction of a trailblazing 36
column5: 000-tonne steel structure to entomb the ruins of the nuclear power plant destroyed in the 1986 Chernobyl disaster.;"Documentary which follows the construction of a trailblazing 36
column6: 000-tonne steel structure to entomb the ruins of the nuclear power plant destroyed in the 1986 Chernobyl disaster. It films close up with the team of international engineers as they race to build the new structure before Chernobyl's original concrete sarcophagus - the hastily built structure that covers the reactor - collapses.

column1: Built to last just 30 years
column2: the temporary sarcophagus is now crumbling
column3: putting the world at risk of another release of radioactive dust. Radiation levels make it impossible for workers to build the new shelter directly over the old reactor
column4: so engineers are erecting the new megastructure - taller than the tower of Big Ben and three times heavier than the Eiffel Tower - to one side and will then face the challenge of sliding the largest object ever moved on land into place over the old reactor.";Science;BBC FOUR;False;2016;59;science-and-nature

column1: 381;381;Lipoedema – Sgeulachd Lorna / Lipoedema – Lorna’s Story;None;Lorna Taggart from Isle of Skye has spent a lifetime battling the condition lipoedema.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09265t1.jpg;BBC
column4: Lipoedema – Sgeulachd Lorna / Lipoedema – Lorna’s Story;Lorna Taggart from Isle of Skye has spent a lifetime battling the condition lipoedema.;A woman’s lifelong struggle with the debilitating fat disorder lipoedema. At last offered treatment
column5: her hopes for surgery are dashed by Covid-19. ;"Lipoedema is a condition thought to affect around 300
column6: 000 women in Scotland. It is a genetic disorder where abnormal fat cells lead to a disproportionate accumulation of weight in the middle of the body. It is highly debilitating
column7: impacting not only on a woman’s appearance and general wellbeing
column8: but on her mobility and state of mind.

column1: Lorna Taggart
column3: has battled lipoedema all her adult life. Broadcaster John McDiarmid is Lorna’s brother and has been filming with her since early 2019
column4: not long after she was diagnosed. The film charts Lorna's journey from her teens through to today as a full-time teacher and mother of three
column5: still facing a future dictated by a condition that very few understand
column6: and that medical practitioners often fail to identify.

The Great Reindeer Migration;Follow the migration of Norway’s Sami reindeer herds across Finnmark.;"Documentary following Norway’s Sami reindeer herds as they migrate across the mountainous region of Finnmark; a week-long journey of over 160 miles far north of the Arctic Circle. ";A BBC Four Slow Christmas treat follows Norway’s Sami reindeer herds as they migrate across the mountainous region of Finnmark
column5: far north of the Arctic Circle. The journey
column6: a little over 160 miles
column7: takes the herd a week
column8: travelling north from the inland winter feeding grounds to their coastal summer pastures. It is a journey fraught with hazardous weather conditions.;Nature;BBC FOUR;False;2018;119;science-and-nature

column1: Series following Calum Maclean as he shares his passion for swimming in remote lochs and rivers. There is nothing that Calum loves better than finding far-flung locations for outdoor swimming
column3: he reveals some of his favourite places throughout Scotland. His chosen settings are ones not often trumpeted and some that can only be accessed after strenuous endeavours. As he states himself
column4: 'I love to swim outdoors alone with no living person to be seen'.

column1: The ten locations featured include River Douchary
column5: Ardnamurchan. Calum also takes up a challenge to swim through punishing currents over to the island of Luing. As we visit all of these amazing spots
column6: we learn more about wild swimming and its current popularity
column7: and why Calum goes to such lengths for that perfect swim!

385;385;Jack the Ripper - The Case Reopened;None;Documentary which casts new light on the Jack the Ripper case.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k332t.jpg;BBC
column4: Jack the Ripper - The Case Reopened;Documentary which casts new light on the Jack the Ripper case.;Presented by Emilia Fox and Professor David Wilson
column5: this documentary casts new light on the Jack the Ripper case
column6: identifying another victim and naming the killer.;"In 1888 the most infamous serial killer of all time
column7: Jack the Ripper
column8: began his reign of terror in the East End of London. Between August and November
column9: five horrifically violent murders took place in Whitechapel.  There was a huge manhunt
column10: but the Ripper was never caught. Since then there has been endless speculation about who the Ripper was
column11: what motivated his crimes
column12: and how the killer escaped justice.

column1: Presented by the star of BBC One drama Silent Witness Emilia Fox and Britain’s top criminologist Professor David Wilson
column2: this documentary casts new light on the Jack the Ripper case. Together Emilia and David look at the Ripper’s modus operandi using modern technology - like a digital autopsy table - and recreating the murder sites to help understand the extraordinary risks the Ripper took to kill his victims.  Also
column3: using the Home Office Large Major Enquiry System (HOLMES)
column4: a bespoke computer system used by the police to help detect patterns in criminal activity
column5: and evidence uncovered within the investigation
column6: results strongly indicate that Martha Tabram was in fact the first Ripper victim.

column1: Convinced that Martha Tabram was the Ripper’s first victim
column2: Emilia and David ask a geographical profiling expert to take a fresh look at the pattern of Ripper murder sites
column3: which takes the investigation in a completely different direction
column4: ultimately identifying the most likely suspect.

column1: The debate about Jack the Ripper’s true identity is already over 130 years old and is sure to continue
column2: but this documentary casts new light onto the case and is as definitive as could be in naming the killer.";Science;BBC ONE;Contains upsetting scenes.;2019;59;science-and-nature

column1: 387;387;Climate Change: Countdown to COP26;Series 1: Episode 8;A special series of programmes helping us make sense of the challenges facing our planet.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09w50yy.jpg;BBC

column1: 388;388;Shop Well for the Planet?;Series 1: Episode 3;Can a family be convinced that going greener doesn’t have to cost more or be a hassle?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xvkm9.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;Can a family be convinced that going greener doesn’t have to cost more or be a hassle?;A young family are challenged to cut their carbon footprint and save money. Can they be convinced that being green doesn’t have to cost the earth and can still be convenient?;"This week
column6: Chris Bavin and Melanie Sykes help a time-stretched family with a new baby. Steve and Saskia live in Shrewsbury with their five-month-old daughter Cece and Saskia’s six-year-old daughter Edi. They are a family who would love to be greener but just can’t find the time to do it. Having a young family has prompted them both to start thinking about the planet and whether they can become more climate conscious
column7: but a busy work and home life has meant that it’s convenience and not the planet that is taking priority. Can they be convinced that being greener doesn’t have to cost the earth or turn their lives upside down?

column1: Before Chris and Melanie can help Saskia and Steve go greener
column3: seeking out their biggest not-so-eco spends and secretly setting up a pop-up shop with their stuff. They want to show them where they think they could be greener and save some money along the way. To track their progress
column4: Melanie and Chris reveal the family’s carbon footprint. Steve and Saskia are relieved to hear that they aren’t doing too badly
column5: but this is short lived when they find out what we should all be aiming for. Determined to lower their carbon footprint
column6: they get to work.

column1: When the family are out
column2: we go in and turn their home greener
column3: swapping cleaning products they know and trust for eco-friendly alternatives and stripping their bathroom of single-use plastics. We even challenge them to give reusable nappies a go. Nothing is out of bounds: we even swap their favourite cheeses for vegan alternatives. And we don’t stop inside - Saskia’s beloved car is swapped for an electric one.

column1: Saskia thinks that vegan cooking will take more time and make more mess
column2: so Jordan Banjo takes on the challenge. Together
column3: they rustle up a katsu-style cauliflower that any meat eater would enjoy. Chris takes Steve to their local fruit and veg market to give him a crash course in how to buy seasonally
column5: sustainably and cheaply. Saskia is not a fan of plant-based milk
column6: but Melanie wants them to do a blind taste test to see if they can tell which is which. Jo Page visits an Asda trial store that opened last year that is piloting ways to help customers shop more sustainably. And the great British public put a vegan version of a family favourite to the test: fishless fish fingers. Which plant-based fingers take top spot for our testers? ";Food;BBC ONE;False;2021;58;science-and-nature

column5: a remote Scottish community focused on spirituality and sustainable living.;"Documentary telling the story of what’s it’s like to be raised at the Findhorn Foundation
column6: a community dedicated to sustainability based on north east Scotland’s remote Moray coast.

column1: Told from the perspective of three young people who grew up in the community
column2: the film explores how the ideals of the foundation helped inform their opinions and lifestyle choices as adults.

column1: Growing Up Green offers a unique perspective on the climate crisis through the eyes of a generation raised in families where environmental protection is a way of life.";Nature;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;28;science-and-nature

column1: 390;390;The Planets;Series 1: 5. Into the Darkness: Ice Worlds;In the last episode
column2: Professor Brian Cox explores the remotest part of the solar system.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jby2g.jpg;BBC
column5: The Planets
column6: Series 1: 5. Into the Darkness: Ice Worlds;In the last episode
column7: Professor Brian Cox explores the remotest part of the solar system.;In the final episode
column8: Professor Brian Cox journeys to the remotest part of the solar system
column9: a place that the most mysterious planets call home.;"In the final episode
column10: Professor Brian Cox journeys to the remotest part of the solar system
column11: a place that the most mysterious planets call home. These worlds remain shadowy for a simple reason. Beyond Saturn
column12: we have only ever visited the most distant planets once.

column1: Uranus – barely visible to the naked eye - was once thought to be the furthest planet from the Sun. But with the telescope and some careful viewing we discovered it had a companion: Neptune. Thanks to a rare alignment of the planets in 1976
column2: Voyager 2 was sent for our only fly-by of these ice worlds. There we discovered far more vibrant planets than we ever imagined. Even at such cold temperatures
column3: great storms whip around these frozen worlds that are home to spectacular moons and intricate ring systems. After a few hours of observation at each planet
column4: Voyager 2 left them behind. We have never returned.

column1: For decades that was as far as we got
column2: until 2015 when Nasa’s New Horizons probe pushed the frontier even further into space. with its extraordinary passage to the dwarf planet Pluto. Once again
column3: all our assumptions about this distant world were wrong. Pluto is alive with ice volcanoes
column5: and geysers - even a subsurface ocean. What’s more
column6: we discovered that Pluto isn’t alone out there - there is a plethora of weird icy companions
column7: which are redefining everything we thought we knew about the strange
column8: distant reaches of our solar system.";Science & Nature;BBC TWO;False;2019;59;science-and-nature

column5: Yorkshire Wolds Way
column6: Episode 2;Paul Rose explores the Yorkshire Wolds Way
column7: with a unique view of the chalk downland.;Paul Rose explores the 79 miles of the Yorkshire Wolds Way. He gets a unique view of this stretch of chalk downland and gets a special invitation to a military base.;Adventurer Paul Rose continues his exploration of the Yorkshire Wolds Way
column8: arguably Britain's least well-known national walking trail. The 79-mile trail starts at the Humber Estuary and ends at the Yorkshire seaside resort of Filey. In this episode
column9: Paul takes to the skies to get a unique view of this stretch of chalk downland and gets a special invitation to a military base that's been keeping the country safe since the start of the Second World War.;Nature;BBC ONE;False;2017;29;science-and-nature

column1: 392;392;Royal Institution Christmas Lectures;2021: 3. Fighting Back;Jonathan Van-Tam unlocks the science of vaccines
column5: Royal Institution Christmas Lectures
column6: 2021: 3. Fighting Back;Jonathan Van-Tam unlocks the science of vaccines
column7: variants and viral genetic codes.;Professor Jonathan Van-Tam is joined by leading experts to unlock the science of vaccines
column8: variants and viral genetic codes.;"Professor Jonathan Van-Tam explores the inner workings of vaccines to reveal how these medical marvels can help win the war on viruses and potentially fight diseases such as cancer. Joined by vaccine scientist Professor Teresa Lambe and microbiologist Professor Sharon Peacock
column9: the team peel away the scabs of smallpox and inject the puss of a milkmaid to uncover the key milestones that led to vaccines over 200 years ago. Science has not stopped since. The Covid-19 vaccines are a triumph
column10: but can the audience take them a step further? Can they use a vaccine to blow up cancer cells on the lecture theatre floor?

column1: Viruses have a trick up their sleeve. They can mutate. A pack of dastardly dogs help unlock the secrets of variants
column3: but scientists are one step ahead. The pandemic has pushed the speed and scale of genetic sequencing technology to unprecedented levels and we can crack the virus’s genetic code to watch it evolve in near-real time. It’s a crucial tool to stay on top of Covid-19. Combined with solutions from nature
column4: from fruit bats to furry llamas
column5: science may never be the same again.";Science;BBC FOUR;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 394;394;Seven Worlds
column2: One Planet;Continents of Wonder;The most spectacular moments from the series.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07y7113.jpg;BBC
column5: Seven Worlds
column6: One Planet
column7: Continents of Wonder;The most spectacular moments from the series.;The most spectacular moments from the series
column8: highlighting the incredible rich and wonderful diversity of life found on our planet's seven unique continents.;"The most spectacular moments from the Seven Worlds
column9: One Planet series that highlights the incredible rich and wonderful diversity of life found on our planets seven unique continents. Millions of years ago huge forces ripped apart the Earth's crust
column10: creating seven distinct continents. Over time
column11: each one developed its own remarkable wildlife.

column1: We see the extraordinary variety of life found in South America and visit the largest of all continents - Asia
column2: so big it still hides rarely seen creatures. We explore the cities of Europe
column5: home to the greatest gatherings of animals. We travel to the searing heat of Australia with its weird and wonderful wildlife
column6: and witness the pioneering animals of North America that make the most of every opportunity. Finally
column7: we venture to the frozen wilderness of Antarctica were
column8: on the most hostile continent of all
column9: life manages to thrive against the odds. And we reveal how today the biggest challenge faced by wildlife is the impact of human activity on all seven of our incredible continents.

Spring Serenity;Springwatch has been out filming with people who are passionate about British wildlife.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09kx6bf.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Springwatch 2021. Red Button, 1. Spring Serenity;Springwatch has been out filming with people who are passionate about British wildlife.;Springwatch has been out filming with some passionate people as they enjoy the best seasonal wildlife from across the British Isles.;Spring has the capacity to bring out the best in all of us. It’s a time of new beginnings
column3: rejuvenation and transformation. Days are warmer and longer and we’re able
column5: to get out and about into the spring sunshine. We’ve been filming the very best wildlife with some of the most passionate people all across the UK.

column1: As we all emerge blinking into the light following a year like no other
column2: Springwatch is here to remind us all how important nature has been in our recovery. Chantelle Lindsey from the London Wildlife Trust reveals the secret history of London’s Great North Woods showing us the preserved pockets that still remain and the species that they support. As aspiring natural history filmmaker Rachel Bigsby faced her second redundancy as a result of the pandemic
column3: she put her unplanned time to good use… by chasing her dreams and heading to the coast to film a free spirit that had long captured her imagination – the fulmar. Penny Metal has quite a draw to her local Peckham park in London… but it’s not the people that pull her in
column4: it’s the enormous array of insects that call it home. Penny’s passionate about telling their story so that we all can live happily alongside these miniature marvels and naturalist and presenter Ajay Tegala works as a wildlife ranger in the East Anglian fens. He’s on the lookout for cranes - a truly majestic bird that was driven to extinction in Britain
column5: but Ajay is pleased to see Britain’s tallest bird returning to his region. Join the team as we celebrate Spring 2021.";Nature;BBC WEBONLY;False;2021;20;science-and-nature

column1: 396;396;Earth’s Tropical Islands;Series 1: 3. Hawaii;Exploring Hawaii
column2: a tropical sanctuary for any wildlife that can reach its remote shores.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07y8wbb.jpg;BBC
column5: Earth’s Tropical Islands
column6: Series 1: 3. Hawaii;Exploring Hawaii
column7: a tropical sanctuary for any wildlife that can reach its remote shores.;Exploring Hawaii
column8: a tropical sanctuary for any wildlife that can reach its remote shores. From humpback whales to waterfall-climbing fish
column9: it is home to an extraordinary wealth of wildlife.;"This is a journey across Hawaii’s varied islands
column10: discovering how they were made and the incredible wildlife that thrives there.

column1: Hawaii is the most remote island chain on earth
column2: and its tropical shores are hard to reach. But for the hardy creatures that can make it here
column5: a land of opportunity awaits. From newly formed lava fields to lush jungles and vibrant coral reefs
column6: these diverse and beautiful islands have it all.

column1: Packed with surprising stories
column2: the hidden gems of this tropical paradise are uncovered using stunning photography. Dramatic footage of the humpback whale heat run – the biggest courtship battle in the world – and intimate views of the world’s oldest known bird feeding its chick are just some of the highlights of what Hawaii has to offer.

column1: The islands are so isolated that it used to be that one new species arrived every 100
column3: but the arrival of people has radically changed the face of Hawaii. Now it gains around 20 new species every year. The remarkable Jackson’s chameleon is one of the animals recently introduced. Showing off its voracious appetite
column4: the programme reveals how it is eating its way through the native animals and contributing to wiping them out entirely.

column1: But this is a place where people are looking to the future and attempting to bring wildlife back from the brink of extinction. White terns
column2: once extinct on the main islands of Hawaii
column3: have gone from a single pair to over 2
column4: 000 birds in the last 60 years. It is a huge challenge
column5: but people are seeking progressive new ways to live alongside nature to allow Hawaii’s wildlife to continue to thrive.";Nature;BBC TWO;False;2020;59;science-and-nature

column1: 397;397;Frozen Planet;7. On Thin Ice;David Attenborough investigates the effects of rising temperatures in the polar regions.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jv364.jpg;BBC
column5: 7. On Thin Ice;David Attenborough investigates the effects of rising temperatures in the polar regions.;David Attenborough journeys to the poles to investigate what rising temperatures will mean for the people and wildlife that live there
column6: and for the rest of the planet.;"David Attenborough journeys to both polar regions to investigate what rising temperatures will mean for the people and wildlife that live there
column7: and for the rest of the planet.

column1: David starts out at the North Pole
column2: standing on sea ice several metres thick
column3: but which scientists predict could be open ocean within the next few decades. The Arctic has been warming at twice the global average
column4: and David heads out with a Norwegian team to see what this means for polar bears. He comes face to face with a tranquilised female and discovers that mothers and cubs are going hungry as the sea ice on which they hunt disappears. In Canada
column5: Inuit hunters have seen with their own eyes what scientists have seen from space - the Arctic Ocean has lost 30% of its summer ice cover over the last 30 years. For some
column6: the melting sea ice will allow access to trillions of dollars' worth of oil
column7: gas and minerals. For the rest of us
column8: it means the planet will get warmer
column9: as sea ice is important to reflect back the sun's energy. Next
column10: David travels to see what is happening to the ice on land. In Greenland
column11: he follows intrepid ice scientists as they study giant waterfalls of meltwater
column12: which are accelerating iceberg-calving events and ultimately leading to a rise in global sea levels.

column1: Temperatures have also risen in the Antarctic - David returns to glaciers photographed by the Shackleton expedition and reveals a dramatic retreat over the past century. It is not just the ice that is changing - ice-loving adelie penguins are disappearing and more temperate gentoo penguins are moving in. Finally
column2: we see the first ever images of the largest recent natural event on our planet - the break up of the Wilkins Ice Shelf
column3: an ice sheet the size of Jamaica
column4: which shattered into hundreds of icebergs in 2009.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2011;58;science-and-nature

column1: 399;399;Forces of Nature with Brian Cox;4. The Pale Blue Dot;Professor Brian Cox explains the science behind the colours of the planet.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b3dsh6.jpg;BBC
column4: Forces of Nature with Brian Cox
column5: 4. The Pale Blue Dot;Professor Brian Cox explains the science behind the colours of the planet.;Professor Brian Cox reveals how Earth's beauty is created by just a handful of forces. In this episode Brian explains the science behind the colours of the planet.;"In this final episode Professor Brian Cox travels to Iceland
column6: where the delicate splendour of a moonbow reveals the colours that paint our world
column7: and he visits a volcano to explain why the sun shines. By exploring how sunlight transforms the plains of the Serengeti
column8: drives the annual migration of humpback whales to the Caribbean and paints the moon red during a lunar eclipse
column9: Brian reveals the colour signature of our life-supporting planet.

column1: Finally
column2: at an observatory high in the Swiss Alps
column3: he shows how these colours aren't simply beautiful
column4: but that understanding how they're created is allowing us to search for other Earths far out in the cosmos.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2016;58;science-and-nature

column5: Hughs Wild West
column6: Series 1: Episode 12;Hugh meets Beryl Casey
column7: who has transformed her home into a hedgehog hospital.;In the last episode
column8: Hugh Fearnley Whittingstall meets Beryl Casey
column9: who has transformed her home into a hedgehog hospital
column10: nursing sick and injured hogs back to health.;"In the final episode
column11: nature lover Hugh Fearnley Whittingstall pays tribute to the wildlife heroes who are protecting the West Country's creatures. He meets Beryl Casey
column12: who has transformed her home into a hedgehog hospital
column13: nursing sick and injured hogs back to health. The UK's hedgehog population has halved since the millennium so every animal counts
column14: and Hugh helps return one of Beryl's patients to the wild.

column1: Across the region
column2: Hugh discovers volunteers working hard to safeguard their local wildlife - whether that is helping amorous toads to cross busy roads in the breeding season
column3: keeping watch over precious gull nests or creating space for nature in a bustling caravan park. And one Somerset teenager

column5: Series 1: 4. What Is Time?;Brian explores one of the greatest mysteries in physics today – what is time?;Brian explores the enigma of time – a phenomenon that we take for granted but which
column6: as far as physicists are concerned
column7: is one of the biggest mysteries in the universe.;Brian explores a simple question that is causing a big stir today: what is time? Modern science shows it to be far stranger than we think. He recalls some highlights from his TV series that touch upon different aspects of this physics conundrum: from a mindboggling encounter with Doctor Who
column8: to breaking the sound barrier in a Eurofighter in order to see two sunsets in one day
column9: to witnessing one of the oldest animal life cycles on earth on a remote beach in Costa Rica. He also explores Chankillo
column10: the oldest and best-preserved astronomical observatory in the Americas.;Science;BBC TWO;False;2021;58;science-and-nature

column1: 403;403;Blue Planet II;Oceans of Wonder;This extended special journeys to new worlds and reveals new animal behaviours.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p05rrp4f.jpg;BBC
column5: Oceans of Wonder;This extended special journeys to new worlds and reveals new animal behaviours.;This extended special of the nature documentary series journeys from the equator to the unexplored depths
column6: meeting the best-loved characters from the series.;"In recent years
column7: our knowledge of life beneath the waves has been transformed. Using cutting-edge technology in this extended special we celebrate the highlights from the series. From the intense heat of the tropics to our planet's frozen poles
column8: through to its unexplored depths
column9: we reveal new worlds and extraordinary never-seen-before animal behaviours.

column1: Starting in the tropical coral reefs - the most diverse ocean habitat - a tusk fish demonstrates a surprising level of ingenuity - tool use - as it uses corals as an anvil to break open clams. In the Seychelles
column2: half a million terns nest on an island. Fledglings must eventually take to the wing
column3: but danger lurks beneath the waves: metre-long giant trevally fish leap clear out of the water to snatch birds on the wing.

column1: In the tropics sun heats the sea
column3: winds and huge storms that drive up towards higher latitudes. Here the seas change with the seasons. In spring thousands of mobula rays gather in Mexico's Sea of Cortez. At night
column5: tiny organisms that light up when disturbed react to their wingbeats
column6: creating an enchanting bioluminescent firework display.

column1: The seasonal seas are home to bountiful kelp forests. In the undersea forests of southern Africa
column2: one resident - the common octopus- has become the ultimate escape artist. To outwit her nemesis
column5: never filmed before.

column1: On the coast
column2: two worlds collide. Where sea meets land
column3: coasts are the most dynamic and challenging habitats in the ocean. The ever-changing tides create rock pools. But these temporary worlds are a battleground. Predatory starfish turn a magical garden into the stuff of nightmares.

column1: The big blue is the world's greatest wilderness - it's a vast marine desert where there is little to eat and nowhere to hide. Sometimes there is a brief explosion of food in this marine desert
column2: but ocean hunters must be fast to make the best of this bonanza. We witness super-pods of up to five thousand spinner dolphins racing to herd vast shoals of lanternfish
column3: briefly caught at the surface where it is thought they spawn. New aerial footage reveals
column5: the spectacular feeding frenzy of 90kg tuna and dolphins smashing through the lantern fish shoals turning the sea white with foam.

column1: The deep is perhaps the most hostile environment on Earth
column2: at least to us - a world of crushing pressure
column3: brutal cold and utter darkness. We have barely begun to explore it and yet it is the largest living space on our blue planet
column4: home to strange worlds like methane volcanoes and undersea lakes of salty brine. But life adapts in ingenious ways
column5: like the sea toad - a fish that walks instead of swims. And barrel-eye - a deep sea fish with a translucent skull so that it can see through the top of its head to make the most of any glimmer of light.

column1: The deep is more closely connected to our own world than we ever thought possible due to giant ocean currents. We join these ocean currents as they begin their lives in Antarctica and flow from the poles to the tropics and back again
column2: linking every ocean. Ocean currents move heat around our planet and maintain a climate favourable for life. But our ocean system
column4: is changing at a worrying rate.

column1: Deep in the polar north
column2: we meet walrus mothers and their newborn calves
column3: searching for an ice floe to rest on; but with rising temperatures
column4: summer sea ice is retreating- their battles to survive are becoming ever harder. As we begin to understand the true complexity of the lives of our ocean creatures so do we recognise the fragility of their home.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2018;88;science-and-nature

column1: 404;404;Planet Earth;11. Ocean Deep;The final episode looks at the largest of all habitats - the ocean.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jv3v5.jpg;BBC
column5: 11. Ocean Deep;The final episode looks at the largest of all habitats - the ocean.;Series showing our planet in its natural glory. A look at the largest of all habitats
column6: the ocean
column7: which encompasses 90 per cent of all the living space on the planet.;"David Attenborough narrates the final episode in the documentary series that shows our planet in all its glory. In this part
column8: he looks at the largest of all habitats - the ocean. From the surface to the distant abyss
column9: it encompasses 90 per cent of all the living space on our planet. Its depths plunge to over 11 kilometres down and it hides over 30
column10: 000 immense volcanic mountains
column11: some far taller than Mount Everest. Much of this vastness is a virtual desert
column12: but the creatures that do live here include the most bizarre
column13: most powerful and most charismatic of all. It is the home of the greatest animal ever to have existed
column14: the blue whale
column15: twice the size of the largest known dinosaurs.

column1: So
column2: from the sinister 'vampire squid from hell' glowering in the depths
column3: to the scintillating attacks of 100 sabre-billed sailfish speeding at the surface
column4: explore the alien world of the open ocean in the safety of your living room.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2006;59;science-and-nature

column1: 405;405;Primates;Series 1: 3. Protecting Primates;Meet the scientists making groundbreaking discoveries about this remarkable animal family.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08b5th2.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 3. Protecting Primates;Meet the scientists making groundbreaking discoveries about this remarkable animal family.;Documentary. Today
column6: more than half of the world’s primates are under threat of extinction. Meet the scientists making groundbreaking discoveries about this remarkable animal family.;"Today
column7: more than half of the world’s primates are under threat of extinction. Now they need our help. Meet the scientists making groundbreaking discoveries about this remarkable animal family and the dedicated people going to extraordinary lengths to safeguard their future.

column1: Only by truly understanding primates can we protect them. Researcher Dr Cat Hobaiter has spent 13 years studying chimpanzees in the jungles of Uganda. She is fascinated by their communication and
column2: after recording thousands of hours of footage
column3: has revealed that our closest cousins have a secret language.

column1: On Thailand’s east coast
column2: Dr Amanda Tan reveals something rare in the animal kingdom: tool use. A population of long-tailed macaques have
column4: used tools to harvest shellfish. And in Brazil
column5: researcher Vedrana Slipogor plays videos to some of the world’s tiniest monkeys - common marmosets – as she tries to understand the subtleties of primate personality. In Madagascar
column6: drones mounted with thermal-imaging cameras might be the key to protecting some of the world’s most elusive lemurs. And in the rainforests of Tanzania
column7: we witness the moment when primatologist Dr Russell Mittermeier becomes the first person to have seen every type of primate on the planet.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2020;58;science-and-nature

column6: can save their people.;"In a hundred years
column7: rising sea levels will make small Island states like Samoa inhabitable. Sustainable living is part of the way of life in the Pacific Islands
column8: but the rest of the world has not caught on. The BBC's Gender and Identity reporter
column9: Megha Mohan
column10: exclusively follows Samoa's first female leader Fiame Naomi Mata'afa
column11: and other female leaders and activists in the Pacific Islands
column12: to ask whether female leaders in the most climate vulnerable region in the world
column13: with the lowest female parliamentary representation
column14: can save their people.

column1: A personal portrait of the crofting calendar on South Uist
Made from rock as old as the moon
column2: Uist has been shaped by winds
column3: tides and the people who have continuously worked this landscape for 5
column4: 000 years. The traditional crofting methods enable rare species of birds and flowers to thrive that are extinct elsewhere in the British Isles. Conflicts arise from the dramatic weather system and the front-line cycles of life and death
column5: and from the flocking geese.

column1: Over the last 30 years
column2: the resident population of Greylags has increased from less than 1
column4: 000 birds. With little to check the breeding Greylag
column5: the geese are destroying the cultivation of Uist corn.

column1: How the crofters meet these and other challenges with wit
column2: humour and determination is a core driver of the action. Always there is the need to sow the seed and cultivate the corn to feed the cattle. And to shepherd the sheep on the hills.";Nature;BBC ALBA;False;2018;59;science-and-nature

column5: 4. Eight People Sipping Wine in Kettering;A look at psychoanalytic techniques used by western political powers to gain power.;This episode looks at how both the UK Labour Party and US Democrats have used psychoanalytic techniques - namely
column6: focus groups - to mislead and gain power over the masses.;"This episode explains how politicians on the left
column7: in both Britain and America
column8: turned to the techniques developed by business to read and fulfil the inner desires of the self.

column1: Both New Labour
column5: used the focus group
column6: which had been invented by psychoanalysts
column7: in order to regain power. They set out to mould their policies to people's inner desires and feelings
column8: just as capitalism had learnt to do with products.

column1: Out of this grew a new culture of public relations and marketing in politics
column2: business and journalism. One of its stars in Britain was Matthew Freud who followed in the footsteps of his relation
column4: the inventor of public relations in the 1920s.

column1: The politicians believed they were creating a new and better form of democracy
column2: one that truly responded to the inner feelings of individual. But what they didn't realise was that the aim of those who had originally created these techniques had not been to liberate the people but to develop a new way of controlling them.";Science & Nature;BBC TWO;False;2002;59;science-and-nature

column1: 414;414;Black Black Oil;None;An exploration of our economic
column2: historical and emotional entanglement with North Sea oil.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b12k9r.jpg;BBC
column5: Black Black Oil;An exploration of our economic
column6: historical and emotional entanglement with North Sea oil.;Documentary exploring our economic
column7: historical and emotional entanglement with North Sea oil
column8: which is getting evermore complex as we hurtle towards climate breakdown.;"North Sea oil has been an invisible machine at the core of the UK. It now faces an uncertain future as activists and investors demand change. Is the era of North Sea oil over?

column1: This documentary draws on the voices of young activists
column3: economists and pension fund managers to explore the vital questions that affect all our lives. We have 5-10 years to control our oil addiction
column4: and yet the licensing of new oil fields such as the Cambo oil field off Shetland is seen to be in direct contradiction to the government’s alignment with the Paris Climate Agreement and hosting of COP.

column1: There is also a look at how the drama of global climate action is playing out in the fight over North Sea oil. Oil companies are convinced that they can continue to keep drilling while keeping to net zero ambitions through adopting new technologies
column2: such as carbon capture. But climate scientists are deeply sceptical of the net zero concept and the time it would take for these technologies to be effective.

column1: The film reveals the hidden infrastructure of oil from the offshore rigs and the buried pipelines
column2: to its flow through the stock markets of London. As the North Sea industry struggles to meet the need to cut carbon emissions
column3: oil workers see their livelihoods under threat
column4: and investors seek to protect their assets. Meanwhile
column5: a younger generation of climate activists are catalysed by the signs of impending chaos and the threat of global sea level rises.

column1: Black Black Oil explores the complexities of transitioning away from oil and gas as a society and considers how quickly we can do it.";Nature;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;58;science-and-nature

column1: 415;415;Wonders of Life;Original Series: 5. Home;Brian Cox considers what it is about our world that makes it a home for life.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09xh7pd.jpg;BBC
column5: Original Series: 5. Home;Brian Cox considers what it is about our world that makes it a home for life.;Brian Cox considers what it is about our world that makes it a home for life and asks what transformed this once barren planet into the earth we know today.;"As far as we know
column6: there is only one place in the universe on which life has taken hold - earth - but for how much longer will this distinction remain? Astronomers are on the brink of finding other worlds the same size as earth and the same distance from their star. Professor Brian Cox considers what it is about our world that has made it a home and asks what ingredients are necessary to turn a tiny spec of rock in space into a living
column7: vibrant planet.

column1: To find out
column2: Brian has come to one of earth's richest and most bio-diverse territories
column3: Mexico. He begins by diving in search of our most essential ingredient in a beautiful azure sink hole or cenote
column4: a characteristic feature and primary water source in southern Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. He then travels aboard the spectacular Copper Canyon Railway to measure the impact that the sun has on our planet
column5: discovering how early life had to learn to survive under its glare in ways that still survive in us all today.

column1: At the end of the train journey
column2: he arrives in Mexico's beautiful mountain interior
column3: where he uncovers how the relationship life has with the sun has led to one on the most astonishing of all life's inventions: photosynthesis. By turning sunlight into energy
column4: life has tapped a seemingly endless energy source and introduces a vital ingredient to the planet's atmosphere - oxygen.

column1: Finally
column2: Brian visits a remote enclave high up in the pine forests of central Mexico to witness one of nature's greatest sights
column3: the arrival of the monarch butterflies. Each year they make one of the longest migrations of all the butterfly species
column5: 000 kilometres from northern Canada to Mexico
column6: by tapping into one the most elusive
column7: intangible and perhaps rarest planetary ingredients of them all.";Science & Nature;BBC TWO;False;2013;59;science-and-nature

column1: 418;418;Measuring Mass: The Last Artefact;None;What are the consequences if the object against which we measure all other things changes?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09vgqc1.jpg;BBC
column4: Measuring Mass: The Last Artefact;What are the consequences if the object against which we measure all other things changes?;A piece of metal that defines the mass of a kilogramme has
column5: over time
column6: lost the equivalent of the weight of an eyelash. What are the consequences for how we measure our world?;"Just outside Paris
column7: inside a hi-tech vault
column8: and encased in three vacuum-sealed bell jars
column9: rests a small metallic cylinder about the diameter of a golf ball.

column1: It may not look like much
column2: but it is one of the most important objects on the planet. It affects nearly every aspect of our lives including the food we eat
column4: even the medicines we take. It is the kilogramme
column5: the base unit of mass in the International System of Units. This small hunk of metal is the object against which all others are measured. Yet over time
column6: its mass has mysteriously eroded by the weight of an eyelash. A change that
column7: unbeknownst to most
column8: unleashed a crisis with potentially dire consequences.

column1: Measuring Mass: The Last Artefact follows the ensuing high-stakes
column2: two-year race to redefine the weight of the world
column3: and tells the story of one of the most important objects on the planet.";Science;BBC FOUR;False;2021;56;science-and-nature

column1: 426;426;River Walks;Series 1: 1. The Nidd;Blind adventurer Amar Latif takes us along one of Yorkshire’s most stunning river valleys.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bm6hbv.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 1. The Nidd;Blind adventurer Amar Latif takes us along one of Yorkshire’s most stunning river valleys.;Blind adventurer Amar Latif takes us along one of Yorkshire’s most stunning river valleys. He abseils into a hidden gorge
column6: canoes across a reservoir and meets the local llamas.;"Blind adventurer Amar Latif takes us on a route along one of Yorkshire’s most stunning river valleys. He abseils into a hidden gorge
column7: canoes across a reservoir
column8: and meets the local llamas while following a riverside trail along the Nidd.

column1: Grab your boots and join adventurer Amar Latif as he takes us on a journey along one of Yorkshire’s most surprising rivers. As a blind man with a passion for outdoor adventure
column2: Amar discover how the stunning landscape along the River Nidd has been shaped
column3: while abseiling into a hidden canyon
column4: discovering the remains of an abandoned village
column5: canoeing over Bradford’s water supply and meeting the local llamas.

column1: Amar’s 13-mile route takes in the most stunning parts of this unique river valley. It’s the place where mysterious gorges have been carved out over thousands of years
column2: where villages have been left abandoned after huge civil engineering projects
column3: and where the farms of the future are taking hold in the landscape. It is packed with intriguing history

column1: We hear how Amar was introduced to outdoor adventure after he became blind when he was 18. Climbing Yorkshire’s Three Peaks was his first major challenge so the scenery of North Yorkshire still means the world to him.
His journey starts at Scar House Reservoir
column2: where the source of the Nidd rises dramatically behind the dam wall. He starts his journey by canoe with a local instructor
column3: paddling across the reservoir – before he explores the remains of a mysterious vanishing village that was once home to 1
column5: he discovers how it housed families working on the revolutionary reservoir project which now provides most of Bradford’s water supply. Remains include the projection booth of a stunning 600-seat cinema.

column1: Amar’s journey then continues down the Nidd valley – where the landscape is rapidly changing. Farmer Martyn Brown has turned his back on sheep and crops
column3: 000 trees on his 970-acre farm by the Nidd. He is part of a movement to revolutionise the way farms connect with nature. Amar meets him to investigate how this farm is transforming the fortunes of the local wildlife – and also helps out with a spot of dry stone walling to stop the sheep nibbling the new trees.

column1: Walking with his guide
column2: Amar then heads up and over the moor before descending to the dramatic How Stean Gorge. On the way
column3: there is a brief stop at Middlesmoor where he explains how blind people can still enjoy stunning views like this.

column1: Putting on his wetsuit
column2: Amar then takes on a spectacular limestone ravine carved out over thousands of years by the power of the river. With instructor Tony Liddy
column3: he abseils 45 feet into the gorge below. With specialist waterproof cameras
column4: they explore a hidden area of incredible beauty and examine the natural rock formations and how the gorge came to be.

column1: Continuing downstream
column2: with stunning aerials and idyllic filming
column3: Amar and his guide continue to Pateley Bridge – stopping to help catch wild brown trout on the river.

column1: Amar then heads to what is officially the oldest sweet shop in England. Tasting the old classics
column2: operating the vintage confectionary machines and talking all things sweet with its charismatic owner
column3: Amar revels in the nostalgia that brings so many visitors to this beautiful village.

column1: His journey then continues down the river valley – as the autumn leaves line the path as the river widens. His journey concludes by meeting a remarkable farmer’s wife. After going to buy a horse and coming home with a llama ten years ago
column2: Suzanne Benson is the proud owner of a llama trekking farm in the beautiful countryside beside the River Nidd. Suzanne takes Amar on a llama trek
column3: where he reflects on how he was in Peru when he last came across one
column4: and wonders if a llama would make for a good guide dog replacement. They finish with a scenic trek overlooking this unique part of the Yorkshire Dales.

column1: With high quality drone filming
column3: shots under the surface of the river itself and bespoke craft filming
column4: this is a high quality film showcasing one of the most impressive but rarely visited parts of Yorkshire – all fronted by a witty
column5: engaging and dynamic new presenter.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2018;29;science-and-nature

column5: she visits a research farm that is exploring ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated by beef and dairy cows. Greta also looks closer to home and contemplates how everyone can play a part – from our choice of the food we eat to the clothes we wear.

column5: Series 1: 5. The Big Bang: Before the Dawn;Why are we here? Brian Cox journeys back 13.8 billion years to the origin of the universe.;It’s the ultimate question: why are we here? Brian Cox explores how cutting-edge space missions take us back 13.8 billion years to the origin of the universe.;"Professor Brian Cox asks the ultimate question: how did the universe come to be? It is daunting in its scale. We live on one planet of eight that orbit just one of the 400 billion stars in our galaxy
column6: which in turn is one of trillions in the universe. Yet it is amongst those galaxies that we have been able to unravel the story of the universe’s creation. Thanks to a series of discoveries
column7: our most powerful space missions have unravelled 13.8 billion years of cosmic evolution and revealed the story of our universe from its birth all the way to the arrival of our nascent civilisation.

column1: Our guide on this odyssey back to the dawn of time is light. Telescopes are time machines - by looking out into the distant universe
column2: they open a window to the past. One telescope more than any other has helped us journey through the history of the universe: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope. Over the course of three decades
column3: Hubble has shown us cosmic evolution in action – including stars and planets being born and galaxies colliding. Remarkably
column4: Hubble has even found one of the first galaxies ever to exist in the universe
column5: which was born some 13.4 billion years ago. It's a discovery that hints at the beginnings of our own Milky Way. Vivid CGI brings this ancient galaxy to life
column6: allowing us to witness for ourselves the first dawn. It was the beginning of a relationship between stars and planets that would
column7: on a faraway world
column8: lead to the origin of life - and ultimately to us.

column1: Hubble’s incredible discoveries have allowed scientists to piece together much of our cosmic story
column2: but it cannot take us back to the most important moment in history: the Big Bang. For decades
column3: the moment the universe began was the subject of pure speculation
column4: but by combining astronomy and cosmology
column5: scientists have finally found a way to put their theories to the test and study the momentous events that took place during the Big Bang. They can do this because the European Space Agency’s Planck space telescope has seen the afterglow of the Big Bang itself – something we call the cosmic microwave background. The unparalleled detail Planck gave us has helped confirm something remarkable: the Big Bang may not be the beginning. There was a time before the dawn – a place beyond anything we can comprehend. Brian transports us back to the fraction of a second before the Big Bang
column6: when the seeds of our universe were planted.

column1: The story of our universe's origin is an improbable odyssey
column2: one that helps us understand how we came to be here
column3: contemplating this vast cosmic drama.";Science;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 445;445;A Perfect Planet;Series 1: 5. Humans;Humans are changing our planet so rapidly
column5: A Perfect Planet
column6: Series 1: 5. Humans;Humans are changing our planet so rapidly
column7: it’s affecting earth’s life support systems.;Humans are changing our planet so rapidly
column8: it’s affecting earth’s life support systems: our weather
column9: our oceans and the living world.;"Earth is the only living world we know of
column10: but a new force threatens our perfect planet. That force is us. Humans are changing our planet so rapidly
column11: it’s affecting earth’s life support systems: our weather
column12: our oceans and the living world. To understand what is going wrong
column13: we must look to the past.

column1: Earth has been through at least five mass extinction events
column2: most of which have been caused by cataclysmic volcanic eruptions. It’s not the lava or ash that wiped out life
column3: but an invisible gas released by volcanoes: carbon dioxide.

column1: Through compelling animal-led stories and expert interviews
column2: we discover how CO2 is destabilising our planet. We meet rescued orphaned elephants in Kenya
column4: and join ocean patrols off the coast of Gabon fighting to save endangered sharks. In the Amazon
column5: we witness wildlife teams saving animals in the shrinking forests
column6: and in San Diego we enter a cryogenic zoo preserving the DNA of endangered species before they become extinct.

column1: Almost every part of modern life depends on energy created by burning fossil fuels
column2: and this produces CO2 in huge amounts. Humans are now acting like a super-volcano
column3: releasing carbon dioxide at an even greater rate than the prehistoric mega-eruptions that extinguished life in the past. Globally
column4: we now release 100 times more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than all of Earth's volcanoes combined.

column1: The greatest change to be made is in how we create energy
column2: and the planet is brimming with natural power that can help us do just that. It’s these forces of nature - the wind
column4: waves and geothermal energy - that hold the key to our future.";Nature;BBC ONE;False;2021;58;science-and-nature

column5: from the forests of New Guinea more than 50 years ago to the desert of Qatar today.;"Birds of paradise are one of David Attenborough's lifelong passions. He was the first to film many of their beautiful and often bizarre displays
column6: and over his lifetime he has tracked them all over the jungles of New Guinea. In this very personal film
column7: he uncovers the remarkable story of how these 'birds from paradise' have captivated explorers
column8: naturalists
column9: artists
column10: film-makers and even royalty. He explores the myths surrounding their discovery 500 years ago
column11: the latest extraordinary behaviour captured on camera and reveals the scientific truth behind their beauty: the evolution of their spectacular appearance has in fact been driven by sex.

column1: And in a final contemporary twist to this story of obsession and royalty
column2: he travels to the desert of Qatar
column3: to a state-of-the-art facility which houses the largest breeding group of these birds in the world - a sheikh's very own private collection. There he has his closest ever encounter with a greater bird of paradise and its dramatic display
column4: reliving the experience that captivated him in the forests of New Guinea more than 50 years ago.

column1: 449;449;Animals with Cameras;Series 2: Episode 2;State-of-the-art cameras offer a fresh look on some of Australia’s wild animals.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09v6qck.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 2: Episode 2;State-of-the-art cameras offer a fresh look on some of Australia’s wild animals.;Wildlife cameraman Gordon Buchanan leads a team using specially designed on-board cameras to film groundbreaking new behaviour in some of Australia’s most iconic creatures.;"Wildlife cameraman Gordon Buchanan fronts the team helping scientists to investigate the lives of some of Australia’s most iconic animals. Using state-of-the-art cameras to film groundbreaking new behaviour
column6: the programme unveils the fascinating worlds that are often out of reach to regular camera crews.

column1: Care and consideration for the wildlife is a priority as discreet and lightweight on-board devices are deployed to film the animals. Wearing the cameras
column2: these creatures give us a unique perspective
column3: carrying out the detective work that will help scientists to answer vital questions about their lives.

column1: In this episode
column2: the brains behind our tiny cameras
column4: works with biologists and researchers to develop bespoke cameras tough enough for the Australian landscape
column5: withstanding the heat and the height that the animals have to live with. The results take us airborne and under the cover of night.

column1: In New South Wales
column2: Gordon encounters a marsupial facing a complex set of challenges when he meets a population of kangaroos that are being pushed to the very brink by a coastal development boom. How are they surviving on the edge of this urban expansion? Gordon meets the scientists driven to find out more about what the roos are feeding on as they are pushed onto the coastal fringes. As we become immersed in their world
column3: we get a better understanding of kangaroos' social lives and the impact of human encroachment on their diet.

column1: In southern Australia
column3: where one of the team’s toughest challenges yet is to create the lightest of cameras to find out what the lure of the big city is to a colony of newly arrived fruit bats. Their appearance is a bit of a puzzle. Are they a threat to the local commercial fruit crops or have they found other ways to adapt to city life? For the first time ever
column4: the fruit bats take our cameras up above the cityscape
column5: showing us a unique view of their nocturnal worlds while providing information crucial to their future.

column1: In Queensland
column2: we help scientists find out if koalas really deserve their dozy daytime reputation when we join researchers at a reserve to discover some incredible revelations surrounding their night-time manoeuvres. The team’s tech allows us to shadow them after sundown
column3: unveiling their remarkable agility and surprising navigational skills. Specially designed with tree-hugging in mind
column4: koalacams offer an insight which could help koalas as we find out what they need to survive - not just here
column5: but elsewhere in the country.";Nature;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

column1: 450;450;Serengeti;Series 1: 6. Rebirth;It's the end of an extraordinary year for the animals of the Serengeti.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jj0vp.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 6. Rebirth;It's the end of an extraordinary year for the animals of the Serengeti.;It's the end of an extraordinary year for the animals of the Serengeti. In the aftermath of a huge fire
column6: which families made it through alive?;"In this final episode
column7: it’s time to close another chapter in the lives of the animals of the Serengeti
column8: the end of an extraordinary year for them all. But first
column9: all around is a blackened smoking wasteland
column10: the aftermath of the huge fire. Which of the families made it out alive and who is still missing?

column1: Torrential rain brings hope and the land is reborn into a green paradise as water quenches the scorched earth. Mirroring the changes in the landscape
column2: the cycle of death and rebirth comes to the fore as the Serengeti’s elders prepare their young for adulthood and a life on their own.

column1: Lioness Kali is alive
column2: but one of her three cubs is missing. Kike the cheetah returns and must train her grown-up cubs to survive on their own. The short
column3: lush grasslands make the perfect training grounds for her lessons of survival. She teaches them to stalk
column4: chase and trip their prey. A giraffe
column5: grieving over the unexplained death of her calf
column6: interrupts the cubs’ training regime. Leader of the wild dogs Jasari is also showing his pups how to survive on their own
column7: but when he teaches them to fight off hyenas
column8: they too are interrupted by the grieving giraffe.

column1: In the flooded river
column2: elephant matriarch Nalla’s baby struggles in the torrents. Bakari returns when a huge fight with a rival baboon troop threatens his family
column3: and he shows his bravery once more.

column1: Kali has yet more surprises in store which bring hope for her and her pride’s future. Kike has to leave her cubs and hope that they are ready for independence. With the death of an old male elephant
column2: all the families come together and old rivalries end in a remarkable truce.

column1: With a new regime in place among the baboons
column2: the harmony of nature is restored and for now
column3: the future is bright for the families of the Serengeti.

column2: whales and dolphins provide a stunning end to Chris and Meg’s road trip.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09t233h.jpg;BBC

column6: Series 1: 6. Western Isles;Golden eagles
column7: whales and dolphins provide a stunning end to Chris and Meg’s road trip.;Chris Packham and Meg McCubbin’s wildlife-watching road trip draws to a close with golden eagles on Harris
column8: Risso’s dolphins off the Lewis coast and a few surprises for the pair.;"The final leg of Chris and Meg's journey takes them to the Western Isles in the far north of Scotland. Meg spots a minke whale and a pod of dolphins on the ferry before they even reach the isles!

column1: On the Isle of Harris
column2: the pair are delighted to see white-tailed eagles almost as soon as they leave the car park
column3: before spotting several golden eagles up in the hills. Next
column4: they make a stop in Bragar on the Isle of Lewis to marvel at the Whalebone Arch – a garden gate fashioned from the jaw bones of a blue whale which washed up on a nearby beach over 100 years ago.

column1: Later
column2: they head out on a boat from Stornoway Harbour and are treated to a display by a pod of Risso’s dolphins. Often mistaken for orcas due to their sizeable dorsal fins
column3: Risso’s dolphins are larger and harder to spot than their common cousins.

column1: On the last day of the trip
column2: Meg has a surprise for Chris as she takes him to visit Steve Dilworth
column3: an artist living on the Isle of Harris
column4: whose work Chris fell in love with when he visited the island 30 years ago. Steve preserves the bodies of birds found around the island in ornate caskets made from natural materials – revering the wildlife we take for granted.

column1: On the stunning white sands of Luskentyre Beach
column2: Chris and Meg toast their trip with a glass of local gin infused with sugar kelp from the island.";Science & Nature;BBC TWO;False;2021;29;science-and-nature

column1: 458;458;Attenborough's Life in Colour;Series 1: 2. Hiding in Colour;How animals use colour to hide and disappear into the background.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0980bk1.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 2. Hiding in Colour;How animals use colour to hide and disappear into the background.;David Attenborough reveals the extraordinary ways that some animals use colour to hide and disappear into the background. ;"David Attenborough reveals the extraordinary ways that some animals use colour to hide and disappear into the background. New science reveals how the Bengal tiger in central India uses its orange-black stripes to hide from its colour-blind prey. In Kenya’s Masai Mara
column6: the zebra’s black-and-white pattern confuses predators with an extraordinary effect called motion dazzle. And on the island of Cuba
column7: a small snail uses colourful stripes in a surprising way to hide from its enemies.

column1: Other animals use colour to trick and to deceive. On Australia’s Great Barrier Reef
column2: a blue-striped blenny uses colours to mimic other fish and launch a sudden attack. In the grasslands of Zambia
column3: the chick of a pin-tailed whydah mimics the patterns of its nest mates to ensure that it is not detected as an imposter. And specialist cameras reveal how a tiny crab spider uses bright ultraviolet colours to lure in its victims.";Nature;BBC ONE;Contains flashing images.;2021;58;science-and-nature

column5: Series 1: Episode 2;Colin Stafford-Johnson turns his childhood garden into a wildlife haven.;Wildlife cameraman Colin Stafford-Johnson returns home to Ireland on a personal quest to transform his old childhood garden into a haven for native wildlife. ;"Wildlife cameraman Colin Stafford-Johnson returns home on a very personal project - to turn his old childhood garden into a haven for native wildlife. After 30 years of filming the world’s most iconic creatures
column6: Colin heads back to Ireland
column7: to a garden he spent his childhood summers spraying and mowing into a perfect lawn. But now he wants to transform his old playground into a sanctuary for the native plants and animals now struggling to survive on these islands
column8: and inspire viewers to do the same.

column1: This episode takes us through Colin's second year as he begins to reap the rewards of his labours. Working through the winter
column2: Colin reflects on his journey so far and plans the busy spring and summer months ahead. With most of the heavy lifting done
column3: Colin will now use a gentle hand to maintain the garden as he tries to lure back as many wild creatures as possible. Early on
column4: he is treated to a great surprise as a creature he has not spotted here for over 40 years makes a remarkable return - the elusive red squirrel. He takes this as a good omen for the year ahead – he must be doing something right!

column1: As we move through the seasons
column3: some more welcome than others. A small herd of deer begin to make nightly visits to feast on young trees
column4: and Colin reluctantly serves them an eviction notice. Early spring sees temperatures rising and the ponds bursting with life. Clouds of insects take to the wing and
column5: after some nocturnal visitors
column6: frog spawn appears as if by magic. The native meadow comes into its own
column7: attracting over a dozen different kind of butterflies and clouds of aerial predators.

column1: Colin meets Professor Dave Goulson at his own wild patch in East Sussex to chat about his work on bumblebees and his crazy dream for the British countryside. He visits a tiny wild corner of central London that 70 years ago was just rubble from buildings bombed in the Blitz
column2: and is now home to over 450 native species of plants and animals. Wild spaces like this are rare anywhere
column3: let alone in central London. As Colin’s second year draws to a close
column4: he reflects on the urgent need for everyone to make space for nature. With our natural world being pushed closer and closer to the brink
column5: every single patch counts
column6: big or small.";Nature;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;science-and-nature

Events keep happening that seem inexplicable and out of control. Donald Trump
column5: Brexit
column6: the War in Syria
column7: the endless migrant crisis
column8: random bomb attacks. And those who are supposed to be in power are paralysed - they have no idea what to do.

column1: This film is the epic story of how we got to this strange place. It explains not only why these chaotic events are happening - but also why we
It shows that what has happened is that all of us in the West - not just the politicians and the journalists and the experts
column2: but we ourselves - have retreated into a simplified
column3: and often completely fake version of the world. But because it is all around us we accept it as normal.

column1: But there is another world outside. Forces that politicians tried to forget and bury forty years ago - that then festered and mutated - but which are now turning on us with a vengeful fury. column5: Bitter Lake;Adam Curtis’s epic story of how Britain
column6: America and Russia got lost in Afghanistan.;Adam Curtis’s epic film explains how everyone - Britain
column7: America and Russia - got lost in Afghanistan. How a toxic blend of arrogance and ignorance led to the present disaster.;"Politicians used to have the confidence to tell us stories that made sense of the chaos of world events. But now there are no big stories and politicians react randomly to every new crisis - leaving us bewildered and disorientated.

column1: Bitter Lake is an adventurous and epic film by Adam Curtis that explains why the big stories that politicians tell us have become so simplified that we can’t really see the world any longer.
The narrative goes all over the world
column4: Russia and Saudi Arabia - but the country at the heart of it is Afghanistan. Because Afghanistan is the place that has confronted our politicians with the terrible truth - that they cannot understand what is going on any longer.

column1: The film reveals the forces that over the past thirty years rose up and undermined the confidence of politics to understand the world. And it shows the strange
column2: dark role that Saudi Arabia has played in this.

column1: But Bitter Lake is also experimental. Curtis has taken the unedited rushes of everything that the BBC has ever shot in Afghanistan - and used them in new and radical ways.
He has tried to build a different and more emotional way of depicting what really happened in Afghanistan. A counterpoint to the thin
column2: narrow and increasingly destructive stories told by those in power today.";Film;BBC WEBONLY;Contains strong language and disturbing scenes.;2015;137;films

column2: Michael Parkinson walked down those famous stairs for the first time and introduced the first ever Parkinson show. The guests were celebrity snapper Ray Bellasario and comedy actor Terry-Thomas. Seen as a temporary ten-week filler programme
column3: it went on to record over 650 episodes featuring interviews with over 2
column4: 000 guests and was voted by the BFI one of the top ten UK television programmes of all time.

column1: This programme tells the full story of the humble beginnings of the show and how it rose to become an award-winning Saturday night staple
column2: a source of water-cooler moments before that phrase had even been thought of. It tells the story of how Michael left Fleet Street and stumbled into television at Granada
column3: where he made his first attempt at celebrity interviewing in an encounter with Mick Jagger. Poached by the BBC
column4: he then found himself hosting the show that would make his name
column5: and he recounts how the success of the show was secured by convincing Orson Welles to appear
column6: as well as how the first series was wiped
column7: losing interviews with John Lennon and Yoko Ono amongst others.

column1: It was a time when the likes of Jimmy Cagney
column3: Lauren Bacall and Ingrid Bergman could be interviewed in depth for the first time
column4: though the show developed into something more than just a celebrity gabfest. Michael reveals some tricks of the interview trade and remembers some of his favourite moments
column5: including his encounters with Muhammad Ali and Billy Connolly
column6: as well as some less successful meetings with Meg Ryan and Helen Mirren. He also explains his decision to leave the interview game in 2008.";Entertainment;BBC ONE;Contains adult themes.;2021;58;entertainment

column5: Series 2: 5. Fulham/Posh Pastels;Fulham: Two polar opposite housemates get a pastel dreamy makeover.;"Robin and Jasmin are getting the dream makeover
column6: as Whinnie and Tyler help them to find some common ground and turn their bland living room

column1: into a posh pastel palace.";"Flat Out Fabulous is a unique makeover show for Generation Rent full of tips and inspiration for renters. You don’t have to own your own home for our stylish yet thrifty interior designer to come knocking. Whinnie Williams is a design queen who dares to be different
column2: and she believes that if housemates clubbed together and rolled their sleeves up
column3: for just the cost of a big night out
column4: you can boujee up your living room and transform it into a sick pad. Whinnie and her co-host Tyler West are passionate about showing that home renovations don’t have to cost a fortune – you can have that million pound look for less. Scouring vintage shops
column5: online auctions and with loads of smart
column6: money saving upcycling ideas and decorating tips
column7: she’s about to share how anyone can do it.

column1: Whinnie and Tyler are in Fulham in London meeting Robin and Jasmin
column2: two housemates that are polar opposites when it comes to taste but love living together. Robin works for a leather company
column3: likes grey tones and the finer things in life
column4: whilst Welsh art teacher Jasmin loves lots of splashes of colour and a vintage bargain. Their living room is a great space but it’s grey and doesn’t reflect either of their creative personalities or how they want to save money renting. They’re hoping Whinnie and Tyler can help make the space their own. Much to his displeasure
column5: Whinnie’s tasked Robin and Tyler with making expanding foam photo frames whilst she and Jasmin design sofa cushions. Robin’s not certain about the powder pink chairs he and Whinnie paint and the lilac walls of the living room. Whinnie’s promising to surprise them with a wavy console table in front of a hand painted patterned wall and a stone effect top shelving unit come desk. With two conflicting housemates
column6: a big room and a tight budget

column1: 689;689;Caitlyn Jenner: Honesty;None;Caitlyn Jenner on why honesty is the key to peace of mind.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07t6fwn.jpg;BBC
column4: Caitlyn Jenner: Honesty;Caitlyn Jenner on why honesty is the key to peace of mind.;The world's most famous transgender woman
column5: Caitlyn Jenner
column6: explains why honesty is the key to peace of mind.;"The world's most famous transgender woman
column7: Caitlyn Jenner
column8: explains why honesty is the key to peace of mind. In 1976
column9: Caitlyn – then known as Bruce – won Decathlon gold at the Montreal Olympics. She was called 'the world's greatest athlete'. Fame and adulation followed
column10: but gender dysphoria – where there's a mismatch between someone's biological sex and their gender identity – was always bubbling away under the surface. In 2015
column11: Caitlyn finally came out as a transgender woman.

column1: In this programme
column2: Simon Mundie and Caitlyn discuss some of the lessons she has learnt during her incredible life. They talk about the importance of honesty and being true to yourself and your family around you
column3: and about not judging a book by its cover
column4: as someone who apparently has it all may well be suffering inside. It’s all about the challenges you overcome
column5: not the heights you attain. You can hear the full
column6: unedited version of this interview on BBC Sounds – just search for the Radio 4 podcast Don't Tell Me the Score.";Sport;BBC WEBONLY;False;2019;35;entertainment

column6: fetch the answer! The teams must grab objects from around the house in order to answer Frankie and Wayne’s questions.

column1: Jackie interrupts a live Del Amitri gig to surprise one of our nominees who was a lifeline to many during lockdown
column2: and she heads to Aberdeen to meet two young football fans who fundraised tirelessly for the MS Society. She visits Peebles to honour the local postie
column3: who happens to be a volunteer first responder who saved lives during lockdown
column4: and joins a group of young people in Kilmarnock who want to pay tribute to a man who changed their lives. In Pollokshields
column5: she meets a powerhouse volunteer who brought an incredibly diverse community together
column6: and she pays tribute to a couple who used their own tragedy to bring music into the lives of terminally ill children.
