column1: We're in Middlesbrough
column2: and our home squad of Becca
column3: Tracey and Kaitlin are three Boro girls who like to work hard and play hard. The 20-year-olds
column5: are at Teesside Uni studying law. 24-year-old Kaitlin is studying accountancy at university whilst working for an optician. All three are keen to meet guys from further afield to find out if they can find something they haven’t yet found with the guys closer to home.

column1: Cue the away squad – 20-year-olds Jude and Jacob and 19-year-old Ash. These firm friends met at the University of Lancaster
column2: where they are all studying. Jude and Ash have enjoyed relationships which have largely ended amicably but are keen to meet different types of people than those they’re surrounded by in Lancaster. But another motivation for the lads is to finally get 20-year-old Jacob on his first ever date!

column1: Since scaling the heights of Hollywood

column12: leaving the judges to choose their favourite from a sweet butternut squash pie and two Thai-inspired curries. Once the Rustle Up winner is chosen

column14: one that involves the cooks making choux pastry
column15: caramel and a dessert centrepiece fitting for the most glamorous of celebrations. Whoever survives this challenge will return for Mary Berry's Ultimate challenge. On day two of the final

column18: one meat
column19: one plant-based and one fish. A host of familiar faces return to support the cooks

column2: he usually ends up living off takeaways. But that doesn’t mean his tastebuds have to be disappointed – he likes his fast food to be fancy!

column1: To help him find the best fast food when he’s on the road
column2: Josh enlists the help of two local celebrities who think their favourite takeaway is unbeatable
column3: and pits them against each other in a Fast Food Face-Off.

column1: Josh is in Northern Ireland and local celebrities Kristian Nairn and Gemma Bradley are representing their go-to takeaway.

column1: However
column2: the couple are relying on store cards and online credit to pay for clothes and household items
column3: as while larger one-off payments are unaffordable
column4: smaller monthly ones seem more manageable. Throw in monthly subscription boxes and regular toy-buying for their two daughters
column5: and these two are spending more than they realise. Melanie and Jo bring Steve and Sarah face to face with the extent of their spending to make them see just where their money is going.

column1: 778;778;The World's Most Extraordinary Homes;Series 2: 8. Israel;Piers and Caroline are in Israel
column2: where modern houses are inspired by rich traditions.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p06bfnbq.jpg;BBC
column5: The Worlds Most Extraordinary Homes
column6: Series 2: 8. Israel;Piers and Caroline are in Israel
column7: where modern houses are inspired by rich traditions.;Piers Taylor and Caroline Quentin are in Israel
column8: where exciting modern houses are inspired by rich cultural and historical traditions.;"Piers Taylor and Caroline Quentin are in Israel
column9: where exciting modern houses are inspired by rich cultural and historical traditions. J-House is in Herzliya
column10: a millionaire's playground by the Med. It is a palatial white home tucked away in a suburban plot and reached by a bridge over lush gardens. Piers and Caroline discover luxurious
column11: warm and vibrant interiors that contrast with the modernist facade. Glass walls open up to connect the entire living area with the gardens and pool.

column1: Shutter House sits on a hillside overlooking the Sea of Galilee. It is an elegant
column3: and its subtle colours and materials match the soil and stone of the olive and carob groves. To combat the 40-degree heat
column4: the architects used a traditional system of balconies
column5: breezeways and beautiful wooden screens
column6: which cast light and shadows throughout this peaceful house. Caroline says being here is 'a religious experience.'

column1: Piers and Caroline's next destination is the historic city of Jerusalem. Barud House is a love poem to Jerusalem stone - named after the warning cry given by quarry workers before detonating explosives. Its facade is made from 50
column3: arranged into a symmetrical pattern that casts shadows across the house all day. Inside Piers and Caroline discover more stone - the rough rock face behind the house has been left exposed and is boldly revealed behind a glass wall. Gleaming white interiors
column5: games room and big city views enhance the glamour of this striking house.

column1: The final stop is the Arab village of Musmus and the House of Three Gardens. Tel Aviv architect Ron Fleisher has designed a house that combines traditional Islamic architecture with modernism. He has linked existing buildings with a stunning double-height traditional liwan
column3: and a gleaming white staircase. Ron also designed a light
column4: spacious drawing room and created three beautiful themed gardens to honour the family's farming history.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2018;59;lifestyle

column6: focusing on 29-year-old Liane as she undergoes treatment.;"Documentary exploring body dysmorphic disorder
column7: a condition which causes people to believe they are extremely ugly. The film follows 29-year-old Liane and her boyfriend Mitch over a year as Liane starts therapy to try and conquer this crippling condition. Each week Liane meets Professor David Veale
column8: one of the world's leading experts on BDD
column9: who attempts to undo some of her deeply entrenched habits
column10: often leading to uncomfortable and revealing realisations.

column1: 780;780;Rhod Gilbert: Stand Up to Shyness;None;Rhod Gilbert confronts his painful shyness
column2: looking at what can be done about it.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p05v1kjs.jpg;BBC
column5: Rhod Gilbert: Stand Up to Shyness;Rhod Gilbert confronts his painful shyness
column6: looking at what can be done about it.;Stand-up comedian Rhod Gilbert presents a documentary in which he confronts his painful shyness
column7: looking at why he suffers from it and what can be done.;"Stand-up comedian Rhod Gilbert is painfully shy. He might hide it well
column8: but he can't even go into a cafe to buy a coffee. No joke. In fact
column9: his social anxiety has had a massive effect on his life. In this documentary
column10: Rhod's going to try find out why and what can be done. Talking to fellow shy comedian Greg Davies
column11: other shy sufferers and scientists
column12: Rhod comes up with a radical solution for how we can all stand up to shyness.

column1: Rhod can stand up in front of 20
column2: 000 people and make them laugh for two hours solid. But he has always found it virtually impossible to talk to people one to one. From childhood
column3: it has been a life-limiting condition. And in this Rhod is certainly not alone. It is estimated that nearly half the population in the UK have some manifestation of shyness and social anxiety. For many it is a minor irritation
column4: but for some it is a condition that can virtually destroy a life.";Documentary;BBC ONE WALES;Contains some strong language.;2018;59;lifestyle

column6: cutting ties with the UK. They also explore their roots as they receive DNA test results.;"Andi and Miquita travel to Barbados as this most British of Caribbean islands prepares to become a republic
column7: cutting ties with the UK.

column1: The duo meet anti-colonial calypso star the Mighty Gabby and his son for a moving musical performance and discuss why forging a new identity is so important for Barbados. Further immersing themselves in Bajan culture
column2: Andi and Miquita go swimming with horses and enjoy local food and breakfast rum with soca stars Peter Ram and Alison Hinds.

column1: As progressive prime minister Mia Mottley is preparing to modernise the constitution
column3: Andi and Miqutia meet members of the LGBTQ+ community to talk about the island's first pride marches. They also have an unsettling meeting with the descendants of slave owners at a plantation house
column4: where they have tea with resident Brits and tourists who remain a powerful force on the island and get their perspectives on republicanism and the modernisation of Barbados.

column1: Finally
column2: they engage in a moving exploration of their African roots when they receive their DNA results and visit Ngozi Farm
column3: where African culture and its connection to the Caribbean is celebrated.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2022;60;lifestyle

column7: Powys.;"Armed with his 1930s Bradshaw’s Guide
column8: Michael travels from Aberystwyth into the Cambrian Mountains at Devil’s Bridge and finishes in Newtown
column9: Powys.

column1: In the elegant coastal town of Aberystwyth
column2: Michael visits the National Library of Wales
column3: set high on a hill with views over Cardigan Bay. Michael hears how the idea of a repository for works in the Welsh language and an institution in which to preserve Welsh culture took shape and culminated
column5: in this prestigious institution. Michael is fascinated to see William Morgan’s Welsh translation of the Bible
column6: published in 1588.

column1: An unforgettable excursion on the Vale of Rheidol Railway takes Michael on a steep climb to Devil’s Bridge
column2: past spectacular waterfalls and wooded hillsides.

column1: Close by
column2: in the Bwlch Nant yr Arian Forest
column4: where magnificent birds of prey come to feed. At the time of his Bradshaw’s Guide
column5: the red kite was close to extinction. But Wales’s favourite bird now thrives
column6: and in order to keep it that way
column7: astonishing numbers are fed here daily. Michael dares to lend a hand.

column1: High above Aberystwyth
column4: amazing discoveries were made. At Pen Dinas
column5: a young professor from Aberystwyth University dug deep below Roman remains and found an iron age settlement. Michael learns how archaeological methods have changed today.

column1: Michael’s 250-mile tour of north Wales draws to a close in style at the birthplace of the nation’s first classical music festival
column3: near Newtown. Michael is intrigued to discover that its founders
column5: used the fortune they inherited from their grandfather
column6: a noted Welsh railway builder
column7: to establish the country estate as a centre for art and music from 1933. In the glorious music room
column8: a Welsh harpist helps to evoke the spirit of festivals past and present.";History;BBC TWO;False;2021;29;lifestyle

column1: 790;790;Clive James;6. Postcard from London;Clive James recalls his first experiences of London life in the early 1960s.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p01hhbyh.jpg;BBC
column5: 6. Postcard from London;Clive James recalls his first experiences of London life in the early 1960s.;First transmitted in 1991
column6: Clive James recalls his experiences in 1960s London and trades anecdotes with Victoria Wood
column7: Terence Donovan
column8: Peter Cook and Michael Caine along the way.;"First transmitted in 1991
column9: Clive James recalls his experiences of London life in the early 1960s. In between his visits to some of London’s tourist sites
column10: such as the National Gallery - ""still the best free show in town"" - James trades anecdotes with some of his famous friends.

column1: Victoria Wood explains how she once shared a bed with him without him knowing. Terence Donovan fondly recalls the sense of freedom in the sixties and the effect that miniskirts had on his driving. Peter Cook evokes a cutting edge side of the capital as he talks about The Establishment

Recent scientific reports from around the world have revealed that the link between football and dementia could be a result of brain damage caused by heading the ball.

column1: Shearer remains the Premier League's all-time top scorer
column2: with 46 of those goals coming from headers. With recent reports of a worrying number of the England 1966 team suffering from dementia
column3: the former Newcastle forward has a vested interest in football's potential links with brain injury.

column3: then after school she practices those verses.

column1: 797;797;Grand Tours of Scotland's Rivers;Series 1: 6. Salt of the Earth;The River Ayr is the destination for this Grand Tour
column5: Grand Tours of Scotlands Rivers
column6: Series 1: 6. Salt of the Earth;The River Ayr is the destination for this Grand Tour
column7: which ends on the Clyde coast.;Paul heads to the River Ayr for this Grand Tour. Starting on Hareshaw Hill
column8: he uncovers a legacy of mineral wealth and religious conflict before reaching the Clyde coast.;"Paul follows the River Ayr as it flows from Loch Glenbuck towards the sea and the Clyde coast. The old mining village of Glenbuck was demolished long ago
column9: but its memory is kept alive by former resident Barbara Alexander whose uncle
column10: the famous Liverpool football manager Bill Shankly
column11: was a Glenbuck man. From Glenbuck
column12: Paul follows the river through a landscape pockmarked by the scars of old mineral extraction and industry.

column1: At Muirkirk he discovers how a local man illuminated the cities of the world with gas lighting
column2: and how a certain Mr McAdam invented tarmac for the roads of the world. The course of the river Ayr flows through land rich in covenanting history when religious conflict cost many lives. In the Ayr gorge
column3: Paul encounters the extraordinary tale of the radical preacher Alexander Peden
column4: whose life on the run forced him to hide in caves while still preaching hellfire sermons to the people.

column1: Finally reaching the coast
column2: Paul visits the only working salt evaporation tower in the world. Here
column4: he learns how sea water is evaporated by wind and sun to make brine
column5: from which sea salt is made.

798;798;Easy Ways to Live Well;Series 1: Episode 3;Surprising solutions for everything from body confidence to sedentary behaviour.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p080l217.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Easy Ways to Live Well, Series 1: Episode 3;Surprising solutions for everything from body confidence to sedentary behaviour.;Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall and Steph McGovern help the Humberside Police to combat their sedentary behaviour, and they also meet a family struggling with body confidence and test the power of CBD.;Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall and Steph McGovern tackle something that has been described as a 'global epidemic' and 'as dangerous as smoking' - sedentary behaviour. Over 15 million of us spend half our days at a desk
column2: in our cars or on the sofa. It might seem harmless
column3: but over six hours of prolonged sitting increases the risk of obesity
column5: type 2 diabetes and certain types of cancer.

column1: This week’s 'laboratory' is the Humberside Police. Hugh and Steph challenge both the 999 control room and managerial staff to bring more movement into their daily routines
column2: which up until now consist of long shifts sat at their desks.

column1: But if they are cajoling others to live well
column2: then Hugh and Steph feel it’s only fair that they walk the walk themselves. With Steph in a very demanding job
column3: she readily admits she struggles to turn off. Dr Zoe prescribes weekly sessions of forest bathing
column4: which recent scientific studies have proved can cut cortisol levels by up to 15 per cent.

column1: While Hugh is an enthusiastic jogger
column2: like many over the age of 45 he has noticed he is losing his muscle strength. Dr Zoe recommends he tries some simple training exercises to help build up his below-average muscles.

column1: In our image-obsessed world
column2: Steph then meets one family struggling with body image. Mum Sunita may have lost several stone in weight recently
column3: but it hasn’t stopped her from feeling intensely self-conscious
column4: and now she is worried that her daughter Simran might follow in her footsteps. Steph suggests they try life drawing – a recent scientific study found that painting people in the nude can increase self-confidence by 25 per cent. Meanwhile
column5: Hugh wants to test one of the most popular health crazes to hit the market – CBD – on three volunteers suffering from insomnia.

column1: After trialling easy ways to live well
column2: Hugh and Steph find out which ones not only work but feel possible to incorporate into our everyday routines.";Lifestyle;BBC ONE;False;2020;58;lifestyle;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p080l217.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p080l217.jpg;hugh fearnleywhittingstall steph mcgovern tackle something described global epidemic dangerous smoking sedentary behaviour 15 million u spend half day desk car sofa might seem harmless six hour prolonged sitting increase risk obesity heart disease type 2 diabetes certain type cancer week ’ laboratory humberside police hugh steph challenge 999 control room managerial staff bring movement daily routine consist long shift sat desk cajoling others live well hugh steph feel ’ fair walk walk steph demanding job readily admits struggle turn dr zoe prescribes weekly session forest bathing recent scientific study proved cut cortisol level 15 per cent hugh enthusiastic jogger like many age 45 noticed losing muscle strength dr zoe recommends try simple training exercise help build belowaverage muscle imageobsessed world steph meet one family struggling body image mum sunita may lost several stone weight recently ’ stopped feeling intensely selfconscious worried daughter simran might follow footstep steph suggests try life drawing – recent scientific study found painting people nude increase selfconfidence 25 per cent meanwhile hugh want test one popular health craze hit market – cbd – three volunteer suffering insomnia trialling easy way live well hugh steph find one work feel possible incorporate everyday routine;1

column5: 4. The Nineties and Noughties;A look at the era that saw the biggest lifestyle changes of all - the 1990s and 2000s.;Reinvention was the key in the decades which saw the biggest lifestyle changes of all to the home
column6: and the rise of makeover television - the 1990s and 2000s.;"Reinvention is the key as the series concludes with the era that saw the biggest lifestyle changes of all to the home - the 1990s and 2000s. BBC Two was making over homes by chucking out the chintz
column7: turning gardens into outside rooms and kitchens into pukka Jamie Oliver zones. But it didn't stop there. Soon there was a craze for decluttering and minimal living linked to the crazed flipping of homes in the mortgage-mad Noughties. Inevitably
column8: a slew of programmes about buying and selling property
column9: homes in the country and living abroad followed.

column1: The stars of this new era of makeover television
column4: are all on hand to try and explain how this bewilderingly fast reinvention of the very idea of home happened - and why it couldn't last.

Edinburgh Zoo prepares to welcome back giraffes after a 17-year absence.;"It’s 17 years since Edinburgh Zoo said farewell to their last giraffes. But that’s all about to change as staff prepare to welcome five new young males to their brand new state-of-the-art home. And as their arrival fast approaches head keeper Jonny is keen to make sure no detail is overlooked.

column1: Vets are called in to investigate a worrying growth in the jaw of a skink called Cullen. And keeper Helen is keeping an eye on Nala
column2: a giant anteater whose large appetite but rapid weight-loss is cause for concern.

column1: Polar bear Walker on the other hand has been gaining too much weight. Keepers at Highland Wildlife Park have decided to put him on a diet and training to get him on the scales is essential.
There are also training sessions in place for Bactrian camels Karnali and Caramel as vet Ellie attempts to get to know the pair. And keeper Becky gets stuck into a spring clean of their enclosure.
Narrated by Gail Porter.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;58;lifestyle

column1: 803;803;Barbershop for Bald Men;None;A visit to the Barbershop for Bald Men sees three young men totally transformed.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09bybcv.jpg;BBC
column4: Barbershop for Bald Men;A visit to the Barbershop for Bald Men sees three young men totally transformed.;A visit to the Barbershop for Bald Men sees three young men share their stories about premature hair loss and undergo astonishing transformations.;"Male pattern baldness affects around half of all men by the age of 50
column5: typically starting in their late twenties to early thirties. It can be a hugely traumatic life event because most men refuse to talk about it. The urge to ‘man up’ and the fear of being seen as vain or vulnerable means a lot of guys simply suffer in silence.

column1: But it doesn’t have to be this way. Now help is at hand in the Barbershop for Bald Men. We meet Bryan
column2: Matty and Jason. Bryan started losing his hair in his late twenties and believes it has robbed him of the confidence to start dating. Matty started losing his when he was just 18 and went on to have a failed hair transplant a few years later. Jason
column3: who also happens to a barber
column4: despairs at spending his days surrounded by mirrors
column5: working on the very thing he wants most. They share their stories about their hair loss before undergoing an astonishing transformation. Keris Weir
column6: hair stylist to the stars
column7: fits each of them with cutting-edge hair replacement systems – and the haircut they’ve been longing for.

column1: Will they love their brand new hair or decide to finally accept that bald is beautiful?

806;806;Michael Palin’s Himalaya: Journey of a Lifetime;None;Michael Palin recalls his fifth great journey, exploring across and around the Himalaya.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p090hhgl.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Michael Palin’s Himalaya: Journey of a Lifetime;Michael Palin recalls his fifth great journey, exploring across and around the Himalaya.;Michael Palin revisits his fifth travel series – a journey to explore the Himalaya. Featuring fans including Levison Wood and Ade Adepitan as they reflect on his achievement.;This special episode sees Michael revisit his fifth travel series – Himalaya.
For Michael
column2: this epic journey across the world’s highest mountain range is the fulfilment of boyhood dreams inspired by the 1953 ascent of Everest by Hillary and Tensing. Beginning in the famous Khyber Pass
column3: he travels through Pakistan and India and ascends into Nepal and Tibet to reach Everest base camp itself
column4: before venturing into the mountain kingdom of Bhutan.

column1: But Michael’s journey isn’t all about scaling peaks – it’s also about finding out what life is like for the people who live in some of the harshest environments on Earth. He is curious to see countries that were cut off by the mountains for centuries and that have developed their own distinct cultures and ways of survival
column2: to discover the different ways that religion influences society here
column3: and to meet the hardy inhabitants of the mountains.

column1: Along the way
column2: Michael sees Pakistan’s historically volatile North West Frontier region and narrowly avoids a bull during a bull-racing festival. Crossing the border into India
column3: he visits the Sikh city of Amritsar and the Golden Temple
column4: where he learns about Sikhism and eats with the thousands of pilgrims who come there. And in Dharamshala
column5: he learns about Buddhism and meets the Dalai Lama – who turns out to be a Palin fan.

column1: Moving ever upwards into the mountains
column3: and at one point thinks he might have to give up. But he recovers and is rewarded with stunning views of the Annapurna range. Eventually
column5: where he reflects on the achievement of walking in the footsteps not only of Hillary but of the earlier British explorers Mallory and Irvine
column6: who were childhood heroes of his.

column1: Being curious to find out how people live up at high altitude
column2: he spends time with a Nepalese yak-herder and his family
column3: making a real connection despite not speaking their language. In Nagaland
column4: he has a chat with an elderly headhunter
column5: who turns out to be much friendlier than he looks. Finally
column6: Michael journeys through the isolated and magical nation of Bhutan
column7: before descending to sea-level in Bangladesh.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2020;89;lifestyle

column4: but Elsa remained with the Adamsons. Joy's quest to train Elsa to survive in the wild and Elsa's subsequent independence became the basis for the book and film Born Free.

column1: Jin and husband Joe have been struggling to conceive for 11 years. After three rounds of IVF

column4: and she is terrified that something will go wrong. In a state of high anxiety

column8: My Brother and Our Balls is an intimate and personal documentary exploring male fertility with Love Island star Chris Hughes and his brother Ben. When Chris
column9: who had suffered from testicular health scares in the past
column10: appeared on live television to have a testicular examination
column11: it made a huge impact. Chris’s aim was to raise awareness of testicular cancer and encourage men to check themselves. What he didn’t expect was the effect it would have closer to home.

column1: As a consequence of that appearance
column2: and inspired by his brother for having 'had the balls' to do it
column3: Chris’s older brother Ben checked himself for the first time
column4: found a lump and was diagnosed with testicular cancer. Prior to an operation to have his testicle removed
column5: Ben went to freeze his sperm for potential use after the operation. It was during this process that he discovered his sample didn’t contain any sperm at all.

column1: With both boys now concerned about their fertility
column2: they embark on a journey to find out where they stand and what the future holds for them. Aside from their own medical stories
column3: where Chris discovers how his fertility has changed since he was last tested six years earlier and Ben learns about his fertility prospects
column4: the brothers meet a variety of people to explore the wider issues. Chris and Ben chat with their mates down the pub about how little men know about the causes of male infertility. They meet with one of the UK’s leading experts for a step-by-step guide to sperm
column5: learn how infertility affects masculinity from a GB Olympic rower
column6: and consider how their fertility struggles could impact on their family
column7: and their girlfriends
column8: in the long term.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2020;57;lifestyle

Alternative Cancer Cures;Layla Wright investigates the death of Sean Walsh who declined hospital cancer treatment.;Journalist Layla Wright finds out why Sean Walsh turned down conventional cancer treatment and investigates the alternative therapies he turned to.;"Sean Walsh was 20 when he found out his cancer was back. He’d been in remission for less than two years and was determined that this time round
column5: he would not have conventional treatment. He turned down chemotherapy in the hope that he could cure his Hodgkin’s Lymphoma through an alternative approach
column6: including a vegan diet
column7: cannabis oil and coffee enemas. Throughout his treatment he used controversial thermography scans to monitor his progress
column8: and was convinced he was getting better.

column1: Journalist Layla Wright followed Sean’s journey on social media as he attempted to heal himself
column3: it seemed to be working. He raised thousands of pounds to fund his treatment
column4: and beat the doctor’s prognosis. But in January 2019 Sean died
column5: and his family believe alternative treatments cost him his life.

column1: Through the testimony of those closest to him
column3: Layla explores why Sean– and many others– took this approach. She meets the family of Linda Halliday who also relied on thermography scans for reassurance that alternative treatments were working
column4: and investigates the clinic that provided them.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2020;29;lifestyle

column4: Freddie Flintoff: Living with Bulimia;Freddie Flintoff finally faces up to the eating disorder he has kept secret for 20 years.;On an unflinching journey to tackle his secret eating disorder of 20 years
column5: Freddie Flintoff meets sufferers and specialists to challenge the stigma around the condition in men.;"In this powerful and unflinching documentary
column6: Andrew ‘Freddie’ Flintoff goes on an acutely personal journey into the eating disorder he has kept secret for over 20 years – bulimia.

column1: Freddie reveals how bulimia has played a part in the course of his life. He discusses his experience in visceral detail and meets specialists and young men with eating disorders across the UK. Together they challenge
column3: some of the stereotypes that men and boys in their position face – that is
column4: suffering with a serious mental health condition that is perceived to be something ‘only girls get’ – and finally give a public voice to a much-misunderstood illness.

column1: Experts estimate that over 1.5 million people in the UK have an eating disorder like bulimia
column2: of which 25 per cent are male. And yet eating disorders are still considered to be illnesses that only teenage girls suffer with. As a result
column3: boys and men with eating disorders most often live in silence with the double stigma of having a mental health condition that is not recognised in their gender.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Freddie must ask himself whether he needs professional treatment to tackle his eating disorder once and for all.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2020;59;lifestyle

column4: Colombia with Simon Reeve;Adventurer and journalist Simon Reeve explores Colombia at a pivotal point in its history.;Simon Reeve explores Colombia at a pivotal point in its history. For 50 years
column5: Colombia has been in the grip of a brutal civil war
column6: but in late 2016 a peace deal was signed.;"Adventurer and journalist Simon Reeve heads to one of the most spectacular countries in the world - Colombia. For 50 years
column7: Colombia has been in the grip of a brutal civil war that has killed more than 200
column8: 000 people and displaced seven million. But in late 2016
column9: a peace deal was signed promising to end the conflict and finally bring peace to the country.

column1: In this hour-long documentary for the award-winning This World strand
column2: Simon explores Colombia at a pivotal point in its history. He travels into the jungle and comes face to face with the guerrilla army Farc
column3: which is now promising to lay down arms. In the Pacific coast city of Buenaventura
column4: Simon finds out more about the fearsome right-wing paramilitary gangs who now dominate the cocaine trade. As the Farc abandon the countryside
column5: there is a fear that these groups will only grow in power. Travelling in the countryside
column6: Simon meets the coca farmers who are demanding government support to stop growing coca and stop the flow of money to criminal gangs. With land ownership
column7: poverty and drugs at the heart of Colombia's problems
column8: it is in the countryside that the country's precarious future will be decided.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2017;59;lifestyle

column1: 837;837;Ambulance;Series 8: Episode 6;It’s an unusual Easter bank holiday weekend for the staff of North West Ambulance Service.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09wr1rn.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 8: Episode 6;It’s an unusual Easter bank holiday weekend for the staff of North West Ambulance Service.;As society opens up
column6: the Easter bank holiday has consequences for North West Ambulance Service. A call for a patient stuck in a forest in Cumbria takes priority.;"As crews book on across Lancashire and Cumbria for the sunny Easter bank holiday weekend
column7: an urgent call from the police for backup to help a patient who is walking into the sea on Blackpool beach takes priority. Crewmates Holly and Craig are immediately dispatched
column8: but when they arrive on the scene
column9: he has disappeared. As they begin their search
column10: a fresh 999 call is answered for a patient who has been assaulted by their partner. It doesn’t take long for the team in control to piece together that the call is related to the patient
column11: who has now been found on Blackpool beach.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: a new 999 call is received from a carer who has found a resident on the floor
column3: having been there all night. Crewmates Hannah and Richard are immediately dispatched
column4: and on arrival they are saddened to discover the reasons why the patient didn’t call for help.

column1: Three hours into the shift and already 172 patients are currently being treated across the North West. There are a further 28 patients waiting for an ambulance to arrive but a call for an elderly patient who frequently dials 999 which takes priority
column2: there are fears that this time it isn’t a false alarm and the patient has actually taken an overdose. Crewmates
column3: Holly and Craig arrive on scene to find that the patient does need to be taken to hospital for further assessment. However
column4: when they arrive at the hospital
column5: besides being offered treatment the patient is also served with an ASBO to try to stop her misusing NHS & council services by frequent calling.

column1: As midday approaches
column2: the streets of Blackpool are coming alive with tourists - a sight which hasn’t been seen for over a year. But it isn’t just in the towns that people are going out

column1: 999 call for a patient who has come off their bike in the middle of the Cumbrian woodland takes priority. With fears that the patient has suffered multiple injuries
column3: Vinny is sent to manage the patient care on scene. He faces over an hour long journey to the patient which will see him snake through the Cumbrian fells with a trip on the Lake Windermere ferry in order to reach him. When he arrives it is quickly determined that his condition is serious enough that he will needs the assistance of the mountain rescue team and the air ambulance. Whilst Vinny waits for additional support
column4: in Kendal ambulance crew Matt & Wendy are sent to the aid of another cyclist who has also fallen from their bike.

column1: As the weekend begins to wind to an end
column2: a new shift begins for Holly and Craig
column3: who are dispatched to a familiar patient. It is a woman who frequently rings 999 and who has again claimed to have taken an overdose. It quickly becomes apparent why she has become one the most frequent callers across the whole of the region and just how difficult it is to help her.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Hannah and Richard are sent to a patient who has been suffering from seizures. When they decide to take the patient to hospital
column3: they must find someone to look after the patient's dog
column5: the patient reveals that she has been struggling to come to terms with the many losses in her life
column6: and it provides a moment of reflection for Hannah
column7: who has also recently suffered the loss of someone close.

column1: Life slowly comes back to normal for the staff of North West Ambulance Service as the country celebrates the Easter bank holiday weekend. It demonstrates that behind the immediate challenges of the pandemic
column2: the ambulance service still has to deal with many intractable issues: domestic violence
column4: loneliness and mental health. But all of these issues jostle for priority as more straightforward emergencies start coming in.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 838;838;Railways: The Making of a Nation;Time;How do you organise a rail network in a country made up of separate time zones?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p048nkhm.jpg;BBC
column4: Railways: The Making of a Nation
column5: Time;How do you organise a rail network in a country made up of separate time zones?;Exploring how Britain's expanding rail network sparked a social revolution. How do you organise a network in a country of separate time zones and no recognised timetables?;"Historian Liz McIvor explores how Britain's expanding rail network was the spark to a social revolution
column6: starting in the 1800s and continuing through to modern times. A fast system of transportation shaped so many areas of our industrial nation - from what we eat to where we live
column7: work and play. The railways generated economic activity but they also changed the nature of business itself. They even changed attitudes to time and how we set our clocks. Our railways may have reflected deep class divisions
column8: but they also brought people together as never before
column9: and helped forge a new sense of national identity.

column1: This episode looks at how you organise a rail network in a country made up of separate local time zones and no recognised timetables. Before the railways
column2: our country was divided and local time was proudly treasured. Clocks in the west of the country were several minutes behind those set in the east. The railways wanted the country to step to a new beat in a world of precise schedules and timetables that recognised Greenwich Mean Time. Not everyone was keen to step in line
column3: and some complained about the new world of one single time zone and precise schedules.";History;BBC ONE;False;2016;29;lifestyle

column1: 839;839;India's Frontier Railways;3. The Samjhauta Express;A look at life on the India-Pakistan cross-border train known as the Samjhauta Express.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p02m3d39.jpg;BBC
column5: 3. The Samjhauta Express;A look at life on the India-Pakistan cross-border train known as the Samjhauta Express.;Documentary series. A look at the cross-border train known as the Samjhauta Express
column6: which travels from Lahore to Delhi
column7: and some of its passengers.;"Freedom came to the subcontinent in August 1947. The British hastily partitioned British India before they left. Independence was attended by a million deaths and 14 million people were displaced.

column1: Yet despite three wars
column2: Pakistan and Indian railways have established a cross-border train
column3: known as the Samjhauta Express - Samjhauta meaning agreement.

column1: Amongst the passengers on the Samjhauta Express from Lahore to Delhi are Bilal and his father Abiz. Seventeen-year-old Bilal was the victim of an accident which damaged his eye. Unable to source the right treatment in Pakistan
column2: father and son trawled the internet and finally found a suitable clinic. But it was in India. They have never stepped outside Pakistan
column3: so they are a little nervous. Will they be successful in getting Bilal's eye treated?

column1: Also on the train is Rahat Khan
column2: the hockey queen. She's a Pakistan international and a railway hockey champion. She is travelling with her Pakistan girls' hockey team to play a match in India. But not everything goes to plan.

column1: For the Sikh community
column2: the Punjab is home. The golden temple of Amritsar is the holy of holies. But each year
column4: the railway runs special trains across the border to the guru's birthplace in Pakistan
column5: despite the security concerns.";History;BBC FOUR;False;2015;59;lifestyle
column6: history

column1: 841;841;Africa with Ade Adepitan;Series 1: Episode 4;At Paradise Island
column5: Africa with Ade Adepitan
column6: Series 1: Episode 4;At Paradise Island
column7: Ade finds an abandoned hotel.;The last leg of Ade Adepitan’s tour sees him travelling from the beaches of Mozambique
column8: through South Africa. At Paradise Island
column9: Ade finds an abandoned hotel.;"The final leg of Ade Adepitan’s epic tour of Africa sees him travelling from the beaches of Mozambique
column10: through South Africa
column11: before ending his entire trip in Zimbabwe.

column1: He begins on the golden sand beaches of Mozambique’s Bazaruto Archipelago
column2: one of Africa’s highlights. At Paradise Island
column4: a visual reminder of Mozambique’s recent history - this place was once a high-end tourist destination
column5: but 25 years of colonial and then civil war put a stop to development. But the local wildlife has benefited from the fact that so few tourists now come here
column6: and Ade is able to snorkel with one of the world’s most elusive sea creatures - a dugong.

column1: Since the wars
column3: and Ade meets someone for whom life is especially hard – a wheelchair user like himself. In a country where disability is viewed with fear and superstition – and believed by many to be contagious – even catching a bus proves impossible for Castigo. The best thing in his life is exactly the same thing that turned Ade’s life around - wheelchair basketball - and Ade can’t help getting carried away in a game. Along the coast
column4: at one of Mozambique’s largest ports
column5: Ade finds out that China is investing a huge amount in Mozambique – and elsewhere across Africa. The money often comes with strings attached
column6: but a poor country like Mozambique needs financial help
column7: which has to come from somewhere.

column1: Ade’s next stop is South Africa. The country is famous for its wildlife but Ade hears how Chinese influence is having a dramatic impact here – the country’s rhino population has been decimated by poachers
column2: driven by a demand for rhino horn in Chinese medicine. Ade follows rangers with a surprising way of tackling the problem - by cutting off the rhino horn themselves

column1: Ade travels to Johannesburg to see how the country is faring 25 years after apartheid ended. On a tour of the city
column2: he is upset to discover that although the black population now have voting rights
column3: they are living in an economic form of apartheid
column4: with 25% unemployed and many squatting on whatever land they can find. In an emotional scene
column5: Ade visits a squatted piece of land
column6: moments after the police have destroyed people’s houses
column7: to hear claims that Mandela’s legacy has been forgotten. Land reform is the big political issue here today
column8: with many calling for a redistribution of land from rich white farmers to the black population.

column1: The final stop on Ade’s African adventure is Zimbabwe – where land reform has already happened
column2: with disastrous results. Ade finds a country still struggling economically. His first stop is the Kariba dam
column3: and a hair-raising boat ride on the vast and stunning Lake Kariba. Ade finds that locals are worried about the stability of the Kariba dam and work has begun to stabilize undermined foundations. The worrying decay of this crucial dam is a sign of how much this country suffered under the rule of Robert Mugabe.

column1: As Ade has seen so often on his trip around Africa
column2: Zimbabwe is a country that should be rich. It has huge quantities of gold – enough
column4: for the entire population to be a millionaire. But there isn’t the infrastructure of investment to get at it - in a country dogged by poverty and corruption. But the departure of dictator Robert Mugabe brought a new optimism
column5: and Ade meets gold miners who are willing to risk daily exposure to toxic mercury for every scrap of gold they can get and an entrepreneur who believes the industry can be transformed. Despite the return of violence and repression in Zimbabwe
column6: Ade ends his journey on a high
column7: visiting a remote hut that has been turned into the set of a music video. He joins UK indie musician Shingai Shoniwa as she shoots the video for her forthcoming debut single
column8: Coming Home
column9: in a country that she believes is on the up
column10: and deserves a fresh chance.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2019;59;lifestyle

column5: 2021: Episode 2;Rachel de Thame and Joe Swift lead the team of garden experts.;Rachel de Thame and Joe Swift lead the team of garden experts as this year's RHS Flower Show Tatton Park comes to a close.;"Rachel de Thame and Joe Swift lead the team of garden experts as this year's RHS Flower Show Tatton Park comes to a close.

column1: Love will be in the air as Carol Klein discovers the ‘plants with passion’ on display in the floral marquee. We see how gardens can help us love ourselves and love the planet with eco-builds
column2: wildlife-friendly planting and gardens designed to benefit our mental health.

column1: Frances Tophill takes a look around a rewilding garden
column2: where nature becomes the lead designer. And we see the second head-to-head ‘presenter patch’ challenge – this time Arit Anderson and Adam Frost compete under the watchful eye of judge Carol.

column1: Finally
column2: we’ll reveal the winner of the much-anticipated RHS Young Designer of the Year competition.";Lifestyle;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 843;843;Scotland’s Sacred Islands with Ben Fogle ;Series 1: 4. Shetland;Ben Fogle explores whether spiritual life is easier in a place with fewer distractions.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09yb1v3.jpg;BBC
column4: Scotland’s Sacred Islands with Ben Fogle
column5: Series 1: 4. Shetland;Ben Fogle explores whether spiritual life is easier in a place with fewer distractions.;Travelling across Shetland
column6: Ben Fogle meets people whose lives are rooted to these islands’ history and visits a tiny church with big ideas.;"At the end of his spiritual journey across Scotland’s Sacred Isles
column7: Ben Fogle visits six islands across Shetland.

column1: On the beautiful and uninhabited St Ninian’s Isle
column2: he contemplates those in the distant past who sought out remote spots for quiet contemplation. And he visits the Isle of Oxna with a father and daughter whose ancestors once lived there.

column1: Andy and Sabina Holt moved from a hippy lifestyle to live on the island of Papa Stour 48 years ago. Sabina then had what she calls 'a marvellous encounter' with Jesus
column2: and the two have been living as committed Christians since. Ben discusses the effect living somewhere as remote and beautiful as this has on their faith.

column1: Ben also meets crofter Vic Thomas
column2: who shares his belief in the life cycles of birth
column4: and their spiritual meaning in a place where Mother Nature is so much in evidence.

column1: Ben catches up with Shetland chef Akshay Borges
column2: a champion of the island’s ‘sea harvest’. Akshay arrived from Goa in 2011
column3: a life-changing decision he made on the flip of a coin.

column1: Travelling to the Isle of Yell
column2: Ben visits a chicken shed converted into one of the UK’s smallest chapels. Its keeper
column4: explains that Shetland’s many Christian denominations seem to blend into one
column5: as if the remote wildness forges a common spirituality.

column1: And on Unst
column2: the UK’s most northerly inhabited isle
column3: Ben meets Orthodox nun Mother Mary
column4: who lives a solitary life of prayer and contemplation in this very remote place.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 844;844;Gareth Edwards’s Great Welsh Adventure;Series 2: Episode 5;The duo enrol in tank school and return to the canal to prove they can nail narrowboating.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0br7bcp.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 2: Episode 5;The duo enrol in tank school and return to the canal to prove they can nail narrowboating.;Gareth and Maureen enlist in tank school and gear up for a drive like no other. In the Brecon Beacons
column6: they discover if they’ve finally cracked the art of narrowboating.;"For the last of their new adventures
column7: Maureen has arranged a trip to the spectacular Brecon Beacons. But it’s not the usual walks amid epic mountain scenery on the agenda. In a first for both
column8: the childhood sweethearts enlist in tank school. After donning cam cream and military gear
column9: the couple get a lesson in controlling a full-sized tank. Maureen’s keen to see if the new vehicle can pick up speed.

column1: Their accommodation is another new experience – a shepherd’s hut complete with lush rolling hills for a view and sheep for neighbours. Gareth is a keen clay pigeon shooter and wants Maureen to try her hand at the sport. After getting some tips from farmer and Welsh champion clay shooter Rhys Lewis
column2: the competitive pair are both determined not to be the one to miss.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Gareth and Maureen’s inability to take one in-focus photograph of their adventures continues. Photographer Rhian Mai meets them at a spectacular natural cave to help hone their skills. The weekend ends where the original adventure began – on one of Wales’s most beautiful canals. Hopes start high as
column4: they manage to stay on course and not crash. But it isn’t long before the barge runs aground and the battle resumes to determine who was responsible. column6: Misfits Salon
column7: Series 1: 6. Katia;Katia
column8: a young artist dealing with grief
column9: gets a confidence boost with an overhaul.;Katia
column10: a young artist dealing with grief
column11: gets a confidence boost in Misfits Salon with an incredible orange coloured overhaul.;"Katia is a 24 year old artist living in Brighton. Two years ago a close friend died and it affected her hugely. The grief triggered an attack of acne
column12: which she never struggled with before. She’s been left with scarring that makes her extremely self-conscious. Convinced that people are staring at her skin
column13: Katia has always shied away from finding love and has never been on a date.

column1: In the salon
column2: Sophia finds out that Katia cuts her mousy blonde hair herself and hides in oversized coats. When she lost her friend she lost her self-esteem
column3: and now two years later she wants to press the re-set button. With Katia’s dream hair colours as oranges and reds
column4: Sophia’s vision for her make-over is a bright orange style
column5: a bold cut to enhance her fringe and clothes to really get her noticed.

column1: As Twinks talks all things fashion
column2: we learn that Katia has a love of monochrome and bohemian style dresses but has never had the courage to wear anything bold or bright before. As Katia never wears make-up
column3: MUA Bernicia shows Katia how to not let her skin hold her back by giving her a flawless base.

column1: 847;847;Burma with Simon Reeve;Series 1: Episode 2;Simon visits Mandalay and travels to a conflict zone to meet a rebel army.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bh3b53.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 2;Simon visits Mandalay and travels to a conflict zone to meet a rebel army.;Two-part documentary series. Simon visits Mandalay and travels to a conflict zone to meet a rebel army who have been fighting the Burmese military for decades.;"The second of a two-part series
column6: in which adventurer and broadcaster Simon Reeve travels deeper into beautiful and troubled Burma.

column1: Simon journeys up the vast Irrawaddy River to the old royal capital of Mandalay
column2: home to an exotic market for precious jade. In Burma's mountainous highlands
column3: he experiences the country's vibrant ethnic heritage at an extraordinary and explosive fire-balloon festival
column4: then visits an elephant sanctuary and finds out how a growing tourism industry is helping them survive after working for decades in the logging industry.

column1: Burma is a melting pot of different ethnic groups
column2: and having seen first-hand the suffering of the Rohingya people on the first leg of his journey
column3: Simon now travels secretly into one of Burma's many other conflict zones to meet a huge rebel army who have been fighting the Burmese military for decades. Simon goes on combat patrol into the jungle with the rebels and learns why they have been fighting the longest-running civil war in the world.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2018;59;lifestyle

column1: 849;849;Tom Kerridge's Fresh Start;Series 1: 6. We've Got This;The experiment is ending and Tom discovers if his families are now healthier and happier.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07j56kn.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 6. Weve Got This;The experiment is ending and Tom discovers if his families are now healthier and happier.;In the last part of his experiment
column6: Tom gets the families to cook bigger dishes than ever before and tests whether they are healthier and happier than 12 weeks ago.;"The eight families who are following Tom Kerridge's Fresh Start plan have risen to every challenge he has set them
column7: transforming mealtimes at home. Now
column8: as the experiment draws to a close
column9: they're coming together to celebrate their achievements - and to take on Tom's final challenge: cooking generous dishes for groups of friends and family.

column1: Tom kicks things off by cooking beef biryani for his own extended family. With a one-pot wonder like this
column2: the most important thing is to pack in tons of flavour. Tom roasts the mince for the biryani in the oven to maximise the flavour before adding it to the pot. He doesn't hold back on the ginger
column3: garlic and spices either. The finished dish contains around half the calories of a standard takeaway curry and has loads of veg thrown in so there's no need for extra side dishes.

column1: The Johnson family love hosting parties but are unhappy about the food they usually offer their guests; frozen pizzas and tinned hot dogs were the norm.   Now they are throwing their first party since starting Tom's experiment. It's Mum Becky's 40th birthday and they want to serve real
column2: homemade party food. Tom and the Johnsons - including three sons - work as a team to prepare chicken ranch burgers for 20 hungry guests. The recipe can be prepped ahead so the Johnsons have more time to relax and celebrate when friends and family arrive.

column1: Over the last two and a half months
column2: the gang have learnt loads of new cooking techniques.  Now Tom wants them to use what they've learnt to be even more ambitious.  He is challenging them to make bigger dishes for more people than ever before - to show how delicious food has the power to bring people together. Back in his kitchen
column4: ham and leek Pie - perfect for a large group to share
column5: hot or cold. This is exactly the sort of dish that can transform how Tom's gang cook for their friends and family.

column1: To mark the end of the experiment and celebrate their achievements
column2: all the families are getting together for a picnic in a few days' time. Tom has asked them all to cook a dish they can bring along and share with the group. And Tom's not going to arrive empty handed either; he's doing his own version of Eton mess
column3: a summer pudding that both kids and adults love. Meringues from scratch and a simple strawberry coulis are things all of us can make - other than that there's not much 'cooking'. This is a dish with lots of separate elements that taste incredible when combined and it's ideal for a summer party.

column1: Meanwhile Tom asks each family to come up with a resolution to take forward now that the experiment is coming to an end; a pledge that's personal to their own experience and will help keep their cooking and eating on track in the months and years ahead. He also asks the gang to take the same set of health and fitness tests as they did at the start
column2: to find out how much progress they've made.

column1: The final day of the experiment comes around and all the Fresh Start gang gather together for a picnic and cricket match. Twelve weeks on they've come a long way - they're all cooking from scratch
column4: eating together as a family more often. Tom reveals the results of the recent health tests and there's plenty to celebrate; from weight loss and improved fitness to greater happiness. And the families reveal their new resolutions and share the incredible food they've all made.

column1: Cooking and eating together has brought so many positive changes to the lives of these eight families. But the thing Tom's most delighted by is how much happier they all are as a result.";Food;BBC TWO;False;2019;29;lifestyle

column10: the junior doctors have continued to learn on the job and have become more confident. But as they near the end of their time on their wards
column11: the pressure is on as they are expected to take on even more responsibility.

column1: It’s all change for second-year doctor Luke as his more experienced colleagues leave the ENT department
column2: meaning he will need to work more independently. Unsure if ENT is the specialty for him
column3: Luke takes a trip back home to Derry to seek advice from his GP father.

column1: Second-year doctor Tom has been working in Salford Royal’s A&E department
column4: and the emotional pressure is beginning to take its toll. First-year doctor Zohaib has to lead a family discussion about how to treat an elderly patient should her condition deteriorate. Although routine
column5: discussing how to treat
column6: and whether to resuscitate
column7: a patient is a sensitive matter. Zohaib has learnt to appreciate the unique complexities and rewards of the geriatrics ward
column8: but will he be able to lead this sensitive discussion alone?

column4: Tropic of Cancer with Simon Reeve
column5: 6. Laos to Hawaii;Simon travels from the jungles of Southeast Asia to the tropical paradise of Hawaii.;Simon Reeve continues his epic journey. In the last episode of the series
column6: he samples local delicacies in Laos and meets high achieving children in Taiwan.;"Simon Reeve continues his epic journey around the world following the tropic of Cancer
column7: the northern border of the tropics region.

column1: The last leg of Simon's journey begins in the jungles of Southeast Asia and ends in the tropical paradise of Hawaii.
Prevented from following the tropic through China by the Chinese government
column2: Simon instead discovers the increasing Chinese influences in neighbouring Laos and Vietnam. And in Laos
column3: he samples some local delicacies: roast squirrel (or is it rat?) and caterpillars. In Vietnam
column4: he discovers cruelly caged moon bears
column5: farmed for their bile
column6: which is used in traditional medicines.

column1: Next stop is Taiwan
column2: and in the Tropic of Cancer primary school he meets some of the world's highest achieving children.

column1: The journey around the world ends in Hawaii
column2: a tropical paradise blighted by environmental problems
column3: including some of the dirtiest beaches on the planet.

column1: After travelling around the tropic of Capricorn and the Equator
column2: this series completes Simon's trilogy of journeys exploring the amazing tropics region with his toughest

column1: 856;856;Sort Your Life Out;Series 1: Episode 6;Stacey and her team help a family transform their home through a life-changing declutter.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b0c8xt.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 6;Stacey and her team help a family transform their home through a life-changing declutter.;Stacey Solomon transforms a multi-generational home with a mammoth declutter and clever upcycling hacks
column6: including an office of dreams and DIY panelling for a cosy family snug.;"Stacey and her gang - organizer Dilly
column7: carpenter Rob and cleaner Iwan - challenge the Waller family to sort their life out in seven days
column8: and in order to do this they’ll have to embark on a mammoth declutter. In this family home
column9: they’ve converted a garage full of stuff to create an annex for Nan and Grandad
column10: but as a result the clutter has now taken over the rest of the house.

column1: With Stacey’s help
column2: the family start packing all their possessions into boxes. Every single item is stripped from the family home revealing how much space there is under all their things. We get to know the family behind the clutter – working mum Kelly
column3: policeman Dan and their two daughters – and why their house is making them miserable.

column1: With the house all packed up
column2: the family’s possessions are laid out in a giant warehouse like an art installation of their entire lives; including 107 boardgames
column3: 640 old CDs and hundreds of odd socks. With everything displayed in front of them
column4: the family are shocked to see how much they really own and how it all fitted into their house in the first place.

column1: There are emotional moments in the warehouse as the family try let go of baby items they’ve held on to
column2: and tensions rise as the sheer enormity of the task takes its toll.

column1: The items they do decide to let go of will be put into piles to recycle
At the house
column2: carpenter Rob breathes new life into the home by creating a multi-purpose spare room and transforming the office into a workspace of dreams. Cleaner Iwan gives the home a supersize spring clean
column3: with lots of useful tips along the way
column4: and organizer Dilly shows us all the best way to organise our paperwork.

column1: When the family are left with only the must keep items
column2: they are packed back up to the house before it’s stylishly refilled by Stacey and her team
column3: ready for the big reveal to the family.

column1: 861;861;The Americas with Simon Reeve;Series 1: Episode 5;In this fifth leg
column2: Simon travels across Central America from the Caribbean to the Pacific.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07q0yy2.jpg;BBC
column5: The Americas with Simon Reeve
column6: Series 1: Episode 5;In this fifth leg
column7: Simon travels across Central America from the Caribbean to the Pacific.;Simon Reeve continues his journey through the Americas. In this fifth leg
column8: Simon travels across Central America from the Caribbean to the Pacific.;"Simon Reeve continues his journey through the Americas. In this fifth leg of the journey
column9: Simon travels across Central America from the Caribbean to the Pacific. He begins by diving on a coral reef on the coast of northern Belize and visits a rescue centre for orphaned manatees. In Belize’s Chiquibul National Park
column10: Simon witnesses a gun battle between armed park rangers and intruders from neighbouring Guatemala intent on clearing the rainforest for farming.

column1: Simon's next stop is Guatemala
column2: where over half the population live off the land. The staple crop is corn
column3: but Simon discovers that a vast area of Central America is suffering from a severe drought
column4: partly blamed on climate change. Half of children under the age of five are malnourished
column5: and Simon visits one mother who only has eight days of food left to feed her young family. The drought is not only causing hunger but mass migration to the United States.

column1: In El Salvador Simon encounters the other big factor in the migration crisis: the brutal gang violence that causes thousands to flee the country. A new government in El Salvador is cracking down on the gangs
column2: and Simon heads out on patrol with an elite police unit tasked with taking back control of the streets. In a dark situation
column3: Simon finds a ray of light in a volunteer organisation that takes young teenagers from gang neighbourhoods and trains them to be paramedics.

column1: The last destination on this leg of the journey is Costa Rica
column2: a small tropical paradise that's home to 6% of the world's biodiversity. In a troubled region
column3: Costa Rica is a beacon of hope and stability. It has led the world in eco-tourism and aims to become the first carbon neutral country in 2021. Simon joins school children to plant trees
column4: one of many projects to restore the country's tropical forests and fight climate change.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2019;69;lifestyle

column1: 862;862;Great Coastal Railway Journeys;Series 1: 24. Carmarthen to Pembroke;Michael travels the breathtaking rural coastline of Carmarthenshire and Pembrokeshire.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bj1bt2.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 24. Carmarthen to Pembroke;Michael travels the breathtaking rural coastline of Carmarthenshire and Pembrokeshire.;Michael Portillo travels the breathtaking rural coastline of Carmarthenshire and Pembrokeshire
column6: visiting a bee garden with a quarter of a million honeybees
column7: and Pembroke's magnificent Norman castle.;"Michael Portillo travels the breathtaking rural coastline of Carmarthenshire and Pembrokeshire in south Wales.

column1: From Carmarthen Bay
column2: he tracks up the estuary and River Towy to the historic town of Carmarthen and Middleton Hall
column3: home of Wales’s National Botanic Garden. Michael is on the trail of the quarter of a million honeybees who live in the bee garden
column4: where the master beekeeper shows Michael their hives. Michael helps to collect honey from a frame and hears how researchers are tracking which of the estate’s 5
column5: 000 flowering plants the bees like best.

column1: Whitland is Michael’s next stop
column3: where he teams up with an expert forager to comb the rock pools for tasty morsels such as seaweed
column5: mussels
column6: periwinkles and prawns and cooks them up for a beachfront banquet.

column1: In the picture-postcard harbour town of Tenby
column2: Michael tracks down a Welsh icon – the lovespoon. Michael learns from an expert how these pieces are carved from a single piece of wood and does his best with a chisel on a railway sleeper.

column1: Pushing west from Tenby
column2: Michael reaches Pembroke and its magnificent Norman castle. Here
column3: he discovers the origins of the Welsh flag and the beginning of one of Britain’s greatest royal dynasties – the Tudors. Henry VII was born at this castle in 1457.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;29;lifestyle

column1: 864;864;Sudden Death: My Sister’s Silent Killer;None;Patrick tries to understand what caused the sudden
column5: Sudden Death: My Sister’s Silent Killer;Patrick tries to understand what caused the sudden
column6: unexpected death of his sister Lauren.;Patrick tries to understand what caused the sudden and unexpected death of his sister Lauren. In seeking answers
column7: he is shocked to discover the true extent of the problem.;"After the sudden and unexplained death of his 19-year-old sister Lauren
column8: Patrick is left grieving
column9: struggling to understand how a young person could go to sleep and never wake up. Every year over 600 young and seemingly healthy people die suddenly and unexpectedly from sudden cardiac death. Lauren's death was registered as SADS
column10: or sudden adult death syndrome
column11: a cause of cardiac death even the experts don’t completely understand.

column1: Patrick finds himself unable to talk to his friends or family
column2: but he needs answers. What could have been done to prevent Lauren’s death
column3: and is there a way to stop other young people dying this way? He and his family are referred to St George’s Hospital in Tooting to undergo cardiac tests in hope of understanding what happened to Lauren. He learns that he
column5: could be at risk
column6: as in nearly half of SADS cases
column7: a problem is also detected in other family members.

column1: Patrick also attends a bereavement counselling session in London with other young people who have lost a sibling to SADS. Among them is Tash
column2: who lost her brother when he suffered a cardiac arrest at the wheel of a car
column4: whose brother - a semi-professional rugby player - died following a workout at the gym. Patrick discovers that sudden cardiac death is the leading cause of death in young athletes during exercise. He visits Tonbridge Angels Football Club in Kent
column5: who lost three of their players to sudden death and instigated a screening programme as a result. Here he learns that mandatory screening of athletes in Italy has reduced sudden cardiac death by nearly 90 per cent.

column1: Footballer Fabrice Muamba famously survived SADS after collapsing halfway through a match at White Hart Lane. He and Patrick retrace Fabrice’s steps
column2: as Fabrice tells Patrick how it felt when his heart stopped for 78 minutes.

column1: Finally
column2: Patrick meets a leading cardiac pathologist
column4: who believes SADS deaths are under-reported. Based on her research
column5: she understands sudden cardiac death to be the third biggest killer of young people
column6: after road traffic accidents and suicide.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;50;lifestyle

column1: 869;869;Critical: Inside Intensive Care;Critical: Coronavirus in Intensive Care;Filmed by intensive care teams at the Royal Gwent Hospital battling coronavirus.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08c6krl.jpg;BBC
column5: Critical: Coronavirus in Intensive Care;Filmed by intensive care teams at the Royal Gwent Hospital battling coronavirus.;When the Royal Gwent Hospital found itself at the epicentre of the coronavirus pandemic
column6: staff in intensive care began to film their lives.;"When the Royal Gwent Hospital in Newport found itself at the epicentre of the coronavirus pandemic
column7: staff at the Intensive Care Unit began to film their own lives
column8: in and out of work. The result is a powerful new documentary showing life in critical care as the virus threatens to overwhelm the NHS.

column1: The Intensive Care teams are on the frontline in the battle against coronavirus
column2: and we see the emotional impact their work has on them – as well as the gratitude they feel for the public support. The film shows the staff working tirelessly to triple the unit’s bed capacity
column3: the struggles coping with PPE and the toll the epidemic takes on family life.

column1: This unique documentary
column3: presents an extraordinary personal insight into hospital life during the most serious public health crisis in living memory.

column1: Produced by the BAFTA Cymru-award-winning team behind Critical: Inside Intensive Care
column2: the 60-minute documentary for BBC One Wales follows the lives of medical staff during the four weeks from the time the lockdown came into force
column3: until the number of cases begins to level off in late April.

column1: Filmed on mobile phones and small cameras
column2: the film captures life at the sharp end of the fight against the virus
column3: as the dedicated medical staff struggle to contain the outbreak. The Aneurin Bevan Health Board that covers Newport and the Gwent Valleys emerged as one of the UK’s coronavirus hotspots
column4: with more cases than anywhere outside London
column5: per head of population.

column1: Wales has fewer intensive care beds than anywhere else in Britain. This
column3: long-standing social problems and close proximity to the urban populations of England
column4: meant  that the Gwent outbreak was one of the most serious in Britain.

column1: Intensive Care Consultant Dr David Hepburn recovered from coronavirus to return to work on the unit. He says in the film: ‘There’s a huge variation in the demographic
column2: but traditionally this has been an area of high social deprivation and particular health problems
column3: and Newport is known for seeing more extreme pathology than in some of the more metropolitan areas like Cardiff
column4: so not a desperately healthy population. But at the minute
column5: we are at the epicentre of this outbreak
column6: outside the big metropolitan areas of London and Birmingham.’

column1: ‘Per head of population
column2: we are seeing more people in Newport who are desperately unwell than most areas and certainly than anywhere else in Wales.’

column1: Emotional video diaries show doctors and nurses leaving their families to come into work to find the unit full of patients on ventilators. It shows the challenges of communicating with colleagues in full PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) and the heartbreak of having to tell relatives over the phone that their loved ones have died
column2: as the hospital is closed to visitors.

column1: It shows the extraordinary outpouring of public support for NHS staff
column2: with gifts of food and drink sent to the unit and the reaction of staff the Thursday night Clap for Carers. We see how the staff work together to keep morale high under incredibly traumatic circumstances.

column1: Intensive Care Consultant Dr Laura McClelland speaks of her hope for the future: ‘From a personal perspective
column2: as much as the lockdown has been difficult
column3: it’s been quite a period of reflection and prioritisation.

column1: ‘I believe that the inclination of mankind to recognize the value of the family and the community and time spent just being and appreciating what they have
column4: is something we can bring forward into the future.’

870;870;Travelling Blind;None;Blind traveller Amar Latif sets off to explore Turkey with comedian Sara Pascoe.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k2vk6.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Travelling Blind;Blind traveller Amar Latif sets off to explore Turkey with comedian Sara Pascoe.;Blind traveller Amar Latif sets off to explore Turkey with the comedian Sara Pascoe as his sighted guide.;Amar Latif was told
column3: that he would be blind by the time he was 18. However
column4: his lack of sight hasn’t prevented him from experiencing the world. He has travelled extensively
column5: visiting over a hundred countries and taken up skydiving
column6: bungee jumping and skiing. Whenever Amar travels he relies on someone sighted to guide him. In return he opens their eyes and all their senses to a completely different way of travelling.

column1: Amar is joined by comedian Sara Pascoe as he attempts to open her eyes to the potential of travelling blind and ‘seeing’ the world differently. The destination is Turkey and their journey takes them off the beaten track as they explore the country’s bustling cities
column2: remote mountains and extra-ordinary landscapes. What becomes clear is that Sara and Amar travel in completely different ways. Sara prefers to stand back and observe while Amar needs to be in the thick of things. Their journey through Turkey becomes as much about their relationship with each other
column3: as it is about the country.

column1: Amar and Sara start their travels in Istanbul and as they navigate the city’s vast Grand Bazaar to get to their hotel
column2: Sara is keen to guide them straight there but Amar just wants to smell
column3: listen and touch every item in the bazaar. It is Sara’s first lesson in guiding - if you are blind then things need to be experienced
column4: or else they don’t really exist.

column1: After three days in Istanbul
column2: Amar and Sara head east to the mountains along the Black Sea. Traditional communities still live here and have a long history of summer festivities. One of these is oil wrestling – a sport Amar has heard about but never witnessed. Sara must describe the complexities of large men in leather trousers covering themselves in olive oil and throwing each other onto the ground and she rises to the challenge.

column1: Their time in the mountains also gives Amar and Sara time to understand each other better. Amar opens up of how he went blind
column2: and the impact it had one his teenage life. By 18
column3: he had lost his sight completely and found himself trapped in darkness
column4: just as his friends were getting girlfriends and exploring the world. Amar overcame his depression by deciding to say yes to everything and becoming an immensely positive person.

column1: However
column3: Amar is now beginning to forget what things look like. Images that were once familiar in his imagination - clouds
column5: his mother’s face - are fading.  Sara is deeply affected by this and decides to take Amar to a place that is unlike anywhere he has been before. And she plans to describe it so well that it creates a new visual palate in his imagination. They head to Cappadocia
column6: a unique landscape formed from volcanic mud that has been eroded to create staggering rock formations. For 24 hours
column7: Sara describes the scene in forensic detail to the extent that Amar can picture it in his mind and ‘see again’. By the end of their transformational journey they have both learnt a huge amount from each other and how we interact with the world around us.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2019;59;lifestyle

column1: 871;871;Beauty Laid Bare;Series 1: 3. The Ingredients;The group discovers the potentially harmful effects cosmetics can have on health.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p081trmg.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 3. The Ingredients;The group discovers the potentially harmful effects cosmetics can have on health.;During two weeks investigating America’s beauty industry
column6: the group discovers some of the potentially harmful effects favourite products can have on health.;"During two weeks investigating America’s beauty industry
column7: the group sees the good
column8: the bad and the ugly side of it. They see first-hand how cosmetics are produced and sold and are confronted with the environmental and health effects of the products used. They then have the opportunity to put what they have learnt into practice and make their own products
column9: and they discover the dilemmas faced when trying to create a product that is both ethical and affordable.

column1: Finally
column2: the group travels to New York City to meet esteemed beauty journalist Jane Larkworthy
column3: who reviews the products they have created and gives her frank assessment of the beauty industry. Is it capable of change? And will the group make any changes based on what they have discovered?
