872;872;Our NHS: A Hidden History;None;David Olusoga meets the overseas health workers who have transformed the NHS.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09nwx50.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Our NHS: A Hidden History;David Olusoga meets the overseas health workers who have transformed the NHS.;David Olusoga meets nurses, doctors and health workers from overseas who have transformed the NHS in spite of hostility and discrimination.;As we emerge from a global pandemic that has turned our world upside down
column2: David Olusoga explores the hidden history of the nurses
column5: have been coming to Britain from overseas to serve in the NHS. Without them the NHS would have been in danger of collapse - not least during the current COVID crisis - but from the very start the story of this beloved British institution has been intertwined with one of the most divisive social and political issue of the age
column6: immigration. The people who came to this country to work in the NHS have found themselves fighting battles they neither sought nor expected.

column1: Today
column2: more than 13 per cent of the 1.2 million people who work for the NHS are from overseas
column4: and in England and Wales more than 40 per cent can claim minority ethnic heritage
column5: making the NHS the most diverse of all British institutions. The programme gives voice to the moving and often raw experiences of nurses from the Irish Republic
column6: the Caribbean and the Philippines
column7: GPs and surgeons from India
column8: Pakistan and Sri Lanka and paramedics from Central Europe
column9: as well as to the British-born children and grandchildren of immigrants who have found themselves helping and healing with one hand while fending off the sharp end of discrimination and racism with the other. Ultimately
column10: their stories say as much about perseverance
column11: dedication and the overcoming of obstacles as they do about discrimination and prejudice.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains language which may offend.;2021;58;lifestyle

column1: 873;873;The Botox Bust: Ellie Undercover;None;Ellie Flynn exposes a struck-off doctor who is providing Botox for people nationwide.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p076jb99.jpg;BBC
column4: The Botox Bust: Ellie Undercover;Ellie Flynn exposes a struck-off doctor who is providing Botox for people nationwide.;Investigative journalist Ellie Flynn exposes a struck-off doctor who is providing Botox for young people nationwide.;"Investigative journalist Ellie Flynn is on the trail of medics who may be wrongly providing botulinum toxin
column5: commonly known as Botox
column6: and the beauticians who either don't know the strict rules or

column1: are choosing to ignore them.
Researchers suggest that as many as 100
column2: 000 Botox injections are carried out each year in the UK
column3: and campaigners report an astonishing trebling in botched treatments since 2016.

column1: Ellie's investigation takes her all over the UK to visit beauticians who - she discovers - are happy to give her Botox without her having a valid prescription. She has to tread a very fine line to avoid her cover being blown. Some of these beauticians may be connected
column2: and Ellie has to artfully excuse herself during every appointment to avoid the possibility of being injected unlawfully with Botox.

column1: Ellie attends a legitimate Botox Party in Windsor
column2: where the guests receive Botox treatments along with their snacks
column3: party soundtrack and non-alcoholic champagne. She talks to women in their twenties to find out if Botox really is as essential as getting your nails and hair done.

column1: But
column3: like any medical procedure there are risks and side effects
column4: and getting Botox properly prescribed by a medic after a face to face consultation is important. She speaks to someone who was left physically disfigured and unable to speak
column5: eat or drink as a result of

column1: unlawfully acquired Botox
column2: and goes out in search of a doctor who was struck off and is supplying Botox on the basis of telephone conversations.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains very strong language and some upsetting scenes.;2018;28;lifestyle

column1: 874;874;Rent Like A Boss;Series 1: Episode 4;The boys help Emma find digs in Liverpool
column2: and Ben checks out a flatshare in Manchester.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08v4hws.jpg;BBC
column5: Rent Like A Boss
column6: Series 1: Episode 4;The boys help Emma find digs in Liverpool
column7: and Ben checks out a flatshare in Manchester.;The guys go to Liverpool to help wheelchair user Emma find an accessible property in the city
column8: and they think they have found Ben a flatmate
column9: but will they click?;Estate agents Tobias and Big V are determined to show renters there are great properties out there
column10: even on the tightest of budgets. After meeting 24-year-old Ben in Wolverhampton and discovering his bizarre wardrobe storage needs
column11: they have lined him up with a flatshare in Manchester that has plenty of space and is on budget
column12: but will he click with his potential flatmate? Then it’s off to Liverpool to meet 22-year-old Emma. She is currently living alone and paying a whopping £625 a month. She is a wheelchair user
column13: but her current flat doesn’t have all the adaptations she needs
column14: and she would also like to live in a more social setting. Big V and Tobias need to find her a new place with the right setup for her wheelchair

column1: 875;875;Split Up in Care: Life without Siblings;None;Reporter Ashley John-Baptiste explores the separation of siblings by the UK care system.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bhxskv.jpg;BBC
column4: Split Up in Care: Life without Siblings;Reporter Ashley John-Baptiste explores the separation of siblings by the UK care system.;Thousands of children have been separated from their brothers and sisters by the UK care system. Ashley John-Baptiste hears from those whose lives have been changed forever.;"Ashley John-Baptiste is a BBC reporter who grew up in foster care and spent most of his life believing he was an only child. That is until his mid-20s
column5: when he received a life-changing message. A man contacted him on social media telling him that he was his brother.

column1: As it was with Ashley
column2: some children in care grow up completely unaware of their siblings. More common
column4: are cases where looked-after children do know about their siblings – but are split up once in care. The law says they should stay together if it's safe and appropriate to do so
column5: but around half of sibling groups in care in the UK are separated.

column1: To find out why this is happening
column2: Ashley hears from young people and children whose lives have been changed forever by the impact of separation.

column1: In Derby
column2: the director of children's social care explains to Ashley that councils are ‘close to the bone’ and allows him to join a new rapid response team that's just supported a family and sibling group to stay together. Amidst a shortage of foster carers
column3: Ashley seeks advice from Debbie Bright from The Only Way Is Essex. She has looked after more than 200 children in 30 years and introduces Ashley to 23-year-old Bryleigh
column4: who has recently become a foster carer herself.

column1: A new law is Scotland is giving brothers and sisters in care more rights over their relationships than ever before. Ashley meets foster carer Karen in Fife
column2: who has been instrumental in the changes and runs a farm where split-up siblings can come to rebuild their bonds.

column1: For the first time ever
column2: cameras are allowed to capture the reunion of five siblings who are living separated and only see each other two hours every two months. As a part of his quest for answers
column3: Ashley traces back one of his own social workers and uncovers revelatory news that will
column5: impact his life.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2022;29;lifestyle

column5: 6. Indonesia to Australia;The last leg of Simon Reeve's journey begins in Sumatra and ends in Australia.;The last leg of Simon Reeve's journey begins on the northern tip of Sumatra and takes him to the south western corner of Australia.;"The last leg of Simon Reeve's journey begins on the northern tip of Sumatra
column6: near the epicentre of the 2004 tsunami
column7: and takes him to the south western corner of Australia.

column1: In Banda Aceh
column2: Sharia law is in force and Simon joins the local vice and virtue squad who patrol the streets and beaches to eradicate immoral behaviour.

column1: In the Indonesian capital of Jakarta
column2: Simon investigates the shocking trade in exotic pets and encounters the group attempting to save one of the country's most bizarre species

column1: Next stop is Bali
column3: where Simon joins a family of seaweed farmers
column4: who cultivate great areas of sea to provide a new protein source that some hail as a miracle crop.

column1: Australia is the last of 16 countries of this Indian Ocean journey
column2: and site of one of the world's greatest and most unspoilt wildernesses
column3: the Kimberley. On a Barramundi fish farm
column4: Simon meets a real life crocodile hunter
column5: and ends up hauling a three metre crocodile onto the boat.

column1: The journey ends at Cape Leeuwin
column2: at the south west tip of Australia
column3: where Simon draws conclusions from his journey and asks what we can do to preserve the extraordinary diversity of our oceans from the encroachment of mankind.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2012;59;lifestyle

Back in West America

column1: 879;879;Your Home Made Perfect;Series 3: 8. Hemal and Kapila;A couple near Stockport experience two very different visions for their home.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09yhr1c.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 3: 8. Hemal and Kapila;A couple near Stockport experience two very different visions for their home.;Two architects compete using virtual reality to win the opportunity to remodel a four-bedroom house near Stockport. But which option will the owners choose?;"Hemal and Kapila have busy lives
column6: juggling a new business start-up and raising three children who are all under seven
column7: but their house is not helping to ease the pressure. They want their four-bedroom house near Stockport to give them the flexibility for easy
column8: family time together
column9: even when they’re working from home. Hemal and Kapila also yearn for a welcoming home where sisters
column10: aunts
column11: cousins and grandparents can congregate in comfort. But all of this seems like a distant dream.

column1: The room that should be the heart of their home
column3: is in a dark corner separated from the dining room by a wall which forces them to ferry food through the hall and living room to reach their guests. With barely any storage space
column4: all food and drinks are kept in a cold and damp lean-to which is so cold they often put a coat on to go in. Their home is office is also causing problems
column5: as it’s two floors up in the attic
column6: which separates them from family life.

column1: Hemal and Kapila have wrestled endlessly with how to improve things
column2: but the project has not moved forward. Hemal thinks the answer is more space
column3: so he wants a large extension
column4: but Kapila believes they just need to reconfigure the existing footprint.

column1: Desperate for an idea that will unite them
column2: they have invited two competing architects
column4: to turn the house that divides them into one which unites the whole family. Each architect interprets the brief in wildly different ways
column5: but which design will the Hemal and Kapila choose?";Lifestyle;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 881;881;Nadiya: Anxiety and Me;None;Nadiya Hussain sets out to find the cause of her anxiety
column5: Nadiya: Anxiety and Me;Nadiya Hussain sets out to find the cause of her anxiety
column6: and explores various treatments.;In this one-off documentary
column7: Nadiya Hussain sets out to find the cause of her anxiety
column8: exploring the most effective
column9: available treatments.;"Since Nadiya Hussain won Bake Off in 2015 she’s rarely been off our screens. But behind the scenes Nadiya suffers from extreme anxiety and debilitating panic attacks
column10: which she’s had since childhood. For decades
column11: she has kept her anxiety a secret
column12: ashamed to speak out.

column1: She’s never had a proper diagnosis but thinks she has an anxiety disorder
column2: and with around 5 million people suffering from the condition in the UK

column1: In this one-off documentary for BBC One
column2: Nadiya sets out to find the cause of her anxiety
column5: whilst having therapy herself
column6: in the hope of managing her anxiety.

column1: She speaks bravely and honestly about what it’s like to live with anxiety and panic attacks; undergoing a course of cognitive behaviour therapy
column2: each session is a step into the unknown. At times
column4: revealing buried memories and key moments from her past. These sessions are raw and honest
column5: but Nadiya hopes her openness will inspire others to seek help rather than suffer in silence.

column1: She wants to understand how anxiety is affecting the nation’s health
column2: meeting fellow sufferers in the hope of understanding her own issues. Nadiya talks to Laura Bartley about her experiences of treating her anxiety with medication
column3: visits a school in Brighton to see how they are tackling anxiety in their students
column4: and goes online to meet Barry McDonagh
column5: who offers support and therapy to an online community of around 250

column1: Nadiya wants to find out if her anxiety was something she was born with
column2: fearing she might pass it onto her children. At Kings College London
column3: Nadiya hopes groundbreaking research into the role of genetics and environment on anxiety disorders can give her the answers she needs.

column1: Raw
column3: this documentary will speak to the millions of people in the UK suffering with anxiety disorders
column4: shining a light and starting a debate about on an increasingly pressing issue.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2019;58;lifestyle

column11: complete with surrounding shelves and even a fridge. It’s an ambitious build for Les and Ant.

column3: who runs a non-profit furniture service that helps local people in need. Brenda started it three decades ago with just a container on an estate
column4: but it’s now grown to fill a massive warehouse site. Isabelle designs a bench made from durable Douglas fir
column5: to sit outside the caravan Brenda recently moved to. With matching hand-carved peacock heads and complex joinery

column6: encounters extreme violence and beauty in Honduras and finishes in Jamaica.;"Simon begins his journey on the remote Caribbean coast of Nicaragua

column1: Nicaragua is a country on the brink of monumental change. It will soon be split in two by the world's biggest construction project: a new transoceanic waterway set to rival the Panama Canal. Simon visits the Rama-Kriol people who face losing their ancestral homes and
column2: in the nearby town of Bluefields
column3: he meets the city-dwellers who believe the canal will bring long-hoped-for prosperity and wealth to the country.

column1: In Honduras
column2: Simon dives into the crystal waters of the world's second-largest barrier reef and conducts an unusual underwater experiment in the dead of night. Back on shore
column3: Simon discovers Hondurans living in the grip of some of the most violent criminal gangs in the world. San Pedro Sula
column5: has the world's highest murder rate.

column1: Simon's journey ends in the stunning Jamaica
column2: where he discovers a country confronting its violent reputation head-on with a police force cracking down on corruption. Here
column3: he spends time with young people who have rejected gang life
column4: offering a model of hope for future generations.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2015;59;lifestyle

column8: from 20 million to 50 million
column9: but how is the city gearing up for this influx?

column1: Liverpudlian nightclub entrepreneur Chris Wright spent 12 years
running events in Ibiza
column2: but now he is targeting Dubai as the next party capital of the world
column3: opening a bar in a new complex of beach clubs. He is also benefiting from a relaxation in the rules around alcohol.

column1: A former Miss Great Britain
column2: Amy Kitchingman came to Dubai for New Year’s Eve in 2010 and never left. She remembers being given a red card in the shopping mall for wearing a skirt that was too short
column3: but she too has noticed a relaxation in the rules more recently.

column1: And in one of Dubai’s toughest challenges yet
column2: staff at a major art exhibition are hoping to convince the world that Dubai belongs on the global stage for art alongside the likes of London and Paris. Simon stays with descendants of the original Turks in the Taurus Mountains and visits the Black Sea coast.;"Simon Reeve sets off on the second leg of his two-part journey around Turkey
column6: a dramatic and beautiful country that now finds itself at the centre of world events.

column1: In the Taurus Mountains Simon stays with descendants of the original Turks
column3: whose lifestyle is under threat from the modern world and an increasingly religious government. They're not the only minority at odds with the authorities in Turkey; Simon sees first-hand the devastating effects of fighting in the country's Kurdish region. In an area where the government has detained foreign journalists
column4: Simon gathers unique footage in the aftermath of a crackdown on Kurdish militants - the wholesale destruction of the historic centre of one of Turkey's oldest cities.

column1: Away from the conflict in the south
column2: Simon heads towards the Black Sea coast. He meets a wildlife conservationist protecting Turkey's population of brown bears
column3: and villagers who still communicate over long distances using an ancient bird language. In the country's capital he meets a victim of President Erdogan's authoritarian purge of people accused of complicity in the failed coup against him.

column1: Finally Simon's journey comes full circle when he returns to Istanbul - home to the new craze of 'Ottomania'
column2: a celebration of the vast empire that preceded modern Turkey. Simon visits the set of one of the world's most popular TV dramas - even getting a speaking role - based in the court of an Ottoman sultan.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2017;59;lifestyle

column1: The guest judge this week is masterclass mogul Lisa Eldridge

column1: The next day in Glow Up Studios

column3: encapsulating how they have grown throughout the competition. One MUA’s interpretation of unstoppable is based on crystals
column4: which have helped her get to where she is
column5: using the colours as well as unconventional items such as dried lavender and crystals. Another MUA draws inspiration from MRI brain scans and endorphins
column6: hoping his positivity pays off and showing that if you put your mind into it
column7: you can be unstoppable. The last finalist lights up her model with UV paint
column8: in her daughter’s favourite colour
column9: showing her inner warrior that signifies she will always be by her daughter’s side.

As she passes through the patch where she first cut her teeth as a reporter
column6: she takes time to appreciate the stunning landscapes.

column1: From the panoramic viewpoint of Painswick Beacon
column2: Kate descends through beech woods to the village of Upton St Leonards
column3: soaking up the sounds of nature as she goes. From there she climbs Cooper’s

column1: Hill and wanders down to the church at Great Witcombe. Kate relishes the chance to have nothing to do but take in the ‘joy and rhythm of the
countryside’ as she crosses the gentle
column2: rolling hills with just a 360-degree camera for company.

column1: Along the way she meets local craftspeople who are inspired by the ‘living theatre’ of the landscapes. Kate finds her natural surroundings a source of inspiration and resilience as she reflects on a year of challenges and change.

Breast Reduction;Four women watch live breast reduction surgery as they consider going under the knife.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07zr22w.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Plastic Surgery Undressed, Series 2: 3. Breast Reduction;Four women watch live breast reduction surgery as they consider going under the knife.;Vogue Williams and Mobeen Azhar help four women decide if breast reduction surgery is what they really want by watching live surgery and
meeting former patients.";"Breast reduction surgery is explored on Plastic Surgery Undressed.
It’s the second most popular surgery for women in the UK
column2: and many argue there is nothing cosmetic about it. Bad backs and unwanted attention are just two of the problems faced by those with big boobs.

column1: In an exclusive poll of 18-30-year-olds for the BBC
column2: 65% of respondents said a desire to look ‘normal’ led them to consider a cosmetic procedure. It’s something Eden can relate to
column3: as the size of her boobs made her feel out of place at school. Lauren’s breasts not only give her physical pain
column4: but they affect what she is able to do with her children.

column1: Michaela’s partner loves her breasts
column2: but Michaela’s not a fan. From men fixating on her bust to the women who think it’s OK to grab her breasts in public
column3: Michaela is ready to pay for her surgery. Carla thinks women with large breasts are perceived differently
column4: and with a big birthday coming up she’s hoping family and friends will help her raise the cash to change hers.

column1: Downsizing breasts while maintaining function and the shape women want is a complex surgery
column2: as top surgeon Amir Nakhdjevani reveals live when he takes his patient Rosie from a HH cup size down to a DD.

column1: With the breast deconstructed first
column2: the women start to question their surgery choices
column3: but it’s the experiences of former patients that have the biggest impact.

column1: All the seekers are accompanied by family and friends who have their own opinion on the surgery
column2: but ultimately the only view that matters is that of the seekers.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains graphic medical scenes.;2020;53;lifestyle

column2: the atmosphere in the garden is rich with the smell of ripening fruit and wood smoke.

column4: are home to help decide the fate of the cankered apple tree. And Carol has to prepare the garden for visitors to her Open Garden Scheme day.

column1: 905;905;Silenced: The Hidden Story of Disabled Britain;None;The untold story of how disabled people fought back against decades of fear and prejudice.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p094j5nh.jpg;BBC
column4: Silenced: The Hidden Story of Disabled Britain;The untold story of how disabled people fought back against decades of fear and prejudice.;Cerrie Burnell uncovers the shocking story of how disabled people in Britain were shut out of society for decades – and how they fought back.;"For more than a century
column5: one group of people in Britain has been shut out of society
column6: denied basic human rights and treated with fear and prejudice.

column1: Now
column5: actor and presenter Cerrie Burnell is going to uncover the hidden story of how disabled people fought back – and won their freedom.

column1: Cerrie was born without the lower part of her right arm. As a presenter on CBeebies
column2: Cerrie was astonished to learn that some viewers thought her appearance would scare watching children. Now
column3: she wants to find out where these attitudes to disabled people come from and why they persist today.

column1: She discovers how our modern attitudes to disabled people were first formed in the workhouses of Victorian Britain
column2: uncovers the original records of an institution created to segregate disabled people and stop them having children
column3: and traces the hidden lives of those confined to institutions for their whole lives.

column1: Cerrie hears astonishing stories of heartbreak and cruelty. But she also meets some pioneers who changed the lives of disabled people forever. John Evans was one of the very first to move from a residential home into a one of his own
column2: and Alia Hassan brought the streets of London to a standstill as part of a campaign fighting for disabled people to be allowed to get on a bus.

column1: Ultimately Cerrie discovers that although much has changed for disabled people in Britain today
column2: the battle is not yet won.

column1: Silenced is a story of huge social change that many of us still don’t know about
column2: told through the hidden lives of disabled people.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains disturbing scenes.;2021;59;lifestyle

column2: he visits Surfers Paradise near the city of Gold Coast
column3: the Las Vegas of Australia. Behind the sun and surf
column4: this area has become the country's organised crime capital. Police are cracking down on outlaw motorcycle clubs
column5: accused of being criminal gangs. Simon meets the most notorious and feared biker group in Australia to hear their side of the story.

column1: In the wealthy east coast suburbs
column2: he has a different kind of encounter
column3: joining a vet and his team who rescue and treat injured koalas - thousands of which are killed each year by cars and pet dogs.

column1: Arriving in Sydney
column2: Simon discovers a city of huge cultural diversity closely linked to its booming Asian neighbours
column3: India and China. One in ten Aussies are now of Asian origin. Simon gauges Australia's attitude to immigration and meets the country's first Muslim ladies Aussie rules football team.

column2: he takes to the air to witness the devastating and deadly bush fires ripping through the country

column1: 907;907;Michael Palin: Travels of a Lifetime;Series 1: Episode 4;Michael Palin recalls his fourth great journey – around and across the Sahara Desert.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08t203j.jpg;BBC
column4: Michael Palin: Travels of a Lifetime
column5: Series 1: Episode 4;Michael Palin recalls his fourth great journey – around and across the Sahara Desert.;Michael Palin revisits his fourth travel series – a journey to explore the Sahara Desert. Fans including Sir David Attenborough and Joanna Lumley reflect on his achievement;"Michael revisits his fourth - and in some ways
column6: most personal - travel series. Inspired by the apparent emptiness of the Sahara Desert as seen from a flight and by boyhood dreams of exploration
column7: Michael sets off to find out what this ‘blank space’ contains. He is delighted and inspired by the societies he encounters there – nomads
column8: refugees
column9: artists. He also confronts some harsh realities – the effects of war
column10: the migrant crisis and the rise of militant Islam. From Gibraltar
column11: Michael looks across the Mediterranean to what is for him a mysterious land – north Africa.

column1: Arriving in Fez
column3: Michael finds himself immersed in an ancient city that seems to hark back to biblical times. Then
column4: it is across the Atlas Mountains to confront the great desert itself. Here
column5: Michael encounters the more modern reality of this land in the Smara refugee camp
column6: home to displaced people from western Sahara. Then he sets his sights on one of the most alluring destinations of all - Timbuktu
column7: the city that has fascinated so many travellers down the centuries. It is a challenging trip
column8: but Michael makes it
column9: and while the reality of the place doesn’t quite match his image
column10: he learns about its extraordinary history and culture.

column1: Further on
column2: an encounter with a tribe nearly ends in disaster when a gun goes off in Michael’s face. But another tribe
column4: prove fascinating and friendly as Michael sees the men perform an extraordinary dance to attract a bride. And with the Touareg nomads
column5: Michael experiences a magical trek into deep desert as part of a camel train – a journey that allows him to make friends with his guides despite the fact that they don’t speak each other’s language. Finally
column6: Michael reflects on how his life and career have changed since then
column7: thanks to travel.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2020;59;lifestyle

column4: Obesity: The Post Mortem;A specialist pathology team conducts a post-mortem on the body of a 17-stone woman.;Documentary investigating the dangers of fat to the human body by following a pathology team as they conduct a post-mortem on a woman whose body was donated to medical science.;"Documentary revealing just how dangerous too much fat is to our most vital internal organs. The programme follows a specialist pathology team as they conduct a post-mortem on the body of a 17-stone woman whose body was donated to medical science. Their findings
column5: as they dissect the body and its organs
column6: are startling
column7: exposing the devastating impact of obesity with stunning visuals and fascinating medical facts.

column1: Morbid obesity reduces life expectancy by an average of nine years and is blamed for over 30
column2: 000 deaths in the UK every year. With 65 per cent of people already overweight or obese
column3: this extraordinary film is a powerful contribution to the debate about fat
column5: lifestyle and how the health service will cope with the growing obesity crisis.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains graphic medical scenes.;2016;55;lifestyle

column1: 913;913;Russia with Simon Reeve;Series 1: Episode 3;Simon travels from the illegally annexed peninsula of Crimea to the city of St Petersburg.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k04kq.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;Simon travels from the illegally annexed peninsula of Crimea to the city of St Petersburg.;The third and final leg of Simon's Russian journey takes him from the illegally annexed peninsula of Crimea to the historic Baltic city of St Petersburg.;"The third and final leg of Simon's Russian journey takes him from the illegally annexed peninsula of Crimea to the historic Baltic city of St Petersburg. Crimea is part of neighbouring Ukraine but was annexed by Russia in 2014. President Putin's government is investing heavily in the illegally occupied territory - building a huge bridge linking Crimea to Russia. Simon meets the eccentric and fearless owner of a safari park who likes to get up close and personal with his pride of lions. The owner is struggling to get water to his park after a canal that supplied much of Crimea's water was shut off by the Ukraine. And it is not just the lions that are affected - the diminishing water supplies are now beginning to threaten a humanitarian crisis.

column1: Travelling across Russia's vast western plains
column2: Simon discovers depopulated villages and a rural community clinging on to existence and feeling abandoned by central government. At a small cottage hospital he meets an inspiring doctor trying to protect his clinic from closure. Arriving in Moscow
column3: he meets a victim of Russia's draconian laws against protests.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2017;59;lifestyle

column1: 919;919;Why Is Covid Killing People of Colour?;None;David Harewood investigates the reasons behind health inequality in modern Britain.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p097wnhs.jpg;BBC
column4: Why Is Covid Killing People of Colour?;David Harewood investigates the reasons behind health inequality in modern Britain.;David Harewood investigates what the high Covid-19 death rates in black and minority ethnic patients reveal about health inequality in modern Britain.;"At the age of 23
column5: actor David Harewood had a psychotic breakdown
column6: a condition he later discovered was far more likely to affect black men. After the shocking news broke that black
column7: Asian and minority ethnic patients were dying in disproportionate numbers from Covid-19
column8: David felt compelled to discover the reasons why.

column1: David starts his journey in Brent
column2: north west London. During the first wave of the pandemic
column3: the borough had the highest Covid-19 mortality rate in the country. It is also one of the UK's most diverse areas
column4: where nearly 65 per cent of the local population are black
column5: Asian or from other minority ethnic groups.

column1: He visits Dr Tariq Husain
column2: head of the Intensive Care Unit at the nearby Northwick Park Hospital
column3: who describes the tidal wave of cases that overwhelmed their capacity
column4: five times more than the usual rates of admissions
column5: and the fact that people from minority communities seemed to be the hardest hit.

column1: Was this just an isolated incident? To find out
column3: a paediatric doctor and health expert
column4: who reveals that what happened in Brent is mirrored across the country. Staggeringly
column5: as a black man
column6: David is nearly three times more likely to die from Covid-19. What is it about being black that puts David at such an increased risk? Dr Singh explains that a big risk factor is the job that you do. Key workers risk their lives
column7: exposing themselves to the virus as they keep the country running.

column1: Yet people from black and minority ethnic backgrounds are more likely to do these jobs. David visits Tamira
column2: whose father was one of the first members of NHS staff to die from Covid-19. She believes not enough was done to protect him at work. A heart-wrenching but all too common story.

column1: But why do so many people from minority communities do these frontline jobs? David visits his sister Sandra in Birmingham
column2: where they both grew up. They discuss their parents’ experiences as new migrants to the UK in the 50s
column3: and how your skin colour still impacts your chances of getting a job you want. This discrimination keeps whole sections of society at the bottom of the ladder
column4: a process known as systemic racism.

column1: Moving on from how people catch Covid-19
column3: a respiratory doctor whose research shows that patients with chronic conditions such as hypertension or kidney disease are nearly twice as likely to die from Covid-19
column4: and that many patients with these conditions come from deprived areas.

column1: But how can where you live affect your health? Not just in terms of Covid-19 but a range of other diseases? David meets Andrew Grieve
column2: an air quality expert from Kings College London
column3: who reveals how air pollution can harm every organ in your body
column4: and that the lower your household income is
column5: the greater your exposure to air pollution.

column1: The consequences of this can be devastating. Rosamund Adoo-Kissi-Debrah lost her nine-year-old daughter Ella in 2013 to a fatal asthma attack. After discovering that Ella’s most severe attacks coincided with local spikes in pollution
column2: she began campaigning to get air pollution listed as a cause of her daughter’s death. In a landmark ruling in December 2020
column3: the coroner found in her favour
column4: the first time ever that air quality has been acknowledged as a cause of death in the UK.

column1: It is becoming increasingly clear to David that deprivation can have a huge impact on health
column2: and that people of colour are proportionately more likely to live in deprived conditions. But are environmental factors the only explanation for this disparity? Academic Dr Jenny Douglas shares research that black women are five times more likely to die during pregnancy and childbirth than their white counterparts
column3: and that many of the women she has interviewed for her research felt their concerns were not listened to by health professionals.

column1: David is gradually moving to the unhappy conclusion that systemic racism
column3: could be contributing to poorer health outcomes. But a radical theory developed by American professor Arline Geronimus suggests that living with racism can actually have a physiological impact on the body
column4: meaning that black patients age faster and suffer from poor health much earlier - a process she calls 'weathering'. It is a shocking revelation.

column1: Convinced that if there is to be an improvement in the health outcomes for black patients
column2: the role racism plays needs to be acknowledged
column4: the government’s minister for equalities. He wants to know why she has dismissed the idea racism might have played a role in putting black and minority ethnic communities at risk from Covid-19.

column1: He ends his journey frustrated but with some hope. The stark inequalities exposed by Covid-19 and the Black Lives Matter movement have come together at a pivotal time
column2: one he believes can be a moment of change.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 923;923;Race Across the World;Series 2: 9. Revealed;The five teams reunite to reveal fascinating insights into their experiences.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p085vrc8.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 2: 9. Revealed;The five teams reunite to reveal fascinating insights into their experiences.;The five teams reunite for the first time to reveal fascinating insights into their different strategies and individual experiences - from their highest highs to their lowest lows.;"Over 54 days
column6: five pairs of ordinary Brits took on the challenge of a lifetime and attempted to travel the entire length of Latin America
column7: from Mexico City to Ushuaia
column8: Argentina
column9: the most southerly city in the world
column10: with no planes
column11: no credit cards and no smartphones in sight. They came across extreme weather
column12: states of emergency
column13: evacuations and challenging budgets
column14: as well as life-changing encounters
column15: incredible acts of generosity and dramatic landscapes. Most of all
column16: they had to survive each other.

column1: The race may be over but the drama is still unfolding as all five teams reunite for the first time to reveal fascinating insights into their different strategies and individual experiences - from their highest highs to their lowest lows
column2: from money woes to emotional breakdowns
column3: from the hardships of travel to the kindness of strangers
column4: the emotional breakdowns and moments of self-discovery. The confessions continue as they reveal their first impressions of each other and how these changed as the competition between them grew fiercer. Has the unbreakable bond they formed as a group held strong after the race?  Or have old rivalries re-emerged? What has happened since returning to the UK? One thing is certain – the lives of all who took part have been changed for good.

column1: A truly unique
column3: behind-the-scenes look into how these intrepid travellers coped with the trials and tribulations of this incredible
column4: life-affirming race – along with some surprising revelations.";Lifestyle;BBC TWO;False;2020;59;lifestyle

column10: Colin spots signs of an even more elusive mammal. The native plants in his meadow begins to take hold
column11: attracting a new host of visitors as clouds of insects move in.

column1: Colin meets John Ross MacMathúna
column2: a young farmer who is welcoming nature onto his land. He planted his land with native oak trees and it is now a home for long-eared owls
column4: all sharing it with the family suckler herd.

column1: As Colin’s second year draws to a close
column2: he reflects on the urgent need for everyone to make space for nature. With our natural world being pushed closer and closer to the brink
column4: big or small. And in a world of overwhelming news and a sense of helplessness
column5: a project like this can offer hope.";Lifestyle;BBC ONE NORTHERN IRELAND;False;2021;29;lifestyle;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b29973.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b29973.jpg;well regular red squirrel colin spot sign even elusive mammal native plant meadow begin take hold attracting new host visitor cloud insect move colin meet john ross macmathúna young farmer welcoming nature onto land planted land native oak tree home longeared owl red squirrel pine marten sharing family suckler herd colin ’ second year draw close reflects urgent need everyone make space nature natural world pushed closer closer brink every single patch count big small world overwhelming news sense helplessness project like offer hope;8

column1: 929;929;Miriam's Dead Good Adventure;Series 1: Episode 2;Miriam Margolyes wants to know if we can ever be ready to meet death face to face.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k00cj.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 2;Miriam Margolyes wants to know if we can ever be ready to meet death face to face.;In the concluding episode of this compelling documentary series
column6: inimitable actress Miriam wants to know if we can ever be ready to meet death face to face. ;"Actress Miriam Margolyes is 77 and death is busy hoovering up her contemporaries. She has already met people who say they reject death - but what if you have no choice but to confront it? In the concluding episode of this compelling documentary series
column7: inimitable actress Miriam wants to know if we can ever be ready to meet death face to face.

column1: She heads to the west coast of Scotland to meet Tracy
column4: was working as a deputy head teacher in Oxford when she discovered she had terminal ovarian cancer. She decided to move to the remote island of Bute to live the rest of her life doing what she wanted. Now 60
column5: she has just a few months to live. The advantage of knowing you are going to die
column6: she tells Miriam
column7: is that you have time to prepare for death. Miriam helps Tracy plan her wake and meets her daughter Mathilda
column8: 19. Part of Tracy’s preparations include trying to lessen the impact her death will have on Mathilda
column9: so for the past six months Tracy has recorded a series of personal messages and irreplaceable life advice for Mathilda to follow when she is gone. Tracy’s frank and forthright approach to dealing with cancer strikes a chord with Miriam
column10: who is keen to meet people who can talk about the reality of dying without sugar-coating the pill.

column1: Tracy’s openness offers up some surprising and comforting thoughts for Miriam. If you are going to try and prepare for death
column3: maybe it helps to take matters in to your own hands? In Hastings
column4: Miriam hooks up with celebrants Kate and Kate who run Coffin Club
column5: a monthly meet-up for people seeking emotional and practical support for all things death related
column6: including building and decorating their own coffins. Within minutes Miriam is slotting her own flat pack coffin together and painting her unique design on the lid.

column1: Getting to grips with death helps Miriam realise that our end of days doesn’t have to be as scary as she feared
column2: but for some people confronting the terrors of dying requires more extreme measures. In San Francisco
column3: Miriam accompanies Carolyn to the doctors. Following the sudden death of her partner
column4: for the last six months Carolyn has undergone a controversial treatment using psychedelic drugs to help overcome her fear of dying. Dr Phil Wolfson
column5: a pioneer in hallucinogenic psychotherapy
column6: has been treating her end of life anxiety with the horse tranquiliser and recreational party drug ketamine. Illegal unless administered by a doctor
column7: Dr Phil believes that whilst under the influence of the drug
column8: Carolyn’s mind can be transported and her anxieties reduced. Having seen Carolyn’s fears diffused
column9: Miriam starts to wonder if ketamine might be a way to focus less on her ego and instead trust that everything will be fine when she dies with her body and soul melding back in to the cosmos. But preparing for death also means having to accept none of us know when it will come. For some people end of life plans involve more than just building your own coffin and choosing sandwich fillings. Some want to choose when and how they go.

column1: In Amsterdam
column3: aka maverick doctor Philip Nitschke. He runs the controversial right to die movement Exit International
column4: which campaigns for all rational people over 50 to have the right to end their lives peacefully at a time of their choosing. Although assisted suicide is legal in the Netherlands it requires convincing a doctor of the necessity. In his laboratory
column5: Dr Nitschke demos his latest invention for Miriam - a prototype suicide pod called a Sarco. Witnessing the sarcophagus-style tank fill up with deadly nitrogen
column6: Miriam hears his plans to roll out his invention to willing members of the general public within the next two years
column7: with hopes that his machine will be the perfect
column8: peaceful way for people to take control of their deaths.

column1: Although an intellectual supporter of the idea of assisted suicide
column2: Miriam worries Dr Nitschke’s vision might be cheapening life and make death too easy. Going along to one of his workshops
column3: she talks to those attending; from people with painful terminal illnesses to others who just want the choice to opt out. They are not not anti-life
column5: they are just anti-life at any price.

column1: But what about people who shouldn’t be thinking about the end of their life at all? Tyreese
column3: is an 18-year-old rapper with bowel and liver cancer. He is determinedly not thinking about ending his life or even preparing for death. He is choosing to fight it. Miriam recites a heartfelt rap Tyreese has written about his illness. Despite his optimism she worries that death maybe too big even for him to control. As an aspiring footballer before he became ill
column4: Tyreese takes Miriam to watch a local game where she realises that it is Tyreese’s positivity that allows him to cling on to hope.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2019;59;lifestyle

column1: 930;930;Inside the Bruderhof;None;The story of an unusual village in Sussex where there’s no crime
column5: Inside the Bruderhof;The story of an unusual village in Sussex where there’s no crime
column6: debt or homelessness.;In a Sussex village
column7: a community has turned its back on the modern world to live a life free of money
column8: crime and homelessness. But one young resident is questioning her future.;"In one picturesque village in Sussex
column9: life is very different. There’s no crime
column10: debt or homelessness
column11: everyone has a job but no-one earns a wage
column12: and none of the children watch television
column13: use social media
column14: play video games or have a mobile phone.

column1: With unique access to this historically private community
column2: this film enters the remarkable village of Darvell
column3: where for almost 50 years an extraordinary radical Christian community
column5: has lived outside mainstream society. The film holds a mirror up to modern Britain
column6: with its consumerist concerns
column7: high crime and deprivation rates
column8: and looks at this community's simple way of life
column9: while also exploring the personal costs and sacrifices required to live there.

column1: Hannah
column2: Bernard and Hardy are part of the 300-strong village of brothers and sisters living as disciples of Jesus. Bernard
column3: his wife Rachel and their three children live a ‘back to basics’ lifestyle in a shared house with several other families
column4: including Bernard’s parents. Most of their meals are taken with the other residents in a large communal dining room where they eat
column5: sing and worship together.

column1: Outgoing and inquisitive
column2: Hannah is questioning this way of life. At 18
column3: she wants to experience life outside the community she was born into before making a lifelong commitment. The film follows her extraordinary journey as she leaves her family and the familiarity of this closeted community behind
column4: and makes her way to the big city – London. But whilst Hannah experiences the independence of her first paid job
column5: she also begins to question both the Bruderhof way of life and her experiences in mainstream society.

column1: As a teenager
column2: Hardy became acutely aware of the sacrifices members of the Bruderhof have to make. Together with his five siblings

column1: rebelled against the ideals of the community
column3: his family left the Bruderhof and began a new life outside. Hardy has since returned to the community
column4: accepting that a life there is one of sacrifice – not only surrendering all possessions and money
column5: but something greater: giving up personal ambition and the freedom to make his own decisions. Whilst Hardy and Bernard are happy to make this commitment for a greater cause
column6: will the fresh opportunities that Hannah is discovering in the city tempt her away?

column4: Too Fat For Love;A no-holds-barred look into the world of plus-sized love and sex.;21-year-old Emma takes a no-holds-barred look into the world of plus-sized love and sex by asking questions that everyone may be curious about but are too embarrassed to ask.;"21-year-old Emma takes a no-holds-barred look into the world of plus-sized love and sex by asking questions that everyone may be curious about but are too embarrassed to ask.

column1: If Emma believed everything she read in the media
column4: she was simply too big for romance. Not only are there almost no positive role models for “big love” in popular culture
column5: often there is actual hate.

column1: Emma is introduced to the extraordinary Athena May
column3: who performs a masterclass in plus-size sex at an “erotic emporium” in east London.

column1: Emma wonders whether the dating game is any easier for men so she chats to members of a plus-size football league to find out. Despite her self confidence
column2: Emma admits that she still has some hang-ups about her body image so in an attempt to face her demons head-on
column3: she quite literally bares it all.

column1: Her journey ends in London
column2: where she discovers the wonders of a plus-size club night - at last
column3: an oasis in an often hostile dating jungle.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and some sexual content.;2018;17;lifestyle

column7: which Kerie and Dave dream of renovating into a B&B .

column5: Series 7: 6. The Hulme Family;Featuring a family who are stuck in a food rut due to their young son’s food allergies. ;Gregg and Chris head to Cardiff to meet a family who are stuck in a food rut due to their seven-year-old son’s serious food allergies. ;"Gregg and Chris head to Cardiff to meet Steph and Matt
column6: parents to seven-year-old William and four-year-old Alex
column7: with another baby on the way. Matt and Steph are stuck in a food rut due to William’s serious food allergies.

column1: Following an anaphylactic reaction at the age of three
column4: sesame seeds and flax seeds. As a result
column5: the family are brand-loyal to particular products that they know William can safely eat
column6: and they are understandably scared to try new ingredients and foods. Having to check the ingredients on every packet means this family buy and cook the same meals for their two boys every week. Steph and Matt love Asian flavours and dishes
column7: but because of William's allergies they often end up cooking multiple meals. Gregg and Chris are determined to get the family sharing the same meals and the boys eating more veg.

column1: Chris does some research into food allergies and shows us the main allergens to be aware of
column2: while Gregg has a quick and easy recipe up his sleeve that is free of the 14 main allergens. Chris visits Hastings to find out more about a British fish we should all be eating more of
column3: and staff in a Japanese restaurant put five reduced-salt soy sauces to the test to find out which they think is the tastiest.";Food;BBC ONE;False;2021;57;lifestyle

column1: 936;936;Miriam’s Big Fat Adventure;Series 1: Episode 2;With fat threatening to break the NHS
column2: Miriam Margolyes looks at the obesity crisis.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p085rqdq.jpg;BBC
column5: Miriam’s Big Fat Adventure
column6: Series 1: Episode 2;With fat threatening to break the NHS
column7: Miriam Margolyes looks at the obesity crisis.;With fat threatening to break the NHS
column8: Miriam Margolyes continues looking at the obesity crisis and discovers a world of extremes.;"With obesity-related illnesses like high blood pressure
column9: type 2 diabetes and certain cancers costing the NHS over six billion a year
column10: Miriam Margolyes sets out to find out what is being done to combat the obesity crisis and meets people who are going to extreme and sometimes controversial lengths to lose weight.

column1: To understand the true cost of the epidemic
column4: Angela’s leg was amputated. Her weight meant she needed a knee operation
column5: which led to a sepsis infection. Stuck at home
column6: relying on carers to wash
column7: dress and feed her
column8: Angela’s weight upended her life.

column1: It is not just the current generation that need to heed the warning – with statistics predicting the next generation will be the most obese ever
column2: Miriam learns of the latest government initiative. Across the country
column3: primary school children are being weighed and measured
column4: with the obese invited to attend a 12-week course to improve diet and encourage exercise.

column1: Miriam sits in with Emma
column2: from the Live Lighter weight management team in Sheffield. Emma has the unenviable task of cold-calling parents to suggest their child attends the programme. It is no easy task but at least it is addressing the issue
column3: and Miriam wishes it had been available when she was younger. Keen to know what life is like for a child who is overweight today
column4: Miriam meets up with ten-year-old Claudia. Claudia tells Miriam she ‘knows what it’s like to be judged’. Her accounts of her weight struggles and secret eating have a familiar ring as Miriam realises she has met her mini me. Claudia’s parents worry about name-calling and feel responsible but
column5: as Miriam tells them
column6: the blame game is an easy one.

column1: When Miriam was a kid
column2: before Deliveroo and the advent of the all-you-can-eat buffet
column3: she felt people didn’t worry so much about what they looked like – now so many seem to struggle with weight and body image. To discover why
column4: Miriam enters an extreme world of weight loss
column5: meeting people who have taken controversial steps to cut their weight and their bodies to a more desirable size. Jess was 23 stone – but after NHS weight loss surgery to cut her stomach in half and dramatically reduce the amount she can eat
column6: her weight is plummeting
column7: and she is closer to her Beyoncé-shaped dream body. In Chester
column8: Dr Kerrigan
column9: a leading weight-loss surgeon
column10: explains to Miriam that with the NHS spending a million pounds an hour treating diabetes
column11: this surgery not only helps people lose weight but could save the health service millions in the long run. Jess eats miniscule amounts of food and is on course to lose around a stone a month until she plateaus around ten stone. It is hard for Miriam to process – something clearly needs to be done and surgery may be a short cut to being healthier but is it a short cut to being happier? Miriam can’t help but wonder what psychological effect such an extreme change in eating has.

column1: Jess’s friend Sammy had bariatric surgery two years ago. She has lost over half her body weight but it has left her with excess skin
column2: which she is saving up to have removed. Despite dropping from 16 to eight stone
column3: Sammy tells Miriam she has developed body dysmorphia
column4: meaning she sometimes fails to see herself as slim. As Miriam watches Sammy pick at tiny amounts of the topping on her pizza
column5: most of which she can’t eat or she will be sick
column6: Miriam ponders if striving for a slimmer body should be at any cost.

column1: Bariatric surgery doesn’t appeal to Miriam
column2: who wonders if there is another way. She heads to meet people who have achieved sculpted bodies without surgery
column3: through a regimen of strict diet and exercise. Aeronn has lost four stone in just 25 weeks and is now so happy with his body he feels ready to be judged. He invites Miriam to the Welsh Natural Body Building championships in Newport
column4: where he is competing. Miriam wonders if body perfection is the dream
column5: will everyone she meets be blissfully happy? She soon gets her answer. Bart is only 16 but despite having an impressive physique
column6: he wants bigger arms and more muscle and tells Miriam he does bodybuilding to make him feel better about himself.

column1: Miriam starts to wonder if our search for body perfection is just swapping one obsession for another in search of an unobtainable dream. Back home
column2: she re-evaluates her own life. She is overweight
column4: but she is loved by her partner
column5: had doting parents and has good friends
column6: so
column7: despite being 'fat at 78'
column8: maybe she has done ok on the important stuff. Worried young people will struggle to grow up happy facing pressure from social media to conform to certain body types
column9: Miriam heads back to see Claudia
column10: her mini me
column11: at her birthday party to tell her what she has learnt.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2020;58;lifestyle

column6: the final part of Miracle of Bali shows a recital of music and dancing from the Balinese village of Peliatan.;First transmitted in 1969
column7: the final part of Miracle of Bali is a treat for fans of traditional Balinese music and dancing.Narrated by David Attenborough the programme consists of performances filmed in Peliatan linked by an appropriately illustrative detail from Balinese paintings.There are recitals by four musical ensembles featuring bamboo xylophones
column8: jaw harps
column9: bamboo shakers and metallophones. The dances shown include the Tumulilingan Mengisap Sari (the bumblebee sips honey)
column10: the Baris (warrior dance) and the Kecak (monkey dance).;Music;BBC WEBONLY;False;1969;37;lifestyle

column2: tendons and ligaments to turn to bone.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k01wf.jpg;BBC
column5: Living Differently
column6: Series 5: 6. I’m 23 And Turning To Stone;Carli has a disease that has caused her muscles
column7: tendons and ligaments to turn to bone.;Carli has a condition known as Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva (FOP) that has caused her muscles
column8: tendons and ligaments to turn to bone
column9: fusing her into a ‘frozen’ position.;"Carli has a disease that is ‘turning her into stone.’ The incredibly rare condition known as Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva (FOP) has caused Carli’s muscles
column10: tendons and ligaments to turn to bone
column11: fusing her into a ‘frozen’ position. Carli’s hip has locked
column12: forcing her to stand on one leg.

column1: This intimate film shows how Carli battles with intense pain on a daily basis and has already lost significant mobility throughout her body. We see how she struggles to eat
column2: because her jaw now only opens 2mm. There is currently no cure for FOP but Carli is participating in a clinical trial to help treat the condition. But despite slowly turning into a human statue
column3: Carli is refusing to let the condition stop her from moving in with her boyfriend and living life to the full whilst she can.";Lifestyle;BBC THREE;False;2019;8;lifestyle

column5: one of Instagram’s first super-influencers.;"The shocking story of the rise and fall of one of Instagram’s first super-influencers. By 23
column6: Australian wellness guru Belle Gibson had cultivated an adoring global following online with the story that she had successfully treated her own terminal cancer by eating a plant-based diet and using alternative natural therapies. But there was one problem with Belle’s story: she had never had cancer.

column1: Seen through the eyes of those who adored her and those who exposed her
column2: this film lifts the lid on one of social media’s great mysteries: who was the real Belle Gibson – an ingenious con artist or damaged young woman trapped in a lie?";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2021;45;lifestyle

column5: Summer 2021: Episode 15;Thorn the giraffe is having problem with his overgrown hooves.;Thorn the giraffe is having problems with his hooves
column6: but for the vet to get close enough to fix them
column7: he needs to be within kicking distance of the giant animal.;"Thorn the giraffe is an elder statesman of the park and has a reputation for a fiery temper and grumpy demeanour. But as animals get older
column8: they come to rely on their keepers more. Thorn is having problems with his hooves
column9: which have become overgrown. For the vet to get close enough to treat Thorn's hooves
column10: the keepers need to train Thorn to lift his foot on command. Can the keepers train this giant giraffe without getting in the way of a potentially killer kick?

column1: Elsewhere in the park
column2: another team of vets are preparing to perform a procedure on a pair of male reindeer. They need to have their antlers removed before the new growth starts
column3: and it’s a physically demanding job. Reindeer antlers are incredibly tough and need to be sawn off by hand while the animal is sedated. Working on two animals at the same time is a big challenge and requires teamwork between the keepers and the vets
column4: but no anaesthetic is without risk
column5: and one of the reindeer has not responded well to the drugs in the past. Will the two reindeer come through the operation this time?

column5: 3. The End of the Affair;A look at the public response to the impact of motorways on town and country.;Documentary series about Britain's motorways. This final episode explores how people questioned the promises made by the motorways and began to protest.;"When the first motorways opened they did so to national celebration. But after the first 1
column6: 000 miles had been built
column7: their impact on both town and country was becoming apparent and people started to protest.

column1: Middle England rose up and disrupted public inquiries to voice their frustration at motorway building
column2: but it continued and over time the frustration gave way to concerns about saving the planet. In the early 1990s that meant young people willing to risk everything to stop the motorways being built. The programme shows how people began to question the promises made by the motorway
column3: and along the way found their voice of protest.";History;BBC FOUR;Contains some strong language.;2007;59;lifestyle

column4: Chris Packham: The Walk That Made Me;Chris Packham explores his past as he walks a familiar path in the Hampshire countryside.;Chris Packham explores his past as he walks a familiar path in the Hampshire countryside. Chris cut his teeth as a naturalist in this beautiful corner of England.;"Chris Packham explores his past as he walks a familiar path in the Hampshire countryside. Chris cut his teeth as a naturalist in this beautiful corner of England. The journey evokes intimate memories from his childhood.

column1: Wandering along the River Itchen and Itchen Navigation
column2: Chris explains the importance of natural surroundings when it comes to our wellbeing. His journey stirs up powerful and difficult memories from his own struggles with mental health issues. Walking with a hand-held 360-degree camera
column4: starting a few miles outside Southampton and ending up at Winchester Cathedral. Following the path of one the oldest waterways in the country
column5: he meets those who live
column6: work and play in the area.

column1: Chris discusses the joy that water brings to wild swimmers. He also observes local enthusiasts as they maintain centuries-old farming practices by flooding a local meadow. Along the way he reveals some of the difficulties of living with Asperger’s Syndrome and offers thoughts on mental health that may help others.";Documentary;BBC ONE SOUTH;False;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 964;964;The Repair Shop;Series 4 (Shortened Versions): Episode 18;The team restore a faded village war memorial
column2: a 1960s one-armed bandit and a teddy bear.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p086sn7s.jpg;BBC
column5: The Repair Shop
column6: Series 4 (Shortened Versions): Episode 18;The team restore a faded village war memorial
column7: a 1960s one-armed bandit and a teddy bear.;Jay Blades and the team restore a faded village war memorial
column8: an iconic 1960s one-armed bandit and a much-loved teddy bear whose lifelong owner recently passed away.;"Jay Blades and the team bring three treasured family heirlooms
column9: and the memories they hold
column10: back to life.

column1: Dominic Chinea takes on a repair of huge significance to the residents of the village of Norton in Northamptonshire: a faded and misshapen wooden memorial board recording the names of all the men of the village who served in the First World War. Sadly
column2: the names have eroded over time
column3: and many are no longer legible. With the centenary of the 1918 armistice looming
column4: the villagers would dearly love to see the names of the fallen restored so that they can be honoured for years to come. Dom is apprehensive about taking on such an important and time-sensitive repair
column5: but relishes the opportunity to get out his gold leaf kit and bring the faded names back to life.

column1: Maxine Frodsham arrives at the workshop with a dearly loved teddy bear for the attention of toy restoration duo Amanda and Julie. The bear belonged to Maxine’s stepfather Ian
column2: for whom he was a constant companion right from the day he was born over 60 years ago. Sadly
column4: and Maxine and the rest of his family are desperate to see his much-loved plaything restored as a fitting tribute to Ian’s memory.

column1: And ‘Pinball Geoff’ Harvey works his magic on an iconic German-built one-armed bandit that owner Freyja Burrell has treasured ever since she was given it by her father
column3: these machines were highly popular in the 1960s
column4: and this particular example held Freyja enthralled throughout her childhood. But now it is jammed up and non-functioning
column5: and Geoff has his work cut out to get the reels spinning again
column6: to be enjoyed by a brand new generation of Burrells.";Lifestyle;BBC ONE;False;2022;29;lifestyle;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p086sn7s.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p086sn7s.jpg;jay blade team bring three treasured family heirloom memory hold back life dominic chinea take repair huge significance resident village norton northamptonshire faded misshapen wooden memorial board recording name men village served first world war sadly name eroded time many longer legible centenary 1918 armistice looming villager would dearly love see name fallen restored honoured year come dom apprehensive taking important timesensitive repair relish opportunity get gold leaf kit bring faded name back life maxine frodsham arrives workshop dearly loved teddy bear attention toy restoration duo amanda julie bear belonged maxine ’ stepfather ian constant companion right day born 60 year ago sadly ian passed away recently maxine rest family desperate see muchloved plaything restored fitting tribute ian ’ memory ‘ pinball geoff ’ harvey work magic iconic germanbuilt onearmed bandit owner freyja burrell treasured ever since given father aged 4 known beromats machine highly popular 1960s particular example held freyja enthralled throughout childhood jammed nonfunctioning geoff work cut get reel spinning enjoyed brand new generation burrells;16

column1: 965;965;Surgeons: At the Edge of Life;Series 4: Episode 6;The major trauma team have just minutes to perform life-saving medical interventions.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b1qvq5.jpg;BBC
column4: Surgeons: At the Edge of Life
column5: Series 4: Episode 6;The major trauma team have just minutes to perform life-saving medical interventions.;Addenbrooke’s major trauma team and surgeons treat some of the country's most critically injured patients. Multiple teams must decide whether a man's damaged arm can be saved.;"The major trauma team in Addenbrooke's are up against the clock to treat some of the country's most critically injured patients. Chef Adrian is rushed to hospital in the early hours of the morning after crashing his motorbike at high speed
column6: trapping his arm between the crash barrier and impaling his abdomen with a piece of metal. Having lost a third of his circulating blood
column7: Adrian is in a critical condition when he arrives in the trauma department’s resus bay with potential internal haemorrhaging along with the threat of losing a limb.

column1: Led by Dr Mariam Imam
column2: a specialist major trauma team rapidly assembles to assess the external damage before Adrian is sent to CT to see if the metal has pierced any vital organs. The scan very quickly rules this out
column3: so all attention turns to his arm and hand
column4: which are so badly mangled that his hand is potentially beyond repair. Emergency surgeons assess the arm and rush Adrian to theatre so that consultant plastic and hand surgeon Alex Reid can explore the extent of the damage. After determining that there is decent blood supply to the hand
column5: Adrian’s limb is stabilised until he can undergo further surgery.

column1: Forty-eight hours later
column2: Adrian is brought back to theatre with consultant plastic and hand surgeon Ian Grant. He and his surgical colleagues must decide whether they can save Adrian's hand.

column1: Back in the emergency department
column2: the major trauma team prepare for the arrival of another injured patient
column3: a 25-year-old man transferred to Addenbrooke's from hospital in Colchester. Cawley has been assaulted and after hitting his head on the pavement has a life-threatening bleed on the brain. Having been assessed at Colchester
column4: Cawley was put in an induced coma to control the build-up of pressure within his brain and then transferred to Addenbrooke's
column5: which has the trauma specialists he needs for treatment.

column1: At Addenbrooke's
column3: with consultant Angelos Kolias and senior registrar Harry Bulstrode
column4: are on standby to perform an emergency craniotomy to remove the build-up of blood within Cawley’s brain.

column1: Back down in resus
column2: the red phone alerts the team of another incoming patient who has been involved in a head-on car accident. Thirty nine-year-old Sarah has been significantly injured in a high-impact collision which has left her with a broken leg and fractured c-spine. If Sarah doesn’t receive emergency care
column3: the spine fracture could become dislodged and sever the spinal cord
column4: leaving her paralysed from the neck down.

column1: With an injury threatening the spinal cord
column2: Dr Sarah Hazelman and a team of trauma doctors immediately arrange for a CT scan to assess the severity of the fracture. After seeing that the fracture is stable
column3: priorities rapidly switch when the scan picks up that a shard of bone from her broken leg is pressing on an artery
column4: which could lead to severe complications and the loss of Sarah's foot if the blood flow is not quickly restored.

column1: On-call trauma and orthopaedic surgeon Hassan Fawi has to act rapidly to reset Sarah's leg and restore the flow of blood. Only then can the attention return to the fractured neck
column2: which needs to be kept stable.

column1: Two days after the accident
column2: consultant orthopaedic spinal surgeon Doug Hay has to carefully rebuild the broken vertebrae in Sarah's neck using a small piece of bone from her hip along with a titanium plate to secure the join. Without the operation
column4: but there is also a risk of causing permanent damage to the spinal cord during the operation itself.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains upsetting scenes.;2021;59;lifestyle

column1: 966;966;Joey Essex: Grief and Me;None;Can Joey Essex heal the grief he has kept inside for 20 years?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09jjmyl.jpg;BBC
column4: Joey Essex: Grief and Me;Can Joey Essex heal the grief he has kept inside for 20 years?;At age ten
column5: Joey Essex's world was ripped apart when his mum tragically took her own life. Having long buried his emotions
column6: after 20 years can he come to terms with his grief?;"After ten years in the reality TV spotlight
column7: it might appear that everything in Joey Essex’s life is ‘reem’. But fame and a luxury lifestyle haven’t been able to heal the grief he has kept inside for 20 years. Now
column8: as he turns 30
column9: Joey wants to embark on a deeply personal journey to take stock of his life and
column10: for the sake of his future
column11: finally confront his past.

column1: Every year
column3: 00 young people lose a parent in the UK. At the age of just ten
column4: Joey's world was ripped apart when his mum tragically took her own life. Unable to comprehend the loss
column5: Joey has spent the next 20 years of his life burying his grief. He has kept his emotions hidden
column6: rarely spoken about his mother and avoided having pictures of her in his home. But now
column7: as he leaves his twenties behind
column8: he is ready to confront his trauma so he can move forward with his life.

column1: With the help of a clinical psychologist
column3: Joey sets out to finally face the impact his beloved mother’s death has had on him. Up until now
column4: he has only really opened up about his childhood with his family
column5: but even his sister Frankie and cousin Chloe recognise that he has never truly processed his feelings or fully faced his bereavement. Opening up to a psychologist and learning to trust Stephen will be a tough first step.

column1: From talking about his emotions to putting more pictures of his mum around his house and finding a way of coping with his anxiety
column2: Joey is determined to face his fears head on. After an unsure start and trust issues threaten to derail the process
column3: he realises that to be able to move on with his life he has to look back at his past. But after 20 years of living this way
column4: can Joey Essex really come to terms with his grief?";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2021;59;lifestyle

column5: Series 1: Episode 20;A Swiss clock and a collection of skateboards are transformed.;A Swiss clock that caused a honeymooning couple’s first argument 40 years ago and a collection of skateboards in need of a new purpose are among the radical transformations.;"40 years ago
column6: David and Marion bought a Swiss clock as a souvenir on their honeymoon. Its price led to their first argument
column7: and over the years Marion has been tempted to throw it out
column8: as it is no longer used. But they would like it to become something practical that would remind them of a special time together. Metal sculptor Leigh and carpentry expert Shelley offer rival designs for them to choose between: a transformation into a stunning piece of furniture or an artwork to celebrate their ruby anniversary.

column1: Kierhardy cruises into the workshop in his campervan – not for its transformation but because inside it are several old skateboards. Kierhardy is passionate about skateboarding and combines it with youth work in his community. Metals expert Titch has a radical idea for the skateboards that he hopes will impress everyone down at the skatepark.
And Shelley has a special project of her own to work on. The woodwork specialist’s wife Mags lost her mum recently
column2: and Shelley wants to do something that will give them both something to remember her by. Two old vintage cameras that belonged to Mags’s mum are no longer used
column3: but they captured a lifetime of travels and adventures. Shelley designs beautiful pieces of art that bring the cameras back into focus.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2021;29;lifestyle;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09bh31k.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09bh31k.jpg;40 year ago david marion bought swiss clock souvenir honeymoon price led first argument year marion tempted throw longer used would like become something practical would remind special time together metal sculptor leigh carpentry expert shelley offer rival design choose transformation stunning piece furniture artwork celebrate ruby anniversary kierhardy cruise workshop campervan – transformation inside several old skateboard kierhardy passionate skateboarding combine youth work community metal expert titch radical idea skateboard hope impress everyone skatepark shelley special project work woodwork specialist ’ wife mag lost mum recently shelley want something give something remember two old vintage camera belonged mag ’ mum longer used captured lifetime travel adventure shelley design beautiful piece art bring camera back focus;13

column5: Series 2: 3. Debi and Des;Debi and Des want their sloped garden to be transformed into a relaxing family area.;Debi and Des want their uninspiring sloped garden to be transformed into a relaxing space that the whole family can enjoy. Will designers Oliver Bond and Helen Elks-Smith be up to the task?;"Debi and Des live in Enfield
column6: London. Their beautiful family home has a generous urban plot
column7: but it sits on a massive slope that is currently only used as an outdoor exercise space for Des
column8: whose studio gym sits at the end of the garden. Debi would like a space she can relax in after a hard day's work
column9: but the real dream would be transforming the plot into a family space for everyone to enjoy. Having stared out at their uninspiring plot for years
column10: Debi and Des are desperate for a solution.

column1: Stepping up to help are award-winning garden designers Oliver Bond and Helen Elks-Smith. Oliver has got big ideas on how to identify and define new zones in the space
column2: whilst Helen finds an unexpected sweet spot right in the heart of the plot. Using virtual reality
column3: both designers pitch their radically different approaches. Either one would be a perfect fit
column4: but which will the couple choose?";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;59;lifestyle
