Around 1 in 10 adults hear voices in their heads as a result of a number of mental illnesses
column5: including schizophrenia.

column1: Kyle started hearing a voice after he lost his job
column2: house and girlfriend in quick succession
column3: he then attacked himself. As Kyle tries to control the voice
column4: he has to come to terms with the possibility that he may have to get used to life with it.

column1: Emmalina has been hearing a collection of voices since she was a child and has found that by welcoming them in
column2: they can all live relatively peacefully - except when the voice of 'the devil' appears. After traumatic experiences earlier in her life
column3: the voices have become a source of comfort and companionship
column4: but they have also made her more isolated. We follow Emmalina as she strives to become more independent.

column1: After four years Chaz is still fighting her voice
column2: which keeps up a steady stream of abuse in Chaz's ear. She has jumped off a bridge twice
column3: leaving her reliant on a wheelchair - but still she feels drawn back to a nearby bridge. The film follows her attempts to resist
column4: as she looks to poetry as a way to cope.";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2018;48;lifestyle

column6: Series 1: Episode 4;Simon travels across the sea to Spain
column7: and on to Corsica and the French Riviera.;Simon Reeve embarks on the fourth and final leg of his journey around the Mediterranean
column8: travelling from Morocco
column9: across the sea to Spain
column10: and on to Corsica and the French Riviera.;"Simon Reeve embarks on the fourth and final leg of his epic four-part journey around the Mediterranean. Taking a ferry across the Strait of Gibraltar
column11: Simon's first stop is Ceuta
column12: a Spanish exclave surrounded by Morocco. This is one of the few land borders between Africa and the European Union. Simon joins the Spanish border police who check engines and even dashboards for stowaways trying to reach Europe. Migrant and refugees attempting to cross Ceuta's fortress border have quadrupled in the last year. Undaunted by Morocco's failure to issue a filming permit
column13: Simon crosses the border as a tourist
column14: tracking down a group of young migrants hiding out in a forest close to Ceuta. They have travelled thousands of miles
column15: crossing the Sahara to get this far
column16: and now they are just a 20-foot
column17: razor wire fence away from their European dream.

column1: Crossing the Med to Spain
column2: one the busiest shipping lanes in the world
column3: Simon discovers huge numbers of dolphins and even giant whales surviving by dodging the ferries
column4: container ships and oil tankers. Travelling along the arid southern Spanish coast
column5: Simon takes to air to witness the sea of plastic that form over a hundred square miles of greenhouses. It is where much of our supermarket fruit and veg are grown
column6: but as Simon discovers it is a massive industry built on the back of a low paid
column7: migrant workforce. Following in the footsteps of four million Brits who make the journey every year
column8: Simon travels to the Costa Blanca and its most famous resort
column9: Benidorm. Derided by many
column10: Simon is surprised to learn that high-rise Benidorm is now being hailed by experts as a model of sustainable tourism. The Mediterranean region attracts a third of world tourism and visitor numbers are predicted to rise to half a billion a year by the end of the next decade. Simon travels to a western corner of Corsica
column11: a nature reserve that must be one of the most heavily protected bits of sea on earth
column12: and one of the few places where tourists are actively discouraged from visiting. Lying on the beach
column13: hiking in the mountains and watersport activities are all banned. The park's manager shows Simon the results
column14: taking him for a dive in the fishiest place in the Med. In a sea where over ninety percent of fish stocks are over exploited
column15: it is a beacon of hope in what is otherwise an uncertain future for the Mediterranean.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2018;59;lifestyle

column6: Iain Robertson is joined by musician Paul Anderson and actor Joanne Gallagher as they celebrate Scotland's landscape.;"Packing in as much as he possibly can into the final third of the 131-mile Speyside Way walk
column7: Iain Robertson celebrates the river’s whisky tradition
column8: fairy walks and even one of his favourite Scottish landmarks.

column1: Heading out of Ballindalloch
column2: Iain is joined by musician Paul Anderson
column3: who teases Iain with the promise of a tune on the fiddle if he manages the extra few miles past Aberlour to Craigellachie Bridge. Paul explains that the River Spey is the fastest flowing river in the British Isles despite its deceptively gentle look. As they head across bouncy bridges and past the smell of the whisky mash
column4: they take the decision to push on to Craigellachie bridge
column5: where Paul treats Iain to a tune dedicated to the brig.

column1: The next day sees Iain stunned and cheered as he unexpectedly catches a glimpse of the sea. From his vantage point
column2: he watches the River Spey snake its way through Morayshire and join the Moray Firth into the North Sea. Buoyed by this
column3: he pushes forward on his adventure towards Fochabers
column4: knowing that the next day he will be following the Spey all the way to the sea. Finally reaching the coast
column5: Iain realises that this is a moment he will never forget as his achievement begins to sink in.

column1: Although this may be a fitting point to end his adventure
column2: Iain pushes on and joins the Moray Coast Trail
column3: heading towards Cullen before eventually making it to Buckie. He enjoys another slight diversion before starting his final day with a ramble along a fairy path
column4: spotting small fairy houses that have been erected on the path up to Craigmin Bridge.

column1: As he returns to Buckie
column2: he is joined by actor and playwright Joanne Gallagher for the last few miles of his journey. The walking on this stretch offers outstanding views of Scotland’s coast
column3: but Iain is keen to push forward to enjoy some time at Bow Fiddle Rock
column4: one of his favourite spots. Soon after

column8: the Belfast-born former President of Ireland

column11: and to us
column12: and assesses the role it could yet play in sustaining peace.

column5: and tackles the stigmas
column6: myths and misunderstandings surrounding HIV.;"Rugby legend Gareth Thomas lifts the lid on living with HIV. In an emotional and hard-hitting documentary he finally goes public about his condition and reveals how hiding the truth about his health left him feeling depressed and contemplating taking his own life.

column1: Now he is on a journey to change perceptions about HIV by raising awareness
column2: fighting prejudice and taking on the biggest physical challenge of his career - running the world’s toughest Iron Man.

column1: With the help of family
column3: medical experts and others with HIV
column4: he sets about tackling the stigmas
column5: myths and misunderstandings surrounding the condition. Modern medicine may have made the virus treatable and non-transmittable
column6: but old ideas about HIV still persist and Gareth is on a mission to smash the stereotypes and show that 'he has HIV and it’s OK'.";Documentary;BBC ONE WALES;Contains strong language.;2019;60;lifestyle

column4: Kevin Sinfield: The Extra Mile;Follow Kevin Sinfield's 101-mile charity run for those living with motor neurone disease.;"Follow Kevin Sinfield's 101-mile charity run for his friend and former Leeds Rhino teammate Rob Burrow and others living with motor neurone disease.

column1: ;On 22 November 2021
column2: Kevin Sinfield set off on his Extra Mile Challenge. The aim
column3: to run 101 miles from the home of Leicester Tigers to the home of Leeds Rhinos for his friend and former teammate Rob Burrow and others living with motor neurone disease.

column1: He did it in 24 hours with no sleep. Hoards of friends and fans lined the streets to show their support and Rob and his family were there to meet him.
Kevin was aiming to raise £100
column3: which will be split equally between the MND Association and the appeal to build The Rob Burrow Centre for Motor Neurone Disease in Leeds. At the time of making this programme

column1: BBC Breakfast followed the story.

992;992;Britain's Puppy Boom: Counting the Cost;None;Vet Fabian Rivers reveals how the boom in buying puppies is impacting animal welfare.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09pdhq3.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Britains Puppy Boom: Counting the Cost;Vet Fabian Rivers reveals how the boom in buying puppies is impacting animal welfare.;Vet Fabian Rivers reveals how the popularity of bullies and frenchies has triggered a boom in canine fertility courses, one of which is teaching illegal practices to amateurs.;Vet Fabian Rivers reveals how the pandemic has triggered a boom in demand for puppies
column3: frenchies and dachshunds. He investigates the complex worlds of these three dog breeds
column4: explores why there is a boom in people buying and breeding ‘popular’ dogs
column5: questions whether it is causing an animal welfare crisis and asks what can be done to help alleviate the problems?

column1: Fabian has witnessed the puppy boom first-hand through his work at a small animal's veterinary practice in Birmingham. The huge increase in the numbers of people wanting to buy a puppy has resulted in prices going up
column2: which in turn has led to more people breeding dogs and has boosted the relatively new canine fertility industry
column3: with a proliferation of canine fertility clinics offering artificial insemination services for dogs and new training courses that teach people how to do artificial insemination themselves.

column1: Fabian explores the huge price tags for some puppies and what draws people to these popular breeds
column2: unpacks some of the hereditary health and welfare issues the breeds face
column3: and he hears from the Dogs Trust that many puppies bought online are being illegally imported to the UK
column4: requiring tighter regulations needed to improve the situation. Fabian also meets some prospective owners
column5: introducing them to the RSPCA so they can find out the best practice when it comes to buying a new puppy. He also speaks to the RSPCA about the growing problem of dogs having their ears cropped
column6: which has become popular with bully breeds
column7: and highlights how barbaric and damaging this practice is.

column1: To explore the rise in new breeders
column2: Fabian hears from owners about their experiences of breeding their own dogs and the challenges and costs they have faced. He also meets people who have recently opened their own canine fertility clinics and hears concerns about what is being taught on one training course. He also uncovers evidence of worrying
column3: illegal techniques being taught to amateurs on a canine fertility course. After showing footage to a veterinary expert in dog breeding
column4: Fabian takes his findings to the government's chief veterinary officer
column5: Christine Middlemiss
column6: to discuss what happens next and whether more regulation is needed.

column1: Fabian ends the documentary by revealing how the journey of the young couple wanting to buy a dog has concluded and by offering his insight into what can be done to improve the welfare of the nation’s favourite pet.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains upsetting scenes.;2021;58;lifestyle

column2: meeting experts and young sufferers who can’t sleep.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09r64f7.jpg;BBC
column5: Daisy Maskell: Insomnia and Me;Daisy Maskell tackles her insomnia
column6: meeting experts and young sufferers who can’t sleep.;Radio DJ Daisy Maskell tackles her insomnia
column7: revealing emotional insights into her own mental health. She meets experts and some of the thousands of young people who can’t sleep.;"Daisy Maskell
column8: the UK’s youngest ever breakfast radio host
column9: has suffered from insomnia since childhood. For as long as she can remember
column10: she has survived on as little as a couple of hours of sleep each night and is wide awake until the early hours of the morning. With an ever-increasing workload
column11: running on empty is starting to take its toll
column12: so Daisy wants to uncover the roots of her insomnia and take the first steps towards treatment.

column1: She is not alone. According to research by the NHS
column2: hospital admissions due to sleep disorders among young people have almost doubled over the past eight years
column3: and the recent Covid-19 crisis has exacerbated the issue further still. In research conducted by Kings College London on a cross-section of 2
column5: almost half of 16- to 24-year-olds stated that they were sleeping significantly fewer hours than they had been prior to lockdown
column6: in comparison to just a third of those aged 35 and over.

column1: Daisy meets experts and fellow sufferers to investigate why thousands of young people in the UK are struggling with sleep disorders and insomnia. Gaining tips along the way
column2: she tries a multitude of remedies and treatments in a bid to get a better night’s sleep. We see her explore the roots of her insomnia
column3: with revealing emotional insights into her struggles with her own mental health.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2021;57;lifestyle

Jody and Lori have outgrown their cramped house near Southend and are desperate for a modern family home.;"Jody and Lori have outgrown their cramped house near Southend and are desperate for a modern family home - but prices in Essex are rocketing. A four-bedroom new-build in the area starts at £400k
column6: which is way beyond their budget. Determined to stay near friends and family
column7: Jody and Lori decided to gamble everything they have on building a new home from scratch. If they get it right
column8: they will have saved in the region of £200k!

column1: Piers is concerned they have started building before the design is finished. He suggests a series of changes that could turn a very generic house into something flooded with natural light
column2: gets the most out of a limited plot and is full of practical storage ideas to suit a young family.

column1: Kieran takes the couple to see a series of homes tailor-made for the people that live in them. Each is packed with ideas they could try
column2: from a lighting design that works for cosy nights and big parties
column3: ingenious ways of using wallpaper to mark out a dining area and how to disguise a kitchen in an open-plan space.

column1: As the build gathers pace
column2: Lori struggles to make colour choices beyond simply greys and whites
column3: but Piers believes colour is exactly the low-cost trick they need. He explains the basics of colour theory
column4: but will they really move from safe whites and greys to bold oranges and blues?

column1: As the pressure mounts

column5: Paul Merson: Football
column6: Gambling and Me;Footballer Paul Merson sets out to understand his 35-year addiction to gambling.;Former footballer Paul Merson sets out to understand why his life has been so blighted by gambling and asks if enough is being done to prevent others following in his footsteps.;"Over the past 35 years
column7: former Arsenal and England footballer Paul Merson has gambled away a fortune. In this programme
column8: he sets out to understand why his life has been so badly blighted by gambling and explores the relationship between football and gambling at a time when it has never been more urgent to question the industry’s place in the world of sport.

column1: Now on the path to recovery
column2: he wants to understand what caused his addiction. Could it be the way his brain is wired
column3: his environment or both? Paul sets out to meet old teammates
column4: scientists and psychologists to see if he can get close to finding the answer. He starts by meeting former Arsenal teammate Wes Reid. When they received their first pay cheques as Arsenal trainees
column5: Paul and Wes went to the bookies
column6: and Paul lost his entire week’s wages in 15 minutes
column7: kicking off a 35-year struggle with gambling.

column1: Paul also meets footballers Keith Gillespie
column3: who between them gambled away £15 million
column4: and he visits the families of three men who took their own lives as a result of gambling addiction. At Imperial College London
column5: he talks to Dr David Erritzoe
column6: a consultant psychiatrist whose team of researchers are mapping the brain
column7: trying to pinpoint the neurobiological basis of gambling addiction so that new treatments can be developed.

column1: As the government considers whether gambling laws should be reformed to protect those addicted to gambling
column2: Paul wonders if an entire generation of young Brits is at risk of following the same dangerous path that he trod. Advertising and sponsorship by betting firms have exploded in recent years
column3: with more than a third of English Premier League clubs promoting gambling companies on their shirts.";Sport;BBC ONE;Contains some strong language.;2021;58;lifestyle

column1: 999;999;Secret Body;Series 1: Episode 6;Ann Marie and Eilidh try to keep their body transformations hidden from loved ones.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bgdm94.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 6;Ann Marie and Eilidh try to keep their body transformations hidden from loved ones.;An occupational therapist and an inputting processor embark on an undercover transformation - but will their secret body suits keep their efforts hidden from family and friends?;"Undercover weight loss show presented by lifestyle and weight loss experts Stephen Clarke and Rab Shields.

column1: This episode features occupational therapist Ann Marie and inputting processor Eilidh. Ann Marie
column3: wants to set her children a healthier example by being fit enough to join her pal for a run around the island. Meanwhile

column5: presumed dead in an avalanche in 1979
column6: is miraculously brought back to life in the present day. Surely things can't have changed too much?;"Mammoth is a comedy show about the life of PE teacher Tony Mammoth. Mammoth is a man literally out of time. In 1979 he was a happy-go-lucky PE teacher
column7: leading a school skiing trip to the French Alps. Life was good. Right up until an avalanche decided to ruin his day by sweeping him away to what was surely his death: a death which would break the hearts of all the kids that he taught
column8: almost all of his colleagues and several mothers
column9: and devastate his best friend and wingman Roger Buck.

column1: Except
column3: Mammoth didn’t die. He was miraculously found and brought back to life 42 years later. A perfectly preserved man in his forties. Just one born 86 years ago. For a time
column4: he was a global phenomenon. The world was his oyster. But Mammoth has never really liked oysters; he's more of a pub lunch and a pint sort of bloke.

column1: He was given the one thing that everyone at some point wishes they were given - a second chance at life. An opportunity to right wrongs.
But the simple fact is that Mammoth was pretty sure that he absolutely nailed life the first time around
column2: so all he really wanted was his old life back. The same job. The same car. The same friends. Okay
column3: it was bound to feel a little strange at first
column4: but Mammoth had always believed in just getting on with things. And anyway
column5: things couldn’t have changed that much since 1979…";Comedy;BBC ONE WALES;Contains some strong language and adult humour.;2021;29;comedy;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b0c9wf.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b0c9wf.jpg;mammoth comedy show life pe teacher tony mammoth mammoth man literally time 1979 happygolucky pe teacher leading school skiing trip french alp life good right avalanche decided ruin day sweeping away surely death death would break heart kid taught almost colleague several mother devastate best friend wingman roger buck except course mammoth ’ die miraculously found brought back life 42 year later perfectly preserved man forty one born 86 year ago time global phenomenon world oyster mammoth never really liked oyster he pub lunch pint sort bloke given one thing everyone point wish given second chance life opportunity right wrong simple fact mammoth pretty sure absolutely nailed life first time around really wanted old life back job car friend okay bound feel little strange first mammoth always believed getting thing anyway thing ’ changed much since 1979…;16

1024;1024;Britney;None;Charly and Ellen’s ten-year best-friendship is put to the test by a huge discovery.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b3yrl7.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Britney;Charly and Ellen’s ten-year best-friendship is put to the test by a huge discovery.;After living thousands of miles apart, Charly and Ellen are reunited. But they are not as inseparable as Ellen had hoped, and some big news puts their friendship to an even greater test.;Charly and Ellen have been best friends ever since a shared moment of transformational theatre in Year 8 Drama Club. Ten years on, Charly is leaving New York and a dubious career leafleting Broadway to visit Ellen back in their home village of Cumwell. Neither of them can wait to relive the glory days of their friendship: a nonstop rom-com of hair crimping, MmmBop and an unhealthy level of co-dependence. But Ellen soon discovers that Charly isn’t planning on moving back permanently, crushing the dream they always shared of living in London together. With the pair now at odds and no longer as inseparable as they had imagined, Charly discovers that her mysterious lack of periods is a result of something much bigger and scarier. Their world is suddenly tipped upside down as they fight to make sure their friendship has a happy ending.;Comedy;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2021;21;comedy;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b3yrl7.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b3yrl7.jpg;charly ellen best friend ever since shared moment transformational theatre year 8 drama club ten year charly leaving new york dubious career leafleting broadway visit ellen back home village cumwell neither wait relive glory day friendship nonstop romcom hair crimping mmmbop unhealthy level codependence ellen soon discovers charly ’ planning moving back permanently crushing dream always shared living london together pair odds longer inseparable imagined charly discovers mysterious lack period result something much bigger scarier world suddenly tipped upside fight make sure friendship happy ending;13

column5: TV
column6: Dinosaur;Modern dating’s a nightmare. Nina
column7: an undiagnosed autistic woman
column8: is shaking up the rules.;Modern dating is a world filled with white lies
column9: false pretences and confusing games. It's a world that Nina
column10: an undiagnosed autistic woman
column11: is about to shake up.;"Nina is autistic
column12: but yet to be diagnosed. She has always felt different – and is often made to feel it by her family. But Nina finds happiness in the world thanks to her love of paleontology
column13: and she spends all the time she can indulging in the exhibitions on dinosaurs and fossils at the local museum. Yet when her bubbly younger sister Evie asks Nina to be her maid of honour
column14: Nina decides to step out of her comfort zone with a challenge: to find herself a date to bring to the wedding. Nina has never been too bothered by dating before
column15: but after her sister’s engagement
column16: she's curious: what's the big fuss all about? If everyone says love is so difficult
column17: why does everyone want it all the time? She’s determined to find out for herself once and for all.

column1: Tackling the terrors of dating apps
column2: and armed with make-up tips and unintended pick-up lines from Evie and the internet
column3: Nina pursues a date with nerdy but endearing Lee. After a bumpy start
column4: the pair soon hit it off over a common love of fan fiction
column5: and Nina even agrees to send Lee some of her own work. However
column6: things quickly start to get confusing when Nina finds Lee doesn’t seem quite as interested in chatting after the date ends.

column1: Smarting from unanswered texts and feeling slightly sidelined at Evie’s engagement party
column2: Nina decides to confide in her older brother Bo for advice. However
column3: the recently dumped Bo quickly makes his feelings known that Nina is way out of her depth; the trials and tribulations of dating are not worth her time. Nina is frustrated. When everyone else is lying and playing games
column4: why does it feel like she’s the odd one out in the dating charade?

column1: When Nina bumps into Lee on her way home
column2: will she take her brother’s advice
column3: or will she be herself and let Lee know exactly how she feels? Could Nina shake up the unspoken rules of modern dating

column1: Halil
column3: Jaeden and Belle are four very different 15-year-olds who have one thing in common. They have all been permanently excluded from mainstream education and find themselves having to go through Year 10 together at their local PRU
column4: a world seldom seen by the public. They struggle to adhere to even the most basic of expectations and wreak havoc on their teachers’ day. Why does laidback Jaeden never turn up for school? column6: Special;Louise is moving in with Joe
column7: Donna has bagged a rich man and Karen is with a chauvinist.;Comedy based around the tangled love lives of three women. Louise is moving in with Joe
column8: Donna has bagged a rich man with no personality and Karen has found herself a chauvinist.;"One-off special comedy based around the tangled love lives of three women.

column1: Louise is moving in with Joe
column2: the love of her life; Donna has found a rich man with no personality; and Karen has realised that the only thing a woman really wants in life is to make her man happy
column3: so she has found herself a chauvinist.

column1: So everything's sorted
column2: or at least until things start to go wrong. Louise discovers that in actual fact she sort of hates the love of her life and spends more and more time trying to get away from him.

column1: Karen is fine until Billy staggers back into her life and tells her that he's dying. She decides that she's going help him do all the things in life that he wished he done. What she didn't realise was that all these things were to be done on drugs and she is soon sucked back into a world of drunken insanity.
Donna is fine until Karl comes back from Italy. The moment she discovers this she dumps her new rich man
column2: but when she discovers that Karl has returned to marry his Italian girlfriend
column3: she immediately picks the rich man up again and pretends that everything is fine. Donna sees the girlfriend with someone else
column4: but is told that they are having an open relationship. Donna is horrified at what Italy has done to the man she once loved.

column1: Things come to a head when Joe
column3: invites her into a hot-air balloon and promptly asks her to marry him. She turns him down.

column1: Karen finds out that Billy isn't really dying
column2: while Donna tells Karl that she's come to terms with his open relationship.

column10: Jack and Victor decide to stop putting things off and go on that adventure they have been planning for years. A new month rolls round and Jack is excited to see what new picture he will reveal on his calendar
column11: but tensions quickly rise as Victor tries to meddle in his fun. Heading to The Clansman for a calming pint
column12: they suggest Boaby uncovers November on his calendar
column13: while Tam reveals he is far too stingy to buy one.

column1: This marching of time has put Jack into a contemplative mood. He is thinking about how he and Victor should stop making up a load of excuses and should instead accomplish their long-standing ambition to climb the world famous Munro
column2: Ben Lomond. Victor’s bright idea for avoiding disappointment every year is to admit defeat
column3: but Jack is having none of it - they are pioneers and they are going for it! With their new resolve
column5: Winston and Boaby to join the expedition
column6: which quickly sees them scrabbling around for reasons why they can’t possibly go. Turns out
column7: none of them can come up with anything decent so they find themselves agreeing. It is probably for the best anyway.

column1: Over at Navid’s shop
column2: rather than running a mile from charity workers
column3: Isa runs towards them. She is a sucker for a cute little animal story but when Navid finds her acting strangely in the shop
column4: she is forced to admit to him that she has a problem. As Navid conducts an intervention to help Isa onto a better path
column5: the boys head off for Ben Lomond in a bid to conquer that mountain.

1142;1142;Kurupting the Industry: The People Just Do Nothing Story;None;How People Just Do Nothing went from online comedy hit to upcoming Hollywood film.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09r5q77.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Kurupting the Industry: The People Just Do Nothing Story;How People Just Do Nothing went from online comedy hit to upcoming Hollywood film.;People Just Do Nothing went from online comedy hit to Bafta-winning sitcom and is now about to make its big-screen debut as a new feature film. This is the story of how.;The story of how a group of mates from Brentford took their online mockumentary and turned it into a smash hit British comedy. People Just Do Nothing has gone from YouTube to Bafta-winning sitcom and is now about to make its big-screen debut as a new feature film, Big in Japan. We hear from the producers who helped guide the show from YouTube to the BBC and beyond. Celebrity fans and collaborators Craig David, Dizzee Rascal, Clara Amfo and Martin Freeman explain why they think the show has become such a huge success, and the creators and cast of Kurupt FM reflect on their journey from teenage friends to winning the biggest prize in UK comedy. Beyond the show itself, they have sold out gig venues, performed at some of the world's biggest music festivals and worked with some of the biggest artists on the planet. And as they now prepare for their upcoming film release, what next for Brentford's biggest pirate radio crew and the legion of fans they have made all over the world?;Comedy;BBC THREE;Contains strong language.;2021;44;comedy, documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09r5q77.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09r5q77.jpg;story group mate brentford took online mockumentary turned smash hit british comedy people nothing gone youtube baftawinning sitcom make bigscreen debut new feature film big japan hear producer helped guide show youtube bbc beyond celebrity fan collaborator craig david dizzee rascal clara amfo martin freeman explain think show become huge success creator cast kurupt fm reflect journey teenage friend winning biggest prize uk comedy beyond show sold gig venue performed world biggest music festival worked biggest artist planet prepare upcoming film release next brentfords biggest pirate radio crew legion fan made world;3

column6: after yet another one of his spells goes wrong. Meanwhile
column7: Nana and her Panto Frogs go searching for socks in the pond.;"Arthur Sleep is joined by team captains Gail Force and Keith Fitt in this slapstick quiz show featuring guests and clips from Gigglebiz. Joining Gail and Keith for today’s GiggleQuiz are Wizard Tripwick and Captain Adorable.

column1: Round 1 features clips starring Professor Muddles showing off his recycling machine
column2: and Dina Lady delivering one of her delicious cakes.  Wizard Tripwick tries to guess the answer by using his wand. It all goes wrong in a very messy way
column3: and a large cake ends up all over Gail. Wizard Tripwick receives a package from a magical pigeon
column4: unwrapping it to reveal a brand new wand. Keen to test it out
column5: he conjures Gail a cup of tea. Unfortunately
column6: this new wand is more powerful than he thought!

column1: Round 2 is Nana’s Panto Showdown
column2: and this time it features Nana’s frogs hopping into the pond to look for her socks. Round 3 features a clip starring DIY Dan making a garden for his gnomes. Wizard Tripwick is confident he’s got the hang of this new wand and offers help to everyone who buzzes in. Unfortunately
column3: the wand is still too powerful
column4: and throughout the round Wizard Tripwick turns Gail into a garden gnome
column5: Keith and Captain Adorable into trees and even himself into a watering can!

column1: 1175;1175;CBeebies Stargazing;Space Explorers: 5. Neptune and beyond;Chris and Maggie look back at planet Earth from the edge of the Solar System.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p093t4wk.jpg;BBC
column5: Space Explorers: 5. Neptune and beyond;Chris and Maggie look back at planet Earth from the edge of the Solar System.;The Stargazers explore extreme winds at Neptune and enjoy the view that Voyager had of Planet Earth from the edge of the Solar System.;"Inspired by the Voyager missions
column6: CBeebies Stargazing: Space Explorers takes pre-schoolers on a journey of discovery through the Solar System. Robert the Robot tells Chris
column7: Maggie and the Stargazers that the final stop on their journey is the planet Neptune. Maggie explains Neptune is the last planet in our solar system
column8: over four billion kilometres away from planet Earth.

column1: In Mission Control
column2: Robert receives a final update from Astronomer Edward
column3: who uploads a picture of Neptune for Stargazers everywhere to look at. Just as Robert is about to enjoy a tasty cake
column4: another message comes into Mission Control. This time it's from Chris
column5: Maggie and the Stargazers
column6: they’ve made it to Neptune!

column1: Maggie then reveals that when Voyager made it to Neptune
column2: it discovered that there were extreme winds on the planet. The Stargazers feel the power of the wind for themselves when they travel in boats across the lake. More Stargazers then send an update back to Mission Control to inform Robert that both Voyager 1 and 2 are still out there exploring space. They also reveal that the spacecrafts carry a golden record
column4: music and pictures from planet Earth. This gives Robert an idea and he surprises Chris and Maggie with messages from Stargazers everywhere about their favourite things on planet Earth.

column1: Maggie has one final solar system surprise of her own however
column2: and she shows Chris a picture Voyager took on the edge of the solar system. In the picture
column3: planet Earth is a tiny blue dot. Maggie reminds Stargazers everywhere to look after their planet and each other.";CBeebies;CBEEBIES;False;2021;14;cbeebies;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p093t4wk.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p093t4wk.jpg;inspired voyager mission cbeebies stargazing space explorer take preschooler journey discovery solar system robert robot tell chris maggie stargazer final stop journey planet neptune maggie explains neptune last planet solar system four billion kilometre away planet earth mission control robert receives final update astronomer edward uploads picture neptune stargazer everywhere look robert enjoy tasty cake another message come mission control time chris maggie stargazer ’ made neptune maggie reveals voyager made neptune discovered extreme wind planet stargazer feel power wind travel boat across lake stargazer send update back mission control inform robert voyager 1 2 still exploring space also reveal spacecraft carry golden record message music picture planet earth give robert idea surprise chris maggie message stargazer everywhere favourite thing planet earth maggie one final solar system surprise however show chris picture voyager took edge solar system picture planet earth tiny blue dot maggie reminds stargazer everywhere look planet;10

column6: Pippa... yay!

column1: After the class
column2: the twins walk Pippa to a playground where Tony is swinging high on a swing. Dogs aren't allowed in the playground
column3: so Topsy walks around the perimeter fence with Pippa on the lead to show her to Tony from there. Mr Welch calls to Tim to tell him not to play near Tony's moving swing. Tony stops swinging and Mummy and Grandma arrive. They ask where Pippa is. In the hullaballoo with the swing
column4: Topsy got distracted and Pippa has gone!

column1: The children look for Pippa from the top of the climbing frame
column2: but can't see her anywhere. Tony mentions that
column4: his mum is pregnant and he'll be sharing a bedroom with his brother Jack. Then Grandma remembers how they were taught to call Pippa in class. The children climb down and one by one and then altogether they call
column5: loud and jolly. Pippa reappears from a tree nearby. Phew!

column5: Series 1: 20. Jam #20: Bustin Beatbox;YolanDa Brown welcomes special guest beatboxer THePETEBOX.;"YolanDa Brown and her house band ""The Band Jaminals"" entertain an audience of children with live music and guest beatboxer THePETEBOX.";"YolanDa Brown kicks off the show with “Something ‘Bout That Noise”
column6: a song all about dynamics in which the Band Jammers must crouch down low then jump up high when the song goes from quiet to loud.

column1: YolanDa then welcomes superstar beatboxer THePETEBOX to the show.  He explains how a beatboxer is essentially a human drum kit
column2: and even takes on house-drummer Talbert in a drum challenge using just his voice. Pete then shows the Band Jammers some basic beatboxing skills and how his voice can be used to make instrument sounds like a trumpet. In the Fact Jam
column3: we find out more about beatboxing
column4: such as the funny names given to the different vocal sounds
column5: and about how scientists are studying them to find out just how on earth they make such weird and wonderful noises. A short film features some deaf children as they learn how to dance. With the help of deaf dancer Chris Fonseca
column6: the children find out all about ‘vibrations’ and how they can use these to ‘feel the beat’ and dance along to the music
column7: even though they can’t hear it. Finally
column8: Pete is back in the band and ready for the Band Jam. He lends his unique beatboxing skills to the group and even takes on YolanDa by playing the sound of a trumpet alongside her saxophone.";CBeebies;CBEEBIES;False;2019;14;cbeebies;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0746kbw.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0746kbw.jpg;yolanda brown kick show “ something ‘ bout noise ” song dynamic band jammer must crouch low jump high song go quiet loud yolanda welcome superstar beatboxer thepetebox show explains beatboxer essentially human drum kit even take housedrummer talbert drum challenge using voice pete show band jammer basic beatboxing skill voice used make instrument sound like trumpet fact jam find beatboxing funny name given different vocal sound scientist studying find earth make weird wonderful noise short film feature deaf child learn dance help deaf dancer chris fonseca child find ‘ vibration ’ use ‘ feel beat ’ dance along music even though ’ hear finally pete back band ready band jam lends unique beatboxing skill group even take yolanda playing sound trumpet alongside saxophone;10

column1: Jac brushes his hair as he gets ready for the day
column2: and Jemima chooses what she wants to wear. Once ready
column3: Jac’s family visits a local farm shop where they choose a plant and get to pick vegetables! Meanwhile
column4: Jemima goes to a play cafe
column5: where she enjoys a tea party with mum and dad. Back at home
column6: Jac and dad plant their new greenery and talk about how it’ll grow big and tall
column7: just like Jac!

column1: Jemima finishes the day with painting flowers using her hands
column2: but she must remember to wash them afterwards! Jac has his very first haircut - what will he think? Finally
column3: after learning how to do so many new things
column4: they both get ready for bed.

Will her friends guess the secret ingredient?;"Disa's family comes from the Scandinavian country Sweden. She is baking kardemummabullar
column8: which is a Swedish recipe for cardamom buns. Disa makes a milk mixture
column9: sweetened with honey
column10: and mixes it into flour to make a dough. She then grinds her special ingredient
column11: cardamom
column12: into a powder and adds some into the dough and the rest of it into brown sugar.

column1: The dough is flattened
column2: the brown sugar and cardamom mix is spread onto the dough and folded in. The dough is then cut into strips and twisted and wrapped into a bun ready to be baked. Will her friends like the cardamom when it's baked in her kardemummabullar?";CBeebies;CBEEBIES;False;2021;11;cbeebies;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0999g0f.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0999g0f.jpg;disa family come scandinavian country sweden baking kardemummabullar swedish recipe cardamom bun disa make milk mixture sweetened honey mix flour make dough grind special ingredient cardamom powder add dough rest brown sugar dough flattened brown sugar cardamom mix spread onto dough folded dough cut strip twisted wrapped bun ready baked friend like cardamom baked kardemummabullar;13

column5: Series 5: 2. Cable Car and Viewing Tower;Maddie finds out how cable cars work and visits a viewing tower to see how it is made.;Join Maddie as she finds out how cable cars work without engines and visits a tall viewing tower to see how it was made.;"Join Maddie as she finds out how cable cars work and visits a viewing tower to see how it was made. We learn how cable cars don’t have engines inside and see all the different parts that work together. Maddie uses her special cameras to take us on a ride in the cable car and show us how the car moves along the cable as it passes over the support towers.

column1: Maddie then goes to the top of a high viewing tower
column2: which is 170 metres tall and shaped like a sail on a boat. We discover the tower is built on a special platform with concrete columns that are constructed in the sea. Maddie uses her special camera as she climbs inside the hollow tower structure to show us how they bolt the legs of the tower together.

column1: Finally
column2: Maddie travels to the very top
column3: to the viewing platform with a strong glass floor

column1: 1237;1237;Twirlywoos;Series 2: 19. Balancing;The Twirlywoos find out balancing is harder than it looks when they copy a gymnast.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08c6n5r.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 2: 19. Balancing;The Twirlywoos find out balancing is harder than it looks when they copy a gymnast.;Stop-motion preschool programme about the adventures of four inquisitive Twirlywoos. The Twirlywoos find out balancing is harder than it looks when they copy a gymnast.;"Stop-motion preschool programme about the adventures of four inquisitive Twirlywoos. The Twirlywoos are at a gym hall where they watch a gymnast practising a routine on a balance beam. When the gymnast leaves
column6: Toodloo is eager to try it out and leaps up on the beam
column7: performing a gymnastic routine. Chickedy and Chick also try to balance on the beam - they run along it really fast
column8: holding hands to steady themselves. Next it's Great Big Hoo
column9: who finds it difficult and wobbles around
column10: nearly falling off a few times. The others are at the end of the beam encouraging Great Big Hoo along it. Suddenly the gymnast comes back and so Great Big Hoo makes a run for it
column11: getting all the way to the end of the beam and knocking into the others! They fall into the basin of chalk dust that the gymnasts use to help their grip
column12: and as the hooter sounds
column13: they fly away
column14: creating a big cloud of chalk which surprises the gymnast as she comes back into the room.

column1: Back in the boat
column2: a big wave washes Peekaboo and a collection of pebbles out of the hole in the wall and they are scattered all across the boat floor. The Twirlywoos return
column3: but Peekaboo doesn't have enough time to get back into the hole so hides in amongst the pebbles. When the Twirlywoos drop into the boat they land on the pebbles
column4: where they struggle to keep their balance. Chickedy and Chick jump from pebble to pebble like stepping stones
column5: until they unwittingly land on top of Peekaboo's shell. Peekaboo runs off with Chickedy and Chick balancing on top! They career around the boat crashing into the other pebbles
column6: and into Great Big Hoo and Toodloo
column7: ending up with everyone balanced precariously on top of Peekaboo!";CBeebies;CBEEBIES;False;2016;11;cbeebies;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08c6n5r.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08c6n5r.jpg;stopmotion preschool programme adventure four inquisitive twirlywoos twirlywoos gym hall watch gymnast practising routine balance beam gymnast leaf toodloo eager try leap beam performing gymnastic routine chickedy chick also try balance beam run along really fast holding hand steady next great big hoo find difficult wobble around nearly falling time others end beam encouraging great big hoo along suddenly gymnast come back great big hoo make run getting way end beam knocking others fall basin chalk dust gymnast use help grip hooter sound fly away creating big cloud chalk surprise gymnast come back room back boat big wave wash peekaboo collection pebble hole wall scattered across boat floor twirlywoos return peekaboo doesnt enough time get back hole hide amongst pebble twirlywoos drop boat land pebble struggle keep balance chickedy chick jump pebble pebble like stepping stone unwittingly land top peekaboo shell peekaboo run chickedy chick balancing top career around boat crashing pebble great big hoo toodloo ending everyone balanced precariously top peekaboo;13

column1: 1245;1245;Andy's Aquatic Adventures;Series 2: 15. Andy and the Sea Urchins;Andy heads to California and meets some sea otters
column5: Andys Aquatic Adventures
column6: Series 2: 15. Andy and the Sea Urchins;Andy heads to California and meets some sea otters
column7: a garibaldi and some spiky urchins.;Andy blasts off on an aquatic adventure to California to see how kelp forests in the wild deal with urchins. Along the way
column8: he meets a fish called a garibaldi and some sea otters.;"Andy works at Safari World
column9: the biggest and best safari park on the planet
column10: home to animals from all over the globe. He works there with his boss
column11: Mr Hammond and tech wizard Jen
column12: who monitors all the animals from the Aqua Base.

column1: Jen has been working on a new kelp forest for the Aqua Forest Dome
column2: and Mr Hammond calls to find out if it is safe for him to go diving in there. Jen has been very careful to ensure there aren't any dangerous animals in there to hurt him
column3: but when Mr Hammond asks about spiky urchins
column4: Jen starts to look a little worried. She spots hundreds of urchins on the seabed in the new Aqua Dome – not only are they painful to stand on
column5: but they are eating the all the kelp. It’s a disaster! Looking for inspiration in the wild to see how kelp forests deal with urchins
column6: Andy heads out on an aquatic adventure.

column1: Andy boards his safari-sub
column2: a hi-tech underwater submersible capable of travelling to any location on the planet in the blink of an eye. When Andy arrives to the coast of California
column3: he finds a group of male sea otters wrapping themselves up in the kelp so they don’t drift off. Andy would love to stay and watch
column4: but he is on a mission to find out how to stop the urchins. Quite unexpectedly
column5: he gets picked up by a fish called a garibaldi. Garibaldis are very house proud and will remove anything from their territory that doesn’t belong there
column6: including Andy.

column1: The Garibaldi accidentally drops Andy on an urchin spine and goes about moving the rest of the urchins from the nearby seabed. Just when Andy thinks he has his answer
column2: he notices the sea urchins start returning. Is there something else that keeps the urchin numbers down? When Andy figures it out and the mission is accomplished
column3: it’s time to head back to Safari World. Will Andy make it before Mr Hammond goes for his dive?";CBeebies;CBEEBIES;False;2021;14;cbeebies

column1: 1290;1290;Bellator MMA;2022: Bellator 274: Main Event & Prelims;Full coverage of Bellator 274 at the Mohegan Sun Arena in Uncasville
column5: Bellator MMA
column6: 2022: Bellator 274: Main Event & Prelims;Full coverage of Bellator 274 at the Mohegan Sun Arena in Uncasville
column7: Connecticut.;Bellator MMA returns to Connecticut and is headlined by a showdown between two of the welterweight division’s top five ranked fighters
column8: as Neiman Gracie takes on Logan Storley.;"Bellator MMA returns to the Mohegan Sun Arena in Connecticut with a showdown between two of the welterweight division’s top five ranked fighters
column9: as Neiman Gracie takes on Logan Storley with both fighters aiming to strengthen their title credentials. Gracie opened his outstanding professional MMA career by recording nine consecutive wins over  previously undefeated opponents
column10: including eight by submission. His opponent Storley has lost just once in his 13-fight career
column11: with the only blemish on his record a nail-biting
column12: split decision loss to reigning division champion Yaroslav Amosov. The bout promises to produce fireworks as both fighters aim to strengthen their title credentials in the stacked welterweight division.

column1: The card’s co-main event sees another huge welterweight clash with former Bellator world champion Andrey Koreshkov opening his 2022 campaign against returning veteran Chance Rencountre. Russian Koreshkov shut down the highly rated Sabah Homasi by unanimous decision to notch his 24th win in his most recent fight at Bellator 264 last August. Meanwhile
column2: Rencountre will be hoping to extend his two-bout win streak when he fights under the Bellator banner for the first time in more than four years. The 35-year-old American boasts an impressive career professional record of 16 wins from his 20 fights.

column1: Elsewhere on the main card is an all-American bout between 44-fight veteran Georgi Karakhanyan and Adam Piccolotti in the lightweight division. Karakhanyan will be aiming to notch an incredible 32nd victory in a career which has spanned 16 years. His opponent Piccolotti has won 12 of his 16 bouts and will be looking to bounce back from a split-decision loss to Sidney Outlaw in his most recent fight at Bellator 244.

Rounding out the main card is a heavyweight fight between the undefeated Davion Franklin and Surinames’s Said Sowma. Plenty is on the line as the fighters come into the bout tied at eighth in Bellator’s heavyweight rankings
column2: with the winner set to establish himself as one of the division’s top contenders. Sowma will be hoping to continue his fine form having produced back-to-back knockouts in 2021
column3: against Ronny Markes and most recently Vitaly Minakov at Bellator 269 in Moscow.

column1: Elsewhere on an evening of high-class MMA action Connecticut’s Brennan Ward will be hoping the home support will aide him on his return to the cage following a five year lay-off when he takes on Brandon Bell. DeAnna Bennett welcomes Justine Kish to the Bellator cage at women’s flyweight and in the light heavyweight division Kevin Haley makes his promotional debut against top prospect Christian Edwards.
All the action comes live from the Mohegan Sun Arena

column5: exploring why modern TT riders still risk their lives to win this incredibly dangerous event - the ultimate challenge for rider and machine. It has always demanded a commitment far beyond any other racing event
column6: and many have made the ultimate sacrifice in their quest for victory. The film follows the leading riders in the 2010 race

column8: was brought back from the dead.;The story of a community that needed a break and how its football club
column9: exiled for 13 years
column10: was brought back from the dead.;"The Brandywell was one of the poorest areas in Europe and home to Derry City Football Club. In the shadow of the civil rights movement and the Troubles
column11: the club managed to keep playing - until the team bus of Ballymena United was caught up in the violence
column12: taken away and burned. Derry City FC was banned from playing at home and eventually went out of business.

column2: the city needed a saviour. Tony O’Doherty was a Northern Ireland international who had played against England at Wembley. He teamed up with another international
column4: and two other professionals Eddie Mahon and Eamonn McLaughlin
column5: to become the Gang of Four who challenged the status quo. They made it their goal to get senior football back in their hometown.

column1: With repeated rebuffs from the Irish League in Belfast to their requests to gain re-entry
column2: the four lads decided to take their footballing revolution south to the League of Ireland in Dublin.

column1: This film charts the emotional journey of how in 1985
column3: football returned to the Brandywell. The club would go on to lift both silverware and the spirits of the city
column5: pride and optimism.

column1: Featuring interviews with the Gang of Four
column2: rare archive footage and memories of the faithful supporters
column3: the film portrays an inspirational group of people who made their dreams come true. The rollercoaster took the club and community from the depths of despair to footballing nirvana
column4: landing a historic domestic treble in the League of Ireland. It would culminate with the arrival of football royalty with Sven-Goran Eriksson bringing his Benfica team of superstars into the heart of the Bogside for a European Cup tie. column6: Argentina and the Dictators;How South American military dictators attempted to exploit the 1970 and 1978 World Cups.;The story of how
column7: in the 1970 and 1978 World Cups
column8: Brazil and Argentina's military dictators took a vested interest in their nation's football dreams.;"To most fans around the world Brazil and Argentina’s World Cup wins in 1970 and 1978 were wonderful football stories. But to the people of these two nations there was a hugely significant political context to these tournaments. Both nations won the World Cup while suffering under repressive military dictatorships. And in both cases these violent military juntas used their successful football teams to help improve their image around the world.

column1: For many football fans
column2: Brazil’s 1970 World Cup-winning team remains the greatest ever
column3: while the scenes from the River Plate stadium of ticker tape cascading down onto the joyous Argentinian team remains one of the most evocative in footballing history.

column1: In this revealing documentary
column2: filmed in Brazil and Argentina and featuring the players and people directly affected by the tournaments

column5: Jairzinho

column7: Gerson and Tostao.";Sport;BBC ONE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2020;44;sports

column4: Barney Curley: The Man Who Beat the Bookies;How Barney Curley pulled off the greatest gambling coup in horse racing history.;The story of Barney Curley
column5: one of the UK's most celebrated punters and a legend of the turf
column6: and how he pulled off one of the most audacious coups ever seen on a racecourse.;"The Yellow Sam coup of 1975 made Barney Curley a household name in Ireland and Northern Ireland
column7: and is still remembered with reverence today by anyone associated with racing. For the first time
column8: Barney tells the incredible story
column9: in his own words
column10: of how he managed to take £2m (inflation-adjusted) off the bookies in one eventful hurdle race in 1975 - without breaking the law. With access to the bookmakers and the jockey
column11: as well as stars of racing such as Frankie Dettori and Ian Balding
column12: this is the definitive story of one of the great characters of the turf.

column1: Barney went on to win many other massive bets
column2: famously raffling his mansion and as recently as 2016 making millions from a carefully planned accumulator bet. But he was just as famous for his charity
column3: spending most of his time in the last decade directing the building of schools and hospitals in Zambia. This is the story of a man who won millions
column4: only to voluntarily give them away.

1329;1329;Fever Pitch: The Rise of the Premier League;Series 1: Episode 4;When Wenger and Ferguson go head-to-head, the league’s most infamous feud is born.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09tz6ts.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Fever Pitch: The Rise of the Premier League, Series 1: Episode 4;When Wenger and Ferguson go head-to-head, the league’s most infamous feud is born.;Arsene Wenger arrives in London with ideas that revolutionise the game. As his side pose a serious challenge to Man United’s dominance, the league’s most infamous feud is born.;Having won four out of five titles since the start of the Premier League
column2: Manchester United and Alex Ferguson seem unstoppable. In London
column3: Arsenal have barely had a look-in
column4: but vice chairman David Dein has been busy plotting.

column1: He introduces an unknown bespectacled Frenchman to the waiting press at Highbury and announces that he is Arsenal’s new manager. Arsene Wenger looks more like a history teacher than a football manager
column2: and the players have never heard of him. Yet Wenger is about to have a huge impact
column3: not just on the Premier League but on English football
column4: by introducing modern coaching techniques as well as lifestyle and dietary improvements.

column1: The first thing he does is put a stop to the drinking culture – the players’ ‘Tuesday Club’ is consigned to history. He also brings in exciting foreign players from Europe - Patrick Vieira
column3: Nicolas Anelka - to play alongside Arsenal stalwarts like captain Tony Adams. On the pitch
column5: and it’s not long before Alex Ferguson feels the imminent threat
column6: a new rival intent on destroying the legacy he’s building at Manchester United. It’s clear Ferguson is rattled by the new interloper
column7: and the rivalry and tension between the two men is replicated by the players when the two sides meet. It marks the beginning of a ten-year chapter in the Premier league which would become known as The Feud.

column1: But off the pitch
column2: Manchester United’s supporters have another battle on their hands – this time in the boardroom. Sky’s Rupert Murdoch announces an audacious £623m bid to buy the club
column3: which has been accepted by the shareholders. Large swathes of United’s fans are incensed and launch a desperate rear-guard action to try and fight the sale of their beloved club.";Sport;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2021;59;sports

column1: An escalating rivalry between Kevin and his nemesis Shaun White in the run-up to the 2010 Olympics leaves Shaun on top of the Olympic podium and Kevin in a coma following a training accident in Park City
column2: Utah. Kevin's tight-knit Vermont family flies to his side and helps him rebuild his life as a brain injury survivor. But when he insists on wanting to return to the sport he still loves

column4: “I just don’t want you to die.” Kevin’s doctors caution him that even a small blow to the head could be enough to kill him.

column4: Irelands Rugby Number 10;The story of Ireland’s rugby number 10 jersey and players who have worn it.;This is the story of Ireland’s rugby number 10 jersey as told by some of the international players who have proudly worn the iconic shirt.;"The rugby number 10 is an iconic jersey and the players who have worn it have produced some of Irish rugby’s most famous sporting moments.

column1: The number 10 in rugby is arguably the most important player on the pitch. They are the master tactician and the playmaker
column2: the goal kicker and the person who calls the shots. The number 10 shirt carries responsibility
column3: respect and a sense of prestige and the pressure is intense both on and off the pitch. It’s the Irish fascination with the selection of who should wear the number 10 shirt which has produced great debate across the decades and created some of the most intense rivalries in world sport
column4: such as that between Ollie Campbell and Tony Ward or Ronan O’Gara and David Humphreys.

column1: As the shirt is passed from one player to another and one generation to the next
column2: we explore some of Ireland’s best ever number 10s
column3: examine why the iconic shirt is so important and reflect on many of the most memorable moments in Irish rugby history. This is a fascinating story of Irish rugby
column4: as told by some of Ireland’s greatest international players who have proudly worn the iconic number 10 shirt.

column10: unassuming figure
column11: Neil Fachie is a multiple world title winner
column12: a Paralympic gold medallist and a Commonwealth champion. Along with multiple pilots on his tandem bike
column13: he has broken world records in track events since joining UK Cycling in 2009. His achievements in the velodrome are all the more remarkable when you discover that he is  almost completely blind.

column1: However
column2: cycling hasn’t always dominated Neil’s career. Born in Bridge of Don
column3: he developed a passion for athletics as a child
column5: he travelled to Beijing to compete as a sprinter in the 100m and 200m but returned home with nothing. He then discovered that his funding had been removed
column6: and a period of depression and self-doubt followed. But then a chance encounter at the Manchester velodrome led to his inclusion in the UK Cycling squad
column7: and he has never looked back.

column1: Since then
column2: he has conquered his sport with achievements that are unparalleled in world cycling
column3: including Paralympic gold at London 2012 and Commonwealth gold at Glasgow 2014. He has also become a motivational coach.

column1: Featuring interviews with Neil
column2: his family and the pilots he has competed alongside
column3: including Olympians Craig MacLean and Sir Chris Hoy

column1: Scotland has over 550 golf courses and is regarded worldwide as the home of golf. This six-part series takes us on a journey around the country to explore some of the well-known courses as well as some of its hidden gems
column2: and opens the door to golf.  We hear from golfers young and old
column5: and from those who make their living working in golf
column6: plus we capture a few tips from the professionals along the way.

column1: In this episode
column2: we take an aerial journey around a selection of golf courses in the Western Isles. We learn the story of the historic golf course at Askernish in South Uist. Stuart Griffin and Hugh Ross are one-armed golfers who compete internationally
column3: we catch up with them playing at Stirling Golf Club. And professional coach Keil Beveridge demonstrates his weekly top playing tip.

Michaela 2019;Teenager Michaela Williams has always considered herself black but looks white.;Teenager Michaela Williams has always considered herself black but looks white. Now, the Windrush scandal has brought the question of her heritage and belonging into sharp relief.;Teenager Michaela Williams has always considered herself black but looks white. Fighting for her right to self-identify at school, she was puzzled when, years earlier, her great-grandmother Eunice seemed to approve of the fact she looked the way she did. She was close to Eunice, but went to her great-aunt Yvonne for answers. Now, the Windrush scandal has brought the question of her heritage and belonging into sharp relief. A school project gives Michaela an opportunity to look at her own family, explore the wider implications for the Caribbean community in Britain and consider how much longer the community can survive with a discrete identity.;Drama;BBC FOUR;False;2019;13;drama-and-soaps;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07jwpkk.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07jwpkk.jpg;teenager michaela williams always considered black look white fighting right selfidentify school puzzled year earlier greatgrandmother eunice seemed approve fact looked way close eunice went greataunt yvonne answer windrush scandal brought question heritage belonging sharp relief school project give michaela opportunity look family explore wider implication caribbean community britain consider much longer community survive discrete identity;16

column7: with tragic consequences for everyone.;"Every parent wants the best for their kids

A university professor and his team find that their work has been hacked by climate change deniers.;"Conspiracy thriller based on the events of the 'Climategate' scandal in 2009. Professor Phil Jones and his team of climatologists at the University of East Anglia find that their work has been hacked by climate change deniers and turned into the first big fake-news story. The deniers and corporations with vested interests skillfully create the image of climate change as a conspiracy being perpetrated by academic scientists.

column1: Anne argues with Jane Rochford but in her anger Anne divulges that the musician Mark Smeaton and the nobles Francis Weston and Harry Norris have all declared their love to her

Jane Rochford takes great pleasure in reporting these events to Cromwell. She further insinuates that her husband George Boleyn's unhealthy sexual appetite extends to his sister. Cromwell is dumbfounded by such accusations
column2: but brings Mark Smeaton in for questioning. Smeaton foolishly boasts of his own exploits with the Queen
column3: and under duress starts to spill other names including Norris
column4: Weston and William Brereton. Cromwell now has enough information to act and these men together with Anne and George Boleyn are brought to the Tower of London.

column2: he thinks back to Cardinal Wolsey's demise and remembers how each of Norris
column4: Brereton and George Boleyn had cruelly mocked his master. Cromwell has exacted the ultimate revenge.

column12: starring Hugh Grant as Jeremy Thorpe and Ben Whishaw as Norman Scott. A Very English Scandal is the shocking true story of the first British politician to stand trial for conspiracy to murder.  It's the late 1960s
column13: homosexuality has only just been decriminalized
column14: and Jeremy Thorpe
column15: the leader of the Liberal party and the youngest leader of any British political party in a hundred years
column16: has a secret he's desperate to hide. As long as Norman Scott
column17: his vociferous ex-lover is around

column9: brutally murdering him.

column1: Lloyd learns about the techniques employed by professional gamblers who can make thousands of pounds by painstakingly studying greyhound and horse racing form. He also meets with data companies who analyse statistics and put together detailed spreadsheets in order to predict the outcome of football fixtures.
However
column2: Lloyd also witnesses the darker side of the gambling world
column3: meeting people who've suffered the consequences of addiction
column5: depression and suicidal thoughts.

column1: Beginning with that fateful day

column1: It captures the horror of the crush on the terraces
column2: revealing the prejudices held by the police towards football fans. It exposes the police commanders' abject failure in leadership as the tragedy unfolded
column3: and their deceit and determination to deflect responsibility for their failures in crowd management onto those who survived.

column8: removed from view or simply 'forbidden'. She delves into the questions of what
column9: why and how art gets forbidden
column10: who gets to decide and how that has changed over time.

column1: In the first programme
column2: Mary explores some of the challenging ways that artists have shown the human body. She begins with the Romans
column3: heading to the British Museum to discuss a statue of the god Pan having sex with a she-goat
column4: and from there moves through art from the Renaissance to the present day that portrays sex
column5: death
column6: violence and beyond.

column1: 1582;1582;Thatcher: A Very British Revolution;Series 1: 5. Downfall;Splits in Mrs Thatcher's cabinet and public anger lead to her eventual downfall.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jb6ds.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 5. Downfall;Splits in Mrs Thatcher's cabinet and public anger lead to her eventual downfall.;Mrs Thatcher’s leadership style and judgement on Europe and the poll tax create splits in her cabinet and public anger
column6: leading to the challenge that ends in her dramatic downfall.;"In episode five of the series covers the period after the 1987 election when Mrs Thatcher secured a third term as prime minister.

column1: She sets out to play a full part in international affairs
column2: partnering with American Presidents Reagan and Bush to engage with the Soviet Union and play a pivotal role in the journey to the end of the Cold War.

column1: Her international prominence augments her dominant role in British politics where her long period in office of nearly a decade is unprecedented in the 20th century. Within Downing Street
column2: she has a loyal coterie of advisors who project her influence and protect her position but some feel she has become over dependent on loyalists and detached from opinion with the country and the party.

column1: She continues to push hard for the introduction of a radical reform of local government finance
column2: the community charge. The policy is known as the poll tax and is widely disliked. Despite warnings that the tax will negatively affect her constituency in the country
column3: Mrs Thatcher refuses to compromise. Protests against the tax explode in violence in central London but more damagingly
column4: there is widespread disenchantment in Tory strongholds across the country.

column1: Fractures emerge with senior cabinet colleagues over European policy that will jeopardise her authority. Her preference for the counsel of a part time advisor over the views of her chancellor on how to position sterling against other European currencies leads to Nigel Lawson's resignation.

Her prototypical scepticism about Brussels' ambitions for the EU lead to a growing tension with long-term ally Geoffrey Howe. A bravado performance in the House of Commons where she denounces the EU tips Howe into resignation.

Howe’s departure provokes a leadership challenge from Michael Heseltine who had left the cabinet some years before in protest at Mrs Thatcher's leadership style. Mrs Thatcher is plunged into a leadership contest. In contrast to the contest that propelled her to the party leadership in the 70s
column2: her campaign is poorly organised and she has been weakened by the resignation of senior colleagues and the reverberations of the poll tax.

column1: To her shock she does not defeat Mr Heseltine in the first ballot and is forced into a second ballot. Over a dramatic few days
column2: she consults senior colleagues about whether she can depend on their support in a second ballot. Cabinet members tell her they believe she could lose and that she has lost control of the political momentum. Faced with this

column1: In a highly-dramatic cabinet meeting
column2: she offers a tearful resignation and prepares to leave Downing Street. In the country
column3: emotions run high as supporters lament and opponents celebrate her departure.

column4: Alex Brooker: Disability and Me;Alex Brooker examines his disability to acknowledge how much it impacts on who he is.;In this intimate and extremely personal documentary
column5: comedian and TV presenter Alex Brooker examines his disability to acknowledge for the first time how much it impacts on who he is.;"In this intimate and extremely personal documentary
column6: comedian and TV presenter Alex Brooker examines his disability to acknowledge for the first time how much it impacts on who he is.

column1: Alex revisits key moments from his past
column2: uncovering both joyful and difficult memories. Having conversations with family and friends that he has never had before
column3: Alex engages with elements of his disability he has avoided until now.

column1: Turning to the present
column2: Alex explores what it really means to be disabled in the UK today. Admitting that he knows he is out of touch with many people’s disability experiences
column3: Alex comes face to face with the lives of disabled Brits around the country to see the reality of day-to-day life - from prejudice and lack of support to resilience

column1: Alex looks to the future
column2: finally able to address his concerns around his own health and mobility and ready to explore what medical options might be available to him.

column1: By the end of the documentary
column2: Alex has a new perspective on being a disabled person and the role it will play for his sense of self over the rest of his life.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2020;59;signed

column7: Series 1: Episode 2;Anita and her mother return to what is now Pakistan to learn more about the partition.;Anita Rani and her mother Lucky become the first members of their family to return to what is now Pakistan since the Partition of India.;"Anita Rani presents the second episode of a two-part documentary series marking the 70th anniversary of the Partition of India.

column1: Anita begins her own partition journey as she and her mother Lucky become the first members of their family to return to what is now Pakistan since the Partition of India. In the Punjabi village where her Sikh grandfather's first family were slaughtered

column1: Across the border in India
column2: Sameer Butt retraces the epic train journey across the Punjab to Pakistan which his seven-year-old Muslim grandfather Asad and his family took in 1947. Binita Kane explores how her Hindu family managed to escape the violence that engulfed their Bengali village
column3: as well as the perils they faced as refugees.";History;BBC ONE;Contains disturbing scenes.;2017;58;signed

column2: along with their adult grandchildren and other members of the royal family

column1: Originally conceived to mark Prince Philip’s one hundredth birthday
column2: this landmark documentary features interviews filmed both before and after the duke’s death in April. The documentary-makers have been inside Buckingham Palace to meet the duke’s staff and to capture his study

column1: There are poignant recollections

column10: Steph is excited about making a fresh start by transforming her garden. It’s currently a dilapidated outside space
column11: mostly enveloped by shade. The only place that does get the sun is where she keeps the bins. Steph’s dream is to have a garden that offers her calm spaces to practise her yoga
column12: but also one that gives her enough space to have a party. She’s chosen her lifelong friend Nicola to support her
column13: but will it be possible to create a garden that can help kickstart the next chapter of her life?

column1: Stepping up to help are award-winning garden designers Manoj Malde and Pip Probert. Manoj is inspired to bring vibrancy and colour to the space and packs it with different garden rooms
column2: whilst Pip is keen to transform it into a contemporary coastal paradise.

column1: Using virtual reality
column2: both designers pitch their radically different approaches. Manoj tackles the lack of purpose in the space
column3: while Pip chases the sunshine to create light-filled zones to enjoy around the clock. Both designs are brought to life in the virtual world

column5: Joyce reveals a very special lockdown purchase.

column1: Father and daughter team Frank and Georgia Hunter are continually finding ways to adapt and survive on their 600 acre mixed livestock farm.  All farmers' markets are cancelled

column7: and as a black woman in the music industry. Leigh-Anne talks about the racism she experienced growing up. Both her parents are of Caribbean heritage
column8: and Leigh-Anne identifies as black. She is also aware that having lighter skin and being a celebrity means she is in a more privileged position than others. Leigh-Anne embarks on her own very personal journey to understand how she can use her platform and privilege to combat the profound racism she sees in society around her.

column1: After she begins her journey
column2: news of George Floyd’s death and the Black Lives Matter protests start to sweep the world. With the force of a global movement now behind her
column3: Leigh-Anne confronts those closest to her and attempts to bring difficult conversations about black representation right to the top of the music industry.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2021;59;signed

column12: a lined bodice and a bound buttonhole.
