column10: joins a quinceanera and meets an all-female Mexican rodeo team.;"Nadiya Hussain continues her tour of America's culinary melting pot in California.

column1: She starts just a stone’s throw from downtown Los Angeles
column3: home to an authentic Central American night market. Here she find the country’s newest arrivals
column4: on the first step of their American dream
column5: cooking up a taste of home: delicious Guatemalan stuffed chilies and
column6: from El Salvador
column7: thick corn tortillas with spicy salsa.

column1: In LA’s trendy arts district
column3: whose gourmet tacos are redefining modern Californian cuisine. She meets Wes’s father
column4: who emigrated to the USA in the 1970s
column5: causing Nadiya to reflect on her own father’s immigration experience.

column1: Nadiya discovers an extravagant way that Latinos are holding on to their heritage. The quinceanera is a lavish 15th birthday party that celebrates a girl's coming of age. At the centre is an elaborate cake and a fairy tale dress. Nadiya is invited to spend a day with a family as they celebrate a full day of cultural festivities. She discovers that
column5: 000 to mark the occasion.

column1: Over the last three years
column2: hate crimes in the USA have reached an all-time high. Nadiya visits an event at a mosque where halal tacos are being used to bring Latinos and Muslims together and create a greater political voice to tackle racism.

column1: Leaving LA
column2: Nadiya enters a land that looks like the Wild West. Out here
column3: she discovers there is an all-female Mexican rodeo team
column5: carrying out daredevil manoeuvers in a dangerous equestrian ballet that requires skill and bravery. She learns how these modern American Mexican women seamlessly combine their two lives and reflects on her own experience of growing up in two different cultural worlds.

column1: In San Francisco
column2: Nadiya visits the last remaining handmade fortune cookie factory in Chinatown
column3: where she is taught how to mould and fold like the resident expert
column4: the grandma of this family business.

column1: She also visits a charity called La Cocina
column2: which is helping women who are new arrivals in America launch and run their own food businesses.  Nadiya meets women from Palestine
column3: Thailand and Senegal who are preparing authentic homemade food and joins them for a picnic under the Golden Gate Bridge
column4: where she shares with them her own delicious prawn biryani.";Food;BBC ONE;False;2020;59;signed

column1: But Murdoch is tough - he feeds on conflict and revels in playing the underdog

Unstoppable;Europe’s leaders argue about how to deal with hundreds of thousands of new migrants.;Europe’s leaders and their top advisers reveal how the arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants on Europe’s shores plunged the European Union into turmoil.;"This episode exposes how Europe’s leaders fought over how to deal with the migration crisis that reached its peak in the summer of 2015.

column1: As hundreds of thousands of refugees and migrants arrive from North Africa and Syria
column2: Europe divides. The decision by chancellor Angela Merkel
column4: to keep Germany's borders open  tests the fundamental principles of the EU to the limit.

column1: Top leaders
column2: from Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker to prime ministers Matteo Renzi and Mark Rutte
column4: reveal some of the biggest clashes the European Council has ever witnessed.

column1: As Europe is split over whether to share the burden of migrants or toughen up borders
column2: a controversial deal with Turkey – aided by shutting down borders to keep migrants out of Europe – brings the crisis out of control. But the political damage is grave.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains upsetting scenes.;2019;59;signed

column1: 1627;1627;Digging for Britain;Series 9: Episode 6;A 3
column2: 000-year-old Bronze Age wooden coffin is found buried beneath a golf course.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bbccfh.jpg;BBC
column5: Digging for Britain
column6: Series 9: Episode 6;A 3
column7: 000-year-old Bronze Age wooden coffin is found buried beneath a golf course.;Featuring a Roman fort on Hadrian’s Wall
column8: evidence of early writing by the Picts in Scotland and a 3
column9: 000-year-old Bronze Age coffin buried under a golf course.;"The north of England is so rich in archaeological finds that Alice Roberts is travelling back there once again to reveal more of its fascinating history.

column1: She starts this journey at that most spectacular of Roman monuments
column2: Hadrian’s Wall. Alice is on site to witness a new dig at the famous Birdoswald Fort
column3: once home to around 800 Roman infantrymen. She joins a team from Newcastle University as they uncover a completely new building
column4: alluded to in the 1930s but never fully excavated until now.

column1: Next
column2: we travel further north to learn more about the so-called barbarians that the Romans were so worried about. The dig is on the shores of the Moray Firth
column3: where archaeologists are uncovering a fort which once belonged to the Picts. A wealth of new evidence suggests that far from being barbaric savages
column4: they were a sophisticated people who were perhaps far more educated than anyone has given them credit for.

column1: Alice also visits the town of Rochdale in Lancashire
column3: where a huge community dig is altering our understanding of the Industrial Revolution. Alice meets local families who are digging beneath the spectacular Gothic town hall to uncover the remains of terraces and tenement blocks that housed the working men and women of Rochdale
column4: shedding new light on the way industrialisation changed our towns and cities.

column1: In Northern Ireland
column2: another community dig highlights a particularly dark period of recent history
column3: the Great Famine of the mid-19th century. For the first time in Northern Ireland
column4: a team are excavating one of the island of Ireland’s many famine roads. These were roads built by the starving population. Often going nowhere
column5: they were part of a misguided attempt by the British government to boost Irish infrastructure and support the hungry by forcing them to build roads in exchange for money to buy food. Historian Onyeka Nubia travels to London to search for evidence that might explain the British government’s reasoning for what turned out to be a futile relief effort.

column1: Back in Scotland
column2: a new tramline being built from Edinburgh to Leith gives archaeologists the opportunity to study and preserve hundreds of skeletons unearthed at a graveyard dating back to 1300. This dig throws new light on the residents of Leith as they lived through 500 years of Scotland’s history. In the Digging for Britain tent
column3: archaeologist John Lawson brings in one skeleton with a unique set of injuries
column4: and an incredible facial reconstruction brings her vividly to life.

column1: Finally
column2: a once-in-a-lifetime find under a golf course sets archaeological pulses racing as a Bronze Age wooden coffin is remarkably preserved in the waterlogged soil 3
column3: 000 years after it was buried.";History;BBC TWO;False;2022;59;signed

column1: 1632;1632;Katie Price: Harvey and Me;None;Katie Price and her disabled son Harvey face a crucial year of his life
column5: Katie Price: Harvey and Me;Katie Price and her disabled son Harvey face a crucial year of his life
column6: as he turns 18.;A deeply personal film following Katie Price and her disabled son Harvey in a crucial year of his life
column7: as he turns 18 and becomes an adult. ;"A deeply personal film about Katie Price and her disabled son Harvey in a crucial year of his life
column8: as he turns 18 and becomes an adult. It’s an exciting milestone for them both
column9: but for some disabled young adults like Harvey it also brings a daunting uncertainty as the people and places that have cared for him as a child are about to change. Now Harvey and Katie must navigate this transition together
column10: and Katie has some tough decisions to make on Harvey's behalf - such as where he will live and what his future will look like - and in doing so she must also learn to let go.

column1: Harvey was born with septic optic dysplasia
column2: a rare disorder that affects brain function
column5: 000 births. He has a long list of medical and behavioural conditions
column6: and his future is unpredictable. As he moves into adulthood
column7: it marks a transition into unchartered territory as there are no other adults known to have Harvey’s combination of conditions.

column1: As Harvey and Katie explore the options of further education colleges and meet other families with disabled young adults
column2: he reconnects with an old friend whose been through his transition year and is now flourishing in college
column3: and whose mum gives Katie some sound advice.

column1: Katie is forced to face what could be at stake if she makes the wrong decision
column3: whose autistic son Matthew was sectioned at 15 years old. Katie discovers that there are over 2
column4: 000 people with autism or learning disabilities currently kept against their will in assessment and treatment units.

column1: Harvey and Katie open up their lives
column2: sharing their personal highs and lows at a crucial time of change. We get to know Harvey
column3: and through him and his relationship with his mum
column4: we get to know a very different Katie to the one so often seen in the tabloids – as a mum dealing with issues that so many parents of disabled children and young adults face.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2021;58;signed

column1: 1633;1633;Louis Theroux;Shooting Joe Exotic;Louis investigates a captivating and controversial icon: 'Tiger King' Joe Exotic.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09d6whr.jpg;BBC
column5: Shooting Joe Exotic;Louis investigates a captivating and controversial icon: 'Tiger King' Joe Exotic.;A decade on
column6: Louis revisits Joe Exotic - 'gay hillbilly'
column7: convicted felon and cult figure. He digs deep into Joe's background
column8: meets Carole Baskin and asks what made the Tiger King.;"This 90-minute special sees Louis Theroux travel to America to investigate the story of a man who has become one of the most controversial and captivating icons of recent times: the gun-toting
column9: self-described 'gay hillbilly' and 'Tiger King' Joe Exotic.

column1: A decade on from when he first met Joe for the documentary America’s Most Dangerous Pets
column3: responding to a direct call from Joe to tell the ‘real story’ and to explore the saga of an animal hoarder turned convicted felon. Joe now resides in a federal prison
column4: having been found guilty of a murder-for-hire plot and multiple animal cruelty charges. But rather than living as a pariah
column5: Joe is now a media phenomenon
column6: the object of international obsession for pundits
column7: celebrities and viewers
column8: with a well-funded campaign team attempting to win him a presidential pardon.

column1: Looking back at his original documentary
column2: Louis reflects on hours of unseen footage and sets out to understand who the real Joe Exotic is and how he used his considerable charm and wiles to assemble a vast menagerie of animals and humans
column3: all roped into a grand project of vanity and deception. Meeting old friends and family members of Joe’s
column4: Louis picks apart the true crime story of how Joe came to be convicted. He also tells the story of Joe’s captivating charisma and the way in which it became a key ingredient in a viral television sensation
column5: with life-changing consequences for all those involved - most of all Carole Baskin
column6: originally the object of Joe’s vitriol
column7: who found herself the target of his murder-for-hire plot and a mass trolling campaign.

column1: He digs deep into Joe’s family
column2: unearthing the origin story of Joe’s pathology and laying bare an only-in-America saga that is part crime story
column4: part animal rights campaign but ultimately a 21st-century fable of a cowboy-cum-cult leader whose very fragility became a source of power - a power which
column5: in some respects
column6: persists to this day.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains very strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;89;signed

column1: 1634;1634;The Unwanted: The Secret Windrush Files;None;David Olusoga opens secret government files to explore the Windrush scandal.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jhxn0.jpg;BBC
column4: The Unwanted: The Secret Windrush Files;David Olusoga opens secret government files to explore the Windrush scandal.;How black immigrants who made Britain their home came face to face with the government's 'hostile environment'. David Olusoga exposes the secret files behind the Windrush scandal.;"David Olusoga opens secret government files to show how the Windrush scandal and the ‘hostile environment’ for black British immigrants has been 70 years in the making.

column1: The film features Sarah O’Connor
column2: Anthony Bryan and Judy Griffith. Settled here legally since childhood
column3: they were re-classified as illegal immigrants by new ‘hostile environment’ regulations. Unable to show proof of their nationality status
column5: savings and their health
column6: facing deportation back to countries they could barely remember.

column1: David reveals how today’s scandal is rooted in the secrets of the past. The first Windrush generation were Commonwealth citizens - many of them ex-servicemen - coming to rebuild war-torn Britain. Yet even before arriving
column2: they were viewed by the government with hostility. Civil servants and MPs warned of dire consequences if what they called a ‘coloured element’ was introduced into the UK. PM Clement Attlee even suggested diverting the Windrush passengers to east Africa - to pick peanuts.

column1: The same government was actively recruiting tens of thousands of white volunteer workers from Europe - some of them former members of Waffen-SS regiments which stood accused of war crimes on the Eastern Front - for ‘permanent settlement here with a view to their inter-marrying and complete absorption into our own working population’. The files expose how successive British governments spent the next decade trying to devise a way to prevent further Caribbean arrivals without appearing to discriminate against them. PM Winston Churchill
column2: dissatisfied with ministers’ response to what he saw as a serious problem
column3: kept the issue on the cabinet agenda and a special Working Party was set up to gather information to make the political case for immigration controls. Two weeks after the Queen’s coronation as head of the UK and Commonwealth
column4: a secret race survey was undertaken and completed
column5: looking for proof that Commonwealth immigrants were a burden on the welfare state. Chief constables in major cities were asked if ‘the coloured community as a whole
column6: or particular sections of it
column7: are generally idle or poor workmen’
column8: and if they were ‘addicted to drug-trafficking or other types of crime’. The Working Party found no evidence for the view that the ‘coloured community’ was less law-abiding or hard working than other Brits.

column1: When Harold Macmillan’s government introduced the 1962 Immigration Act
column2: its control mechanism was the employment prospects of would-be immigrants. The files show how home secretary ‘Rab’ Butler
column3: described the ‘great merit’ of the scheme was that it ‘can be presented as making no distinction on grounds of race or colour’
column5: in practice
column6: ‘operate on coloured people almost exclusively’. By that time
column7: Caribbean immigration had shrunk to a fraction of earlier levels. But
column8: fearing further restrictions
column9: the Windrush generation now arranged for their children to come. The ‘children of the Windrush' had full legal rights to join their parents in the UK
column10: and many arrived with little paperwork or official record keeping.

column1: Successive governments passed new immigration and nationality legislation
column2: often in response to perceived ‘problems’ or ‘crises’. Harold Wilson rushed through the 1968 Immigration Act
column3: in just three days to stop arrivals of thousands of passport-holding British-Indians living in Kenya
column4: whose businesses and livelihoods were threatened by its government. Edward Heath’s 1971 Act tried to restrict the legal definition of ‘Britishness’. It also placed the burden of proof on the claimant should their Britishness be challenged - a fateful clause for the ‘children of the Windrush’.

column1: Throughout the multiple changes to immigration and nationality law enacted up to 2014
column2: the nationality status of the ‘children of Windrush’ remained unchanged and unchallenged. As British citizens with full legal rights to live here
column5: raised children and grandchildren and contributed in ways great and small to the creation of modern Britain. But with the introduction of the so-called ‘hostile environment’ legislation of 2014 and 2016
column6: their situation changed. Though they were never the intended targets of the new laws
column7: the hostile environment machine that evolved over the decade wasn’t designed to make allowances. Suddenly required to prove their status (due to the 1971 Act)
column8: Sarah
column9: Anthony and Judy found themselves unable to show the levels of proof demanded by the new ‘hostile environment’ regulations. All three lost their jobs for up to two years and ran up debt trying to make ends meet. Anthony was arrested twice by Immigration Officers and held for weeks in detention centres. Then a ticket was bought to deport him to Jamaica
column10: a country hadn’t seen since he left
column11: aged eight
column12: in 1965. ‘They broke me in there
column13: ’ Anthony says. ‘It was hard.’ Judy Griffith
column14: still struggling to repay her debts
column15: says: ‘It makes you question the whole
column16: what is British? What is Britishness?’";History;BBC TWO;False;2019;59;signed

column1: 1645;1645;Zara McDermott;Uncovering Rape Culture;Zara McDermott investigates ‘rape culture’ raging in UK schools
column5: Zara McDermott
column6: Uncovering Rape Culture;Zara McDermott investigates ‘rape culture’ raging in UK schools
column7: revealing her own story.;Zara McDermott uncovers a ‘rape culture’ raging in Britain’s schools. She speaks for the first time about her own sexual assault by a schoolboy
column8: and asks what needs to change.;"Beginning with her own sexual assault
column9: Zara investigates sexism and ‘rape culture’ in Britain. The assault left her with many unanswered questions. Why did it happen? Why did he think he could do it? And where did he learn that? Speaking to her friends
column10: it quickly became clear that they all had their own stories - and many believe the problem starts at school.

column1: In spring 2021
column2: the website Everyone’s Invited was flooded with thousands of anonymous testimonies from schoolgirls sharing stories of sexual assault and harassment. An emergency Ofsted report confirmed that rape culture has been raging unchecked in our schools
column3: and that urgent action is needed to tackle it. In this timely documentary
column4: Zara speaks to young women and girls about their experience of rape culture. Exploring both state and private schools
column5: Zara speaks to pupils to understand first-hand how these toxic behaviours happen.

column1: Zara also meets young women who have been assaulted or raped by pupils at their school
column2: finding out what action was taken by their schools while their cases were underway. One ex-pupil's perpetrator was allowed to remain in school alongside her during the trial and after his sentence was served. Another pupil tells Zara that she is too ashamed to tell her school and parents about her assault
column3: fearing that no-one will believe her. And finally
column4: Zara meets the friends and family of 12-year-old Semina Halliwell
column5: who alleged she was raped by a boy from her school. She took her own life in June 2021. Her mum
column6: Rachel
column7: speaks about the devastation at the loss of her daughter and the rape culture on social media that she blames for Semina's tragic death.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains very strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;58;signed

column5: Series 1: Episode 3;Miriam Margolyes concludes her trip by meeting an all-female biker gang in New Orleans.;Miriam Margolyes concludes her trip by examining race hate in Arkansas
column6: speaking to an inspirational sheriff in Texas and meeting an all-female biker gang in New Orleans.;"This final episode finds Miriam smack in the middle of cowboy country - rural Arkansas - hanging out with Wild West cattle farmers and western goods emporium owners Dan and Peggy Eoff. Seduced by the landscape
column7: Miriam feels the stark divide between city and country folk and sees first-hand why they feel Trump is their man.

column1: But the divisions don't stop there - Arkansas also has one of the highest concentrations of extreme race-hate groups in the US. A short drive from Dan and Peggy's
column3: once dubbed the most racist town in America. With historical links to the Ku Klux Klan
column4: Miriam meets town residents who are determined to clear Harrison's unfortunate reputation. But despite the majority of people she meets helping to reassure her
column5: a member of a local alt-right group also agrees to meet her. Due to his extreme anti-Semitic views
column6: he refuses to be in the same room as Miriam but will answer her questions via a non-Jewish member of the production team.

column1: Upset and shaken by her encounter
column2: Miriam begins to wonder just how united the United States is. Thankfully hope is on the horizon in neighbouring Texas
column3: where she is buoyed by meeting the inspirational Zena Stephens
column4: the state's first ever African-American female Sheriff
column5: who is breaking down prejudice and hate in the divided city of Beaumont.

column1: Still in Texas
column2: one of the most religious states in the country
column3: Miriam heads to stay with the Flanders
column4: a devout Christian family. Doug and Jennifer have 12 children and believe the only way for the USA and the rest of the world to unite is through Christ. Atheist Miriam disagrees.

column1: After nearly two months and over a thousand miles
column2: Miriam's final destination is New Orleans for a thrilling meeting with the Caramel Curves - the city's all-female biker gang. Throughout her trip Miriam has witnessed a country in flux
column3: but at journey's end she is optimistic that the strength of the people she has met will bring the country back on its feet. Failing that
column5: maybe she should be president?!";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2018;58;signed

column1: In November 1969
column2: Helen Puttock was found dead after she went out dancing at the Barrowland Ballroom with her sister. She was the third woman to have been murdered in similar circumstances
column3: and Glasgow detectives now feared that they were dealing with a serial killer.

column1: Journalist Magnus Linklater recounts the interview he conducted with Helen’s sister Jeannie Williams
column2: who was with her the night she was killed. Jeannie left Helen in a taxi with a man named John
column3: who they had met at the Barrowland earlier that night. Jeannie’s testimony about the mysterious red-haired
column4: smart-suited man with crooked teeth who quoted from the Bible would form the basis of the biggest manhunt Scotland had ever seen. This is the story of that incredible and groundbreaking investigation
column5: and the extraordinary effort made by the police
column6: led by DSI Joe Beattie
column7: to try and find the killer.";Documentary;BBC ONE SCOTLAND;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2021;59;signed

column6: the Syrian president must decide how to act as Arab Spring protests reach Syria's streets.;"Three-part series delving into the story of the Assad dynasty. Right at the centre of it are President Bashar and his wife Asma
column7: who met and fell in love in London. Bashar al-Assad trained to be an eye doctor at St Mary's Hospital in Paddington and Asma was a British-born girl from a Syrian family with a career in investment banking. Over a decade ago
column8: they were being welcomed with open arms in Britain. Today
column9: they are entrenched in a brutal war that has led to some of the most horrifying crimes of modern times. Told through rarely seen footage and testimony of those who knew them
column10: worked with them and studied them
column11: the series explores how the couple
column12: who at first were seen as a modernising force
column13: ended up running a regime accused of war crimes.

column1: The final episode gives the view from the presidential palace as the country descends into civil war
column2: charting the moral lines crossed over the past seven years. Bashar al-Assad has been president of Syria for a decade
column3: while his wife Asma is enjoying her role as first lady
column4: pushing charity drives and encouraging schoolchildren to discuss democracy. As a glamorous profile of Asma appears in Vogue magazine
column5: the Arab Spring protests reach Syria. Bashar must decide whether to concede to their demands for greater freedom or follow in his father Hafez's hard line steps. What unfolds shocks the world in its brutality. As the chaos of civil war rages
column6: the so-called Islamic State emerges and it looks like Bashar is on the brink of losing the Assad dynasty's control of Syria. Then a saviour emerges
column7: turning the war back in his favour.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains upsetting scenes.;2018;59;signed

column5: Series 1: 6. Sweet & Easy;Nadiya shares recipes a giant time-saving cookie and a glistening nutty baklava.;Nadiya shares her favourite recipes for when she wants to whip up something sweet and delicious
column6: but deceptively simple
column7: including a giant time-saving cookie and a glistening nutty baklava.;"With unsociable working hours
column8: busy lifestyles and complicated family routines
column9: it is not always easy to make time to cook delicious meals. Nadiya Hussain comes to the rescue with time-saving recipes and ingenious kitchen tips to make sure that everyone has more time to spend doing the things they love
column10: with the people they love.

column1: In the sixth episode of the series
column2: Nadiya shares her favourite recipes for when she wants to whip up something sweet and delicious
column4: when life is really hectic there are times when we all need to spoil ourselves with an indulgent treat
column5: but that doesn't have to mean spending hours in the kitchen. Colourful milkshake funnel cakes have all the fun of fresh doughnuts with none of the fuss. A giant time-saving cookie is so easy it is fried in the pan
column6: and a glistening nutty baklava looks so impressive but is completely foolproof.

column1: On the road
column2: Nadiya joins the Tate and Lyle tea on the River Thames to find out how they produce one of her favourite fast tracks to flavour - golden syrup. And in Liverpool

column1: 1659;1659;Rise of the Nazis;Origins: 3. Night of the Long Knives;Hitler and Himmler conspire to depose Röhm and make the SS the main Nazi paramilitary.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07m9rqy.jpg;BBC
column5: Origins: 3. Night of the Long Knives;Hitler and Himmler conspire to depose Röhm and make the SS the main Nazi paramilitary.;Threatened by the ambition of SA leader Ernst Röhm
column6: Hitler is persuaded by Himmler to destroy Röhm and his stormtroopers and make the SS Germany’s only paramilitary force.;"Adolf Hitler has been chancellor of Germany for just under a year. It is a challenging balancing act. On the one hand
column7: the Nazis must be mindful of President Paul von Hindenburg and Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen
column8: who are members of Germany’s traditional aristocratic ruling elite. On the other
column9: there is the Nazis’ own power base – the stormtroopers - millions of angry
column10: disenfranchised men who wreak havoc on German streets.

column1: The stormtroopers are led by Ernst Röhm
column2: one of Hitler’s oldest and closest friends. Röhm wants Hitler to fulfil his promise to sweep away the traditional ruling class. Hitler owes Röhm: he has paved the way for Hitler’s political career
column3: and his stormtroopers have helped to eradicate left-wing opposition to the Nazi Party. Now
column5: they’re a potential threat - stormtrooper violence is undermining Hitler’s credibility as chancellor.

column1: In a bid to placate Röhm
column3: but Röhm tries to wrestle control of the existing army that reports to President Hindenburg
column4: putting Hitler is in a difficult position
column5: stuck between his president and his old friend.

column1: Röhm’s actions present Hermann Göring with an opportunity to persuade Hitler that his old comrade is no longer a friend
column2: but a threat. But Göring will also need the help of his own rival
column3: Heinrich Himmler. Himmler agrees to help destroy Röhm and his stormtroopers and make the SS Germany’s only paramilitary force.

1661;1661;Inside the Secret World of Incels;None;A never-before-seen look at the incel community.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07j5fhb.jpg;BBC
column4: Inside the Secret World of Incels;A never-before-seen look at the incel community.;A never-before-seen look at the incel community
column5: an online subculture to which multiple mass murders and hate crimes against women have been attributed.;"This documentary offers a never-before-seen look at the incel community
column6: an online subculture linked to multiple mass murders and hate crimes against women.

column2: 22-year-old Elliot Rodger shot and stabbed six of his fellow students to death in a premeditated attack at the University of California
column3: Santa Barbara. His motive? In a chilling video Rodger said he was angry that he was still a virgin and in his words wanted to show himself as 'the true alpha male' by punishing women for not being attracted to him.

column1: The legacy of Rodger's assault catapulted online incels into wider consciousness. Incels - short for 'involuntary celibates' - are a global community of sexually frustrated young men
column2: who have found support amongst one another on the net. Some idolise Rodger
column4: his murder spree seems to have helped inspire at least three further mass killings in North America
column5: that have mainly targeted women.

column1: At its extreme
column3: which blames women for depriving men of sex and relationships. Some forums have recorded up to 40
column4: 000 members and feature depraved ideas like state-sponsored rape and girlfriends.

column1: Following eight months of unprecedented access to incels
column2: this documentary is the deepest exploration yet of this notoriously closed community.

column1: Told primarily through the personal stories of three men who identify as incels
column2: the documentary explores how an online ideology can push young men into very disturbing behaviour. But the film also delves behind the sensationalist media headlines to unearth some of the reasons for incels' existence - many feel alienated and are enduring difficulties

column1: For some
column2: the online forums are a haven to joke
column3: vent and find support in a world where they are struggling to find an identity and where gender relations are changing dramatically. The question is
column4: where are the lines between this radical misogyny and violence?";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains very strong language and disturbing scenes.;2019;50;signed

column1: 1663;1663;Fighting the Power: Britain after George Floyd;None;Reporter Daniel Henry follows the UK’s response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08l3p9t.jpg;BBC
column4: Fighting the Power: Britain after George Floyd;Reporter Daniel Henry follows the UK’s response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota;Daniel Henry follows the Black Lives Matter campaign in the UK
column5: as the country is forced to look again at its record on race in the wake of the death of George Floyd in the US.;"George Floyd’s killing in the US state of Minnesota sparked protests about policing
column6: privilege and a revolution in race relations. Britain boldly presents itself as a beacon of racial tolerance
column7: but with demonstrations sweeping the country
column8: organisers believe that they are closer than ever to changing the way British institutions and individuals treat black people across the UK. There have been multiple campaigns for equality and justice for black British communities in the past
column9: but none quite like this.

column1: The worldwide response to George Floyd’s death has given confidence to a new generation that this time could be different. The people behind the protests in Britain believe that they have the tools
column3: language and technology to create a new reality - but is this country ready to move beyond tolerance
column4: to become an actively anti-racist society? The Windrush scandal
column5: Grenfell and a recent resurgence in far-right terror plots have exposed fault lines across Britain. Now the graphic nature of George Floyd’s death is forcing us all to ask questions about the scale of racism in our communities and to explore what can be done to eliminate it for good.

column1: From Premier League football clubs
column2: to superstar actors like John Boyega
column3: the message is loud and uncompromising: Black Lives Matter. Daniel Henry follows the UK campaign
column4: as the country is forced to look again at its record on race.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2020;48;signed

column1: 1664;1664;The Shipman Files: A Very British Crime Story;Series 1: Episode 3;How the age of Shipman’s victims was key to how he got away with murdering hundreds.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08sjpc0.jpg;BBC
column4: The Shipman Files: A Very British Crime Story
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;How the age of Shipman’s victims was key to how he got away with murdering hundreds.;How the age of Shipman’s victims was key to understanding how he got away with murdering hundreds of patients in plain sight for nearly 30 years.;"This episode opens with the publication of the first report of the public inquiry into the deaths of Shipman’s patients - a report that officially concluded that
column6: while working as a GP
column7: Harold Shipman had murdered 260 of his patients. But how had he got away with killing on such a scale for so long?

column1: Wilson explores the reaction to the staggering total
column2: discovering how commentators came up with a range of theories to try to understand why a seemingly ordinary doctor had killed so many people.

column1: Wilson meets a detective who led a team that questioned Shipman after his conviction about the murders he committed in Todmorden. He reveals how Shipman refused to utter a single word during several days of interrogation – a silence he maintained until he committed suicide in his prison cell
column2: four years into multiple life sentences.

column1: After seeing reports of Shipman’s suicide
column2: a former nurse came forward. She recognised Shipman as a doctor she had worked with as a student nurse at a hospital in Pontefract
column3: West Yorkshire. She had always been troubled by the number of deaths on one of the wards – a ward where she now realised Shipman had worked as a junior doctor. Could he have begun killing there
column4: even before he became a GP?

column1: Wilson tracks down a family whose elderly relative died whilst under Shipman’s care in hospital in Pontefract
column2: as well as another doctor who worked alongside Shipman there. Piecing together their stories
column3: Wilson reveals that not only is it clear that Shipman had begun killing before he qualified as a GP
column4: it is also very likely that Shipman killed at least one child.

column1: The revelation that Shipman had begun killing even before he became a GP and that some of his victims were children is shocking. At the time
column2: the coverage of these revelations differed markedly to the reporting of the deaths of hundreds of Shipman’s elderly victims in Hyde. Wilson asks if these contrasting responses can be explained by the victims’ ages and if that could explain why Shipman targeted mainly elderly patients – not because he was driven by a compulsion to kill old people
column3: but because he knew he would be more likely to get away with it.

column1: Wilson interrogates his own preconceptions about the Shipman case - he had wrongly assumed that Hyde was a town with an above average elderly population and had pictured Shipman’s victims as frail
column4: when in truth they were mostly fit
column5: active members of their community. Wilson concludes that these preconceptions run through the entire Shipman case
column6: informing an attitude and prejudice towards the elderly that allowed a seemingly ordinary GP to get away with murdering hundreds of people
column7: in plain sight
column8: for nearly 30 years.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains upsetting scenes.;2020;59;signed

column10: where people are secretly filmed in their most intimate moments.;"Pornography is illegal in South Korea
column11: and molka has emerged as an illicit DIY alternative. The devastating impact of molka is revealed in the increasing number of molka-related suicides. Now
column12: criminal gangs are starting to install cameras on an industrial scale
column13: selling people’s most private moments as pornography for strangers to consume. The country’s advanced technology allows criminals to stream videos live and share them at lightning speeds.

column1: 1667;1667;Make-up: A Glamorous History;Series 1: 3. Britain in the Roaring 20s;Lisa Eldridge examines how the look of 1920s flappers reflected the freedoms of the era.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09f42z2.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 3. Britain in the Roaring 20s;Lisa Eldridge examines how the look of 1920s flappers reflected the freedoms of the era.;Lisa Eldridge takes us back to Britain in the 1920s. She explores how the look of the flappers reflected the new freedoms of the era and recreates a classic 1920s look.;"Lisa Eldridge explores her favourite era for makeup. This is the moment when modern makeup as we know it arrived in women’s handbags
column6: and it is no coincidence that it appeared at a moment of huge change in British society.

column1: WWI and the global flu pandemic were over. Women were entering the work-force and could now make choices about how they wanted to look and how they spent their money. The flappers cut their hair and put on red lipstick. Lisa explores how
column2: although starting as a shocking look for the few
column3: moved in less than two decades through the pages of magazines and into beauty counters on every high street.

column1: This was the era when Hollywood films
column2: with all their beauty and glamour
column4: and everyone wanted to look like their favourite star. Lisa visits the British Film Institute archives to find out about the impact of cinema on the development of some of our favourite makeup products.

column1: She works with of pharmacist Szu Shen Wong to recreate some of the authentic recipes for foundation
column2: eye makeup and lipstick from the era to try out on herself and on our 21st-century model.

column1: Lisa takes us on a journey across the years when makeup turned from something shocking to a near-requirement among women everywhere.";History;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;signed

Now top insiders from government and finance lift the lid on how it happened.;"The government and the Bank of England took drastic action to save the UK economy in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. Insiders from the world of finance tell us how decisions made to solve the crisis allowed them to ‘make out like bandits.’

column1: From bailing out the banks to pursuing a faster
column2: deeper austerity than any other country

column1: 1673;1673;Ambulance;Series 7: Episode 6;A crew attend to a 13-year-old patient who is stuck on a bus having dislocated her knee.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09r5q2t.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 7: Episode 6;A crew attend to a 13-year-old patient who is stuck on a bus having dislocated her knee.;A quiet start to the night shift is broken by a 999 call on behalf of a 13-year-old patient who is stuck on a bus having dislocated her knee.;"The episode joins the North West Ambulance Service as the Covid-19 vaccine rollout is beginning to take effect. The service has so far managed to vaccinate 70 per cent of its frontline workforce.

column1: A quiet start to the night shift is broken by a 999 call on behalf of a 13-year-old patient who is stuck on a bus having dislocated her knee. She is unable to move and in severe pain
column2: so the crew have no choice but to try to get the knee back in place at the scene.

column1: Across the city
column2: crewmates Adam and Charlotte respond to a call for a patient who is struggling to breathe. As Covid-19 has already affected the patient's family
column3: the crew have no choice but to take them to hospital. Another patient with breathing difficulties is reluctant to go to hospital for fear of catching the virus there. However
column4: Covid-related deaths in the UK are at their lowest since December
column5: and call volumes to the service are also down.

column1: Later
column2: Adam and Charlotte are dispatched to a patient who is lapsing in and out of consciousness. When they arrive on scene
column3: they suspect the patient may have suffered a stroke. Elsewhere
column4: Emily and Lois attend to a patient who has taken an overdose of prescribed medication. As the patient is sent to hospital
column5: it becomes clear that their anxiety has been exacerbated by months of isolation.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains some strong language and some upsetting scenes.;2021;57;signed;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09r5q2t.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09r5q2t.jpg;episode join north west ambulance service covid19 vaccine rollout beginning take effect service far managed vaccinate 70 per cent frontline workforce quiet start night shift broken 999 call behalf 13yearold patient stuck bus dislocated knee unable move severe pain crew choice try get knee back place scene across city crewmates adam charlotte respond call patient struggling breathe covid19 already affected patient family crew choice take hospital another patient breathing difficulty reluctant go hospital fear catching virus however covidrelated death uk lowest since december call volume service also later adam charlotte dispatched patient lapsing consciousness arrive scene suspect patient may suffered stroke elsewhere emily lois attend patient taken overdose prescribed medication patient sent hospital becomes clear anxiety exacerbated month isolation;1

Leeds is a shock to a Greek war bride with a tragic past and a return for students who lived here at the millennium.;"The final episode opens at the outbreak of the Second World War
column6: and our house is home to the Wood family. While father John serves as an ARP warden
column7: teenage son Geoffrey joins the Merchant Navy and finds his ship is a target for German U-boats.

column1: The next residents are Yorkshireman Michael and his Greek wife Popi. Tracing their story
column2: David uncovers a romance forged in war-torn Europe that leads the couple to England via Italy and eventually to a bustling neighbourhood of New York City.

column1: As Britain lifts out of post-war austerity
column2: the house is bought by Alan and Edith Weir. They both work on famous newspaper the Yorkshire Post. In Edith
column3: David discovers a woman with surprising talents.

column1: Finally
column2: there’s an emotional return to Number 5 for a group of students who shared our house around the millennium
column3: witnessing first-hand Leeds’s rebirth from industrial decline to a vibrant modern city.";History;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;signed

column5: Series 4: 5. Who’s Watching the Kids?;Emily Brown investigates the effect social media companies are having on children's lives.;Social media companies collect huge amounts of personal data from children in order to target content at them. How is this affecting their lives?;"Social media companies collect huge amounts of personal data from children in order to target content at them.

column1: Reporter Emily Brown investigates how this is affecting their lives. She looks at the rise of 'kidfluencers'
column2: the children who can make millions talking to other children online. The programme also examines whether regulators should be doing more to control the booming ad tech market.

1677;1677;The Grand Party Hotel;Series 1: Episode 4;MD Kris is asked to fight in a charity boxing match to be staged at the hotel.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08r64wh.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, The Grand Party Hotel, Series 1: Episode 4;MD Kris is asked to fight in a charity boxing match to be staged at the hotel.;The staff go above and beyond again as MD Kris is asked to fight in a charity boxing match at the hotel. Can he make the leap from mild-mannered hotel manager to prize fighter?;Senior director Kris always goes above and beyond the call of duty
column2: and now owner Lawrence has asked him to do something completely out of his comfort zone - fight in a charity boxing match being held at the hotel. Kris is not a fan of boxing and is hesitant to take on the challenge
column3: but the proceeds will go to the homeless shelter that Lawrence set up when he kept finding rough sleepers in the hotel car park. To raise cash
column5: but his wife Katie isn’t keen on seeing her husband in the ring.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: VIP guest Louise Brookes has checked in. She has stayed at the hotel more than 175 times and always requests room 118
column3: but there is a problem with the room
column4: so the staff race to repair the damage. The reason for Louise’s attachment to the room is because it became like home for her when she stayed for many months while attending the inquest into the Hillsborough disaster. Her brother was one of the 96 who died in the tragedy
column5: and during her stay Louise lights a candle for him at the permanent memorial to the victims in reception.

column1: Weddings are an important revenue generator for the hotel
column3: wedding planner Ciara organises up to four weddings per week. But bookings are down for next year
column4: so Ciara launches a new competition called Runaway Bride to promote weddings at the hotel.

column1: Doorman Eric has his hands full at the hotel welcoming a very different sort of guest - 100 pensioners for a ballroom dancing event. Eighty-three-year-old Jerry still likes to stay light on his feet
column2: and when hotel owner Katie’s mum shows up
column3: he tries to make her feel at home. It is Christine’s first big event since her husband passed away. Katie is feeling protective towards her mum
column4: but after a few tentative steps
column5: Christine finds her feet and starts to enjoy herself.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2020;58;signed

column1: 1679;1679;The Black American Fight for Freedom;None;Revealing the moments where America had the chance to become more equal but failed.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09j8cpv.jpg;BBC
column4: The Black American Fight for Freedom;Revealing the moments where America had the chance to become more equal but failed.;Fifty years on from the promise of equality and the Civil Rights Act
column5: this documentary reveals the moments where America had the chance to become more equal and why that didn’t happen.;"In America
column6: if you're black
column7: you're five times more likely to go to prison than if you’re white. And the typical white family has eight times the wealth of the typical black family.

column1: Fifty years on from the promise of equality and the Civil Rights Act
column2: this documentary reveals the moments where America had the chance to become more equal and why that didn’t happen.

column1: Through compelling interviews with those who were at the forefront of the struggle for a fair system in education
column3: the film reveals the key court cases
column4: Supreme Court rulings and laws that failed to bridge the gap.

column1: It gives us the shocking context to the anger felt by the millions of people who took to the streets during the Black Lives Matter protests. The movement was not just calling for an end to police brutality but also asking for something that had been pledged 50 years ago: racial equality.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;signed

column1: 1680;1680;Jay Blades: Learning to Read at 51;None;Jay Blades
column3: struggles to read. It’s finally time to learn.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bhvylz.jpg;BBC
column5: TV
column6: Jay Blades: Learning to Read at 51;Jay Blades
column7: presenter of The Repair Shop
column8: struggles to read. It’s finally time to learn.;Jay Blades
column9: presenter of The Repair Shop
column10: struggles to read. Now he has decided it is finally time to learn.;"Jay Blades
column11: presenter of The Repair Shop
column12: has decided it’s finally time to learn to read. He has been told he has the reading age of an 11-year-old. Throughout his life he has found ways of avoiding the written word
column13: and this film digs deep into how this has shaped him.

column1: Blades left school with no qualifications and nothing to his name than a reputation as a great fighter. Can he now
column3: tackle what he failed to learn the first time round?

column1: He’s not alone in facing this issue. Research findings suggest that a quarter of all children in England leave primary school
column3: unable to read to the expected level. More than eight million adults in the UK have poor literacy skills
column4: and half of all prisoners either can’t read or struggle to do so.

column1: Using a system developed for use in prisons by the Shannon Trust
column2: Jay commits to learn to read with Read Easy
column3: a charity whose volunteers do one-to-one coaching. Along the way
column4: he revisits key moments in his life that were shaped by not being able to read: the ‘learner’ class at school
column5: the dead-end jobs he had to take because he had no qualifications
column6: and not being able to read his children bedtime stories. Daughter Zola is now 15
column7: and Jay wants to read her a story before she reaches adulthood on her next birthday.

column1: Following Jay over six months of learning
column2: this intimate and revealing film goes behind closed doors to see how he organizes his upholstery business without the written word
column3: manages on The Repair Shop without scripts and struggles each day with his vowels and consonants as he tries to learn phonics. We meet Jay’s girlfriend Lisa
column4: his daughter Zola and his ‘adopted’ family who all help him with his reading challenge. Jay also meets school pupils and adults who struggle with reading and writing
column5: as he discovers the human stories behind the nation’s literacy statistics.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains some strong language.;2022;58;signed

The Toughest Challenge Ever;Matilda and her brother race against each other in one of LA's toughest sporting events.;Matilda and her brother Jack race against each other in one of LA's toughest sporting events - the gruelling pier-to-pier swimming race.;The Ramsay bunch are having a fab summer in Los Angeles but it is getting serious as Matilda and her brother Jack go head to head
column6: racing against each other in one of LA's toughest sporting events - the gruelling pier-to-pier swimming race. They have to swim two and a half miles against a strong current
column7: in the cold and very rough Pacific Ocean. Even though super-sporty dad Gordon has been coaching Tilly
column8: Jack is still convinced he can beat her. Because she is otherwise engaged
column9: Tilly has been super-organised and left video instructions for mum Tana to make a delicious post-race re-booster - a fruity smoothie bowl. But before they get to eat that
column10: it is a nerve-wracking time for the Ramsay bunch as they wait to see if Jack and Tilly can complete the toughest challenge they have ever taken on and make it safely back to dry land. To cap off an incredible day
column11: Tilly cooks a celebratory brunch of champions - delicious all-American waffles with letter eggs and scrummy oven-baked chicken.;CBBC;CBBC;False;2017;15;signed;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08jzr2z.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08jzr2z.jpg;ramsay bunch fab summer los angeles getting serious matilda brother jack go head head racing one la toughest sporting event gruelling piertopier swimming race swim two half mile strong current cold rough pacific ocean even though supersporty dad gordon coaching tilly jack still convinced beat otherwise engaged tilly superorganised left video instruction mum tana make delicious postrace rebooster fruity smoothie bowl get eat nervewracking time ramsay bunch wait see jack tilly complete toughest challenge ever taken make safely back dry land cap incredible day tilly cook celebratory brunch champion delicious allamerican waffle letter egg scrummy ovenbaked chicken;7

column5: Series 2: 2. Inside the Enquiry;Exploring what it is like to work on devastating cases like the murder of Alesha MacPhail.;Exploring what it is like to work on devastating cases
column6: like the murder of Alesha MacPhail and the disappearance of Julie Reilly.;"Police Scotland’s major investigation teams deal with around 60 murders a year. This episode delves deeper into the nature of the job.

column1: Through gripping actuality sequences and in-depth interviews with both senior and rookie detectives
column2: discover what it is like to work on such devastating cases like the murder of Alesha MacPhail and the disappearance of Julie Reilly. These are the men and women who go to the very worst crime scenes and deal with the very worst offenders
column3: trying to find answers to situations that defy explanation. Their dogmatic pursuit for justice makes sure no stone is left unturned.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2020;58;signed

column1: 1684;1684;Secrets of an ISIS Smartphone;None;The extraordinary story of a phone used by three British men who joined ISIS in Syria.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09p6vr0.jpg;BBC
column4: Secrets of an ISIS Smartphone;The extraordinary story of a phone used by three British men who joined ISIS in Syria.;With extraordinary access to a smartphone used by three British men who went to fight in Syria
column5: Mobeen Azhar uncovers what made them join ISIS and what happened to them.;"Our smartphones hold our secrets - the version of ourselves we may not want to show the world. With extraordinary access to the contents of a smartphone used by three British men who left their homes to go to Syria and fight with ISIS
column6: journalist Mobeen Azhar uncovers what happened to the three men. Mobeen tries to understand their motivations
column7: how they became radicalised and who is ultimately responsible for their one-way journey to certain death. Using previously unseen videos
column8: photos and screenshots from the smartphone
column9: Mobeen explores what made these three men join an estimated 900 Britons who went out to Syria and Iraq to fight with the world’s most feared terrorist group.

column1: While much of the media’s focus has been on the schoolgirls who went to join ISIS
column2: a much larger number of the Britons who made this journey were young men. The three men who feature on the smartphone came from very different backgrounds
column3: and one was a private school boy. Reaching out to the people who really knew them
column4: Mobeen pieces together their stories of hope and delusion - a case study in how extremist ideology takes hold of a life.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;46;signed

column1: 1685;1685;Statue Wars: One Summer in Bristol;None;Documenting the events that followed the toppling of the Colston statue in Bristol.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09kspxw.jpg;BBC
column4: Statue Wars: One Summer in Bristol;Documenting the events that followed the toppling of the Colston statue in Bristol.;Follows Bristol’s mayor
column5: Marvin Rees
column6: as he and the city respond to the extraordinary events which followed the toppling of the Colston Statue last summer.;"On Sunday 7th June 2020
column7: sparked by the horrific murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis
column8: protestors marching to support the Black Lives Matter movement tore down the statue of slave trader Edward Colston and threw it in the city’s harbour.

column1: This dramatic action in Bristol thrust the city onto the global stage and put it at the forefront of last summer's bitter culture wars.
Caught in the eye of this storm was Bristol’s mayor Marvin Rees
column2: the first directly elected mayor of Black African heritage of a major European city.

column1: DJ and broadcaster Jamz Supernova speaks to fellow DJ’s Sherelle and Plastician and other DJs about what it feels like to go from packed touring schedules to empty diaries and what it might mean for their careers.

column9: Dan Walker and Vick Hope.;"To raise money for 2021’s Red Nose Day
column10: professional racing driver Billy Monger pushes himself to the limit as he takes on a truly unforgettable celebrity challenge - walking
column11: kayaking and cycling 140 miles across England
column12: an enormous test of mental and physical endurance. To complete this incredible challenge
column13: Billy will have to overcome the unpredictable British elements and the odds. Four years ago
column14: Billy became a double amputee as a result of a horrendous racing accident.

column1: To make it to the finish line
column2: Billy will have to walk further than he has ever had to before
column3: kayak for the first time in his life and learn how to cycle again following his crash. But if anyone can do it
column4: Billy can. As a successful racing driver
column5: Billy is already used to pushing the limits of what can be achieved.

column9: who pick up migrants who have illegally crossed the Rio Grande river in search of a new life.;"Simon Reeve continues his journey through the Americas. In this fourth leg of the journey
column10: Simon travels through Texas and down the length of Mexico. In Texas
column11: Simon joins the US Border Patrol
column12: who constantly pick up migrants who have illegally crossed the dangerous Rio Grande river in search of a new life in the United States. In the midst of this humanitarian crisis
column13: Simon meets one woman who risks her life to take vital supplies across the border to stranded migrants on the Mexican side of the border in one of the most violent cities in Mexico. Much of the city of Reynosa is in the grip of a powerful criminal organisation
column14: the Gulf Cartel. Simon visits the elite police force tasked with taking on an enemy that uses high-tech surveillance and an arsenal of US-manufactured weapons to control the border city.

column1: In southern Mexico
column4: culture and history. Chiapas is also home to the largest indigenous population in Mexico
column5: who trace their ancestry to the ancient Mayans. In the depths of the rainforest
column6: Simon explores the Mayan city of Yaxchilan
column7: once a thriving hub of a hugely sophisticated civilisation that prospered long before European settlers arrived in the Americas. Simon discovers that today’s indigenous communities have been marginalised
column8: and many complain they are treated as second-class citizens in Mexico. Until the middle of the 20th century
column9: the Lacandon people had little contact with the outside world. Most still live in the forest like their Mayan ancestors
column10: but as Simon finds out

column5: Series 8: Episode 12;The team restore a chair made for King George VI’s coronation and a mechanical toy clown.;Jay Blades and the team restore a record turntable
column6: a chair made for King George VI’s coronation
column7: a code breaker’s leather writing case and a mechanical toy clown.;"Jay Blades and the team bring four treasured family heirlooms
column8: and the memories they hold
column9: back to life.

column1: Londoner Pablo Henderson is first to arrive
column2: with his late father’s defunct record turntable. His father arrived in the UK from Jamaica in the 1960s and loved music. The turntable would provide the sweet sounds of reggae music for the huge sound system that Pablo’s father set up at neighbourhood parties. Electronics expert Mark Stuckey gets the dilapidated deck back in tip-top condition once again
column3: while Will Kirk crafts an impressive plinth to house it.

column1: Andy Matthews and his daughter Anna have brought in a stately chair for the attention of Will and upholsterer Sonnaz Nooranvary. The chair was made specially for King George VI's coronation ceremony
column2: which Andy’s grandfather attended as an usher. The chair was presented to him as a token of appreciation and has been a source of great pride for their family. However
column3: 90 years have taken their toll on the piece. The wooden frame is unstable
column4: and the velvet fabric is faded and threadbare in places. Together
column5: Will and Sonnaz give it the restoration it deserves.

column1: Wendy Bray is a woman on a mission. She would love leather expert Susie Fletcher to repair and revitalise her late mother’s writing case. Wendy’s mother was a remarkable woman who
column3: worked as a code breaker at Bletchley Park. She was a keen letter writer
column4: and the case was with her always. Wendy would like to preserve the now-tattered case and pass it on to her daughter and granddaughter
column5: through four generations or wonderful women.

column1: And last but not least
column2: Cathy Downie has brought in a beloved mechanical toy clown. It was a gift from her dear Uncle Jimmy
column3: with whom she spent many happy times as a child. She has treasured the acrobatic clown for decades
column4: even though it has been broken for many of them. Fortunately
column5: expert Steve Fletcher knows just how to get this little clown spinning again.";Lifestyle;BBC ONE;False;2022;58;signed;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p099ymlm.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p099ymlm.jpg;jay blade team bring four treasured family heirloom memory hold back life londoner pablo henderson first arrive late father ’ defunct record turntable father arrived uk jamaica 1960s loved music turntable would provide sweet sound reggae music huge sound system pablo ’ father set neighbourhood party electronics expert mark stuckey get dilapidated deck back tiptop condition kirk craft impressive plinth house andy matthew daughter anna brought stately chair attention upholsterer sonnaz nooranvary chair made specially king george vi coronation ceremony andy ’ grandfather attended usher chair presented token appreciation source great pride family however 90 year taken toll piece wooden frame unstable velvet fabric faded threadbare place together sonnaz give restoration deserves wendy bray woman mission would love leather expert susie fletcher repair revitalise late mother ’ writing case wendy ’ mother remarkable woman second world war worked code breaker bletchley park keen letter writer case always wendy would like preserve nowtattered case pas daughter granddaughter four generation wonderful woman last least cathy downie brought beloved mechanical toy clown gift dear uncle jimmy spent many happy time child treasured acrobatic clown decade even though broken many fortunately expert steve fletcher know get little clown spinning;16

column1: Spanning Britain

With anxiety sky-high
column6: in a sport that demands perfection
column7: the mounting pressure proves too much for some.

column1: After narrowly missing out on making the squad last season – by a crushing 0.01 of a point – Emily Hayward is on a mission to ensure this year she makes the grade. To compete with the elite squad
column2: Emily will have to nail her triple jumps
column3: but she suffers a setback when a training session goes wrong. Also hoping to earn a spot on the Performance Squad is 20-year-old skater Eleanor. She has just stepped up from the less pressurised Junior category
column4: and this will be her first competition as a fully fledged Senior competitor.

column1: After failing to impress British Ice Skating judges
column2: ice dance duo Anthony and Eleanor are back in action and more determined than ever to prove to the establishment they are capable of representing GB abroad. Anthony learns a valuable lesson as he grapples with his perfectionist attitude and tries to tame his often cruel inner voice.

column1: Ranked number seven in the world
column2: British ice dance duo Lilah Fear and Lewis Gibson took the skating world by storm with their disco routine in the 2018/19 season and represent Britain’s greatest hope for an Olympic medal in Beijing. The pair travel home from their elite training hub in Montreal and will unveil their brand new programme at the British qualifiers.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2022;50;signed

column1: 1714;1714;9/11: Inside the President's War Room;None;Twelve hours with the president on 9/11 as it changed him
column5: 9/11: Inside the Presidents War Room;Twelve hours with the president on 9/11 as it changed him
column6: America and the world.;Twelve hours with the president on 9/11 – with direct testimony from President Bush
column7: Vice-President Cheney and senior staff – as it changed them
column8: America and the world;"Twenty years ago
column9: at 9.03am on 11 September 2001
column10: the second of four hijacked planes hit the South Tower of the World Trade Center in New York. America was under attack. President George W Bush was sitting in front of seven-year-olds in a classroom in Florida. Members of the president’s security detail thought the next plane could be aimed at them.

column1: A first draft of history and a claustrophobic clock-ticking thriller
column2: this film tells the story of the presidency on arguably the most consequential day in recent history. How should a government deal with a large scale terrorist attack that used four commercial aircraft as missiles? How would they cope with losing their friends? And how could they respond?

column1: As the clock ticks
column2: the administration make the greatest decisions of their lives: should they order fighter jets to shoot on American civilians? Should the president declare war or calm a battered nation? How would the leadership of the most powerful nation on earth grapple with the national and international implications?

column1: This documentary tells the definitive story of the Bush administration through 12 hours of that momentous day
column2: with first-hand testimony from President Bush
column4: National Security Advisor Condoleezza Rice and other senior staff who had their hands on the levers of power. The events of that day led to two decades of conflict in Afghanistan and Iraq. As America and its allies now withdraw from Afghanistan and the Taliban resume control
column5: this is the story of how it all began.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;89;signed

column1: 1718;1718;Cornwall with Simon Reeve;Series 1: Episode 2;Simon Reeve investigates the environmental challenges facing Cornwall.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08xh9lw.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 2;Simon Reeve investigates the environmental challenges facing Cornwall.;Simon Reeve investigates the environmental challenges facing Cornwall and the rest of the country
column6: and on the way encounters some of its iconic wildlife.;"Simon Reeve travels through glorious Cornwall during a summer like no other. As the county emerges from lockdown
column7: the pandemic has thrown up so many questions about the future of one of Britain’s favourite tourist locations.

column1: In the second of two programmes
column2: Simon investigates the environmental challenges facing Cornwall and the rest of the country
column3: and on the way encounters some of its iconic wildlife
column5: the huge grey seal. More than a third of the global population is found in UK waters
column6: where they are threatened by ocean pollution. Diving into coastal waters
column7: Simon accompanies the volunteers who clean up the discarded fishing nets that can entangle and drown the seals.

column1: Travelling inland from the beautiful coast
column2: Simon crosses a county of stunning moorlands. Agriculture is still Cornwall’s biggest employer
column3: and there are exciting new visions for how less intensive forms of farming could be more profitable and environmentally friendly. Simon also discovers the rewilding project where reforesting uplands and introducing beavers promise to tackle the problem of widespread flooding.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2020;59;signed

column1: 1719;1719;The Romantics and Us with Simon Schama;Series 1: 2. The Chambers of the Mind;Simon Schama explores how the romantics became the first explorers of the unconscious.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08qfh29.jpg;BBC
column4: The Romantics and Us with Simon Schama
column5: Series 1: 2. The Chambers of the Mind;Simon Schama explores how the romantics became the first explorers of the unconscious.;Simon explores how the romantics became the first intrepid explorers of dark recesses of the human mind
column6: long before the modern psychological revolution. With contributions from Sir David Attenborough;"With contributions from Tobias Menzies
column7: Peter Doherty
column8: Piotr Anderszewski and Sir David Attenborough
column9: Simon tells the story of how the romantics - fuelled by the failures of the French Revolution and horrors of the industrial revolution – retreated from the tragic uproar of public life to take a journey into their own minds. Here
column10: long before the invention of modern psychology
column11: they discovered the subconscious
column12: something that would have a profound effect on our modern world.

column1: The film starts with the story of one of France’s most celebrated novelists and poets
column2: Victor Hugo. After falling foul of the French emperor
column4: Hugo fled to the island of Guernsey. Here
column5: he created some of the most haunting images of the romantic age
column6: thousands of drawings plucked from his restless
column7: melancholy mind.

column1: Long before Sigmund Freud and the invention of modern psychoanalysis
column2: it is often forgotten that it was the romantics who became the first intrepid explorers of the deepest
column3: darkest corners of the human mind. At the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge
column4: Simon traces the origins of this revolution to the prints of Giambattista Piranesi. His series of Imaginary Prisons are the first images of the inner visions of the mind
column5: and they have had a long-lasting influence in our modern world - not least in modern cinema.

column1: Among those inspired by Piranesi's images was poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge and
column5: writer and wannabe-poet Thomas de Quincey. Both of them used opium to open up ‘the apocalypse of the world within’. Simon tells the story of how both artists changed the way we think about the human mind.

column1: Simon then looks at how the romantics changed the way we think about madness. In their craving for deeper experiences
column2: very few romantics - at one stage or other - didn’t think they were going mad.

column1: One
column3: found a way to avoid the fate of so many his colleagues and friends: William Wordsworth. He was equally interested in the mapping and exploration of his own mind
column4: but he also realised that it was by attaching it to something bigger that he could escape the irrational forces of darkness and self-obsession that threatened to overwhelm him. Meeting Sir David Attenborough
column5: who also reads lines from Tintern Abbey and Wordsworth’s The Tables Turned
column6: Simon asks whether we need to heed the lessons of the romantics before it is too late.

column8: Iain Robertson is joined by photographer Elaine Livingston and River City co-star Grant Stott on the last leg of his 215-mile walk.;"With 71 miles left to tackle on the Southern Upland Way
column9: Iain Robertson is joined by photographer Elaine Livingstone on the walk across to Traquair. They are hopeful of making their way to the famous Traquair House
column10: the oldest inhabited house in Scotland
column11: where they will enjoy a tour of the house's micro-brewery.

column1: Parting company with Elaine
column2: Iain continues to ramble across the country
column3: enjoying hidden gems such as the Cheese Well along the way. He is joined the next day by his River City co-star Grant Stott. The pair head towards Lauder
column4: with Grant sharing anecdotes about his time as a Borders police officer as a youth.

column1: Iain then sets off sets off towards that elusive east coast
column2: dodging an aggressive looking herd of cows
column3: passing over the Lammermoor Hills made famous by a Donizetti opera
column4: and even uncovering the mystery of the Gurkha Bridge in Abbey St Bathans.

column1: The final day of his trek sees Iain navigate his way across a furiously busy A1 as he finally approaches the coast
column2: where a glimpse of the North Sea stops him in his tracks. On his way down to the coast
column4: 'the spiritual end' of the Southern Upland Way

column1: 1723;1723;Patrick Kielty: One Hundred Years of Union;None;Patrick Kielty explores what the future holds for Northern Ireland in its centenary year.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09vxjqf.jpg;BBC
column4: Patrick Kielty: One Hundred Years of Union;Patrick Kielty explores what the future holds for Northern Ireland in its centenary year.;In its centenary year
column5: Patrick Kielty discovers how the trauma of the past is shaping the future of Northern Ireland
column6: and why some feel a united Ireland could be on the horizon.;"On the 100th anniversary of its creation
column7: Patrick Kielty explores what the future holds for Northern Ireland.

column1: He investigates why a new trade border in the Irish Sea has led to violent protests
column2: sparking fear among some of a return to conflict
column3: nearly 25 years after the end of the Troubles; a conflict which claimed thousands of lives
column4: including that of his father Jack Kielty.

column1: In this very personal film
column2: Patrick’s focus is on a new generation born long after the ceasefire
column3: as he tries to understand what is driving this new wave of unrest
column4: particularly in Loyalist communities. He also explores why some feel that a united Ireland could now be on the horizon and how the trauma of Northern Ireland’s past is shaping its future.

1724;1724;Rio and Kate: Becoming a Stepfamily;None;This intimate doc follows the Ferdinands as Kate Wright becomes stepmum to Rio’s children;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0837yh3.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Rio and Kate: Becoming a Stepfamily;This intimate doc follows the Ferdinands as Kate Wright becomes stepmum to Rio’s children;This intimate documentary follows the Ferdinands as Rio’s fiancée Kate Wright integrates into the family and becomes a step mum to his three children.;This intimate and powerful documentary follows the Ferdinand family as Rio’s fiancée Kate Wright integrates into the family and becomes a stepmum to Rio’s three children
column3: Tate and Tia. This is the next stage in the family’s journey following the Bafta- award winning and critically acclaimed 2017 documentary

column1: Two years after Rebecca’s passing
column4: to cancer. So in the months leading up to their wedding
column5: this deeply personal film will look at the emotionally complicated dilemmas this newly formed family unit face following the family’s double bereavement.

column1: For 27 year old Kate
column2: taking on not only the role as Rio’s new partner
column3: but also of ‘mum’ to three grieving children
column4: and with the memory of Rebecca and Janet still very much present
column5: a unique set of emotionally complicated challenges emerge.

column1: Stepfamilies are now the fastest growing family type in the UK. It's estimated that 1 in 3 of all families are now blended families.
In search of answers
column2: Kate and Rio meet other step-parents willing to share their experiences at one of the support groups on offer
column5: a chartered psychologist specialising in stepfamily dynamics.

column1: As Rio and Kate open up about their own experiences
column2: they learn they’re not alone and that stepfamilies often have to overcome challenges when developing their new family units which can affect their mental wellbeing

column1: But whilst Rio and Kate start to explore some of their own questions around step-parenting
column2: they still aren’t sure how the three children are coping with the loss of both grandmother Janet and their mum Rebecca.

column1: On visiting a specialist child bereavement charity
column2: Rio and Kate hear from other children who have lost a parent and now have a new step-parent in their lives. Listening to the powerful advice from these young people
column3: Rio realises that he’s working too hard
column4: and that Kate probably spends more time with the kids than he does.

column1: Armed with new knowledge from these support groups
column2: Kate and Rio make positive changes to their lives
column4: Tia and Lorenz to Child Bereavement UK so they can also benefit from hearing from other young people who have lost a parent.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2020;59;signed
