column1: 1725;1725;Billy Connolly: Made in Scotland;Series 1: Episode 2;Billy is in the Scotland of his childhood
column5: Billy Connolly: Made in Scotland
column6: Series 1: Episode 2;Billy is in the Scotland of his childhood
column7: discussing knitted woolly swimming trunks.;This final instalment finds Billy back in the Scotland of his childhood
column8: where he reveals that knitted woolly swimming trunks were not a figment of his imagination.;"In British comedy there is a line in the sand and that line is Billy Connolly. Before he found fame on an international level
column9: British comedy was an end-of-the-pier kind of affair - but through sheer talent and force of personality
column10: Connolly ploughed a different and deeply personal yet universal approach to comedy and in doing so he changed the face of British comedy forever.

column1: He has been called the Beatles and Jesus of comedy by his peers and an immature 'manure mouth' by the leader of the Scottish Zion Baptist Church. So say what you like about him
column2: but you can't deny everyone wants to know him. And that is what Made In Scotland is about - it is Billy as you have never seen him before - intimate

column1: Weaved around personal accounts and interviews from famous faces
column2: Billy's life is revealed in all its glory - a shaggy dog story approach to his work - and one that has turned him from Billy Connolly the welder into Billy Connolly - The Big Yin.

column1: This final instalment (featuring Eddie Izzard
column5: Tracey Ullman
column6: Val McDermid
column7: Sharleen Spiteri and Eddi Reader) finds Billy back in the Scotland of his childhood
column8: where he reveals that knitted woolly swimming trunks were not a figment of his imagination.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains strong language.;2019;59;signed

column1: 1726;1726;Subnormal: A British Scandal;None;An examination of one of the biggest scandals in the history of British education.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09hc197.jpg;BBC
column4: Subnormal: A British Scandal;An examination of one of the biggest scandals in the history of British education.;An examination of one of the biggest scandals in the history of British education.;"In the 1960s
column5: while young black adults were getting to grips with the struggle for black power and a long fightback against police abuse was starting
column6: the majority of West Indian migrants were keeping their heads down. They were working hard and counting on providing better opportunities and education for their children. However
column7: in a white-dominated country
column8: where the politics were becoming increasingly racialised
column9: there was a question of how society
column10: and its teachers
column11: saw these young black children.

column1: Before having a chance to develop intellectually
column3: difficult and disruptive. The paradox is that many of the new migrants to Britain were in fact highly educated. One of them was Gus John
column4: who arrived from Trinidad as a Dominican novitiate to become a priest. Almost immediately he was contacted by some black parents worried about the schooling of their children. Together with several other educators
column5: John quickly realised that the system was not just inept
column6: but actually rigged against black children.

column1: At the same time
column2: celebrity psychologists Hans Eysenck and Arthur Jensen were propounding theories that black people were genetically less intelligent than white people. These theories infiltrated teacher training and found their way into schools. IQ tests were then based on these theories with the odds horrendously stacked against children from the West Indies.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2021;59;signed

column9: we’re in the Highlands and Islands of Scotland with nearly 5
column10: 000 km of coast. It’s home to five keen walkers
column11: all determined to get their hands on the prize.

column1: Last to lead a walk is 32-year-old Rob from Dundee
column2: who works for a communications company and plays amputee football for Partick Thistle.

column1: So what’s he got planned to win the golden walking stick? He’s leading the walkers to one of the Highland’s best-known spots. Glenfinnan Viaduct has been made famous the world over as the location that the Hogwarts Express steamed through in the Harry Potter movies.

column5: Finding Jack Charlton;The compelling
column6: emotional and definitive portrait of footballer Jack Charlton.;The story of football legend Jack Charlton
column7: which looks at his special association with Ireland
column8: his complicated relationship with brother Sir Bobby Charlton and his final battle with dementia.;"Finding Jack Charlton is the compelling
column9: emotional and definitive portrait of a football life like no other. It is the story of an extraordinary man
column10: an English
column11: World Cup-winning legend who became an Irish hero.

column1: Jack Charlton won the World Cup in 1966 playing alongside his brother
column3: in England’s greatest ever side. A proud Englishman
column4: Jack applied for only one job in his subsequent career as a football manager: the England job. Jack never received a reply from the FA. Instead
column5: he accepted an invitation to manage the Republic of Ireland
column6: and took on a side that had never qualified for a major tournament to the dizzying heights of a World Cup quarter-final.

column1: In doing so he inspired a nation. Ireland’s footballing success represented far more than winning matches
column2: it influenced a social and cultural change in a country that faced deep-seated political and economic challenges.

column1: Finding Jack Charlton tells the story of Jack’s special association with Ireland and also examines his frustration with England and the FA
column2: his complicated relationship with his brother Sir Bobby Charlton
column3: and his final battle with dementia.

column1: Offering an intimate
column2: compelling insight into Jack the man
column3: Finding Jack Charlton includes contributions from Jack’s family
column4: his wife Pat and son John
column5: alongside celebrated Irish players
column6: musicians
column7: writers and politicians

column1: 1737;1737;The Prosecutors;The Babes in the Wood Murders;Following a 32-year fight for justice in a notorious unsolved double child murder.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p06w5ppj.jpg;BBC
column5: The Babes in the Wood Murders;Following a 32-year fight for justice in a notorious unsolved double child murder.;Exclusive documentary following the culmination of a 32-year fight for justice in a notorious unsolved double child murder.;"This exclusive documentary follows the culmination of a 32-year fight for justice in a notorious unsolved double child murder. On 9 October 1986
column6: nine-year-old friends Karen Hadaway and Nicola Fellows went out to play and didn't come home. The whole estate turned out to look for the two girls only to have their hopes dashed when they were found lying dead in undergrowth in Wild Park
column7: on the outskirts of Brighton. Both had been strangled and sexually assaulted.

column1: For their families it was the start of a living hell. Police arrested a man the girls liked and trusted - 20-year-old Russell Bishop - and in 1987 he was put on trial. But the jury took less than two hours to acquit him of the murders. Under the law at the time
column2: Bishop could not be retried even if new evidence were to be found. The families of the murdered girls had to endure years of agony
column3: without any prospect of justice for their lost children. Until 2005
column4: when the double jeopardy law was abolished
column5: rekindling the hopes of the families.

column1: Now police and scientists are using cutting-edge methods to uncover new evidence
column2: which they hope will be enough for the CPS to pursue a fresh prosecution. Following the reinvestigation and proceedings from an early stage
column3: and sharing the experience of the children's families
column4: this film charts the last chance at finally finding justice for Karen and Nicola.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2019;59;signed

column1: 1742;1742;A Hotel for the Super Rich & Famous;Series 1: Episode 2;Tom Kerridge launches the hotel's new restaurant.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jv4db.jpg;BBC
column4: A Hotel for the Super Rich & Famous
column5: Series 1: Episode 2;Tom Kerridge launches the hotel's new restaurant.;Documentary going behind the scenes at London's Corinthia hotel. Tom Kerridge launches the hotel's new restaurant
column6: and Thomas attends a five-star travel convention in Vegas.;"Thomas Kochs
column7: formerly general manager of Claridge's and star of the award-winning documentary series Inside Claridge's
column8: is at the helm of a new
column9: modern five-star hotel in London.

column1: The hotel restaurant isn't doing well and the five-star Corinthia needs a big-name chef to compete with its rivals. Tom Kerridge
column2: the British chef most famous for his two Michelin-starred restaurants in Marlow
column4: takes on the job. His acclaimed traditional British upmarket fish and chips aren't the usual fare for a five-star hotel
column5: and it is his first restaurant in London. It is a family enterprise - his artist wife Beth is providing sculptures to enhance the space.

column1: It is not enough to wait and see if the clients come for the new food and art. Thomas makes an annual pilgrimage to Las Vegas to a five-star trade convention with 6
column2: 000 delegates. He has to sell the hotel
column3: competing with other London and global brands
column4: to American luxury travel agents in hundreds of four-minute meetings. It is exhausting work in 110 degrees in crazy Vegas.

column1: One of the hotel's penthouses costs an eye-watering £22k a night. Some guests choose to stay in the hotel for several months and clients' bills can reach £3 million. At those prices
column3: Thomas can never stand still. There is always more to be done to cater for his super-rich clientele.

column1: Made by Jane Treays
column2: the award-winning director of Inside Claridge's
column4: shot over the course of a year
column5: revisit the land of the rich
column6: who can ask for anything they want and are willing and able to pay for perfection.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2018;58;signed

column2: who discovers he has 25 siblings from the same American sperm donor.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08t1zgf.jpg;BBC
column5: 25 Siblings & Me;The story of Oli
column6: who discovers he has 25 siblings from the same American sperm donor.;The incredible story of Oli
column7: a young man with Asperger’s syndrome who overnight discovers he has 25 siblings from the same American sperm donor dad.;"The incredible story of Oli
column8: a young British man with Asperger’s syndrome
column9: who overnight discovers he has 25 brothers and sisters from the same American sperm donor. Keen to be part of this new family
column10: Oli travels to the USA
column11: meeting his donor and joining a mass sibling reunion. Full of humour
column12: heart and hard truths
column13: the film follows Oli as he navigates the fragile dynamics in this new family formation.

column1: Oli
column3: lives in London and has two mums
column4: who conceived him using an anonymous sperm donor in California. Oli always knew he was donor conceived but is curious about his biology. Signing up to a website that helps children of sperm donors find each other
column5: Oli receives an email from someone called Jordan
column6: who reveals she is Oli’s half-sister and breaks the news that their donor
column7: Daley
column8: has revoked his anonymity. Then she drops the real bombshell: Oli has 25 American half brothers and sisters.

column1: Oli virtually meets his new extended family
column2: who are excited about the latest addition to their network. Within days
column4: as Oli’s strong opinions clash with those of his siblings. Oli was diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome aged 12. He grew up an only child and sometimes found it hard to fit in and make friends.

column1: Oli decides to travel to America
column2: hoping that building relationships will be easier in person. He visits some siblings at home before meeting up with his donor dad and then joining the biggest family reunion to date. Each of the siblings he visits has their own extraordinary story
column3: which is revealed along the way. Will Oli return to London with some lasting sibling relationships? And does he have a future in this extraordinary new family?";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2020;86;signed

column1: 1744;1744;Storyville;Locked In: Breaking the Silence;A film-maker finds the courage to talk to his family for the first time about his illness.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08zksdm.jpg;BBC
column5: Locked In: Breaking the Silence;A film-maker finds the courage to talk to his family for the first time about his illness.;A Storyville documentary. Film-maker Xavier Alford has a rare and life-changing illness. Confronting his fears
column6: he finds talking with fellow patients and his family makes all of them stronger.;"An intimate
column7: personal and surprisingly life-affirming story with a rare illness at its heart.

column1: Director Xavier Alford is finally confronting an illness he has been hiding from family
column2: close friends and even himself. Locked In: Breaking the Silence follows him trying to make sense of the mysterious illness that has taken over his life in the only way he knows how - by making a film about it. What is it like to get a diagnosis of an incredibly rare condition that turns your whole world upside down? No-one can tell you why or how you got it
column3: not even doctors. No-one knows how to beat it and there is no cure.

column1: To grasp what it means for his body
column3: Xavier meets other people who have a condition closely related to his
column5: each shining an unfiltered light on the disability caused by the disease. He’s confronted with the seriousness of the condition when some of the patients he meets are on the edge of life
column6: locked in their own bodies
column7: completely paralysed and unable to move a single muscle
column8: while their brains remain unaffected.

column1: In a time when much of the world is experiencing lockdown
column4: a fresh perspective on coping mechanisms and the recovery from virus-related diseases.";Documentary Film;BBC FOUR;Contains some strong language.;2020;77;signed;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08zksdm.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08zksdm.jpg;intimate personal surprisingly lifeaffirming story rare illness heart director xavier alford finally confronting illness hiding family close friend even locked breaking silence follows trying make sense mysterious illness taken life way know making film like get diagnosis incredibly rare condition turn whole world upside noone tell got even doctor noone know beat cure grasp mean body career family xavier meet people condition closely related guillainbarré syndrome shining unfiltered light disability caused disease ’ confronted seriousness condition patient meet edge life locked body completely paralysed unable move single muscle brain remain unaffected time much world experiencing lockdown locked offer unflinching positivity fresh perspective coping mechanism recovery virusrelated disease;1

column6: Series 1: Episode 4;The Fletchers enter three sheep into the Ashbourne Show

column8: with Daniel the ram lamb preferring to play dead
column9: and reputations are on the line.;"Despite a growing workload on the farm
column10: Kelvin and Liz have entered three of their rare-breed Cotswold sheep into the Ashbourne Show
column11: which is now only a week away. If they can win a coveted rosette
column12: they could increase the value of their flock - but to stand any chance of success their sheep must be trained to walk and stand using a halter.  Unfortunately
column13: Daniel the ram lamb refuses to stay upright
column14: preferring to throw himself on the ground and play dead. To add to their woes

Amy’s chronic bowel condition was a secret she’d keep out of the professional spotlight for fear of it overshadowing her success. But now
column5: for the first time
column6: the Welsh dancing star shows us the brutal reality of living with this disease. As she embarks on the busiest professional and personal few months of her life - from the UK Strictly Tour to her debut solo dance show and summer wedding - Amy is hospitalised due to her illness at the height of the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: In this authored documentary
column2: Amy reveals what it is like to live with a chronic condition and the effect it has on her career as a dancer. She also hears about the severe impact this incurable disease has had on others.";Documentary;BBC ONE WALES;False;2020;58;signed

column1: 1749;1749;The Fires that Foretold Grenfell;None;The story of five fires that foretold and might have prevented the Grenfell Tower disaster;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b57rmz.jpg;BBC
column4: The Fires that Foretold Grenfell;The story of five fires that foretold and might have prevented the Grenfell Tower disaster;The story of the five fires that foretold and might have prevented the Grenfell Tower disaster
column5: in which 72 people died.;"This 60-minute documentary is the dramatic
column6: haunting story of five fires that foretold the Grenfell disaster
column7: told through the eyes of those directly involved. This vivid and moving film for BBC Two collates the memories of survivors
column8: the bereaved
column9: firefighters
column10: safety experts and the politicians linked to five intensely fierce fire disasters that preceded Grenfell. This telling collection of interviews and archive footage shows the clear warnings that existed and could have predicted a Grenfell-type inferno happening in Britain.

column1: The programme focuses on three factors: the application of flammable material and cladding to buildings
column2: the 'stay put' advice given by fire services
column3: the absence of sprinklers - and how they contributed to each of the previous five blazes
column4: sometimes with fatal consequences. Made over the course of 12 months
column5: the film tells the story of the legislative history of building regulations from 1973 to the present day through five fires. It explores the causes
column6: subsequent investigations and the recommendations that were sent to successive UK governments
column7: ultimately posing the question: if lessons had been learned as a result of tragic repetition of errors over the decades
column8: could Grenfell have been avoided?

column1: When Chanell Wallace was 11 years old
column4: was stabbed and killed on the streets of Nottingham. His murderer was given a life sentence
column5: but 13 years on his parole process will soon begin.

column1: Daniel’s family have been invited to write a Victim Personal Statement that will be considered in the parole process
column4: has volunteered to write it. A child when the murder took place
column5: Chanell was shielded from much of the detail
column6: so first she needs to find out what happened to her big brother
column7: why he died so violently
column8: and get to grips with how she feels about the man responsible.

column1: 1751;1751;The Duke: In His Own Words;None;The Duke of Edinburgh remembers the place that mattered to him most - Windsor.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09d6mvd.jpg;BBC
column4: The Duke: In His Own Words;The Duke of Edinburgh remembers the place that mattered to him most - Windsor.;Reflecting on the remarkable life of the Duke of Edinburgh
column5: this programme remembers him in the place that mattered to him most - Windsor.;"Reflecting on the remarkable life of the Duke of Edinburgh
column6: this programme remembers him in the place that mattered to him most - Windsor. Over the course of filming for a year at the castle
column7: we had the perfect guide - Prince Philip himself. And what started as a personal tour turned into something much more revealing and unexpected – a journey through the life of a very modern man
column8: a pioneer and innovator who was at the heart of the British Monarchy
column9: and the Queen's side
column10: for over seventy years. In his role of Ranger he shows us around the Windsor estate
column11: and describes what it was like when he first arrived in 1952: how he transformed the castle inside and out; how he handled the old guard; his biggest bug-bear
column12: the tree-huggers; his successes and (very messy) failures as an ecopioneer; how he turned Windsor into a home fit for a young and growing family; what is was like following in the footsteps of his predecessor and ancestor Prince Albert; he tells us about his love of polo and the real reason he built a polo club on the grounds
column13: and how he wrote the rules for carriage-driving- the sport he never gave up. And he even touches on his own place in history
column14: and his firm belief that it is for others to decide his legacy… There is relaxed banter with the film crew
column15: funny off-camera exchanges (which we include)
column16: but there are also serious and at times some very poignant and reflective moments. And all this at the place he calls home-which of course will be his final resting place too. This is the real Duke
column17: in his own words
column18: a unique and enduring portrait which reveals the side of a man rarely seen.";Documentary;BBC ONE;False;2021;58;signed

column1: 1752;1752;Once Upon a Time in Iraq;Series 1: 5. Legacy;The emergence of Isis concludes the brutal legacy of the Iraq War.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08lqknx.jpg;BBC
column4: Once Upon a Time in Iraq
column5: Series 1: 5. Legacy;The emergence of Isis concludes the brutal legacy of the Iraq War.;America eventually leaves Iraq
column6: but when Isis emerges to take over huge swathes of the country
column7: the US is forced back to confront the brutal legacy of the 2003 invasion.;"In 2004
column8: Waleed Nesyif
column9: heavy metal musician
column10: is forced to flee Iraq following death threats for working for American journalists as a translator. By the time America finally withdraws all its troops from Iraq in 2011
column11: he is a Canadian citizen
column12: happily married and university educated. A year later
column13: he returns to Iraq for the first time since leaving. It is not the same country he left. Naori Al Maliki is in his second term as prime minister
column14: and his Shia-led sectarian policies reignite long-held Sunni grievances. The door is open for Isis. The legacy of the 2003 invasion plays out in a most brutal manner.

column1: Omar Mohmamed
column3: remembers clearly the night armed men invade his city
column4: proclaiming they are the Islamic State. For the next three years
column5: Omar lives under one of the most brutal regimes the world has ever known
column6: witnessing daily executions
column7: hand cutting and stonings. As the anonymous author of a blog exposing the atrocities committed by Isis
column8: he risks his life to share the realities of life under Isis with the world.

column1: He is not the only one to resist. Um Qusay risks her life by sheltering Shia soldiers in her house after they have escaped being executed by Isis. Seeing past sectarian differences
column3: ‘I risked my life to help those boys because they were Iraqis’.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language and disturbing scenes.;2020;59;signed

column8: investigating a possible link to Nelson's HMS Victory. He also learns about an ancestor who was put on trial at Norwich Castle.;Ed Balls
column9: former Labour politician
column10: sequinned Strictly dancer and TV presenter
column11: grew up in a family that wanted to make the world a better place. His mother Carolyn’s dementia means she can’t share their family history with him
column12: so he sets out to discover what kind of characters his ancestors were. Rumours on his paternal side about a link to Nelson’s ship HMS Victory lead Ed to Portsmouth and the story of his great-great-great-grandfather William Dunbar
column13: an assistant surgeon. But as he unravels Dunbar’s medical career
column14: he unearths a dark history of abuse and horror at a Kent workhouse. On his mother Carolyn’s side
column15: he feels a deep connection with Christopher Green

column1: 1755;1755;Gods of Snooker;Series 1: Episode 3;Jimmy White’s off-the-table excess threatens to overshadow his raw talent.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09gkj03.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;Jimmy White’s off-the-table excess threatens to overshadow his raw talent.;Jimmy White’s off-the-table excess threatens to overshadow his raw talent as a young Stephen Hendry emerges as a new threat to his World Championship dreams.;"By the mid-80s
column6: snooker was the biggest sport in the country
column7: but two distinct camps had emerged amongst the players. On one side were Barry Hearn’s ‘Matchroom Mob’
column8: including Dennis Taylor and Steve Davis: clean-living
column9: utterly professional and family friendly. In sharp contrast was a group that included Alex Higgins
column10: Jimmy White and Kirk Stevens
column11: who all embraced a more rock-and-roll lifestyle.

column1: With Higgins’s career quickly spiralling out of control
column2: Jimmy White was next in line to take the crown of ‘people’s champion’. But Jimmy also had an insatiable appetite for the highlife and a string of vices – including cocaine and crack - that threatened to overshadow his raw talent and enormous potential.

column1: Twelve years younger than Alex
column2: Jimmy soon realised that Alex’s popularity and ability was at odds with his success in the game
column3: having won only two world championship trophies in a sport many thought he should dominate. Indeed
column4: Steve Davis had quickly become the world number one through practice and discipline and had suddenly become the man to beat. Desperate for success and tempted by the lucrative rewards brought by towing the line
column5: Jimmy joined Barry Hearn in the hope he could be turned into a champion like his new stablemate
column6: Steve Davis.

column1: Jimmy began the 90s clean and well-prepared and got his best opportunity yet to win his first world championship
column2: coming up against a young emerging Scotsman called Stephen Hendry. With White as the hot favourite and with the crowd urging him on
column3: the 1990 final turned out to be a pivotal moment in British snooker and paved the way for what was to come in the next decade.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains very strong language.;2021;59;signed

column6: Series 1: Episode 3;Seven years after actor Jiah Khan’s death
column7: her family claim they’ve been denied justice.;The case of Jiah Khan’s death has been going on for seven years. A series of investigations found it was suicide. Her family dispute this and believe that they’ve been denied justice.;"Bollywood actor Jiah Khan was found dead in her flat in 2013.

column1: Jiah Khan’s family say the investigation was incomplete. Judges granted Rabia Khan two new investigations
column3: then by the Central Bureau of Investigation. Both concluded Jiah had died by suicide and was driven to it by her boyfriend. Jiah’s family commissioned a legal case review from a British law firm. It concluded there were faults with the investigations from the night she died onwards. Vital evidence might have been missed.

column1: The film also explores Jiah’s early experiences in films as a teenager. She was typecast as ‘bold’ after starring in a version of Lolita. She worked with individuals later accused of sexual harassment during the Bollywood #metoo movement after her death. They deny wrongdoing.
Her boyfriend
column2: charged with driving her to suicide
column4: arguing that Jiah was under pressure from a young age and suffered mental health problems before they met. Her family say she was resilient and had much to look forward to in her career.

column1: The police and CBI declined to take part in the series or to respond to allegations.

1757;1757;Stacey Dooley: Costa del Narcos;None;Following police and smugglers in southern Spain, the main gateway for drugs into Europe.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08b94t2.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Stacey Dooley: Costa del Narcos;Following police and smugglers in southern Spain, the main gateway for drugs into Europe.;Stacey Dooley gains unique access to police, dealers and smugglers in southern Spain, the main gateway for drugs into Europe.;Southern Spain
column2: famous for its beaches and sunshine
column3: has become the main gateway for drugs into Europe. Violent turf wars between drug cartels have caused the government to issue a crackdown. For the last two years
column4: the police have been fighting to take back control.

column1: In this compelling film
column2: Stacey gains unique access to the police
column3: the dealers and the smugglers. She goes out on patrol with the air force team of the Guardia Civil and is invited along to witness a night-time raid in an attempt to arrest a cartel suspect they have been watching for two years.

column1: To understand why this part of Spain sees so much cocaine
column2: Stacey travels to the source – Apartado
column3: Colombia. There she meets one of the biggest smugglers in the region. Faced with highly organised criminal gangs and the insatiable demand for drugs in Europe
column4: Stacey debates whether this a war the police can ever win.

column6: the Holocaust and Me
column7: Series 1: Episode 2;Robert continues his journey and meets the last survivor of the Treblinka death camp.;Robert Rinder continues his journey
column8: meeting a woman whose mother was arrested as a child by the Nazis
column9: a man whose uncle was transported to Belsen and the last survivor of the Treblinka death camp.;"Robert Rinder continues his journey
column10: meeting Noemie Lopian
column11: whose French mother was arrested as a child by the Nazis. Noemie wants to follow in her mother’s footsteps to understand what happened and how her mother survived. In an extraordinary scene she meets the grandson of the man who hid her mother and her mother’s siblings in a chicken shed in his garden during round-ups of Jews in the town of Saint-Junien. Noemie also learns of the incredible sacrifice and courage of a young female French Resistance fighter who saved her mother’s life.

column1: Having discovered the fate of his grandparents in episode one
column2: Bernie Graham is desperate to know what happened to his uncle Bernhard
column4: and who he believes committed suicide in Dachau concentration camp. To unravel what happened to his uncle
column5: Bernie travels to Dachau
column6: where he finds out that his uncle fell ill and died after a horrendous journey there. Despite the dark truths that Bernie uncovers
column7: he hopes that we can learn from these terrible events.

column1: Robert’s mother's family were also impacted by the Holocaust
column2: and he knows that his Polish grandfather’s parents and siblings died in Treblinka death camp in Nazi-occupied Poland. Robert travels with his mother to Treblinka to discover how her grandparents
column5: great-aunts and great-uncle were murdered. They meet the last survivor of Treblinka
column6: 92-year-old Leon Rytz
column7: who tells his harrowing story. The three of them say Kaddish together
column8: the Jewish prayer of remembrance for those who have died.";History;BBC ONE;Contains upsetting scenes.;2020;58;signed

column1: 1760;1760;Blair & Brown: The New Labour Revolution;Series 1: Episode 5;Gordon Brown becomes prime minister
column5: Blair & Brown: The New Labour Revolution
column6: Series 1: Episode 5;Gordon Brown becomes prime minister
column7: only to face crisis after crisis.;After New Labour’s third victory
column8: tensions between No 10 and No 11 are at breaking point. Brown finally becomes Prime Minister
column9: only to face crisis after crisis.;"In 2005
column10: Labour’s General Election campaign was fought against the backdrop of the Iraq War. Tony Blair and New Labour are in a precarious position. Popularity ratings are low and
column11: to top it off
column12: the relationship between Blair and chancellor Gordon Brown has hit rock bottom. In order to win a third term in office
column13: they agree to put their differences aside and form a united front.

column1: The display of unity works
column2: and New Labour wins for a third time. But a new question looms over the government. Tony Blair had agreed with Gordon Brown that he wouldn’t serve a full third term as Prime Minister. As Brown’s allies press the Prime Minister for a departure date
column3: Blair has a change of heart. He feels that more needed to be done before he could step aside
column4: and he isn’t convinced that Brown will fulfil New Labour’s modernising agenda. To Brown’s surprise and frustration
column5: Blair tells the press he will be staying on as leader.

column1: The 'coup' that follows is a bubbling over of tensions within the Labour government. Blair had lost the support of many Labour MPs over Iraq
column2: and the apparent U-turn over his departure sparked outrage among the Brownites
column3: who felt it was high time for Blair to go.

column1: After being pushed into announcing a departure date
column2: Tony Blair steps down as prime minister on 27 June 2007. Gordon Brown is finally able to take the reins. But leading the country is very different to leading the Treasury
column3: and a series of crises put the dampeners on any agenda Brown wants to put forward. His popularity dives further when he fails to call an election. Then
column5: a global financial crash threatens to destroy economies across the world.

column1: We tell the story of how Gordon Brown reacted to the economic crisis
column2: bringing together world leaders and trying to save the global economy. Despite this
column3: the public turn against the Brown government
column5: after 13 years in power
column6: New Labour is finally forced out of office.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;signed

column1: The massive decline in living standards triggers refugee crises
column2: which play havoc with Cuba's already difficult relations with the US and force the two enemies to negotiate for the first time one on one and officially. Infuriated
column3: the Cuban Miami exiles step up their operations against what they think is a weakened regime. But Cuba's robust self-defence kills four Americans and gives no choice to President Clinton but to sign a Congress bill that tightens even further the US embargo on the island. Castro has to find new friends and trading partners.

column1: He strikes gold in Venezuela - the new president there
column3: is a long-time admirer. Cuba agrees to exchange medical aid for much-needed oil in what becomes known as Operation Milagro. This operation not only helps Cuba's economy

column5: Cuba's future remains unclear.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2020;58;signed

George, Peter and Clare;Twin brothers and a woman search for strangers who changed the course of their lives.;Twin brothers who fled Nazi Germany search for the family who helped them escape, and a woman who housed 21 child refugees from Bosnia looks for their mystery schoolgirl translator.;In 1933
column2: identical twin brothers George and Peter were born to a Jewish family in Berlin
column3: six months after Hitler became chancellor of Germany. Peter and George were close friends with the non-Jewish sons of their building's caretaker
column5: and the four boys would play football together. But as the Nazi party steadily increased persecution against Jews
column6: life for the family became very difficult. On Kristallnacht in November 1938
column7: when thousands of Jewish men were arrested and sent to concentration camps
column8: Mr Schadler hid the twins' father Franz in the basement at great risk to his own safety. The following year
column9: with just days to spare before the outbreak of war
column10: Mr Schadler lent the family money to escape Berlin by train and come to London. Now 87 years old
column11: Peter and George would love to reunite with their childhood friends and thank them for the great sacrifice their father made to ensure their family’s safety.

column1: We also tell the story of Clare
column2: who took in 21 refugee children - many of whom she was told were orphans - from war torn Bosnia. The local community in Elgin
column3: Scotland rallied round to welcome them
column4: but it was only when international schoolgirl Petra came to translate that the children were able to properly communicate and share what horrors they had fled. Petra not only gave the refugees a voice
column5: but crucially she also uncovered the truth – that none of them were orphans and all had families they had been forced to leave behind. Clare then embarked upon a years-long battle to reunite the children with their families
column6: many of whom still live locally in Scotland today. Now Clare wants to find Petra
column7: in order to thank her for unlocking the truth and changing the course of the children’s lives.";History;BBC TWO;False;2021;59;signed

column1: Four miles away in the usually bustling village of Tyndrum
column3: and owner of The Real Food Café
column5: is concerned about the large elderly population in the area
column6: which includes her mum. Green Welly Stop owner Fiona continues to provide essential fuel supplies
column7: but she has had to put 60 staff on furlough.

column1: Up at the mine
column2: the small team working on care and maintenance have been able to finally finish preparing the base for the processing plant. There is also the positive news that the price of gold has reached an all-time high and the company is now in a good financial position

column1: At the start of July
column2: the Scottish government’s five-mile travel restriction is lifted and local businesses are able to open. However
column3: Andy at the Tyndrum Inn is worried they won’t make it through the winter
column4: while at The Real Food Café
column5: Sarah explains they are approaching a half a million-pound loss due to missing out on four of their most profitable months.

column1: By November 30th 2020
column2: things are at crunch point. This is the day that investors have been told the mining company will pour the first molten gold. Processing plant manager Nigel is taking on the challenge of turning the crushed quartz vein into gold. Despite not being the quantity they had hoped for
column3: it is both a success and a major step in showing they can be a working goldmine.";Signed;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;59;signed

column2: but the evidence has gone up in smoke. Is it accident or murder?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07j7kww.jpg;BBC
column5: Our Cops in the North
column6: Series 1: Episode 5;A man has died in a fire
column7: but the evidence has gone up in smoke. Is it accident or murder?;Drug-related crime is on the rise in Northumbria. Detectives
column8: neighbourhood teams and response units respond to the fall-out - robberies
column9: burglaries and fatal overdoses.;"In this episode
column10: we follow the work of forensic investigators
column11: response officers
column12: neighbourhood teams and detectives in an array of crimes - from armed robbery and distraction burglaries to arson - all connected in some way by one thing: drugs. Northumbria Police have seen a rise in drug-related crime in the past five years.

column1: Detective Chief Inspector John Bent is proud of his record of solving all the murders he has investigated
column2: but the odds are stacked against him on his latest case
column3: a fire that resulted in one death but could have led to mass fatalities. The evidence has gone up in smoke
column5: and community tensions mean witnesses aren’t coming forward. Meanwhile
column6: Sergeant Phil Hamlani and his neighbourhood team have gathered enough intelligence to raid the address of a suspected drug dealer
column7: but they are aware that there is potential danger behind every door.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: another life is under threat. A grade one call comes in from paramedics who are being obstructed from carrying out CPR. Response officers Mark and Sarah rush to the scene
column3: but the person has fled the scene
column4: a drugs den. Despite the paramedics’ best efforts
column5: the victim is pronounced dead. Meanwhile
column6: reports of a hold-up at a local takeaway have come in
column7: and the suspect is quickly identified from the CCTV. He is a repeat offender and a known drug user. And rural cop Lee Davidson follows up on a curious case of cannabis plants that have been discovered at a country estate.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains strong language and some upsetting scenes.;2021;57;signed

column1: 1783;1783;Why Ships Crash;None;The inside story of the Ever Given accident
column5: Why Ships Crash;The inside story of the Ever Given accident
column6: which blocked the Suez Canal.;When the Ever Given blocked the Suez Canal
column7: it triggered a global crisis. Featuring eyewitnesses speaking for the first time
column8: this documentary aims to find out what really happened.;"On 23 March 2021
column9: the Ever Given – one of the largest container ships ever built – ploughed into the sandy bank of the Suez Canal
column10: blocking the entire waterway. It stopped all traffic in one of the most important shipping lanes in the world for almost a week
column11: causing a ‘ship jam’ of over 300 vessels and delaying deliveries of billions of pounds of vital food
column12: fuel and medical supplies. The disruption to the global supply chain lasted for months.

column1: How did such an advanced ship crash in one of the most closely monitored shipping lanes in the world? How did a team of engineers free the ship in just six days? And who or what is to blame?
Using never-before seen footage
column2: testimony from witnesses speaking for the very first time
column4: this documentary aims to uncover the inside story of the Ever Given accident. And with over 2
column5: 500 shipping incidents a year
column6: the film also asks if this was just a freak accident or whether it reveals a serious weakness in the world’s critical supply chain.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;60;signed
column7: documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bh8wqx.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bh8wqx.jpg;23 march 2021 ever given – one largest container ship ever built – ploughed sandy bank suez canal blocking entire waterway stopped traffic one important shipping lane world almost week causing ‘ ship jam ’ 300 vessel delaying delivery billion pound vital food fuel medical supply disruption global supply chain lasted month advanced ship crash one closely monitored shipping lane world team engineer free ship six day blame using neverbefore seen footage testimony witness speaking first time expert analysis documentary aim uncover inside story ever given accident 2500 shipping incident year film also asks freak accident whether reveals serious weakness world ’ critical supply chain;1

1791;1791;Ethiopia: Caught in the Crossfire;None;Ethiopia's civil war has left a humanitarian crisis in its wake.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bnpk8j.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Ethiopia: Caught in the Crossfire;Ethiopia's civil war has left a humanitarian crisis in its wake.;Catherine Byaruhanga reports on the human price of Ethiopia's civil war through the eyes of the civilians caught up in it.;Ethiopia's civil war has left a humanitarian crisis in its wake. The fighting between government forces and the Tigray People's Liberation Front - who have aligned with other rebel groups - has left thousands dead and over 350,000 facing famine. The UN has accused all sides of war crimes and atrocities. Over the last three months, the crisis has worsened as the rebels threaten to take the capital, Addis Ababa. But there's a lot they don't know about this 'miracle' syrup.;For Altou
column3: having a 'slim thicc' body seems the key to more likes and more work. She's one of thousands of women worldwide who have taken Apetamin
column4: an appetite-stimulant promoted by social media influencers as a quick fix for the extreme hourglass figure popularised by celebrities like Kim Kardashian.

column1: It’s widely available online. But what many don’t realise is that Apetamin is an unlicensed medicine and the misuse of this ""miracle"" syrup is causing serious harm.
When Altou took it
column2: she was so drowsy she fell asleep at her school desk. When her mum took it
column3: she went into a coma. Others have had car crashes
column5: and suffered liver failure.

column1: Altou decides to investigate
column2: discovering just how far people will go to get the Instagram look - and asking whether it’s really worth the risk.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2021;26;news

column1: 1811;1811;Britain's Dangerous Buildings: Is My Home Safe?;None;Sarah Corker investigates the severe financial impact on those trapped in dangerous homes.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b4rcbl.png;BBC
column4: Britains Dangerous Buildings: Is My Home Safe?;Sarah Corker investigates the severe financial impact on those trapped in dangerous homes.;Sarah Corker investigates the severe financial and mental health impact on those trapped in dangerous homes and explores the root causes of this spiralling cladding scandal. ;"Concerns over building safety were triggered by the Grenfell Tower tragedy in 2017
column5: where 72 people died. The external cladding was found to be the primary cause of the rapid spread of the fire. What followed was a reassessment of fire safety on high-rise buildings across the UK.

column1: Today
column3: 000 people are still living in tower blocks wrapped in dangerous
column5: and are now facing eye-watering bills to make their properties safe. Some have already declared bankruptcy.

column1: BBC business correspondent Sarah Corker and producer/director James Stewart investigate the severe financial and mental health impact on those trapped in dangerous homes and explore the root causes of this spiralling scandal. They reveal that those who bought through the government’s affordable housing schemes
column2: often first-time buyers on low incomes
column3: are now facing demands of tens of thousands of pounds. Industry experts have told the BBC that systemic failures of building regulations date back decades and that warnings about a lack of independent oversight and quality issues on building sites were ignored.";News;BBC NEWS24;False;2021;23;news;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b4rcbl.png;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b4rcbl.png;concern building safety triggered grenfell tower tragedy 2017 72 people died external cladding found primary cause rapid spread fire followed reassessment fire safety highrise building across uk today estimated 700000 people still living tower block wrapped dangerous flammable material facing eyewatering bill make property safe already declared bankruptcy bbc business correspondent sarah corker producerdirector james stewart investigate severe financial mental health impact trapped dangerous home explore root cause spiralling scandal reveal bought government ’ affordable housing scheme often firsttime buyer low income facing demand ten thousand pound industry expert told bbc systemic failure building regulation date back decade warning lack independent oversight quality issue building site ignored;1

1832;1832;Ron Jeremy: Fall of a Porn Icon;None;What does Ron Jeremy's arrest say about the changing adult industry?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b757s1.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Ron Jeremy: Fall of a Porn Icon;What does Ron Jeremy's arrest say about the changing adult industry?;The world’s most famous male porn star allegedly sexually assaulted and raped women for decades. What does his arrest say about the changing adult industry?;
For decades
column2: the world’s most famous male porn star
column5: assaulted and raped women.

column1: One of the most unlikely success stories of the adult industry
column4: became an ‘icon’ of porn who appeared in over 2
column5: 000 adult movies and successfully crossed over into mainstream media.

column1: Yet it wasn’t until June 2020 that he was arrested and charged with 34 sex crimes against 21 women. He is currently in prison awaiting trial.
This explosive documentary hears for the first time from some of his alleged victims as well as those who helped raise the alarm about him.
Ginger Banks
column2: one of the first adult performers to shine a spotlight on Ron Jeremy’s behaviour
column3: speaks about her struggle to get the industry to take action.

column1: She says she fought to get Jeremy banned from adult expos and events where he was allegedly assaulting many of his victims. Was the industry turning a blind eye to what Ron was apparently doing? Jeremy – who has consistently denied all the allegations against him and has pleaded not guilty to all the charges – faces up to 330 years in prison if convicted.
Despite the allegations
column2: he still has many supporters. Some friends and former colleagues believe Jeremy has become the #MeToo fall guy for the adult industry.

column1: Conversations about consent have become more sophisticated in recent years
column2: and in the world of porn setting boundaries on set is more important than ever before.

column1: This documentary gains unfettered access behind the scenes of the often secretive adult world and questions what Ron Jeremy’s arrest says about the changing industry.

column1: 1835;1835;When Bridges Collapse: The Genoa Disaster;None;The story of some of the people on the Polcevera Bridge on the day of its collapse.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07kdyfy.jpg;BBC
column4: When Bridges Collapse: The Genoa Disaster;The story of some of the people on the Polcevera Bridge on the day of its collapse.;The story of some of the people on the Polcevera Bridge on the day of its collapse
column5: investigating what caused the bridge to fail so catastrophically.  ;"On 14 August 2018
column6: the Polcevera Bridge in Genoa collapsed
column7: sending 27 vehicles plummeting to the valley below. 43 people lost their lives. It was Italy’s worst ever road-bridge disaster. This film tells the story of some of the people on the bridge that day and investigates what caused the bridge to fail so catastrophically.

column1: The Polcevera Bridge was an icon of 1960s engineering
column2: built by one of Italy’s most celebrated engineers
column3: and hailed by some as a masterpiece. It formed a vital link in the main motorway between the south of France and Rome. Its failure had a huge impact on the local economy. The debris blocked railway lines for weeks
column4: 600 people who lived under the bridge were forced to flee their homes
column5: and lorry drivers had to make a 115km detour.

column1: Ex-professional footballer Davide Capello
column2: who was driving over the bridge when it collapsed
column3: recalls his miraculous escape. ""I found myself tumbling into the void. At that moment I let go of the wheel
column4: I placed my hands behind my head
column5: and I thought I was already dead."" With many of Europe’s highways built in the same era as the Genoa bridge
column6: this tragedy has raised questions about the maintenance of Europe’s ageing infrastructure. Are our bridges safe?";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2019;59;news
column7: documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07kdyfy.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07kdyfy.jpg;14 august 2018 polcevera bridge genoa collapsed sending 27 vehicle plummeting valley 43 people lost life italy ’ worst ever roadbridge disaster film tell story people bridge day investigates caused bridge fail catastrophically polcevera bridge icon 1960s engineering built one italy ’ celebrated engineer hailed masterpiece formed vital link main motorway south france rome failure huge impact local economy debris blocked railway line week 600 people lived bridge forced flee home lorry driver make 115km detour exprofessional footballer davide capello driving bridge collapsed recall miraculous escape found tumbling void moment let go wheel placed hand behind head thought already dead many europe ’ highway built era genoa bridge tragedy raised question maintenance europe ’ ageing infrastructure bridge safe;1

column1: 1840;1840;Special Enquiry;Series 5: 1. A Girl Comes to London;A report on the growing trend of girls from the provinces moving to London. (1956);https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p01hgs7x.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 5: 1. A Girl Comes to London;A report on the growing trend of girls from the provinces moving to London. (1956);First transmitted in 1956
column6: Robert Reid reports on the growing trend of young girls who leave their industrial cities or rural villages behind in search of a better life in London.;First transmitted in 1956
column7: each week 500 girls leave their provincial homes and arrive in London either to take up jobs or look for work. But flaring headlines in Sunday papers about what has occasionally happened to some youngsters causes parents to worry. Are they right to be worried? Robert Reid sets out to find out what really brings the girls to London
column8: what happens when they get there
column9: how they live
column10: what sort of digs they find and what sort of people they are meeting and palling up with. This Special Enquiry seeks to identify the true reality of what awaits these young women upon arriving in the bustling capital.;News;BBC WEBONLY;False;1956;30;news

1853;1853;Global Questions;Africa's Military Coups;Zeinab Badawi and a panel of experts take questions in Nairobi, Kenya.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p02xkk45.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Global Questions, Africas Military Coups;Zeinab Badawi and a panel of experts take questions in Nairobi, Kenya.;Zeinab Badawi and her panel of experts in Nairobi, Kenya, take questions concerning recent successive coups in Africa.;Successive coups in Africa are causing concern that military takeovers are on the rise across the continent
column2: prompting fears they will overturn the democratic gains Africa has made in recent decades. 2021 was a tumultuous year in Africa seeing coups in Chad
column4: Mali and Sudan. This year has already seen two – a takeover by the army in Burkina Faso and a failed coup attempt in Guinea Bissau. And thousands have been killed in wars like Ethiopia's civil war in the Horn of Africa.

column1: Many of the current conflicts are driven by prospects of political power or financial gain
column3: do some African countries believe the army can bring greater stability
column4: reflecting the interests of the international community?

column7: reporting on the fierce political battles behind Brexit.;Laura Kuenssberg goes behind the scenes and beyond the headlines once again as cameras follow her reporting on one of the fiercest political battles of this generation - Brexit.;"Laura Kuenssberg goes behind the scenes and beyond the headlines once again as cameras follow her reporting on one of the fiercest political battles of this generation - Brexit.

column1: Boris Johnson came to power promising to deliver Brexit 'do or die' by 31 October. He didn't achieve it and instead
column2: the public were asked to vote in a general election that would decide if Brexit is delivered or if a second referendum should take place.

column1: This film gains unique access to the prime minister
column2: his cabinet and leading politicians who oppose him for a film that records up close the decisions and drama that unfolds as the deadline to Brexit day looms.

column1: The story begins as Boris Johnson is elected leader of the Conservative party and with it becomes prime minister of the United Kingdom. The film follows his efforts over the summer to secure a deal with the European Union
column2: who had previously refused to reopen the withdrawal agreement. Along the way
column3: dramatic twists and turns in the story look set to block Boris Johnson's path for delivering on his promise to 'get Brexit done'.

column1: A Supreme Court ruling decided that his decision to prorogue parliament was unlawful. A cross-party group of MPs work together to form a 'remain alliance' and pass legislation that requires Boris Johnson to ask for a Brexit extension
column2: and the Labour party ultimately decides to vote to allow a general election to take place.

column1: Throughout these events
column2: MPs from all sides of the argument reveal their candid thoughts on the strategies they are pursuing and the pressures they face from an increasingly frustrated and divided electorate.

column1: As the story unfolds
column2: Laura gives her unique insight into what is really going on behind closed doors
column3: and explains how the political decisions will mean lasting implications for the future of the political parties and the lives of those they represent.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2019;60;news

column1: 1899;1899;Eòrpa;Series 29: Episode 13;A look at the dissatisfaction on the west coast of Scotland with the Calmac ferry service.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bqzycz.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 29: Episode 13;A look at the dissatisfaction on the west coast of Scotland with the Calmac ferry service.;Eòrpa looks at the dissatisfaction in many communities on the west coast of Scotland with Calmac ferry services.;"Tha Eòrpa a’ coimhead  air a’ mhì-thoileachas a th’ann am mòran de choimhearsnachdan air taobh siar na h-Alba mu thrioblaidean le seirbhisean aiseag Chalmac.  Tha Dòmhnall MacLaomainn air a’ bhith a’ rannsachadh a’ bhuaidh a th’aige seo air luchd-cleachdaidh agus luchd gniomhachais.  Tha sùil ga thoirt cuideachd air an t-suidheachadh san Nirribhidh far a bheil seirbhisean aiseag bunaiteach do dh’iomadh coimhearsnachd.  Cuideachd tha Ruairidh MacIllFhinnein ag aithris air mar a tha gnìomhachas a’ bhìdh air a’  bhith dèilgeadh ri àrainneachd mhalairt ùr còrr air bliadhna an dèidh aonta malairt Brexit eadar an Rìoghachd Aonaichte agus an EU.

column1: Eòrpa looks at the dissatisfaction in many communities on the west coast of Scotland with Calmac ferry services.  Donald Lamont speaks to ferry users and businesses about the effects delays in delivery of replacement vessels and an ageing fleet
column3: are having. There is a look at Norway where coastal communities are also dependent on ferry services. Also
column4: over a year after a new Brexit trade deal was agreed between the UK and the EU
column5: Ruairidh Maclennan looks at how producers in the food-producing sector have fared under the new arrangements.

column1: 1902;1902;One Day in Gaza;None;Telling the story of one of the deadliest days in the Gaza Strip for a generation.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jxnlf.jpg;BBC
column4: One Day in Gaza;Telling the story of one of the deadliest days in the Gaza Strip for a generation.;Telling the story of one of the deadliest days in the Gaza Strip for a generation
column5: using footage and testimony from both sides to reveal what really happened.;"Telling the story of one of the deadliest days in the Gaza Strip for a generation. Made by award-winning documentary maker Olly Lambert
column6: One Day in Gaza examines
column7: moment by moment
column8: what happened on that fateful day.

column1: 14 May 2018 started as a day of mass protest at Gaza’s border with Israel
column2: and would end as one of the most deadly days in Gaza for a generation. For weeks
column3: Palestinians had been protesting along the border fence
column4: but tensions were running particularly high due to the opening of the new United States embassy to Israel in Jerusalem - the controversial step ordered by Donald Trump. As Ivanka Trump
column5: Jared Kushner and other senior US officials gathered in Jerusalem to inaugurate the new embassy
column6: tens of thousands of Palestinians gathered at sites along the Gaza border
column7: barely 40 miles away. As the sun set that day
column8: over 60 Palestinians were dead or dying
column9: and over two thousand lay injured
column10: many by live ammunition.

column1: Drawing on more than 120 hours of archive footage filmed on both sides of the border that day - including exclusive videos released by both Hamas
column2: the Palestinian militant group that dominates Gaza
column4: this film reveals the complex reality and human toll of the day
column5: and asks who is to blame for the bloodshed. It also features exclusive interviews with senior commanders and intelligence officers from the Israel Defense Forces
column6: as well as political leaders of both Hamas and Islamic Jihad
column7: another militant group
column8: and civilians who were present on both sides of the border. What really happened that day? Israel said its troops only opened fire in self-defence or on people using the protests as cover for an armed infiltration
column9: while Palestinians and human rights groups have accused Israeli troops of using excessive force against unarmed civilians who posed no threat. This 60-minute film reveals extraordinary new details of what happened.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains upsetting scenes.;2019;58;news

column1: Philip Donnellan's Birmingham-based film gives a voice to West Indian immigrants who movingly describe their experiences of trying to integrate into a surprisingly unwelcoming ‘mother country’. column7: this historic film documents the restoration of the House of Commons
column8: which was severely damaged by a bombing raid in May 1941. It also commemorates the secret location
column9: in nearby Church House
column10: where MPs met following the destruction of the Commons chamber.

column1: The film features Sir Winston Churchill giving a lighthearted commemorative speech to mark the occasion of the reopening of the restored House of Commons. column2: but he doesn't get the reaction he'd hoped for from both his school and
column4: his own father. So Jamie has to make some difficult decisions.

column1: Jamie spends time with an established drag artist and battles his demons
column4: for the very first time in front of a large audience.

column3: the film explores his hopes and fears for the future. Will he get the acceptance he craves from his peers and the confidence to be who he really is?

column6: a 26-year-old African-American man from Mississippi - murder. He was convicted on the sole evidence of signing a confession he had not written. Johnson always denied the killing and appealed against his death sentence for eight years in the US courts.

column7: 4. New Start;The inside story of Barack Obama's relationship with the Kremlin.;The inside story of Barack Obama's campaign to win over Russian president Dmitry Medvedev
column8: and Medvedev's own complex dealings with Vladimir Putin.;"The final episode tells the inside story of two relationships - Barack Obama's campaign to win over Russian president Dmitry Medvedev
column9: and Medvedev's own complex dealings with Vladimir Putin.

column1: Obama became president determined to rid the world of nuclear weapons. To begin the process he needed Russian help. So he set out to reset relations with Russia. Ignoring Putin
column2: whom many considered still in charge

column1: Top officials on both sides take viewers deep inside the negotiations. They describe how a phone call between the two young lawyer-presidents finally clinched the agreement - which cut their countries' nuclear arsenals in half.
But inside Russia
column2: Medvedev had a harder time. He responded to the 2008 global financial crisis by setting out to make Russia into a modern democratic economy. He made little progress. He told Obama that Russia's most famous dissident
column4: would get a fair trial. It did not happen.

column1: In the end
column2: Medvedev stepped aside and nominated Putin to be their party's presidential candidate for the 2012 election. Top Kremlin insiders
column4: tell how the deal was done - and how it set in train a process that made Vladimir Putin look vulnerable for the first time.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2012;59;from-the-archives

column1: Eugenius Okolowicz and Vlodek Bulaj
column2: soldiers exiled after serving in the Second World War
column3: sought shelter in Wales. They came upon a desolate hillside farm which had lain unoccupied and decaying for 20 years. Neither of the Poles had farmed before
column4: but the land was cheap because it was unwanted. This film tells the story of the men's 12th year living at Penygaer. But it is more the tragic story of the price they have paid for poor independence and of their unending struggle
column5: in loneliness and hardship
column6: to be themselves. (1960)";Documentary;BBC WEBONLY;False;1960;30;from-the-archives

column5: 1998: 1. Grand Final: 1998;The 43rd annual Eurovision Song Contest broadcast from Birmingham.;The 43rd annual Eurovision Song Contest broadcast from the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. Terry Wogan both hosted and commentated on the event
column6: alongside Ulrika Jonsson.;"The 43rd annual Eurovision Song Contest broadcast from the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. Terry Wogan managed to both host and commentate on the event
column7: alongside Swedish-born multilingual presenter Ulrika Jonsson.

column1: Dana International won for Israel singing ""Diva"" on the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the state of Israel. She had been at the centre of much media attention in both her country and in the rest of Europe because she was the first openly transgender competitor in the contest. This year marked the last that a Eurovision orchestra was used and the last year with a language restriction. It was also the first year that mass televoting was used instead of the traditional juries.
It was FYR Macedonia's debut in the competition after failing to get their 1996 entry past the qualifier judges
column5: Romania and Slovakia were all able to return to the competition after their year's exclusion for getting the lowest average scores. The voting was extremely close with Israel
column6: Malta and the United Kingdom all vying for top spot as the final votes were cast. Eventually the UK came in second with Malta a very close third.

column1: The contest is also famous for a Eurovision faux-pas. On hearing that the Dutch announcer once performed in the contest
column2: co-host Ulrika Johnson said: ""A long time ago was it?"" provoking laughs and boos from the audience. In fact her seemingly insulting comment was in reply to something Conny van den Bos had said about performing many years ago
column3: although this was lost in the noise from the spectators.";Entertainment;BBC WEBONLY;False;1998;179;from-the-archives;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09gq37m.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09gq37m.jpg;43rd annual eurovision song contest broadcast national indoor arena birmingham terry wogan managed host commentate event alongside swedishborn multilingual presenter ulrika jonsson dana international israel singing diva 50th anniversary establishment state israel centre much medium attention country rest europe first openly transgender competitor contest year marked last eurovision orchestra used last year language restriction also first year mass televoting used instead traditional jury fyr macedonia debut competition failing get 1996 entry past qualifier judge belgium finland israel romania slovakia able return competition year exclusion getting lowest average score voting extremely close israel malta united kingdom vying top spot final vote cast eventually uk came second malta close third contest also famous eurovision fauxpas hearing dutch announcer performed contest cohost ulrika johnson said long time ago provoking laugh boo audience fact seemingly insulting comment reply something conny van den bos said performing many year ago although lost noise spectator;19

column1: How was it possible for Churchill and Roosevelt to deal with one tyrant
column3: in order to help beat another
column4: Adolf Hitler? That's one of the key questions at the heart of this new six-part landmark history series.

column1: The series uses dramatic reconstructions
column2: based on extensive fresh research in Russian and Western archives
column3: and extraordinary testimony from witnesses of the time
column4: including former Soviet secret policemen who have not spoken before on camera
column5: in order to tell a 'Behind Closed Doors' history.

column5: Who Killed the Lindbergh Baby?;One of the most controversial crime mysteries of the 20th Century. (1982);Ludovic Kennedy looks at the evidence for the guilt of Richard Hauptmann who was convicted for the murder of American aviator Charles Lindbergh's baby. (1982);"On March 1932
column6: the baby son of American aviator Charles Lindbergh was kidnapped from his home near Hopewell
column7: New Jersey. Four years later a German immigrant carpenter
column8: Bruno Richard Hauptmann
column9: was convicted of the murder of the baby and died in the electric chair.

column1: The Lindbergh Kidnapping was at the time the ‘Trial of the Century’
column2: a worldwide sensation that inspired many films and books over the years
column3: including Agatha Christie’s Murder on the Orient Express.

column1: But doubts have existed from the beginning about the guilt of Hauptmann. In 1982
column3: his 83-year-old widow reopened the case and sued the State of New Jersey for the wrongful execution of her husband

column1: Ludovic Kennedy looks at the evidence only recently made public and shows that doubts are now more than ever justified. (1982)";From the Archives;BBC WEBONLY;Contains some upsetting scenes.;1982;61;from-the-archives

column6: Germaine Greer interviews pioneer abstract artist Paule Vézelay.;"First transmitted in 1984
column7: Germaine Greer interviews pioneer abstract artist Paule Vézelay.

column1: British painter Vézelay was neglected and ignored by the British art establishment for most of her long life
column2: but she can claim to be Britain's first abstract artist. She was born Margery Watson-Williams in Bristol in 1892
column3: and changed her name when she  went to live and work in Paris in 1926. Her studio was a street away from Picasso's
column4: and she was part of the group of artists who contributed to the revolution in modern art of the 1920s.";Documentary;BBC WEBONLY;False;1984;40;from-the-archives;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p025lzn9.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p025lzn9.jpg;first transmitted 1984 germaine greer interview pioneer abstract artist paule vézelay british painter vézelay neglected ignored british art establishment long life claim britain first abstract artist born margery watsonwilliams bristol 1892 changed name went live work paris 1926 studio street away picasso part group artist contributed revolution modern art 1920s;9

column4: A Taste of Christmas with Andi Oliver;Andi meets three Glaswegian families and joins in with their festive feasts.;Andi meets three Glaswegian families and joins in with their festive feasts. She hopes to learn what the joyous meals mean to them and what they say about their city.;"Andi Oliver joins three Glaswegian families to share the food and the fun of their three very different festive feasts. Rolling up her sleeves to help with their planning and prep
column5: she also hopes to learn what the dishes at the heart of these joyous meals mean to the people who love them and what they say about the city these families all call home.

column1: Andi’s three feasts of Christmas begin when she meets Sara Capaldi and her husband Antonio De Carla
column2: a couple who are part of a big clan of Italian Glaswegians whose Christmas celebrations are built round the classic Italian recipes the family has always known and loved. The centrepiece of the meal is porchetta
column3: traditionally prepared days ahead by curing it with salt
column5: sage and rosemary.

column1: The second family to invite Andi to share their seasonal celebratory meal are the Chaudhrys. Hashim and his wife Atika live with his mum Farkhanda and his dad Masud. They’re Muslims of Pakistani heritage but true Glaswegians
column3: who love to celebrate along with the rest of the city at this time of year. A family feast at the Chaudhrys is a big affair which always sees Farkhanda and Atika preparing a range of salads
column4: curries and meat dishes – two of which Andi gets stuck into to help get it on the table. Dishes include Farkhanda's shoe kebabs
column5: named because the patties of minced chicken are shaped to resemble shoes.

column1: The third and final family to throw open their doors to Andi are the Youngs. Mum Eleanor and Dad Ron are from families that trace their history back to Glasgow as far as anyone can remember. They have three daughters - Amelia
column2: Claudia and Olivia. Ron is in charge of the turkey
column3: but the big event is all the veg that goes with it
column4: with loads of different dishes to make sure everyone gets what they love most. For the girls
column5: the Christmas meal can’t start without Eleanor’s mum Jean’s traditional cock-a-leekie soup.

column1: Reflecting on all the amazing meals she’s enjoyed
column2: Andi feels she has at last got under the skin of Glasgow

column1: 2090;2090;Back in Time for the Corner Shop;Series 1: 6. 21st Century;The Arderns’ shopkeeping adventure continues into the modern day.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p084lgjs.jpg;BBC
column4: Back in Time for the Corner Shop
column5: Series 1: 6. 21st Century;The Arderns’ shopkeeping adventure continues into the modern day.;After 100 years running a corner shop in Sheffield
column6: the Arderns continue their time-travelling adventure by exploring how local shops continue to thrive in the 21st century.;"For the final episode in the series
column7: the family reflect on their 100 years in the shop and investigate how the shopkeepers of today are using the lessons from the past and technology of the future to keep the tills ringing into the 21st century.

column1: The family’s first stop is a modern convenience store that is trialling a new app which could completely transform the role of the local shopkeeper. When the Ardern’s first opened their corner shop
column2: life behind the counter was labour intensive. With no self-service and a shop full of loose goods
column3: shopkeepers had to do almost everything for the customer. The arrival of self service in the 1960s changed all that. From then on
column4: shopkeepers did less and less and the customer more and more. By the time the family closed up shop in 1997
column5: all the shopkeeper had to do was stand behind a counter and take the money.  Dave and Sam find out how a new ‘pay-in-aisle’ app means shopkeepers don’t even have to man the till. As a 21-year-old
column6: Sam loves the speed
column7: convenience and
column8: frankly
column9: not having to chat. Dave is less sure and worries that losing the interaction between customer and shopkeeper is a step too far for smaller shops. Much cheaper to install than a self-service check-out
column10: it could be the future for all our local shops.

column1: Next stop is Panda Store in Sheffield
column2: opened to cater for one of the city’s newest and fastest growing communities - Chinese students.   During their 100 years in the shop
column3: the Arderns discovered how corner shops constantly adapted to reflect – and profit from - the changing neighbourhood
column5: when the customers were mainly local women looking for everyday necessities
column6: to the 1950s
column7: when an influx of new shift workers from the Commonwealth brought early starts
column8: late nights and plenty of white rum. By the 90s
column9: Britain was more diverse than ever and corner shops were much faster than the supermarkets at catering for potential new customers. Nowadays
column10: the most popular model for local shops is to try and cater for absolutely everyone
column11: but Panda Stores is finding success by doing the opposite and going niche.    Jo and Sam visit to check out what the shop stocks to attract the 6
column12: 000 Chinese students who call Sheffield home and
column13: of course
column14: to try out some of the shop’s best-selling items.

column1: Getting customers through the door has always been a vital part of shop keeping and during their time running the shop
column2: the Arderns came up with all kinds of novel and exciting ways to entice people in - from a fruit machine to cash in on Sheffield’s 1920s gambling epidemic and making the most of a national addiction to hula hooping in the 50s to installing a snooker table for a snooker-mad city in the 70s and installing lottery machines in 1994
column3: just in time for Britain’s first ever national lottery draw. Sara invites the whole family to try out what could be the next big thing – a chocolate-head-making machine. Using 3D technology
column4: it makes an exact replica of Dave’s head – but will anyone dare take a bite? It might seem high tech now but this could be perfect bit of kit for shopkeepers of the future to keep attracting customers through the door.

column1: With the supermarkets next door
column2: local shops are having to find new ways to compete. The family discover the merits of offering plastic-free shopping and how some shops survive by being run by the community itself. But one local shop is fighting the supermarkets in a completely different way – by going back to the past. W Martyn in north London still has the original polished wood shelves and counter and offers loose goods and full customer service. Dave and Sam visit to discover how this approach has helped them stay open for 122 years.

column1: While many local shops are thriving
column2: the traditional corner shop has all but disappeared. Sara and Polly meet the Arderns for one last time in an old corner shop that has found a new lease of life as a café. As a welcoming place for a friendly chat
column3: it also offers free classes for kids and displays local art. All over the country
column5: their location making them perfect spots for cafes
column6: coffees shops and microbreweries! The spirit of the corner shop still lives on in the building at the heart of its community.";Food;BBC TWO;False;2020;59;food
