column1: 2094;2094;Simply Nigella;7. Christmas Special;Nigella shares her foolproof guide to stress-free festive cooking and easy entertaining.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p03b03d2.jpg;BBC
column5: 7. Christmas Special;Nigella shares her foolproof guide to stress-free festive cooking and easy entertaining.;Nigella shares her foolproof guide to stress-free festive cooking in this hour-long Christmas special. Nigella's slow-cooked black treacle ham replaces turkey as the centrepiece.;"In this hour-long special
column6: Nigella shares her foolproof guide to stress-free festive cooking and easy entertaining - with a line-up of celebratory dishes which are both indulgent and practical.

column1: Inspired by the sparkling Christmas lights in Kansas City
column3: Nigella shows us how to have our most relaxed
column4: most spectacular Christmas yet. She introduces the local
column5: home-spun food that has inspired some of this year's favourite festive recipes
column6: adding a British twist back in her kitchen.

column1: Her slow-cooked black treacle ham is this party season's centrepiece
column2: paired with an easy make-ahead potato and pepper bake and a dazzling sweet and sour slaw
column4: but three spectacular bundt cakes for dessert.

column1: 2098;2098;Further Back in Time for Dinner;Series 1: 4. 1930s;The family discover a surprising decade of progress and optimism in the 1930s.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p04s5wzf.jpg;BBC
column4: Further Back in Time for Dinner
column5: Series 1: 4. 1930s;The family discover a surprising decade of progress and optimism in the 1930s.;The Robshaw family discover a surprising decade of progress and optimism as they journey through the 30s. Their larder is now stuffed with familiar brands and healthy dinners.;"The Robshaw family are experienced time travellers
column6: but this time they are going further back than they have ever been before - to the turn of the 20th century
column7: to discover how the food we ate and the way we ate it helped shape the modern family. An ordinary house in south London is their time machine
column8: transporting them through five decades and two world wars. Guided by presenters Giles Coren and social historian Polly Russell
column9: they trace the incredible changes to Britain's diet and the extraordinary social transformation they reveal.

column1: In episode four
column2: the family discover a very surprising decade of progress and optimism as they journey through the 1930s. Gone is all the starch formality of previous decades. Their larder is now stuffed with familiar brands and snacks and deliciously healthy dinners too
column3: even if they are made in a pressure cooker that looks more like an unexploded bomb than a bit of kitchen equipment.

column1: Along the way
column2: Brandon and Rochelle take a trip out for dinner and a dance in their very first family car and there is popcorn to go with their own home cinema
column3: but the family's old servant Debbie finds out that the 30s bring hard times for working women like her. As the Robshaws taste the food
column4: wine and hope of a very progressive era
column5: the threats on the horizon come closer with a visit to London's East End to commemorate the battle of Cable St and all the traditional favourites of a Jewish dinner with Giles. But as 1939 comes around
column6: their hopes for the future are dashed as their final party is interrupted by an historic radio announcement.";Food;BBC TWO;False;2017;59;food

column5: Nadiya cooks up a delicious party feast for her loved ones
column6: including sticky BBQ lamb with rhubarb glaze and raspberry ripple eclair pops.;"For Nadiya
column7: summertime is party time
column8: and is the perfect excuse to put her busy life on hold and pull out all the stops. In this glorious hour-long special
column9: Nadiya cooks up an array of mouth-watering dishes that she serves up to her loved ones at her own summer party feast.

column1: Nadiya fires up the BBQ and cooks a delicious butterflied leg of lamb with sticky rhubarb glaze
column2: perfect for feeding a crowd without all the fuss. Colourful sides include zingy kiwi and feta salad
column3: fresh and fragrant edamame wild rice
column5: stuffed with black olive and blue cheese and shaped like a crown. For dessert
column6: Nadiya goes all out with a magical princess torte cake
column7: and her ingenious raspberry ripple eclair pops provide a spectacular centrepiece to ensure her summer party goes off with a bang.

column1: Every summer feast needs a thirst-quenching drink and when the sun is shining Nadiya’s tipple of choice is an elderflower cooler. To find out how elderflowers are produced she heads to the UK's largest plantation in the Vale of Belvoir
column2: where she joins an army of local pickers as they help to bring the harvest home. In search of inspiration for a refreshing dessert
column3: Nadiya meets legendary cookery writer Claudia Roden and her family
column4: who are putting a fresh spin on the classic ice-lolly. And at Nancarrow farm in Cornwall

column8: Gregor demonstrates the merits of honey. His recipe for Swiss roll uses honey in the sponge as well as in the filling.;"Some of the country’s best home bakers welcome Gregor MacLeod into the kitchen to show him their favourite recipes. As a professional cook and baker
column9: he knows that you can’t put a price on a tried and tested recipe and also shares some of his own.

column1: Ever experimenting with flavours
column2: Gregor demonstrates the merits of honey. His recipe for Swiss roll uses honey in the sponge as well as in the filling. He also revisits a classic
column4: but in his recipe he adds pecan nuts for a tasty crunch to complement the sweet filling.

column1: Travelling the islands to taste fantastic home baking
column2: Gregor munches his way through cheese and leek muffins. These would be the perfect partner to a warming bowl of soup. He also meets a baker who combines sweet and salty in one traybake. By using salted snack pretzels she balances out the sweetness in her crunchy marshmallow and popcorn slice.

2105;2105;Sam and Shauna's Big Cook-Out;Series 3: Episode 4;Sam and Shauna celebrate a group of volunteer surf teachers with a stunning lamb dish.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08fkxjn.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 3: Episode 4;Sam and Shauna celebrate a group of volunteer surf teachers with a stunning lamb dish.;Masters of BBQ Sam and Shauna travel to Caswell Bay near Swansea to find out about Surfability
column6: an organisation run by volunteers devoted to making surfing accessible to anyone.;"It is summer and when the sun is out
column7: what is better than heading for the Gower to surf the waves and cook up an inspiring BBQ on the beach?

column1: Sam Evans and Shauna Guinn meet up with the amazing team at Surfability at Caswell Bay
column2: whose volunteers aim to make sure that surfing is something everyone can do. Specially adapted boards mean that having a disability is no barrier to enjoying the waves.

column1: That is definitely something to celebrate
column2: so with the help of the volunteers and some surfing dudes and dudettes
column3: Sam and Shauna cook up an amazing feast.

column1: Firstly
column2: they teach them how to make a simple and tasty vegetarian dish of grilled hispi cabbage with garlic
column3: lemon buttermilk dressing and a Lebanese fattoush salad.

column1: Then it is a quick trip down to the Gower Salt Marsh to learn about the unique environment the sheep there live in
column2: which makes the lamb highly sought after. For the next dish
column3: they make kofta flatbreads and barbecue lamb ribs with a maple ketchup.

column1: Of course
column2: no visit to Caswell Bay is complete without a spot of surfing
column3: so Sam and Shauna take to the waves where they make a big splash!

column8: they cook some mesquite chicken with a fennel and peach salad.

column5: which are mini burgers. Beef

column5: from a Belfast banquet held in 1859 to commemorate the centenary of the birth of Scotland’s most famous bard. ;"Chef Paula McIntyre recreates dishes from an 1859 banquet to celebrate Burns Night.

column1: Back in 1859
column2: a lavish banquet was held in Belfast’s Music Hall to commemorate the birth of Robert Burns. More than 300 Belfast citizens gathered at a feast which included mock turtle soup
column3: turkey with truffles and an array of mouthwatering desserts.

column1: The menu and an account of the banquet was published in the Belfast Newsletter. Using this as inspiration
column2: Paula has set herself the challenge of recreating some of the dishes for a special dinner which will incorporate traditional recipes and local ingredients

column1: Paula is cooking for 12 guests in the beautiful surroundings of Montalto House
column2: near Ballynahinch. Montalto has its own unique connection with Robert Burns in the form of Lady Rawdon
column3: who lived there in the 18th century and was one of the original sponsors of the first Edinburgh edition of Burns’s poems.

column1: Paula chats to food historian Annie Gray
column2: Ulster-Scots broadcaster and blogger Mark Thompson
column3: and visits the Linenhall Library to view the world-famous Gibson collection.

column1: Her final selection of dishes to be cooked at the banquet include potage a la reine (chicken and almond soup)

column3: who happens to have one in the freezer and finds out more about this cut of meat and how to cook it. And guess who is coming to tea to taste the finished stew?

column1: 2119;2119;Slighean Trailleachd (Slavery Routes) ;Series 1: Episode 4;An investigation into the slave trade in black Africans from the 7th to the 20th century.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09yt3fp.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 4;An investigation into the slave trade in black Africans from the 7th to the 20th century.;An investigation into the slave trade in black Africans and how after 1789
column6: the abolitionist movement gathered momentum.;"From 1789 to 1888
column7: in the new frontiers of slavery

column1: in London
column3: the abolitionist movement was gathering momentum. After the slave rebellion in Santo Domingo
column4: and facing the public opinion’s growing outrage
column5: the major European powers abolished the trans-Atlantic trade in 1807.

column1: Yet Europe
column2: in the midst of the industrial revolution
column3: could not do without the slave workforce. To satisfy its needs in raw materials
column4: it pushed further the frontiers of slavery and turned a blind eye on the new forms of human exploitation in Brazil
column5: the United States and Africa. At a time when legal trade was finally prohibited
column6: the deportation of African captives would explode
column7: and become more important than ever. Within 50 years
column8: nearly 2.5 million were deported.

Each detail is brought back to life in a spectacular ceremony as Lucy reveals how this event saved the monarchy and invented modern marriage.

column1: Aided by a team of experts
column2: Lucy recreates the most important elements of the ceremony and the celebrations
column5: newspapers and Queen Victoria's diaries for the details. She reveals how every moment was brilliantly stage-managed for maximum effect. Like every good marriage celebration
column6: the film is a heady mix of fine food
column7: fabulous clothes
column8: music
column9: emotion
column10: gossip and intrigue. From the white dress to the massive tiered white cake
column11: from the music sung by the choir to the moment rings were exchanged
column12: each element has been carefully researched and remade for a grand staging of the big day itself.

column1: The experts include food historian Annie Gray
column2: clothing expert Harriet Waterhouse and military historian Jasdeep Singh. Woven into the recreation of the wedding day is the story of Victoria and Albert's courtship and engagement
column3: and its political importance. Lucy unpacks and explores the hidden iconography and symbolism of this hugely significant wedding
column4: and reveals new insights into Victoria and Albert's relationship; both public and private.

column1: The film sheds new light on the wider implications of the wedding and reveals how this one extraordinary event helped to invent modern marriage.";History;BBC TWO;False;2018;89;history

column1: 2122;2122;Back in Time for the Factory;Series 1: Episode 5;The story of the original factory girls who took on the fight for equality.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p074rhnj.jpg;BBC
column4: Back in Time for the Factory
column5: Series 1: Episode 5;The story of the original factory girls who took on the fight for equality.;The story of the original factory girls who took on the fight for equality at home and at work
column6: with behind-the-scenes footage of the making of the series. Presented by Alex Jones.;"In this final episode
column7: original factory girls give first-hand accounts of their experiences on the factory floor
column8: at the kitchen sink and on raucous nights out. The women speak of terrifying bosses
column9: everyday sexism
column10: union battles
column11: camaraderie and of lifelong friendships forged on the production line. With Wales-born presenter Alex Jones guiding us through this most important chapter in industrial history
column12: the programme also shows how the factory was lovingly brought back to life using the testimony of those original factory girls as inspiration.

column1: The women's real-life stories are grounded in the south Wales valleys where female factory workers were poorly paid
column2: unfairly treated and denied basic rights. In the 60s and early 70s it was perfectly legal for women to be paid less than men
column3: to be sacked when they were pregnant and to be denied the right to apply for the same jobs as men. But women fought back
column4: and when the female workers at Ford Dagenham walked out demanding equal pay
column5: they set in motion a fight for equal pay in factories across Britain.

column1: The original factory girls share their memories of starting work at the factories
column2: often swapping the school gates for the factory floor at the age of 15. A job in the factory gave the teenagers the freedom and wages they had never had. But as they grew in experience and became skilled seamstresses they realised they were being treated as second-class citizens
column3: often working in harsh conditions and earning much less than their male counterparts. There was little equality at home too - once the shift was over
column4: it would be time to go home to make the tea. But there was also a lot of fun to be had in the factory. The long hours
column5: sitting side by side on the production line
column6: gave the women a strong sense of camaraderie and they forged friendships that would last a lifetime.

column1: But then came the 80s - while conditions had improved and the fight for equality was starting to pay off
column2: the clothing industry came under serious threat with the loss government subsidies and the economic pressures of globalisation. The original factory girls share their devastation at seeing their livelihood and whole way of life come to an end. This programme is an opportunity to hear the voices of the unsung heroes who achieved so much in the fight for women's rights.";History;BBC TWO;False;2018;59;history

column9: recalls battles in the air.;Norman Macmillan
column10: an infantryman turned fighter pilot
column11: recalls the precision with which air operations were carried out and the adrenaline of a dangerous strafing mission.;"Norman Macmillan enlisted as a Private with the Glasgow Battalion of the Highland Light Infantry. He served as an infantryman in France from November 1914 until September 1916
column12: when he was commissioned to the Royal Flying Corps as a temporary second lieutenant. This was his calling. Norman describes one particular strafing mission at Passchendaele that became the most thrilling flight of his life.

column1: With a natural flair for manoeuvres and for developing his own combat techniques
column2: Norman excelled in what was a very lonely and terrifying task. The skies of Passchendaele were also the stage for dogfights
column3: and with incredible detail Norman recalls tactics that scattered seven German Albatross Scout planes and shot down their leader.

column1: His account is a rare opportunity to hear of the differences between life in the trenches and in the air.";History;BBC WEBONLY;False;2014;24;history;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p01t624c.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p01t624c.jpg;norman macmillan enlisted private glasgow battalion highland light infantry served infantryman france november 1914 september 1916 commissioned royal flying corp temporary second lieutenant calling norman describes one particular strafing mission passchendaele became thrilling flight life natural flair manoeuvre developing combat technique norman excelled lonely terrifying task sky passchendaele also stage dogfight incredible detail norman recall tactic scattered seven german albatross scout plane shot leader account rare opportunity hear difference life trench air;11

column5: The Man Who Saw Too Much;The story of 106-year-old Boris Pahor
column6: a concentration camp survivor.;106-year-old Boris Pahor
column7: believed to be the oldest living survivor of a Nazi concentration camp
column8: talks about life and death at Natzweiler
column9: where almost half the prisoners died.;"The Man Who Saw Too Much tells the story of 106-year-old Boris Pahor
column10: believed to be the oldest known survivor of the Nazi concentration camps. He was sent to Dachau
column11: Dora
column12: Harzungen
column13: Bergen-Belsen and Natzweiler – one of the Nazis' least known but most deadly camps. Twenty years after the war
column14: Pahor wrote an extraordinary book about his experiences called Necropolis - City of the Dead.

column1: Alan Yentob visits Boris Pahor at his home in Trieste
column2: where he talks about his fight against fascism and the Nazis. Boris
column5: cosmopolitan city of Trieste in 1913. After World War I
column6: when it became part of Italy and Mussolini rose to power
column7: fascists burned down the Slovene cultural centre
column8: closed their schools and the speaking of Slovene in public was banned. During World War II
column9: Boris fought with the Italian army until its surrender in 1943
column10: when he returned to Trieste just before the Nazis took over the city. He joined the Slovene resistance but was betrayed and handed over to the Gestapo
column11: and sent on to the camps. Natzweiler
column12: where he was to stay the longest
column13: is hidden in the mountains of Alsace. Nearly half of its 52
column14: 000 prisoners died through the effects of forced labour
column15: malnutrition
column16: illness and execution. The Nazis conducted medical experiments on prisoners and
column17: on one occasion
column18: 86 Jews were brought to the camp and executed to provide skeletons for a Nazi professor of anatomy’s collection. Natzweiler was the first concentration camp in western Europe to be discovered by the Allies – but the camp was empty
column19: its prisoners has been taken to Dachau.

column1: Pahor’s harrowing descriptions are illustrated with remarkable drawings by fellow prisoners
column2: creating a unique record of conditions in the Nazi death camps. His testimony
column3: along with details from a shocking report into the camp by British intelligence officer Captain Yurka Galitzine and the chilling testimony by SS commandant Josef Kramer
column4: infamous as the Beast of Belsen
column5: combine to tell an extraordinary story.

column1: 2130;2130;Empire of the Tsars: Romanov Russia with Lucy Worsley;3. The Road to Revolution;Lucy investigates how the family's grip on Russia unravelled in the years 1825-1918.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09b30bz.jpg;BBC
column4: Empire of the Tsars: Romanov Russia with Lucy Worsley
column5: 3. The Road to Revolution;Lucy investigates how the family's grip on Russia unravelled in the years 1825-1918.;Lucy investigates how the Romanov family's grip on Russia unravelled in their final century
column6: with the years 1825-1918 being bloody and traumatic.;"Lucy Worsley concludes her history of the Romanov dynasty
column7: investigating how the family's grip on Russia unravelled in their final century. She shows how the years 1825-1918 were bloody and traumatic
column8: a period when four tsars tried - and failed - to deal with the growing pressure for constitutional reform and revolution.

column1: Lucy finds out how the Romanovs tried to change the system themselves - in 1861
column2: millions of enslaved serfs were freed by the Tsar-Liberator
column3: Alexander II. But Alexander paid the ultimate penalty for opening the Pandora's box of reform when he was later blown up by terrorists on the streets of St Petersburg.

column1: Elsewhere
column4: war and - in the case of the last tsar
column5: Nicholas II - a fatalistic belief in the power of God
column6: with Nicholas's faith in the notorious holy man Rasputin being a major part in his undoing. Lucy also details the chilling murder of Nicholas and his family in 1918
column7: and asks whether all of this horror have been avoided.

column1: Lucy also shows how there was a growing movement among the people of Russia to determine their own fate. She traces the growth of the intelligentsia
column2: writers and thinkers who sought to have a voice about Russia. Speaking out came with a risk - after Ivan Turgenev wrote about the appalling life of the serfs in 1852
column3: he was sentenced to house arrest by tsar Nicholas I. Lucy also shows how anger against the Romanov regime created a later generation of radicals committed to overturning the status quo. Some would turn to terrorism and
column5: revolution.

column1: As well as political upheaval there is private drama
column2: and Lucy explains how Nicholas II's family life played into his family's downfall. His son and heir Alexei suffered from haemophilia - the secrecy the family placed around the condition led them into seclusion
column3: further distancing them from the Russian people. It also led them to the influence of man who seemed to have the power to heal their son
column4: and who was seen as a malign influence on Nicholas - Rasputin.";History;BBC FOUR;False;2016;59;history

column1: 2137;2137;Britain's Forgotten Slave Owners;2. The Price of Freedom;David Olusoga traces the propaganda war waged between pro-slavery lobby and abolitionists.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08gkbzx.jpg;BBC
column5: 2. The Price of Freedom;David Olusoga traces the propaganda war waged between pro-slavery lobby and abolitionists.;Documentary. David Olusoga traces the bitter propaganda war waged between the pro-slavery lobby and the abolitionists.;"Historian David Olusoga continues his examination of Britain's forgotten slave owners. In this episode
column6: David explores how in 1834 the government arrived at the extraordinary decision to compensate the slave owners with the equivalent of £17 billion in today's money. Tracing the bitter propaganda war waged between the pro-slavery lobby and the abolitionists
column7: he reveals that paying off the slave owners for the loss of their human property was
column8: ultimately
column9: the only way to bring the system to an end.

column1: Meticulously kept records held at the National Archives detail the names of the 46
column2: 000 slave owners from across the British empire who had a slice of this vast handout. Combined with new research
column3: shared exclusively with the BBC by University College London
column4: it reveals more about Britain's slave owners than we've ever known before.

column1: Of the 46
column5: yet they owned half of the slaves across the empire and pocketed half of the compensation money. These include members of the clergy and of the House of Lords. The records also show that at the point of abolition
column6: more than 40 per cent of all the slave owners were women.

column1: David goes on to investigate what happened to the wealth generated by the slave system and compensation pay out. He reveals aspects of Britain's spectacular industrialisation in the 19th century
column2: the consolidation of the City of London as a world centre of finance
column3: and a number of the country's most well-known institutions that all have links to slave-derived wealth.

column1: Ultimately
column2: David discovers that the country's debt to slavery is far greater than previously thought
column3: shaping everything from the nation's property landscape to its ideas about race. A legacy that can still be felt today.";History;BBC TWO;False;2015;59;history

column1: 2138;2138;The Asian Welsh;Series 1: Episode 3;Onkar Singh Purewal explores how Indian immigration has transformed the Welsh economy.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b6lfrj.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;Onkar Singh Purewal explores how Indian immigration has transformed the Welsh economy.;Onkar reveals why family combined with a serious work ethic has meant immigrants from the Indian subcontinent have excelled in business and transformed the Welsh economy in the process.;"Onkar reveals why family combined with a serious work ethic has meant immigrants from the Indian subcontinent have excelled in business and transformed the Welsh economy in the process. He starts with the story of his own father. Sukdev arrived in Britain in 1976 with one suitcase and £75 in his pocket. From there
column6: he built up a business empire of a corner shop
column7: a chip shop and a hotel. Onkar also unearths why a fifth of corner shops in Wales are run by Indian immigrants. In the valleys and tight-knit communities outside big cities
column8: Asian immigration helped smooth race relations
column9: but in urban areas it was a different story.

column1: Tea shop owner Kasim Ali grew up in Cardiff in the 1970s
column2: and his parents ran a corner shop. He reveals the racist abuse they suffered and how that affected him growing up. But he also shares how times have changed and talks about the community bonds he has forged in opening up a chain of successful cafes across Cardiff. Onkar takes a crash course in tea making and tea etiquette as he finds out the secrets behind Kasim’s success.

column1: In Colwyn Bay
column2: Onkar rolls up his sleeves to take part in a Bollywood dance session run by entrepreneur Ghazala Jabeen. Pakistani-born
column3: she moved to Colwyn Bay 25 years ago and is now one of a growing number of female Asian entrepreneurs able to spot an opportunity and grow a brand new business. Her Bollywood fitness classes have taken off across north Wales and bagged her a string of awards. She shares how being in Wales made it happen and why she thinks her business has been such a success.

column1: Onkar heads for Cardiff market to try out his sales patter with the Singh family
column2: who have run a mobile phone stall for 30 years. Finally Onkar meets Rakesh Aggarwal who runs Wales’s biggest beauty retailer – a business that started in his parents' garage and is now global. We hear how it employs a huge Welsh workforce and how the business could only have happened in Wales!";History;BBC ONE WALES;False;2021;28;history

column5: paratroopers shot dead 13 innocent civil rights marchers in Northern Ireland. It is forever known as Bloody Sunday. Peter Taylor analyses what happened.;Fifty years ago this month
column6: Paratroopers shot dead 13 innocent civil rights marchers in Northern Ireland. It was the British Army's darkest day - forever known as Bloody Sunday. No soldier has been prosecuted. The tragedy helped fuel the IRA's bloody campaign over the violent decades ahead and set back the chances of peace for more than 20 years. column10: 000 miles in four months

column12: a charming fixer solving international and domestic disputes everywhere from Canada to Burma.

column1: 2158;2158;Planet Defenders;Series 1: 6. Jack and Rewilding;Environmentalist Jack Harries investigates the impact of rewilding projects in the UK.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09bl8wq.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 6. Jack and Rewilding;Environmentalist Jack Harries investigates the impact of rewilding projects in the UK.;Environmentalist Jack Harries is on a mission to film beavers
column6: red squirrels
column7: pine martens and Scottish wildcats
column8: as he investigates the impact of rewilding projects in the UK.;"Environmentalist Jack has made films since he was very young and has a loyal following online. More recently he has thrown himself into climate change activism and working to increase awareness of the threats to our planet. His mission is to investigate the growing but sometimes controversial movement to rewild Britain.

column1: Jack discovers how the first legalised reintroduction of the beaver to England is having dramatic results. It is re-engineering river systems and creating rich habitats for many other species. He learns that despite the benefits of having this giant rodent around
column2: some people think bringing it back is bad news.

column1: Jack travels to the Highlands of Scotland to witness the beauty of a 300-acre area of land that has been allowed to regenerate in its natural way for the past 40 years. It is here that he comes face to face with endangered wildlife such as red squirrels and pine martens
column2: that have crept back from the brink of extinction to live in this wilderness. He also learns about a vision of the future to reintroduce one of Britain’s most elusive and special predators: the wildcat.";CBBC;CBBC;False;2021;24;cbbc;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09bl8wq.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09bl8wq.jpg;environmentalist jack made film since young loyal following online recently thrown climate change activism working increase awareness threat planet mission investigate growing sometimes controversial movement rewild britain jack discovers first legalised reintroduction beaver england dramatic result reengineering river system creating rich habitat many specie learns despite benefit giant rodent around people think bringing back bad news jack travel highland scotland witness beauty 300acre area land allowed regenerate natural way past 40 year come face face endangered wildlife red squirrel pine marten crept back brink extinction live wilderness also learns vision future reintroduce one britain ’ elusive special predator wildcat;8

She first wanted to help after feeling upset seeing rough sleepers on the streets around Christmas time. She collects donations of clothes and shoes from her local community and then gives them out to rough sleepers. Mia has great support from her family and friends
column6: and the homeless community in Manchester really appreciate the work she is doing to help. column1: 2235;2235;My Life;Series 12: Battle of the Ballroom;Ballroom dancers Bailey and Summer get ready for Blackpool
column5: My Life
column6: Series 12: Battle of the Ballroom;Ballroom dancers Bailey and Summer get ready for Blackpool
column7: their biggest competition yet.;Ballroom dancers Bailey and Summer are on a quest to show off their cha-cha-cha at the Blackpool championships. But will all their practise pay off to win them a medal?;"Bailey and Summer are budding ballroom champions from Blackwood
column8: South Wales. Bailey has autism and is also visually impaired
column9: but if anything
column10: autism is the secret to Bailey’s success. It gives him focus and determination
column11: and he has never been self-conscious on the dance floor. After 18 months of lockdowns and dancing on their own - in their kitchens and bedrooms - Summer and Bailey are now finally back in training for the biggest competition of their lives
column12: at the world-famous Tower Ballroom in Blackpool.

column1: Summer and Bailey are firm friends. We meet them as they celebrate turning 13 together over a meal with their families
column2: the all-important members of the Bailey and Summer dance support team. Dancing ballroom at competition level is a huge commitment for everyone
column4: who get to spend their evenings taxiing the dancers to their lessons
column5: and are also required to buy some very expensive dance outfits. As for the dancers themselves
column6: ballroom success means hours and hours of hard work on the dance floor.

column1: Bailey and Summer go to their busy local dance school most nights of the week for three or four-hour training sessions. When he is not doing ballroom and Latin with Summer
column2: Bailey is out doing ballet classes
column3: as well as tap and jazz. Summer’s school friends are all into dance
column4: and on an afternoon in the park they choreograph their own routine and talk frankly about how dancing has kept them going during lockdown.

column1: Bailey’s autism can give him anxiety
column2: so he likes to know exactly what he is doing and needs to keep to a regular weekly schedule. He feels that dance is the thing that helps him free his mind and keep him calm in times of stress.

column1: As part of their preparations for Blackpool
column2: Summer and Bailey take part in an online dance competition where they survive an unlucky incident with a flying shoe! As the big competition approaches
column3: they are lucky enough to be invited backstage at the studios of their favourite TV show
column5: where they are given competition tips from some of the Strictly stars.

column1: As the Blackpool Championships get closer
column2: we see Bailey and Summer’s final preparations: the competition haircuts
column3: the tricky business of choosing the right costume
column4: and of course the all-important competition spray tan! Summer and Bailey dance ballroom and Latin
column5: but of all the different steps their favourite is the cha-cha-cha. Is this the routine that will win them a medal?

column1: At Blackpool there are more than 600 competitors in the different classes and categories
column2: and it is a heady atmosphere on the dance floor as dancers from all over the UK celebrate their first chance to dance in public since Covid shut everything down. For Bailey and Summer
column3: their whole family are on the sidelines cheering them on
column5: after all the months of training
column6: they finally get to battle it out on the ballroom floor!";CBBC;CBBC;False;2021;28;cbbc

column1: 2250;2250;Greetings from Scotland;Series 1: Episode 2;A humorous look at the Scottish tourism industry through the years.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09czd1p.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 2;A humorous look at the Scottish tourism industry through the years.;Documentary taking a humorous look at the Scottish tourism industry through the years. In this episode
column6: expensive films and cheap flights mean Scotland is swarming with excited tourists.;"In the autumn of 1995
column7: two events transformed Scottish tourism - Braveheart was released and the first ever Easyjet flight took off
column8: from Luton to Glasgow.

column1: Braveheart sold Scotland around the world
column2: making it synonymous with Mel Gibson’s epic. Meanwhile
column3: low-budget airlines and the deregulation of air travel enabled direct routes from the US to open up. The year following Braveheart's release saw the first Tartan Day parade in New York
column4: and Sean Connery beseeched long-lost Scots to return to their homeland.

column1: However
column2: the tourism business itself was changing rapidly
column3: with the emerging internet giving tourists a chance to be a travel critic themselves via TripAdvisor reviews
column5: and Scotland had to play catch up to ensure even the smallest businesses had a website. In 2006
column6: the tourist board renamed itself Visit Scotland
column7: and its focus has increasingly been online marketing – including paying influencers and Instagrammers to come and promote Scotland.

column1: The second most popular subject searched for online is genealogy
column2: and Scotland has benefited from a glut of Americans
column3: Australians and South Africans returning to trace their roots. Roots tourism is a huge market
column4: and when people track down their ancestors to a cottage or grave
column5: it often cements a deep and meaningful bond with Scotland and with their ancestors' place in Scottish history.

column1: Visitors come in search of ‘the real Scotland’ - the rustic fisherman’s cottage
column2: the folk music in the pub
column4: due to the money to be made
column5: everyday life in Scotland is often changed by tourism. Edinburgh has suffered from relentless waves of tourism
column6: and a walk down the Royal Mile shows the capital is in danger of turning into a tartan theme park. But Edinburghers are fighting back
column7: questioning the need for more hotels and fighting for residents' rights.

column1: In rural Scotland
column2: the benefits of tourism are also bittersweet
column3: with campaigns to curtail Airbnb and a plea to ensure local communities are not overwhelmed by coach tours and tourism.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;58;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09czd1p.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09czd1p.jpg;autumn 1995 two event transformed scottish tourism braveheart released first ever easyjet flight took luton glasgow braveheart sold scotland around world making synonymous mel gibson ’ epic meanwhile lowbudget airline deregulation air travel enabled direct route u open year following bravehearts release saw first tartan day parade new york sean connery beseeched longlost scot return homeland however tourism business changing rapidly emerging internet giving tourist chance travel critic via tripadvisor review travel blog like scotland play catch ensure even smallest business website 2006 tourist board renamed visit scotland focus increasingly online marketing – including paying influencers instagrammers come promote scotland second popular subject searched online genealogy scotland benefited glut american australian south african returning trace root root tourism huge market people track ancestor cottage grave often cement deep meaningful bond scotland ancestor place scottish history visitor come search ‘ real scotland ’ rustic fisherman ’ cottage folk music pub empty glen however due money made everyday life scotland often changed tourism edinburgh suffered relentless wave tourism walk royal mile show capital danger turning tartan theme park edinburghers fighting back questioning need hotel fighting resident right rural scotland benefit tourism also bittersweet campaign curtail airbnb plea ensure local community overwhelmed coach tour tourism;3

column6: whose paranoid schizophrenia prompts him to disappear and go into hiding.;"It’s late at night when 25-year-old Oli calls Gloucestershire Police. His father
column7: Michael
column8: has missed an appointment with his mental health worker
column9: and no-one knows where he is. Michael is known to be suffering from paranoid schizophrenia and is thought to have stopped taking his medication. When PC Jade Chitcuti leads a search of Michael’s house in Cheltenham
column10: the evidence of his paranoia is clear for police to see. While Michael is not thought to be suicidal
column11: he is known to hide
column12: which could place him at increased risk if he is outdoors and not found quickly.

column1: Michael has been receiving treatment for his mental health for many years and this is not the first time he has gone missing.  Oli is becoming increasingly desperate to find a way of helping Michael and restoring him to the happy
column2: cheerful father he remembers.  But try as he might
column3: Oli is battling to get his father to acknowledge he is ill and to get him to accept the treatment he needs. When police find Michael hiding after three days out in the open
column4: having had nothing to eat or drink
column5: it’s an indication of how much he will neglect himself in his bid to get away. But what they do not yet know is that this just the start of a number of increasingly erratic and challenging missing episodes that will test both their resources and ingenuity to the limit.";Current Affairs;BBC ONE;False;2020;58;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08njqy9.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08njqy9.jpg;’ late night 25yearold oli call gloucestershire police father michael missed appointment mental health worker noone know michael known suffering paranoid schizophrenia thought stopped taking medication pc jade chitcuti lead search michael ’ house cheltenham evidence paranoia clear police see michael thought suicidal known hide could place increased risk outdoors found quickly michael receiving treatment mental health many year first time gone missing oli becoming increasingly desperate find way helping michael restoring happy cheerful father remembers try might oli battling get father acknowledge ill get accept treatment need police find michael hiding three day open nothing eat drink ’ indication much neglect bid get away yet know start number increasingly erratic challenging missing episode test resource ingenuity limit;1

column1: 2252;2252;My Mate's a Muslim;None;Famous Muslims Krept and Rumena challenge their non-Muslim friends to fast for Ramadan.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08d8b31.jpg;BBC
column4: My Mates a Muslim;Famous Muslims Krept and Rumena challenge their non-Muslim friends to fast for Ramadan.;Rapper Krept and vlogger Rumena are fasting for Ramadan and challenge their non-Muslim friends to join in. Can their mates make it through the day without food or water?;"As Muslims
column5: rapper Krept and vlogger Rumena both look forward to the holy month of Ramadan as a time for reflection and self-improvement
column6: but this year will be a little different.

column1: In the year of the pandemic panic
column2: there will be no mosques with fellow worshippers
column3: no late-night shisha with friends and no full-on feasts with the family. Which means young Muslims across the world are hungry for camaraderie and banter after weeks of isolation. Enter social media apps and video calls to keep the joy and community spirit of the holy month alive.

column1: So as the boredom for all of us has fully set in - where virtual pub quizzes have become passé
column2: boxsets have been binged and your hour of government-mandated exercise is no longer cutting it - Krept and Rumena get their non-Muslim mates in on the Ramadan act. They challenge their mates Kritikal and Olivia to join them in a day of no eating and drinking to learn about the true experience of Ramadan. Fasting in lockdown might be a match made in heaven!

column1: Watch the outrageous 3.00am wake-up calls demanding that they drag themselves out of bed and get some food down them. Brace for the 11.00am sugar crash and desperate pleas for a sip of water. Witness the 5.00pm delirium as the lack of calories sets in and the temptation to cheat on a cheeky snack kicks in. Finally
column2: friends get together on video chat to count down the moments before breaking their fast and capture that true friendship of achieving something together.

column1: Will the carb crash be ugly or enlightening? Can you calm your hyperactive friend by banning their morning coffee? Will the confident chest thumpers fail at fasting before they have even got to lunchtime? Can you really trust your mates not to cheat on the challenge? And will the experience help friends learn more about each others’ communities? Get ready to let your stomachs rumble.";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2020;29;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08d8b31.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08d8b31.jpg;muslim rapper krept vlogger rumena look forward holy month ramadan time reflection selfimprovement year little different year pandemic panic mosque fellow worshipper latenight shisha friend fullon feast family mean young muslim across world hungry camaraderie banter week isolation enter social medium apps video call keep joy community spirit holy month alive boredom u fully set virtual pub quiz become passé boxsets binged hour governmentmandated exercise longer cutting krept rumena get nonmuslim mate ramadan act challenge mate kritikal olivia join day eating drinking learn true experience ramadan fasting lockdown might match made heaven watch outrageous 300am wakeup call demanding drag bed get food brace 1100am sugar crash desperate plea sip water witness 500pm delirium lack calorie set temptation cheat cheeky snack kick finally friend get together video chat count moment breaking fast capture true friendship achieving something together carb crash ugly enlightening calm hyperactive friend banning morning coffee confident chest thumpers fail fasting even got lunchtime really trust mate cheat challenge experience help friend learn others ’ community get ready let stomach rumble;13

column7: Tasnim wonders if her mum was abused by a wider network of men as well as her dad. Tasnim speaks to a victim of grooming gangs in Telford and hears again that Lucy’s death was used as a violent threat to silence victims. She is still haunted by the threat to this day.

column1: Tasnim is determined to secure justice for Lucy. Azhar has always denied the charge of murder and
column3: he was never prosecuted for any crimes relating to child sexual exploitation. Tasnim meets with the police to ask why her dad will not be prosecuted for these offences. Tasnim visits her local MP
column5: to request that her mum’s case be included in the Independent Inquiry into Child Sexual Exploitation in Telford
column6: set up to establish the scale of the abuse and why it went undetected for so long.

column1: Ahead of her dad’s parole hearing
column2: Tasnim looks to the future and hopes that her family will find happiness and justice. column5: the daughter of a convicted sex offender
column6: steps into the unsettling world of sex offender rehabilitation to see what can be done to stop them reoffending.;"Becky Southworth’s father was convicted of sex offences against children and served ten years in prison. He has since been released
column7: but while in prison he undertook a sex offender rehabilitation programme. Becky does not know if it worked and doesn’t speak to her father now
column8: but wants to know if rehabilitating sex offenders is even possible.

column1: In this film
column2: she steps into the unsettling world of sex offender rehabilitation
column3: meeting sex offenders living in our communities and trying to understand what drove them to commit these horrific crimes
column4: while seeing what treatment is available to stop them committing any more. Filming across the UK in anonymous locations with extreme protective measures in place to protect the sex offenders from attacks from the public
column5: Becky meets a growing group of offenders who have not been sent to prison for their crimes and have received treatment in the community. Through meeting these people and reflecting on her past
column6: Becky questions if sex offenders can really ever change.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2020;55;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08njrb4.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08njrb4.jpg;becky southworth ’ father convicted sex offence child served ten year prison since released prison undertook sex offender rehabilitation programme becky know worked ’ speak father want know rehabilitating sex offender even possible film step unsettling world sex offender rehabilitation meeting sex offender living community trying understand drove commit horrific crime seeing treatment available stop committing filming across uk anonymous location extreme protective measure place protect sex offender attack public becky meet growing group offender sent prison crime received treatment community meeting people reflecting past becky question sex offender really ever change;11

column8: for them
column9: the positives outweigh the negatives.;"At the end of 2019 it was estimated that there were more than 2.5 billion active gamers around the world
column10: yet still
column11: there is a lot of confusion and debate around the effect video games have on our mental health and wellbeing.

column1: Can they make us addicted? Are they a conduit to violent behaviour? Are these even the right questions to ask?
With a pandemic in full swing
column2: and more people than ever spending their lives online
column3: we believe there is a better question to be asked: How do video games make us feel?

column1: While some still warn of their risks
We meet Abi
column3: a gamer and cosplayer whose love for a particular game
column5: helped her become more in-tune with her own emotions
column6: feelings and identity.

column1: Joe
column2: an old school gamer from Glasgow
column3: told us about how gaming helped him in coming to terms with his depression; and Elissa
column5: details how ‘Animal Crossing’ made the lockdown much easier for her and her friends at uni
column6: providing the connection and sense of community they were missing.

column1: Video games are still under the scrutiny
column2: and while the science is still not there in terms of understanding how they can affect us
column3: many argue that the positive sides of it outdo the negative.

column1: 2261;2261;Who Owns Scotland?;Series 1: Episode 2;Martin Geissler reveals what we do and don’t know about land ownership in rural Scotland.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09z0lyr.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: Episode 2;Martin Geissler reveals what we do and don’t know about land ownership in rural Scotland.;Martin Geissler travels across Scotland to reveal what we do and don’t know about who owns our rural land
column6: and discovers how the ways land is used and valued is undergoing radical change.;"In this episode
column7: Martin Geissler investigates our rural land – who owns it
column8: what they are doing with it
column9: and what the future might hold for it.

column1: Because of the way land ownership has historically been recorded in Scotland
column2: it can be even harder to find out who owns our rural land than it is to find out who owns the land in our town and cities. With the help of researcher and writer Andy Wightman
column3: and the visualisation skills of design collective Lateral North
column4: Martin explores what we do and don’t know about land ownership in rural Scotland and finds out why it matters.

column1: Martin visits Lossiemouth
column2: where ownerless property is losing the town a fortune in tourist income
column3: and finds out how patchy and incomplete historic records saw the anglers of Selkirk miss out on their traditional fishing rights. He sees how easy it has been in the past for landowners to hide behind offshore trusts and explores an ancient pine forest and a highland estate to ask whether the way we think about and value our rural land is changing.

column1: He also delves into the past
column2: looking back to a time when Scotland was covered with common land
column3: and asks whether the community buyout is revolutionising our pattern of land ownership.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;58;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09z0lyr.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09z0lyr.jpg;episode martin geissler investigates rural land – owns future might hold way land ownership historically recorded scotland even harder find owns rural land find owns land town city help researcher writer andy wightman visualisation skill design collective lateral north martin explores ’ know land ownership rural scotland find matter martin visit lossiemouth ownerless property losing town fortune tourist income find patchy incomplete historic record saw angler selkirk miss traditional fishing right see easy past landowner hide behind offshore trust explores ancient pine forest highland estate ask whether way think value rural land changing also delf past looking back time scotland covered common land asks whether community buyout revolutionising pattern land ownership;8

column1: Since meeting online in 2019
column4: making social media their full-time job. However
column5: their unconventional way of life generates strong emotions from their followers
column6: and they have been targeted by trolls in a relentless campaign of online bullying
column7: while offline
column8: they are grappling with life struggles and decisions that many of us will never have to face.

column1: Charlie is transitioning from female to male
column2: and has taken matters into his own hands after being unable to deal with the psychological torture of long NHS waiting lists and delayed treatment. Meanwhile
column3: Lauren is dealing with deeply debilitating OCD and emetophobia
column5: which has caused a dangerous addiction to anti-sickness pills. Unable to work a normal nine-to-five job
column6: Lauren has entered the risqué world of online sex work. However
column7: but as the money flows in
column8: so does the online abuse
column9: and there is an ever-growing fear that there is no way out of life online. The couple desperately want a family of their own – but will their quest for normality ever be achieved

column1: In August 2020
column2: Roman’s life changed dramatically with the sudden and unexpected death of his best friend
column3: radio producer Joe Lyons. This timely documentary sees Roman taking a closer look at the urgent issue of young men’s mental health
column4: exploring why increasing numbers are taking their own lives and the reasons why so many of them never ask for help.

column1: Wanting to find some answers in a difficult time
column2: Roman explores what can be done to encourage people to seek help

column4: and the lasting impact mental health issues and suicide can have on friends and families. This is a film about Roman’s generation

column5: revealing the people flooding the country with fake clothes and pills.;"The black market is where we go for our fake gear
column6: but who is behind it all? Investigative reporter Livvy Haydock has spent the last six months investigating the people flooding the UK with fake clothes
column7: bags and even pills.

column1: During the course of her investigation Livvy meets a young importer of fake goods ready to sell on to buyers and markets around the country. She also investigates the back alley sweatshop clothes factories making the fakes right here in the UK.
Livvy also meets the people manufacturing and selling counterfeit Xanax pills
column2: which hit the headlines recently with over 200 deaths in the UK since 2015 attributed to fake copies of the drug. It is legally available but only on private prescription
column3: resulting in young customers turning to the black market for their fix.

column1: She meets dealers selling fake Xanax to 14-year-olds
column2: as well as others who use customers as human guinea pigs to test whether their product is safe.

column5: Betty Campbell
column6: and the statue that will celebrate her lifetime of remarkable achievements.;"Cerys Matthews presents the story of Wales’s first black head teacher
column7: Betty Campbell
column8: and the new statue that will honour her lifetime of remarkable achievements.

column1: After a public vote
column2: Betty Campbell was chosen from a shortlist of incredible women from history to be immortalised as the first public statue of a named Welsh woman. Those who knew Betty well recall the life and work of this community icon from Cardiff’s Butetown and her journey from a tough childhood marked by tragedy and setbacks to the pioneering achievements that brought her plaudits from the likes of Nelson Mandela.

column1: Told a working-class black girl could never achieve her ambitions
column2: Betty proved her doubters wrong by battling racism to pursue her goal. After becoming Wales’s first black head teacher in 1973 on her home patch of Butetown
column4: and ensured her pupils knew their history
column5: by putting their multicultural heritage on the school curriculum. Her pioneering approach saw her create her own books and projects to teach her pupils about the positive contribution to British society by people of all races. She also helped create Black History Month.

column1: Former pupils tell of how Betty Campbell's support was vital to their success. One
column3: left Cardiff in her early twenties and rose to one of the highest positions in American law enforcement after being nominated by President Barack Obama to become a US marshall. Cerys discovers how Betty’s influence on Wales grew beyond the classroom with positions in public life and politics
column4: and she finds out how Betty proved a passionate advocate for the people of Butetown as a councillor.

column1: Filmed over three years
column2: the programme follows the unfolding story of the groundbreaking statue that will keep her legacy alive
column3: including the challenge faced by the world-renowned sculptor chosen to capture this heroine’s spirit. As unveiling day arrives and the statue for Betty Campbell is revealed to Wales and the world

column2: work and contradictions of one of the most important Ulster Irish writers of the 20th century

column1: Séamus Ó Grianna was a gifted novelist
column2: lyricist and activist from Rannafast in the Donegal Gaeltacht who shaped his local dialect into a national literary language. While he was a pioneering and prolific writer
column3: a tireless campaigner for Ulster Irish and a thorn in the side of successive Dublin governments
column4: at the end of his career he wrote that he regretted ever writing one word of Irish.

column1: 2275;2275;Extinction Rebellion: Last Chance to Save the World?;None;Reporter Ben Zand gains access to the climate activism movement Extinction Rebellion.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07j5fwm.jpg;BBC
column4: Extinction Rebellion: Last Chance to Save the World?;Reporter Ben Zand gains access to the climate activism movement Extinction Rebellion.;A huge new global protest movement is changing public attitudes to climate change. Reporter Ben Zand gains access to the most high-profile activist group
column5: Extinction Rebellion.;"2019 has marked a change in public attitudes to climate change driven in part by a huge new global protest movement.

column1: In this timely and powerful documentary
column2: reporter Ben Zand gains access to the most important of the protest groups
column3: Extinction Rebellion. He is with them for four months as they build towards “the rebellion” - 11 days of protest in April during which they take over and occupy four iconic locations in London.

column1: The film follows three young people who have been inspired to join and lead the protests. Many are not only protesting for the first time in their lives but are also putting their liberty on the line to demand radical action from the government. We are there as they organise street protests and direct actions - risking arrest for their commitment to the cause.
16-year-old Dani from south London has never been on a protest before - since joining Extinction Rebellion in 2018
column2: she has co-organised nationwide school strikes. Sam is 22 and a recent graduate
column3: but now works full-time for Extinction Rebellion and is willing to get arrested again and again until something changes. Jack joined the movement recently at age 18. He is inspired by the tactics and research laid out by Extinction Rebellion and has an eye on organising controversial splinter actions for the movement.

column1: Ben also spends time with the leader of the movement
column3: who has spent years academically researching tactics for social change. He says you need 2000 people to get arrested and 400 people to go to prison if you want the government to meet your demands. Ben challenges him on his methods and asks whether it is justifiable to encourage young people to break the law.

column1: This film is the first to get inside the new climate movements. It reveals how they have mobilised a generation to take radical action to help save the planet from climate change.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2019;44;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07j5fwm.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07j5fwm.jpg;2019 marked change public attitude climate change driven part huge new global protest movement timely powerful documentary reporter ben zand gain access important protest group extinction rebellion four month build towards “ rebellion ” 11 day protest april take occupy four iconic location london film follows three young people inspired join lead protest many protesting first time life also putting liberty line demand radical action government organise street protest direct action risking arrest commitment cause 16yearold dani south london never protest since joining extinction rebellion 2018 coorganised nationwide school strike sam 22 recent graduate work fulltime extinction rebellion willing get arrested something change jack joined movement recently age 18 inspired tactic research laid extinction rebellion eye organising controversial splinter action movement ben also spends time leader movement roger hallam spent year academically researching tactic social change say need 2000 people get arrested 400 people go prison want government meet demand ben challenge method asks whether justifiable encourage young people break law film first get inside new climate movement reveals mobilised generation take radical action help save planet climate change;8

column5: working in the music industry is a dream come true - but behind the glamour there lies a dark secret. Tamanna Rahman investigates.;"For many women
column6: working in the music industry is a dream come true - but behind the glamour there lies a dark secret. From inappropriate messages and unwanted sexual advances to violence and rape
column7: reporter Tamanna Rahman explores why women in music have remained silent for so long.

column1: In an exclusive interview
column3: former girlfriend of hotly tipped rapper Octavian
column4: reveals why she decided to go public on social media with claims of physical abuse at his hands. Her Instagram post led
column5: in November last year
column6: to the artist and his long-awaited debut album being cancelled by his record label
column7: Black Butter
column8: part of Sony Music. Tamanna explores why Hana felt she had to go public with her allegations.

column1: Questions are also asked about the relationship between Island Records
column3: and one of music’s most dangerous men
column4: Solo 45. Today the grime star is in jail for 30 years for raping and torturing women. But before Island handed him a deal
column5: he served six months in prison in Cyprus for domestic violence. Was this taken into consideration before the label invested in his music?";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains very strong language and upsetting scenes.;2021;44;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0957m64.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0957m64.jpg;many woman working music industry dream come true behind glamour lie dark secret inappropriate message unwanted sexual advance violence rape reporter tamanna rahman explores woman music remained silent long exclusive interview hana former girlfriend hotly tipped rapper octavian reveals decided go public social medium claim physical abuse hand instagram post led november last year artist longawaited debut album cancelled record label black butter part sony music tamanna explores hana felt go public allegation question also asked relationship island record subsidiary universal one music ’ dangerous men solo 45 today grime star jail 30 year raping torturing woman island handed deal served six month prison cyprus domestic violence taken consideration label invested music;5

column1: 2279;2279;After 9/11: Scotland’s Story;None;How the series of events that unfolded after 9/11 affected the people of Scotland forever.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09vm0zr.jpg;BBC
column4: After 9/11: Scotland’s Story;How the series of events that unfolded after 9/11 affected the people of Scotland forever.;"Using first-hand testimony
column5: this documentary pieces together those seismic consequences of 9/11 that have been keenly felt in Scotland over the last 20 years.

column1: ;On 11 September 2001
column2: 19 al-Qaeda hijackers snatched control of four passenger jets and committed an act of terrorism
column3: the like of which had never been seen before. As television images of the burning twin towers in New York spread around the globe
column4: normal life ended for many people as a series of events unfolded that would change the world forever.

column1: Using first-hand testimony
column2: this documentary pieces together the seismic consequences that have been keenly felt in Scotland over the last 20 years
column3: from the moment when the first plane impacted in New York

column1: Among those in Scotland whose lives were immediately affected were those in the Asian communities. As early reports suggested that those behind the attack were ‘Islamic’ and ‘extremist’
column2: acts of racism became more common
column4: and religious in nature. Muslims were suddenly faced with a very real and frightening backlash as they came under suspicion
column5: were physically attacked
column6: and their mosques were fire-bombed.

column1: Yasmine Chaudhry was attacked on a bus only two days after 9/11
column2: with her attacker smashing a glass bottle over her head after making it clear that he was doing it because of the attack.

column1: Amjid Bashir was verbally attacked at McDonalds the next day. He had just attended Scotland’s biggest vigil for the victims when another customer suggested that a bullet should be added to his burger so his head ‘would be blown off’.
The reaction was swift and unsurprising
column3: the US and UK led an invasion of Afghanistan to dismantle al-Qaeda
column5: Osama Bin Laden
column6: and remove the Taliban from power. The war in Iraq
column7: just over a year later
column8: was not so easily justified and huge protests sprung up against it. Campaigner Osama Bhutta was one of those who spoke at the Stop the War march outside Glasgow’s SECC while Tony Blair was giving a speech inside. He felt crushed when the coalition
column9: again led by the US and UK
column10: went ahead and Scottish troops found themselves embroiled in two wars thousands of miles from home.

column1: Rose Gentle lost her 19-year-old son
column3: when he was killed while on a routine patrol in Basra. After his death
column4: she became a strong opponent of the war in Iraq. The inquest into his death concluded that it was through the failure of the UK government to provide adequate equipment
column5: that her son died.

column1: Dave Devenney
column2: a veteran Royal Marines Commando from the Falklands War in 1982
column3: experienced both wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Scottish journalist David Pratt also saw both wars first hand. As foreign affairs editor for the Herald
column4: he had reported from Afghanistan extensively from the days of the Russian occupation to the rise of the Taliban and had met Osama Bin Laden while there.

column1: Despite the war in Afghanistan
column3: throughout the US and Europe. In 2005
column4: the 7/7 bombings wreaked bloody havoc on London’s transport network
column5: and two years later in Scotland
column6: the people inside Glasgow Airport narrowly avoided a similar fate when it was attacked by two men in a burning jeep laden with explosive gas.

column1: During this period the Muslim population of Scotland continued to feel the pressure of racist
column2: violent and verbal attacks. Paramedic Araf Saddiq was verbally abused by patients who said they didn’t want to be treated by him as they thought he might be a terrorist.

column1: It is thought that up to a million people may have died in the US War on Terror and the campaign
column2: which is now the longest in US history
column3: is only now coming to a chaotic end in Afghanistan
column4: after almost 20 years. Yet despite these many traumas
column5: and attacks that have continued since then
column6: some feel that Scotland’s experience of terrorism and its aftermath has not brought about the severe splits and division that might have been expected.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;Contains very column1: Is doiligh a shamhlú go mairfidh an iascaireacht sna pobail seo ach is doiligh fosta stad den nós atá Go Domhain san Fhuil agus atá beo ar éigean san Aigéan Atlantach.
In Magheraroarty the O'Brien family fish for crab behind Tory Island and towards the Scottish coast. It's tough
John O'Brien skippers the Handa Isle with a crew of three
column5: skippers the Aoibh Áine. With the price of crabs falling
column6: the pressure is on to spend longer at sea just to remain in business.

column1: The locals recall when seasonal fishing of salmon could switch to lobster
column3: mackerel and white fish. A ban on salmon fishing in 2007 was the beginning of the end for many communities and for a way of life that had lasted for generations. It’s hard to imagine a future for fishing in this most marginal of communities
column4: but it's just as hard to shake what's 'in the blood'
column5: the instinct to fish the Atlantic.";Documentary;BBC TWO NORTHERN IRELAND DIGITAL;False;2020;29;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08jnzlb.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08jnzlb.jpg;gníomhaíocht í iascaireacht chleachtann glúnta éagsúla bpobail ghaeltachta machaire rabhartaigh dtír chonaill san áireamh obair chrua mhaslach atá ann tá john ’ brien ina scipéir ar handa isle agus mhac seán mar dhuine den fhoireann tá mac eile colm ina scipéir ar aoibh áine tá luach na bportán ag titim agus tá brú orthu níos mó ama chaitheamh ar fharraige lena mbeatha thabhairt dtír cuimhnítear ar iascaireacht mar bhíodh agus báid ag malartú idir iascaireacht shéasúrach bradán go dtí iascaireacht gliomach portán murlas agus iasc geal cosc ar iascaireacht bradán 2007 chuir tús lei mheath agus cuireadh deireadh le saol chuaigh siar na blianta doiligh shamhlú go mairfidh iascaireacht sna pobail seo ach doiligh fosta stad den nós atá go domhain san fhuil agus atá beo ar éigean san aigéan atlantach magheraroarty obrien family fish crab behind tory island towards scottish coast tough unrelenting work john obrien skipper handa isle crew three including son seán another son colm skipper aoibh áine price crab falling pressure spend longer sea remain business local recall seasonal fishing salmon could switch lobster crab mackerel white fish ban salmon fishing 2007 beginning end many community way life lasted generation ’ hard imagine future fishing marginal community hard shake whats blood instinct fish atlantic;14

column6: that hard-fought progress has vanished overnight.;"Over the past 20 years
column7: Afghanistan has given birth to a new generation characterised by freedom
column8: achievements and opportunities for all. Now

column1: 2282;2282;AstraZeneca: A Vaccine for the World?;None;The inside story of Britain’s Covid 'vaccine for the world'. Did politics get in its way?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bm6d4h.jpg;BBC
column4: AstraZeneca: A Vaccine for the World?;The inside story of Britain’s Covid 'vaccine for the world'. Did politics get in its way?;BBC medical editor Fergus Walsh examines the extraordinary ambition behind the Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid jab. Intended as a vaccine for the world
column5: did politics get in its way?;"Celebrated as our national jab
column6: the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine has been praised as a 'remarkable example of British innovation and scientific excellence' and recognised for its success at home. Around half of all adults in the UK received two doses of it.

column1: But when Oxford scientists developed the jab
column2: they had far greater ambitions: a 'vaccine for the world'
column3: designed specifically to be distributed to lower income countries and sold at cost for the duration of the pandemic. For both humanitarian and scientific reasons
column4: they argued sharing vaccines fairly globally was the best way to bring coronavirus under control.

column1: A year later
column2: more than 2.5 billion doses have been distributed worldwide. But with only one in 20 people in low income countries double jabbed and the Omicron variant spreading globally
column3: how far did the vaccine meet its original purpose?

column1: Beset by challenges including supply disputes in Europe and
column3: the vaccine has never been approved in the US and is now barely used in the UK. So how much were these problems self-inflicted
column4: or did nationalist politics get in the way?

column1: The BBC’s medical editor
column3: who has been reporting on the vaccine since its early development
column4: examines the challenges this jab faced in Europe and beyond
column5: and asks if it fulfilled the original hopes of the scientists in Oxford.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bm6d4h.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bm6d4h.jpg;celebrated national jab oxfordastrazeneca vaccine praised remarkable example british innovation scientific excellence recognised success home around half adult uk received two dos oxford scientist developed jab far greater ambition vaccine world designed specifically distributed lower income country sold cost duration pandemic humanitarian scientific reason argued sharing vaccine fairly globally best way bring coronavirus control year later 25 billion dos distributed worldwide one 20 people low income country double jabbed omicron variant spreading globally far vaccine meet original purpose beset challenge including supply dispute europe concern rare blood clot vaccine never approved u barely used uk much problem selfinflicted nationalist politics get way bbc ’ medical editor fergus walsh reporting vaccine since early development examines challenge jab faced europe beyond asks fulfilled original hope scientist oxford;1

column1: 2283;2283;Unsolved;An Alibi for Omar?: Episode 1;Reporter Bronagh Munro uncovers new evidence that casts doubt on a murder conviction.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09fwhgr.jpg;BBC
column5: An Alibi for Omar?: Episode 1;Reporter Bronagh Munro uncovers new evidence that casts doubt on a murder conviction.;Reporter Bronagh Munro uncovers new evidence that casts doubt on the conviction of a man who has spent 19 years in prison for murder.;Reporter Bronagh Munro uncovers new evidence that casts doubt on the conviction of a man who has spent 19 years in prison for murder. Omar Benguit was jailed for killing 26-year-old Korean student Jong-Ok Shin as she walked home from a night out in Bournemouth in 2002. The only evidence to place him at the murder scene came from a heroin addict with a history of making false allegations against innocent people. Police used other vulnerable witnesses to support the addict’s story
column6: but some of them tell Bronagh they were pressured to make false statements. She also finds evidence that could give Omar Benguit an alibi for the night of the murder. His lawyer and family are convinced there has been a miscarriage of justice and are using the new evidence to try to take the case to the Court of Appeal for a third time.;Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2021;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09fwhgr.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09fwhgr.jpg;reporter bronagh munro uncovers new evidence cast doubt conviction man spent 19 year prison murder omar benguit jailed killing 26yearold korean student jongok shin walked home night bournemouth 2002 evidence place murder scene came heroin addict history making false allegation innocent people police used vulnerable witness support addict ’ story tell bronagh pressured make false statement also find evidence could give omar benguit alibi night murder lawyer family convinced miscarriage justice using new evidence try take case court appeal third time;11

column1: 2284;2284;America's Child Brides;None;Ellie Flynn investigates the US laws letting older men marry girls under the age of 16.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k08qd.jpg;BBC
column4: Americas Child Brides;Ellie Flynn investigates the US laws letting older men marry girls under the age of 16.;Ellie Flynn investigates the legal loopholes allowing underage girls in the USA to be married off to much older men.;"An investigation into the US laws letting older men marry girls under the age of 16.

column1: Ellie Flynn travels to the USA to visit states poised to reconsider their child marriage laws. South Carolina is considering closing its 'marry-your-rapist' loophole that allows girls under 16 to marry if they are pregnant and have a parent’s consent. Visiting the record office in Spartanburg County
column2: Ellie finds 16 child marriages in the county in the last decade. In ten of those cases
column3: the groom could have been prosecuted under statutory rape laws.

column1: One of these marriages was between teenager Keri
column5: Paul agreed to marry her and help look after the baby in order to avoid prison. This raises a central question for Ellie: whose rights are more important: the underage
column6: pregnant girl or the unborn
column7: potentially fatherless baby?

column1: Ellie also travels to Georgia to meet 17-year-old Zion. She married at 16
column2: and her groom David was just two years older than her
column3: so Zion didn’t need to use the marry-your-rapist loophole
column4: and nor was her groom at risk of prosecution for statutory rape. Many campaigners want to change Georgia’s minimum marriage age to 18
column5: but Zion is convinced that this would have meant the end of her and David’s family
column6: as they would have been forced to live apart for two years.

column1: But not all child marriages end in family harmony. Often it breaks families apart
column2: as Ellie finds out in Idaho. Here
column4: religious beliefs and ideas of parental responsibility left two men in prison and a family at war. In Idaho
column5: child marriage laws require a court order from a judge

column2: but within the fashion world it is famous for being home to the world's most beautiful women. Reggie joins international scouts as they board the Trans-Siberian railway and cross Siberia looking for the freshest new faces.

column11: he terrorised communities along the north Wales coastline
column12: killing four men and allegedly attacking many more. By day he was a well-respected shopkeeper and cinema owner in Kinmel Bay
column13: and by night he was a sadistic killer who seemed to target gay men.

column1: In this special edition of Dark Land

column1: Moore is revealed as a man with a violent secret life
column2: hiding in plain sight. Beneath the façade of a respectable businessman was a mind warped by a dysfunctional upbringing; a man who seized upon a climate of gay prejudice to embark upon a 20-year spree of savage attacks
column3: confident his victims wouldn’t feel able to come forward to complain.
