column1: Waldemar looks in considerable depth at the work of Georges Seurat
column2: taking into consideration his academic training at the Beaux-Arts School in Paris and the artists that influenced him
column3: such as Piero della Francesca and Puvis de Chavannes.

column1: There is also an insight into the complex but fascinating world of optics and art
column2: and the ways in which the Impressionists were using the new discoveries in light and eyesight to influence their work. A fascinating 'after-image' experiment brings to life the ways in which our own eyes see colour
column3: both in its presence and its absence.

column1: Van Gogh's time in Paris
column2: a period very little is known about
column4: charting the incredible journey the artist made from his brown and dull canvases to the splendid colour and light that pervaded his work on the cusp of his departure for the South of France.

column1: The film finishes with a revisiting of Monet and his later waterlily paintings in the Orangerie in Paris. Waldemar investigates how a bad case of cataracts was responsible for a seismic shift in his colour palette and his brushstrokes. Spending time with an ophthalmologist

column5: Series 1: 2. Hustle;Amira is determined to make it in the music industry and not be distracted by the violence;Amira is determined to make it in the music industry and transform her life with a big payday. She doesn’t want to be distracted by the violence around her.;"Last year
column6: as London’s murder rate and youth violence hit the headlines
column7: some parts of the capital were thrust into the spotlight. One of these areas was a corner of north London around Tottenham and Wood Green
column8: where last spring three young people were murdered in consecutive months. But what about the young people who don’t make the news? This timely two-part series goes beyond the headlines to find out what life is really like growing up in an area that is as famous for its music industry icons as it is for the London riots or Premier League football.

column1: 21-year-old Amira is determined to follow in her brother’s footsteps by making it in the music industry. She’s trying to make it as an artist manager at a Tottenham-based record label. She’s focussed on launching Foz
column2: a new artist fresh from Australia
column3: and is determined not to be distracted by the troubles around her. She’s been to three funerals of friends within one year
column4: all of whom have died as a result of youth violence. She thinks the area is one that can make or break

column1: you
column2: but she won’t let it break her. But with her MOBO-award winning brother away from the music scene for now
column3: and unexpected challenges in her life
column4: she’s also having to hold things together at home for her mum. Life is never straightforward
column5: but Amira is always hustling to make it and earn that big payday.

column1: On the streets nearby
column3: who is living in the shadow of the new Spurs stadium. He’s put down his uni books to lead his neighbours in a fight against the council over housing. Tash’s family
column5: might lose their home if the planned redevelopment around the stadium goes ahead.

column1: Up the road is business school student and entrepreneur Naomi. She’s a self-made model
column2: working for the likes of Nike and Vivienne Westwood – and also a stylist to the stars. She’s fiercely defensive of the place that’s made her. She knows the value of Tottenham and uses her neighbourhood as inspiration for her work. She hates the fact that gentrification might replace the unique culture that makes her neighbourhood so special.

column1: Over the border
column3: lives 24-year-old Cherno. He’s an inspirational football agent
column4: who is turning the loss of his friend into

column1: something positive. Can he make the difference to young people in his area?

column11: this programme follows the slow and painstaking process of making a classic Windsor chair.

column1: A beautifully simple object
column2: it is in fact anything but. Filmed over five days
column4: time-consuming processes involved in creating the chair
column5: made by Jim Steele in his Warwickshire workshop.

column1: This traditional design features woods chosen for their different qualities - ash
Jim makes just 12 such chairs each year
column2: using traditional techniques and aided by few modern tools. There are just two screws in the finished chair. From the steam bending of the back to the turning of spindles
column3: the carving of the seat to the planing of the arms
column4: it's a remarkable process to observe.

column1: The bold style of the film
column3: static shots with no music or commentary allows the viewer to admire in exquisite detail the painstaking craftsmanship.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;False;2015;29;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bkq430.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bkq430.jpg;part bbc four go slow programme follows slow painstaking process making classic windsor chair beautifully simple object fact anything filmed five day film reveals complex timeconsuming process involved creating chair made jim steele warwickshire workshop traditional design feature wood chosen different quality ash elm hardtosource yew jim make 12 chair year using traditional technique aided modern tool two screw finished chair steam bending back turning spindle carving seat planing arm remarkable process observe bold style film making use long static shot music commentary allows viewer admire exquisite detail painstaking craftsmanship;11

column1: 2302;2302;We Are Black and British;Series 1: Episode 2;The group tackle race at work
column5: TV
column6: We Are Black and British
column7: Series 1: Episode 2;The group tackle race at work
column8: marrying in or out
column9: and where mixed-race people fit in.;The other three members of the group reveal their stories as they tackle breaking down barriers at work
column10: whether race matters when it comes to love and where mixed-race people fit into black identity.;"Six black Britons from very different backgrounds and viewpoints are coming together under one roof at a time when race and racism in the UK have sparked a nationwide discussion about what needs to change. They grapple with tough
column11: unsettling and emotional questions about being black and British in search of a way forward. Each of them has a deeply personal story to share about an event that proved to be a seismic moment in their life. They confront their differences
column12: hoping to find answers from each other and from those who are trying to change Britain.

column1: The most radical of the group
column3: set up Britain's first black studies degree. He believes it's time for a fundamental change to Britain. He has a revolutionary idea to reveal to the group which could prove divisive - black-only workplaces. Although recent years have seen black leaders taking the top jobs at some big companies
column5: there wasn't a single black CEO in a FTSE 100 company. At the other end of the pay scale
column6: however
column7: black people are overrepresented in lower-paying jobs. The group meet someone who won one of the UK's biggest race discrimination payouts in recent years and debate whether taking companies to task or race-based quotas could be the way forward. One of the panel from last year's controversial race commission report also drops in to discuss whether or not racism is still the most significant barrier holding back progression for black people in Britain.

column1: 29-year-old NHS doctor Raphel has matters of the heart on his mind.  He's at a stage in life where he's looking to settle down and feeling the pressure to marry within the black community
column2: so he wants to ask the group whether race should matter when it comes to love. Black men in Britain marry outside their race far more than white and Asian men
column3: but black women are statistically more likely than black men to be in same-race relationships. To find out more
column4: some of the group head off for a night out at a diverse dating event in the West Midlands to meet other single people dealing with the same dilemma.

column1: Last to reveal her story is 34-year-old property and litigation contractor Lin with an extremely personal experience that is born from her mixed heritage. 1.2 million people in the UK are mixed-race
column2: and the numbers are growing. Lin's experience of racism from both sides of her extended family has led her to question where mixed race people fit in when it comes to being black. It strikes a chord with many in the group
column3: raising fundamental questions about what it means to be black.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bp5lmf.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bp5lmf.jpg;six black briton different background viewpoint coming together one roof time race racism uk sparked nationwide discussion need change grapple tough unsettling emotional question black british search way forward deeply personal story share event proved seismic moment life confront difference hoping find answer trying change britain radical group university professor kehinde set britain first black study degree belief time fundamental change britain revolutionary idea reveal group could prove divisive blackonly workplace although recent year seen black leader taking top job big company latest count wasnt single black ceo ftse 100 company end pay scale however black people overrepresented lowerpaying job group meet someone one uk biggest race discrimination payouts recent year debate whether taking company task racebased quota could way forward one panel last year controversial race commission report also drop discus whether racism still significant barrier holding back progression black people britain 29yearold nh doctor raphel matter heart mind he stage life he looking settle feeling pressure marry within black community want ask group whether race matter come love black men britain marry outside race far white asian men black woman statistically likely black men samerace relationship find group head night diverse dating event west midland meet single people dealing dilemma last reveal story 34yearold property litigation contractor lin extremely personal experience born mixed heritage 12 million people uk mixedrace number growing lin experience racism side extended family led question mixed race people fit come black strike chord many group raising fundamental question mean black;18

column1: 2303;2303;Foot and Mouth - The Killing Fields in Wales;None;A documentary telling the story of the foot and mouth crisis in Wales 20 years on.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09ybg7w.jpg;BBC
column4: Foot and Mouth - The Killing Fields in Wales;A documentary telling the story of the foot and mouth crisis in Wales 20 years on.;The story of the foot and mouth crisis in Wales 20 years on
column5: a dramatic moment in recent history when the farming industry in Wales was at risk of being wiped out.;"Exactly 20 years ago Wales was emerging from an epidemic that lasted six months and saw over six million animals killed across the UK. The impact of foot and mouth disease was felt in every corner of Wales. Major events like rugby internationals were cancelled
column6: access to the countryside banned and schools closed in rural areas. Farmers were forced to isolate at home and tourism was struggling.

column1: It was one of the first major challenges for the newly devolved Welsh administration
column2: with a young Carwyn Jones finding himself at the eye of the storm as the minister responsible for agriculture.

column1: Many people most closely involved - the farmers
column3: the people who slaughtered the animals - have never spoken before about the lasting effect that the epidemic had on them. It is clear that the emotion and trauma they experienced is still raw 20 years on.

column1: This film looks back at what happened. There were desperate attempts to contain the epidemic and controversy over how to deal with a rapidly spreading disease. Hard decisions were made to cull hundreds of thousands of healthy animals in a bid to stop the infection.
Events reached a climax with the controversial decision to bury carcasses at the Epynt
column2: an upland area near Sennybridge used as a military range. Locals blocked roads and Carwyn Jones faced his biggest challenge yet.

But what’s the reality?;Slick Instagram accounts and YouTube channels point to foreign exchange (Forex) trading as a route to extra cash. BBC reporter Dion Hesson dives into this world
column2: meeting a host of passionate and charismatic young educators
column3: some of whom say the Forex training they sell will put him on a path to financial independence. But what is the reality?

column1: Dion’s journey begins within IM Academy
column2: an American multilevel marketing (MLM) company that sells foreign exchange education. Having paid for two months membership
column3: Dion tests his skills on the live market. He generates a profit but realises he would need to invest thousands more to cover the fees he is paying for tips and education or to come close to making a living. Dion also explores the other side to this company
column4: the side that encourages you to sign up new members
column5: first to cover your fees and then to make money of your own.

column1: Next
column2: Dion looks at a company called FTMO. It apparently offers ‘funding for serious traders’
column3: helping people make profit through Forex trading
column4: without risking any of their own capital. He travels around the UK and Ireland to meet smart
column5: driven and hopeful traders who are investing substantial time and money in challenge fees and education
column6: with the aim of trading with FTMO. But when Dion takes a closer look at the company
column7: he discovers that traders who pass the challenge are trading on a demo account with fictitious funds and that it is up to FTMO whether any of these trades are executed in the real world or not.

column1: Lots of people have big dreams about becoming a successful trader
column2: but with four out of five people losing money on actual trading
column3: Dion suggests checking out the price tag and the fine print before signing up with educators in this field.";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2021;43;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09qjgb0.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09qjgb0.jpg;slick instagram account youtube channel point foreign exchange forex trading route extra cash bbc reporter dion hesson dive world meeting host passionate charismatic young educator say forex training sell put path financial independence reality dion ’ journey begin within im academy american multilevel marketing mlm company sell foreign exchange education paid two month membership dion test skill live market generates profit realises would need invest thousand cover fee paying tip education come close making living dion also explores side company side encourages sign new member first cover fee make money next dion look company called ftmo apparently offer ‘ funding serious trader ’ helping people make profit forex trading without risking capital travel around uk ireland meet smart driven hopeful trader investing substantial time money challenge fee education aim trading ftmo dion take closer look company discovers trader pas challenge trading demo account fictitious fund ftmo whether trade executed real world lot people big dream becoming successful trader four five people losing money actual trading dion suggests checking price tag fine print signing educator field;18

column7: and she works in the sex industry.;"Three strangers immersed in the world of camming come together to discuss its impact on young people. But their views are radically different. While one sees it as a respectable trade full of dedicated and liberated women
column8: another sees it as a direct exploitation of the male libido. The third sees it as a haven for lonely people like himself to reconnect with the intimacy that’s missing from their lives.

column1: What they don’t know is that they all have one person in common – and she’s watching the conversation from the next room. Bex is a curvy cam model
column2: and she’s witnessing their unfiltered feelings about her and the industry unfold.

column1: 2308;2308;Catch Her If You Can;None;Mariam Mola is a businesswoman - and a career con artist. We expose her wild double life.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08wtj6d.jpg;BBC
column4: Catch Her If You Can;Mariam Mola is a businesswoman - and a career con artist. We expose her wild double life.;Mariam Mola is a self-made businesswoman - and a career con artist. In this wild game of cat-and-mouse
column5: she is exposed by her victims as the fraudster she really is.;"Mariam Mola is addicted to Louis Vuitton
column6: Fendi
column7: and flexing on social media. Her Instagram feed is a love letter to luxury London
column8: from the velvet booths of Soho restaurants to the bling outfitters of Hatton Garden jewellery boutiques. She seems to have it all.

column1: But this self-made girlboss from London’s docklands is actually a career con artist who has served time all over Europe.
Mariam’s scams haven’t just targeted credit card companies and luxury boutiques. Over the years she’s also finessed close friends
column2: colleagues and impressionable teenagers who took her at her word.

column1: And then she encountered Tamara.
When Tamara found a suspicious invoice addressed to her husband
She discovered that her husband had transferred large sums of money to Mariam from their joint account. And she soon realised Mariam had myriad other money-making schemes
So began a dogged pursuit of Mariam.
Using a fake alias to gather information
column2: Tamara assembled a group of Mariam’s victims. Together
column4: who went to prison on fraud charges. But it wasn’t over. Every time they thought they’d got her
column5: Mariam came back and pulled off an ever bigger scam than before.

column2: Tamara discovered that Mariam was now a senior Pastor with a notorious church: SPAC Nation.

column1: SPAC Nation is under investigation by police and the charity commission. It claims it is helping disadvantaged kids – but former members say that its leaders
column3: encourage young congregants to take out loans and give huge sums to the church.

column1: In this film
column2: Tamara joins forces with Mariam’s other victims to expose her as the ruthless fraudster she really is.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2020;30;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08wtj6d.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08wtj6d.jpg;mariam mola addicted louis vuitton fendi flexing social medium instagram feed love letter luxury london velvet booth soho restaurant bling outfitter hatton garden jewellery boutique seems selfmade girlboss london ’ docklands actually career con artist served time europe mariam ’ scam ’ targeted credit card company luxury boutique year ’ also finessed close friend colleague impressionable teenager took word encountered tamara tamara found suspicious invoice addressed husband knew something discovered husband transferred large sum money mariam joint account soon realised mariam myriad moneymaking scheme began dogged pursuit mariam using fake alias gather information tamara assembled group mariam ’ victim together exposed mariam went prison fraud charge ’ every time thought ’ got mariam came back pulled ever bigger scam 2019 tamara discovered mariam senior pastor notorious church spac nation spac nation investigation police charity commission claim helping disadvantaged kid – former member say leader including mariam encourage young congregant take loan give huge sum church film tamara join force mariam ’ victim expose ruthless fraudster really;11

column4: Jesy Nelson: Odd One Out;Little Mix’s Jesy Nelson opens up about the abuse she has suffered online from trolls.;Little Mix star Jesy Nelson goes on a journey of rehabilitation as she opens up about abuse she has suffered at the hands of cyberbullies and its effects on her mental health.;"When Jesy Nelson rose to fame with pop band Little Mix
column5: she was abused online for being 'the fat one'. Now
column6: for the first time
column7: she opens up about the heartbreaking effects cyberbullies have had on her life. In this intimate
column8: personal documentary
column9: Jesy exclusively reveals the impact online trolls had on her mental health as she goes on a journey of rehabilitation.

column1: Allowing cameras a behind-the-scenes look at her personal and professional life
column2: Jesy begins to understand the layers of protection she has built in order to cope with the bullies. To help her heal
column3: she meets other victims of cyber abuse
column4: sharing devastating stories of online trolling.

column1: Little Mix members Perrie

column6: a 23-year-old man from Bedford who survived an abusive relationship with his girlfriend Jordan Worth.

column1: Combining observational filming with personal and police archive
column2: this film provides a raw and uninhibited window into a teenage romance that descended into terrible violence.

column1: Alongside Alex's shocking and thought-provoking testimony
column2: his family and friends also share their stories of seeing him slowly slip away
column4: and unaware of how bad it would get.

column1: Bedfordshire Police described Alex's case as one of the most extreme cases of domestic violence they had ever dealt with. In hospital
column2: doctors examined Alex's body and told him that he was just ten days away from death.

column1: In April 2018
column2: Jordan was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison. She became the first female in the UK to be convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour.

column1: By sharing his story
column2: Alex hopes to challenge assumptions about violence and masculinity in relationships

column10: all of whom have very different reasons for working at night.;"Series in which we meet the unsung heroes of the graveyard shift - the one in seven workers in Wales who are at work through the night. This invisible army is wide awake when the rest of us are fast asleep. In this episode
column11: we meet steel factory workers
column12: a taxi driver and a portrait artist who all have very different reasons for working at night.

column1: Stuart has been working night shifts at Tata Steelworks in Port Talbot for almost 20 years
column2: but he says ‘you never get used to nights’. There’s plenty of work to keep him busy though; two huge cranes are in the harbour to unload material bound for the blast furnace but they’re both broken and while the cranes are at a standstill the costs are escalating. But there’s a delay in the spare part needed to fix one crane and an electrical fault on the other which can’t be repaired. He’ll try to motivate his engineering teams to fix both cranes by the end of the night shift.

column1: Sian is on the late-night taxi shift in Swansea and there’s no sign that the long queue at the rank is going to disappear any time soon. Her first passengers are from out of town and in Swansea for the first time
column2: enjoying hearing the ‘homely’ Welsh accent. Later
column3: she takes a couple of tipsy girls home
column4: admitting that she ‘loves being nosey’ and feels there should be a confession box in her cab where people can admit to their sins.

column1: In Cardiff
column2: Nathan is melting chocolate in a microwave and trying hard not to be tempted by the delicious smell to have a taste. He’s a portrait artist and his specialism is creating artwork from food; his work has adorned album covers
column3: restaurant walls and one-off showbiz events. Tonight
column4: he’s creating a portrait of Lord Alan Sugar using sweets and confectionery which will adorn the opening of a new shop in London. Nathan works best at night; it’s quiet and he can be undisturbed by the stresses of the day. column5: and 130 people die every day from opioid overdoses. 8.7 million children nationwide have a parent who suffers from a substance use disorder

column1: One of the companies accused of sparking the opioid epidemic was Purdue Pharma – wholly owned by the philanthropic Sackler family – who have made billions from the sale of the drugs. But where were the medical regulators and government agencies that should have prevented this crisis?

column1: While the CRS are used to working tirelessly in difficult conditions

column3: the CRS were also tasked with the distribution of essential PPE to key workers on the frontline of the pandemic.

column1: In north Belfast
column2: CRS teams launch a major search operation for 14-year-old Noah Donohoe
column3: who has been reported missing. In a show of solidarity
column4: the local community come together to assist in whatever way they can
column5: making this search one of the most profound the CRS have ever faced.

column1: In the west of Northern Ireland
column2: a different CRS station responds to a high-risk person who has been reported missing near to a major river. The search area widens
column3: and teams on the ground are assisted by dogs and specialist water teams.

column1: It’s Christmas Eve
column2: and teams receive an urgent call to search for a high-risk missing male who has difficulties with his mental wellbeing. Winter conditions later in the festive period mean the search for a missing 80-year-old man intensifies fast. CRS are urgently called to Co. Armagh to scour the local area for the missing man
column3: as low temperatures make this search a priority.

column18: she did not count on so many obstacles: Brexit

column20: her language barrier and a growing joint and muscle pain caused by her physical jobs.

2325;2325;The Last Mountain;None;The fateful story of climber Tom Ballard who perished on Nanga Parbat in 2019.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09wsf6n.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, The Last Mountain;The fateful story of climber Tom Ballard who perished on Nanga Parbat in 2019.;The unforgettable story of the 30-year-old climber Tom Ballard who disappeared on the so-called killer mountain, Nanga Parbat, in 2019.;The compelling story of 30-year-old climber Tom Ballard who disappeared on one of the Himalayas' most deadly mountains
column3: in February 2019. Tom was the son of mountaineer Alison Hargreaves
column4: who perished on K2 in 1995. Mother and son
column5: two of the greatest climbers of all time
column6: died at almost the same age in neighbouring mountain ranges
column7: both doing what they loved best. They now lie forever encased in the ice of two of the world’s highest mountains. Left behind to cope with the enduring tragedy are Tom’s sister
column8: Kate
column9: and their father
column10: Jim.

column4: on an expedition to K2’s basecamp to say farewell to their mother. The result was a BBC film
column5: Alison’s Last Mountain. Now
column6: The Last Mountain follows Kate Ballard on a parallel trip to say goodbye to her brother on Nanga Parbat. Using archive material from 1995 and Tom's own extraordinary footage taken up until the days before his death
column7: the film explores what made Tom continue his ascent with Italian climber Daniele Nardi after the other two members of the expedition turned back.

column1: The film features revealing interviews with those left behind. Combining 25 years of intimate
column2: unseen family archive material with footage of the family that director Chris Terrill has shot in the years since
column3: the documentary tells the unforgettable story of a family who lived - and were prepared to die for - the love of scaling the icy heights of the world’s highest peaks. column6: Kirsty Young offers a unique view of their life together. It is a love affair that is said to have started with the briefest of encounters on a rainy day in July 1939
column7: and one that was sealed with a fairy-tale wedding on 20 November 1947.

column1: In the decades that followed
column2: the couple have experienced the same milestones as many others - with the birth of children
column3: grandchildren and many more moments of pride
column4: but they have also had to survive challenges few others have had to face. Every step of their life together has been played out in public
column5: but through it all
column6: the Queen and her prince have not only kept their relationship strong
column7: they have kept the nation strong too
column8: steering it through decades of change.

column8: whose crimes have made them pariahs living on the fringes of society.

column1: The State of California has some of the toughest regulations anywhere in America controlling sex offenders. On leaving prison they can spend years on parole
column3: and a lifetime on an online sex offenders register.

column1: Louis spent several months at some of the hostels in Los Angeles where sex offenders live
column2: talking in depth to sex offenders themselves as well as the people charged with monitoring them. The tough rules governing where they can live and who they can see make it hard for registered sex offenders to find work or even housing
column3: and many are forced into homelessness.

column3: it is right to give sex offenders a second chance.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language and disturbing scenes.;2014;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p01v2h4t.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p01v2h4t.jpg;final episode louis therouxs la story louis spends time twilight world city paroled sex offender whose crime made pariah living fringe society state california toughest regulation anywhere america controlling sex offender leaving prison spend year parole tagged tracked lifetime online sex offender register louis spent several month hostel los angeles sex offender live talking depth sex offender well people charged monitoring tough rule governing live see make hard registered sex offender find work even housing many forced homelessness meeting outcast louis asks whether tough rule keep society safer ever right give sex offender second chance;11

column5: who was convicted of a large number of sexual offences against children in Malaysia.;"Reporter Bronagh Munro investigates how a teenage gap year student became one of Britain's worst ever paedophiles.

column2: 30-year-old Richard Huckle was imprisoned after being convicted at the Old Bailey of abusing 23 children in Malaysia and Cambodia. Working as an English teacher and posing as a Christian
column3: Huckle raped and sexually assaulted vulnerable and poor children of all ages. On the dark web
column4: he shared tens of thousands of images of his crimes
column5: boasted about them and even published a manual for paedophiles.

column1: This film investigates how Huckle escaped detection for nearly a decade and reveals that he could have been stopped earlier. Following Huckle's trail to India
column2: where his movements have not been investigated by the authorities
column3: Munro uncovers potentially previously undetected crimes. The film asks whether Huckle also abused children in Britain and reveals that the true count of his victims is likely to number into the hundreds.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and disturbing scenes.;2017;62;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07sjg5n.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07sjg5n.jpg;reporter bronagh munro investigates teenage gap year student became one britain worst ever paedophile 2016 30yearold richard huckle imprisoned convicted old bailey abusing 23 child malaysia cambodia working english teacher posing christian huckle raped sexually assaulted vulnerable poor child age dark web shared ten thousand image crime boasted even published manual paedophile film investigates huckle escaped detection nearly decade reveals could stopped earlier following huckles trail india movement investigated authority munro uncovers potentially previously undetected crime film asks whether huckle also abused child britain reveals true count victim likely number hundred;1

column6: the concept of “spending black”
column7: consciously choosing to buy from black-owned businesses
column8: became an even more popular way in which to support the black community in their everyday lives.

column1: Stats showed that whilst black people are three times more likely to start a new business than white people
column2: they were also more likely to fail to get it off the ground.

column1: Could investing in the black pound be the answer to some of the problems black people face?
For presenter
column3: “spending black” is not a new concept.

column1: However
column2: the unprecedented new interest in “buying black” sends Aaron on a journey to explore what impact this has had on the black community and on the businesses themselves.

column1: He meets businesses that have benefitted financially and culturally from consumers choosing to “spend black” and utilises the latest data to draw conclusions on who and in which areas people are choosing to “spend black”.

Ultimately Aaron questions to what extent this surge in “spending black” will last? column5: and days following Ireland’s historic referendum to repeal the eighth amendment
column6: investigative journalist Ellie Flynn follows the story of the landmark vote to legalise abortion.

column1: Ahead of the referendum
column2: Ellie travels to Ireland to meet activists and campaigners from both sides of the debate to try and understand the impact of the Law for young Irish voters and discovers that this incredibly divisive and emotionally charged issue is not as black and white as it seems.

column1: She meets a young ‘No’ vote campaigner who believes he's only alive because the amendment stopped his mother from aborting him in her youth and speaks to a woman who made the tragic decision to travel to the UK to abort her much wanted daughter after discovering she would be in extreme pain for the few moments she was likely to survive.
In a behind the scenes look at UK abortion clinic
column2: Ellie speaks to Irish women who have travelled abroad to abort and meets the woman facilitating medical abortions on Irish soil.

column5: self-proclaimed 'virgin voter' Hayley Pearce gets a crash course in Welsh politics to better understand how her vote can make a difference.

column1: ;Hayley Pearce gets a crash course in Welsh politics to better understand how her vote at the forthcoming Senedd elections can truly make a difference.
Hayley is a 'virgin voter'; she knows almost nothing about politics and has never voted in her life. She openly admits to having ‘absolute ignorance’ on the subject – but she is not stupid
column4: she’s never been interested enough to care. In this election
column5: though
column6: she pledges to change her ways and get involved.

column1: Heading off on a spending road trip across Wales
column2: Hayley attempts to get to the bottom of how some of our roughly £17 billion annual budget is spent and grills a host of experts to ask unashamedly basic questions. Hayley puts together her own imaginary budget and discovers that if she was in charge of the purse strings
column3: she’d quickly run out of cash.";Documentary;BBC ONE WALES;False;2021;29;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09f95n5.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09f95n5.jpg;hayley pearce get crash course welsh politics better understand vote forthcoming senedd election truly make difference hayley virgin voter know almost nothing politics never voted life openly admits ‘ absolute ignorance ’ subject – stupid ’ ’ never interested enough care election though pledge change way get involved heading spending road trip across wale hayley attempt get bottom roughly £17 billion annual budget spent grill host expert ask unashamedly basic question hayley put together imaginary budget discovers charge purse string ’ quickly run cash;13

column11: of the birth of the NHS
column12: which charts a day in the life of a modern-day regional hospital.;"Made in 2018 to mark the 70th anniversary of the birth of the NHS
column13: acclaimed poet Owen Sheers takes us on a journey that weaves the extraordinary story of the birthing of Nye Bevan's vision of free healthcare for all people with personal stories of the NHS in British society today.

column1: Based on scores of interviews with NHS workers - ranging from brain surgeons to cleaners - The NHS: To Provide All People charts the emotional and philosophical map of what defines the NHS and the personal experiences at the heart of the service
column2: and recognises its achievements and the challenges it faces.

column5: mother and grandmother on television and radio for more than half a century.;"For more than 50 years
column6: Gloria Hunniford has been one of the most familiar faces on British TV. From her early days as an eager news reporter on BBC Northern Ireland to prime time fame as chat show host on BBC One
column7: she has been a well-loved household name for generations of viewers.

column1: In Gloria: My Life On TV
column2: she looks back at her extraordinary career and reveals what it has been like to be woman
column3: a mother and a grandmother on television and radio for more than half a century.

column1: Gloria tells us her experience as a young woman working in the male-dominated newsrooms of the era and how she had to prove herself reporting stories on the streets of Belfast at the height of the Troubles.

column2: Gloria was the first woman to have her own radio show on BBC Radio 2
column3: which she presented for 13 years. She was also one of the first women on British television to have her own chat show

column1: Speaking candidly about her personal life
column2: Gloria reveals how she survived personal tragedies such as the loss of her beloved daughter Caron to cancer in 2004 and how
column4: came the establishment of a foundation in Caron’s name that has raised thousands of pounds for hundreds for cancer charities.

column7: global pay protests and Covid.;Insiders from Theresa May’s government reveal how attempts at economic reform were stymied by Brexit struggles. Covid-19 threatens the promises of levelling up made by the new PM.;"In the second episode
column8: the government and the Bank of England are forced to react to the economic shocks brought on by Brexit and the Covid-19 pandemic. Insiders from the world of finance tell us how these crises create an opportunity for the rich to vastly increase their fortunes.

column1: Theresa May enters office in the aftermath of Brexit
column2: setting her sights on tax dodgers
column3: bloated executive pay and unethical multinational companies.

column1: But as May struggles to implement Brexit
column2: wealth inequality and executive pay are increasing while average wages are barely growing

column1: 2366;2366;Jobfished;None;Catrin Nye investigates the glamorous company that faked its own existence.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bpdxg5.jpg;BBC
column4: Jobfished;Catrin Nye investigates the glamorous company that faked its own existence.;Catrin Nye investigates the glamorous design company that tricked its own staff into believing it was real through an online universe of fake profiles
column5: stolen work and lies.;"It’s 2020. Covid Britain is in lockdown
column6: and the world is working from home. In the depths of the deadly pandemic and when people are at their lowest
column7: someone spots an opportunity. This is the insane story of how people from all over the world were hired to work for a seemingly glamorous and successful design agency… but the whole thing was fake.

column1: In this documentary
column2: investigative journalist Catrin Nye and her team expose a tangled web of lies
column3: confronting the boss to get to the truth of what really happened. The company was built on fakery
column4: and its office wasn’t real. But its own staff had no idea. For months
column5: they slogged as unwitting victims of an elaborate online con
column6: tricked into believing they had good jobs at a successful company. They had been jobfished.

column1: Many of the bosses and colleagues they had been working with over email and Zoom turned out to be fake profiles. But somewhere
column2: someone real must have been behind all of it. If the whole thing was a game
column3: it wasn’t a funny one. Workers got into debt waiting for paychecks that never arrived. They lied to thousands of people trying to get new business for the company. Others were promised life-changing visas to the UK. But all of it was a lie
column4: and it was only uncovered after curious staff did some digging.

column1: Who was behind the con? And what on earth were they trying to achieve? Catrin Nye and her team set out to find the answers and get to the bizarre truth of what happened.";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2022;42;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bpdxg5.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bpdxg5.jpg;’ 2020 covid britain lockdown world working home depth deadly pandemic people lowest someone spot opportunity insane story people world hired work seemingly glamorous successful design agency… whole thing fake documentary investigative journalist catrin nye team expose tangled web lie confronting bos get truth really happened company built fakery office ’ real staff idea month slogged unwitting victim elaborate online con tricked believing good job successful company jobfished many boss colleague working email zoom turned fake profile somewhere someone real must behind whole thing game ’ funny one worker got debt waiting paycheck never arrived lied thousand people trying get new business company others promised lifechanging visa uk lie uncovered curious staff digging behind con earth trying achieve catrin nye team set find answer get bizarre truth happened;1

column1: 2371;2371;Scary Adult Things;Series 1: 6. Feeling Connected;Duncan questions what it means to feel connected.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0998sd1.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 6. Feeling Connected;Duncan questions what it means to feel connected.;Reflecting on all of the connections he has made while filming the series so far
column6: Duncan begins to wonder what it actually means to feel connected.;"Reflecting on all of the connections he has made while filming the series so far
column7: Duncan begins to wonder what it actually means to feel connected.

column1: He decides to speak to somebody who actively chooses to remove technology from their life as much as is realistically possible
column2: to see how connected they feel. He finds Hamish
column3: a young man who makes Pictish crafts
column4: who takes Duncan to a secret loch to go rowing in coracles and to camp overnight by the fire the way the Picts used to.

column1: Duncan then heads off to meet Michelle
column2: a fashion blogger from Kenya who now lives in Perth. With more than 11
column4: Duncan asks how she stays connected with all of her followers.

column1: Duncan's next stop is to meet young painter Ellis O'Connor
column2: a millennial living on North Uist. Ellis is happy in her own company and thrives in isolation
column3: and she shows Duncan the benefits of getting out of the city to a smaller community where people look out for each other.

column1: With loneliness being listed as the number one fear of young people today
column2: Duncan wonders what you do if you want to make a new friend. It’s often harder to meet people as you age
column3: so he tries advertising for a new friend using friendship apps
column4: which leads him to meet Dana. The pair meet up to see a film - but is making this new connection worth it
column5: or is it just awkward and uncomfortable?

column1: Duncan then decides to try and reconnect with his friend Raj
column2: someone he lost touch with and hasn’t spoken to for years. Raj is now married with kids - will he even remember Duncan?

column1: Reconnecting with Raj goes better than expected
column3: Duncan ties this in with his thoughts and conclusion on the series as a whole
column4: reflecting on what has he learnt and how is he feeling about the future.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;Contains adult themes.;2021;28;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0998sd1.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0998sd1.jpg;reflecting connection made filming series far duncan begin wonder actually mean feel connected decides speak somebody actively chooses remove technology life much realistically possible see connected feel find hamish young man make pictish craft take duncan secret loch go rowing coracle camp overnight fire way picts used duncan head meet michelle fashion blogger kenya life perth 11000 follower instagram duncan asks stay connected follower duncan next stop meet young painter elli oconnor millennial living north uist elli happy company thrives isolation show duncan benefit getting city smaller community people look loneliness listed number one fear young people today duncan wonder want make new friend ’ often harder meet people age try advertising new friend using friendship apps lead meet dana pair meet see film making new connection worth awkward uncomfortable duncan decides try reconnect friend raj someone lost touch ’ spoken year raj married kid even remember duncan reconnecting raj go better expected feeling hopeful duncan tie thought conclusion series whole reflecting learnt feeling future;18

column1: 2372;2372;Is Uni Racist?;None;How is racism at Britain’s universities being dealt with
column5: Is Uni Racist?;How is racism at Britain’s universities being dealt with
column6: and what impact is it having?;Linda Adey investigates what happens when students of colour complain about racist abuse to their universities.;"Britain’s universities are some of the most prestigious in the world
column7: but are they safe places for students of colour? Reporter Linda Adey investigates the experiences of black and ethnic minority students at British unis and examines what happens when victims of racist abuse at university want to complain.

column1: Linda’s journey starts in Manchester
column2: where a 19-year-old student was held up against a wall by university security staff demanding to see his ID because
column4: they think he is a drug dealer and not a university student.

column1: Linda’s investigation also leads her to students who experienced alleged racism at one Oxford college
More generally
column2: Linda asks whether the distress of initial racist incidents is being compounded by the way universities handle complaints. She hears that the majority of students who face racism don’t report it
column3: but some students who do complain say they’re locked out of the process
column4: left dissatisfied and have been failed by their university. Those students say it has had huge consequences for their mental wellbeing and educational outcomes.

column1: Linda finally gets to put the students’ experiences she has heard to the universities
column2: but are they willing to admit to any failings? And can universities become safer places for black and ethnic minority students?";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2021;37;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09fdxx9.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09fdxx9.jpg;britain ’ university prestigious world safe place student colour reporter linda adey investigates experience black ethnic minority student british unis examines happens victim racist abuse university want complain linda ’ journey start manchester 19yearold student held wall university security staff demanding see id according student think drug dealer university student linda ’ investigation also lead student experienced alleged racism one oxford college christ church generally linda asks whether distress initial racist incident compounded way university handle complaint hears majority student face racism ’ report student complain say ’ locked process left dissatisfied failed university student say huge consequence mental wellbeing educational outcome linda finally get put student ’ experience heard university willing admit failing university become safer place black ethnic minority student;0

column1: 2373;2373;Lockdown Heroes;None;Stacey Dooley is on the hunt for the everyday heroes of the coronavirus lockdown.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08c9k4r.jpg;BBC
column4: Lockdown Heroes;Stacey Dooley is on the hunt for the everyday heroes of the coronavirus lockdown.;Stuck in her flat
column5: Stacey Dooley is on the hunt for the everyday heroes of the coronavirus lockdown
column6: from emergency service staff to charity volunteers.;"Stacey Dooley's on lockdown! But she's on the hunt for the everyday heroes of the crisis.

column1: Stuck in her flat but armed with social media and a network of contacts
column2: Stacey reaches out to people across the country in search of those who are trying to help others.

column1: In Wigan
column3: a teacher turned scrubs maker who is making protective equipment and has a backlog of orders to fill. She’s working 14-hour days for free
column5: to provide desperately needed equipment to frontline service workers. Those on the front line include people like Serena and Richard
column6: St John Ambulance volunteers who have joined thousands of others to help the health service manage the crisis. Stacey learns what's driving people to such selfless acts up and down the country.

column1: There’s also Elly
column2: a mum to be who has suddenly found herself about to give birth in the middle of a global pandemic. These are crazy times
column3: and Elly can’t quite believe the world she’s bringing her baby into. Being a new mum is hard at the best of times
column4: but Elly is ready to take on the challenge.

column1: While Brits across the world struggled to get home
column2: some chose to stay overseas and help others. Freya was one of them. She decided her charity work was more important than coming home to be with her mother
column3: who is at risk. While people around the world are being urged to stay at home
column4: she is working in Greece to help those who have been forced from their homes by a different but still deadly kind of crisis.

column1: The impact of the disease is taking its toll
column3: junior doctor Zainab is working to support those struggling with the challenges of lockdown
column4: and those recovering from the shock of being in intensive care. She knew that the workload of a junior doctor can be intense
column5: but she didn’t imagine it would be like this
column6: testing her resilience beyond all expectation. Still
column7: she is determined to rise to the challenge.

column1: Stacey gets in touch with Jonathan in Glasgow. He has hit the streets to support homeless people who were dependent on food handouts that have stopped since the city went into lockdown. In just a few weeks
column2: countless volunteers have got together to provide food every night for the homeless. These people have no home to be safe inside
column5: they are dependent on the self-sacrificing kindness of volunteers.

column1: Along the way
column2: Stacey talks us through her lockdown at home in London - how she is keeping sane
column3: and the difficulties of being stuck at home every day. But with every lockdown hero she finds
column4: she becomes more in awe of mankind's ability to meet a crisis with determination
column5: selflessness and compassion.";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2020;29;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08c9k4r.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08c9k4r.jpg;stacey dooleys lockdown shes hunt everyday hero crisis stuck flat armed social medium network contact stacey reach people across country search trying help others wigan ’ charlotte teacher turned scrub maker making protective equipment backlog order fill ’ working 14hour day free managing team 70 seamstress provide desperately needed equipment frontline service worker front line include people like serena richard st john ambulance volunteer joined thousand others help health service manage crisis stacey learns whats driving people selfless act country ’ also elly mum suddenly found give birth middle global pandemic crazy time elly ’ quite believe world ’ bringing baby new mum hard best time elly ready take challenge brit across world struggled get home chose stay overseas help others freya one decided charity work important coming home mother risk people around world urged stay home working greece help forced home different still deadly kind crisis impact disease taking toll croydon junior doctor zainab working support struggling challenge lockdown recovering shock intensive care knew workload junior doctor intense ’ imagine would like testing resilience beyond expectation still determined rise challenge stacey get touch jonathan glasgow hit street support homeless people dependent food handout stopped since city went lockdown week countless volunteer got together provide food every night homeless people home safe inside ever dependent selfsacrificing kindness volunteer along way stacey talk u lockdown home london keeping sane difficulty stuck home every day every lockdown hero find becomes awe mankind ability meet crisis determination selflessness compassion;1

column5: all available on BBC iPlayer.;"Documentary fans are in for a treat as renowned documentarian Louis Theroux dived into the BBC Archives and selected his favourite documentaries. Each of them had an impact on Louis. They cover a range of styles - some vérité-driven
column6: others told more through interview - but in all of them you see life at its most raw
column7: its most strange and therefore its most human.

column1: In Louis Theroux: Docs That Made Me Louis explains why he chose the documentaries and how they have inspired his work.
All the documentaries are available to watch on BBC iPlayer right now:
Between Life and Death (2010)
Inside Story: Mini (1975)
Fourteen Days In May (1987)

2375;2375;The Battle for Britney: Fans
column2: Cash and a Conservatorship;None;Mobeen Azhar untangles the complexities surrounding Britney Spears’ conservatorship.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09g8wfj.jpg;BBC
column5: The Battle for Britney: Fans
column6: Cash and a Conservatorship;Mobeen Azhar untangles the complexities surrounding Britney Spears’ conservatorship.;Mobeen Azhar journeys from Los Angeles to Britney’s hometown of Kentwood
column7: untangling the complexities surrounding her controversial conservatorship.;"Bafta-winning journalist Mobeen Azhar seeks to uncover the truth behind the conservatorship that Britney Spears has been under for the last 13 years. This film follows Mobeen as he journeys from Los Angeles to Britney’s hometown of Kentwood
column8: Louisiana
column9: untangling the complexities surrounding the conservatorship.

column1: Mobeen delves into one of the most passionate fan bases in modern celebrity
column2: attending a court hearing along the way and finding himself in the midst of the ongoing battle between Britney's conservatorship team and the passionate fans behind the #FreeBritney movement. He attempts to speak to those on both sides of the fence surrounding the still-unfolding story of one of pop’s biggest ever superstars.

column1: The film includes never-before-seen interviews with
column5: celebrity blogger Perez Hilton and lawyer Lisa MacCarley.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some strong language.;2021;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09g8wfj.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09g8wfj.jpg;baftawinning journalist mobeen azhar seek uncover truth behind conservatorship britney spear last 13 year film follows mobeen journey los angeles britney ’ hometown kentwood louisiana untangling complexity surrounding conservatorship mobeen delf one passionate fan base modern celebrity attending court hearing along way finding midst ongoing battle britneys conservatorship team passionate fan behind freebritney movement attempt speak side fence surrounding stillunfolding story one pop ’ biggest ever superstar film includes neverbeforeseen interview among others britney ’ makeup artist billy brasfield former choreographer brian friedman celebrity blogger perez hilton lawyer lisa maccarley;1

column1: 2376;2376;Trump in Tweets;None;Examining how Trump used Twitter to change the face of US politics.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08jmwbg.jpg;BBC
column4: Trump in Tweets;Examining how Trump used Twitter to change the face of US politics.;Examining how Trump used Twitter to change US politics
column5: exploring why this technophobe became a serial tweeter and witnessing the impact his tweets have on the world.;"Examining Donald Trump’s love affair with social media. Using his tweets and first-hand testimony from White House insiders
column6: this documentary for BBC Three explores how the president of the United States came of age on Twitter and documents the impact of his tweets on politics in America and across the world.

column1: With unprecedented access to people in his inner circle and interviews with experts
column2: journalists and some of his most avid Twitter followers
column3: this documentary tells the story of how Trump weaponised Twitter and used it as a tool to shape policy
column4: conduct diplomacy and wage war on the establishment.

column1: From Trump’s first innocuous tweet to his early celebrity beefs
column2: from his feuds with politicians to the extraordinary exchanges with North Korea’s leader and his continuing war on anyone who opposes him
column3: Trump uses Twitter to tell the world what he is thinking and doing at all times. The film explores how his tweets provide an insight into his psyche and help maintain his cult-like popularity amongst his followers. And in light of the recent events and protests across the US (and the rest of the world)
column4: the programme asks whether his tweets are a threat to democracy or the mark of a president who has revolutionised the way leaders communicate with their people.

column1: Trump in Tweets features interviews with
column4: former White House director of communications
column5: who reveals what it is like when the president turns his Twitter feed on you
column6: Sean Spicer
column7: Trump’s first presidential press secretary
column8: who got caught between the president’s tweeting and the press
column9: and Rudy Giuliani
column10: Trump’s personal lawyer.

column1: The film also gains access to Peter Costanzo
column2: who started Donald Trump’s Twitter account and wrote his first ever tweet
column4: former political consultant to Donald Trump
column5: who was part of a team who helped Trump build a loyal following with a series of conservative tweets
column6: including fuelling the conspiracy theory falsely claiming that Barack Obama had a fake birth certificate
column7: Lauren Batchelder
column8: who endured a sustained tirade of online abuse after she questioned Trump about his attitudes to women at a political event
column9: and Emmy Bengtson
column10: deputy social media director to the Hillary Clinton campaign
column11: who wrote Hillary Clinton’s tweets during the ‘Delete Your Account’ Twitter battle between Clinton and Trump.

column1: Yeonmi Park
column3: gives her perspective of Trump’s ‘Rocket Man’ tweets
column4: which dramatically raised tensions in the Korean peninsula
column5: and Bryson Gray
column6: a Trump supporter
column7: explains what happened to him after Trump tweeted to endorse one of his raps.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong column1: 2377;2377;Is This Sexual Harassment?;None;A group of people come together to try to understand what constitutes sexual harassment.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07j89ks.jpg;BBC
column4: Is This Sexual Harassment?;A group of people come together to try to understand what constitutes sexual harassment.;Social experiment hosted by journalist and presenter Ben Zand in which a group of people come together to try to understand what constitutes sexual harassment.;"2018 saw the downfall of a series of famous men in the face of allegations of sexual harassment. The issue has never received so much media attention
column5: but the debate about what is and isn't appropriate in the workplace continues. A hand on someone's back
column6: complimenting their fragrance - is this a colleague being friendly
column7: or are they crossing a line? What constitutes sexual harassment?

column1: To find out
column2: BBC Three conduct a social experiment
column3: hosted by journalist and presenter Ben Zand. They bring together 20 people between the ages of 18-30 to see if they understand the rules of behaviour in the workplace. Over the course of two days
column4: they watch a specially written drama in three parts telling the story of a professional relationship between a man and woman at work which ends with an accusation of sexual harassment. At each stage
column5: the group are given the opportunity to vote on the behaviour displayed and if it is offensive or unwanted
column6: before finally voting if they believe it constitutes sexual harassment.

column1: They also hear directly from people whose lives have been affected by sexual harassment
column2: including a false accusation of harassment.

column1: The debate between the young people is wide ranging and impassioned. The programme reveals just how much confusion and disagreement there is when it comes to specifying exactly where a line should be drawn - a line which can become blurred. It shows the significant differences that exist between the genders when it comes to their perspective on what is acceptable.
And finally
column2: the group hears from a barrister who lays down the law and answers the question posed by the drama - is this sexual harassment?";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2019;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07j89ks.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07j89ks.jpg;2018 saw downfall series famous men face allegation sexual harassment issue never received much medium attention debate isnt appropriate workplace continues hand someone back complimenting fragrance colleague friendly crossing line constitutes sexual harassment find bbc three conduct social experiment hosted journalist presenter ben zand bring together 20 people age 1830 see understand rule behaviour workplace course two day watch specially written drama three part telling story professional relationship man woman work end accusation sexual harassment stage group given opportunity vote behaviour displayed offensive unwanted finally voting believe constitutes sexual harassment also hear directly people whose life affected sexual harassment including false accusation harassment debate young people wide ranging impassioned programme reveals much confusion disagreement come specifying exactly line drawn line become blurred show significant difference exist gender come perspective acceptable finally group hears barrister lay law answer question posed drama sexual harassment;11

column1: 2378;2378;Festival Drugs: Meet The Dealers;Series 1: 3. The Deadly Pushers;Livvy Haydock gains access to a gang preparing to target the festival scene with drugs.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07p58dr.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 3. The Deadly Pushers;Livvy Haydock gains access to a gang preparing to target the festival scene with drugs.;Investigative journalist Livvy Haydock gains access to a gang getting ready to target the UK festival scene with MDMA and cocaine.;"With the UK festival market booming like never before
column6: investigative journalist Livvy Haydock meets the people on the dark side of Britain’s festival season. In this episode
column7: Livvy gains access to a gang getting ready to target the UK festival scene with MDMA and cocaine.

column1: The gang reveals that for a dealer
column2: festival season and the illicit drug market it attracts is like Christmas. The gang buys up to 20 festival tickets in bulk
column3: wraps and distributes drugs to event-ready dealers and plans the logistics for a military-style festival takeover.

column1: Livvy meets the gang
column2: gaining an understanding of each role they take in the business of flooding festivals with drugs. One prepares the drugs for the festivals and distributes them to his most trusted dealers
column3: co-ordinating the gang’s workers; another stashes knives on the event ground before the festival barriers are set up; and another brings in and sells drugs
column5: and wielding knives to fend off rival gangs.

column1: Super-strength MDMA is on the rise in the UK. In the last two years
column2: there have been 12 confirmed drug-related deaths inside UK festivals. Livvy goes undercover inside festivals and encounters dealers selling openly despite the heavy security presence.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the gang continues to target festivals
column3: and at the end of the summer Livvy catches up with them to find out if everything went to plan
column4: and whether they feel any guilt for being involved in the drugs industry.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2019;30;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07p58dr.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07p58dr.jpg;uk festival market booming like never investigative journalist livvy haydock meet people dark side britain ’ festival season episode livvy gain access gang getting ready target uk festival scene mdma cocaine gang reveals dealer festival season illicit drug market attracts like christmas gang buy 20 festival ticket bulk wrap distributes drug eventready dealer plan logistics militarystyle festival takeover livvy meet gang gaining understanding role take business flooding festival drug one prepares drug festival distributes trusted dealer coordinating gang ’ worker another stash knife event ground festival barrier set another brings sell drug evading police security wielding knife fend rival gang superstrength mdma rise uk last two year 12 confirmed drugrelated death inside uk festival livvy go undercover inside festival encounter dealer selling openly despite heavy security presence meanwhile gang continues target festival end summer livvy catch find everything went plan whether feel guilt involved drug industry;11

column1: 2379;2379;Hame;Series 4: Episode 2;Mark and Ruth explore Ulster’s links to the Scottish county of Ayrshire.  ;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bm6m8s.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 4: Episode 2;Mark and Ruth explore Ulster’s links to the Scottish county of Ayrshire.  ;Mark and Ruth explore Ulster’s links to the Scottish county of Ayrshire
column6: from the former shipbuilding town of Irvine to the spectacular coastal castle of Culzean.;"Mark Thompson and Ruth Sanderson explore Ulster’s links with the Scottish county of Ayrshire.

column1: In the historic town of Ayr
column2: they catch up with legendary broadcaster Billy Kay
column3: a pioneer of Scots programming on radio and television. Ruth heads north to the village of Dunlop
column4: where she visits a memorial built by James Hamilton
column5: one of the masterminds of the Scottish settlements of Ulster. In New Cumnock
column6: Mark meets up with three men from Northern Ireland who are all leading congregations in the area.

column1: The coastal town of Irvine was once a thriving centre of shipbuilding which attracted thousands of folk from Ulster
column2: and it's here that Ruth meets a local historian to discover more about those connections. And at the spectacular coastal castle of Culzean
column3: Mark meets a young piper from Portavogie who is making his mark on Scotland’s traditional music scene.";Documentary;BBC TWO NORTHERN IRELAND DIGITAL;False;2022;29;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bm6m8s.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bm6m8s.jpg;mark thompson ruth sanderson explore ulster ’ link scottish county ayrshire historic town ayr catch legendary broadcaster billy kay pioneer scot programming radio television ruth head north village dunlop visit memorial built james hamilton one mastermind scottish settlement ulster new cumnock mark meet three men northern ireland leading congregation area coastal town irvine thriving centre shipbuilding attracted thousand folk ulster ruth meet local historian discover connection spectacular coastal castle culzean mark meet young piper portavogie making mark scotland ’ traditional music scene;18

column1: 2380;2380;Transitioning Teens;None;Charlie Craggs meets teens starting to transition
column5: Transitioning Teens;Charlie Craggs meets teens starting to transition
column6: sometimes without medical intervention;Trans activist Charlie Craggs meets trans teens waiting to be seen by the NHS and explores the risks and costs involved in starting to transition
column7: sometimes without medical advice;"This film follows Charlie Craggs
column8: trans activist and author
column9: as she meets teenagers across the country who have been waiting years for a first appointment at an NHS gender identity clinic. Charlie explores what some feel they have to do to start their own transitions and meets young trans people who are choosing to take matters into their own hands and going down the dangerous route of using unregulated medications and starting their transitions themselves.

column1: With the wait in England lasting over 3 years in some cases for a gender identity clinic appointment
column2: some young people feel as if they have no other option then to begin their transitions without medical intervention. With personal experience of this herself
column3: Charlie Craggs asks what can be done to support trans teenagers and meets an NHS doctor running a new pilot service commissioned by NHS England to help address the backlog at the current adult gender clinics.

column1: This topic is not without controversy and a divided area of medicine and Charlie meets a doctor who has been suspended in relation to her work with trans teens and a lawyer who is working on a legal challenge on behalf of a 14-year-old who has been waiting over a year for his first appointment with the NHS. Charlie explores the high court judgement regarding teenager’s ability  to consent to taking hormone blockers and meets a teenager who changed their mind and de-transitioned to find out what happened.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2021;43;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09qslln.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09qslln.jpg;film follows charlie craggs trans activist author meet teenager across country waiting year first appointment nh gender identity clinic charlie explores feel start transition meet young trans people choosing take matter hand going dangerous route using unregulated medication starting transition wait england lasting 3 year case gender identity clinic appointment young people feel option begin transition without medical intervention personal experience charlie craggs asks done support trans teenager meet nh doctor running new pilot service commissioned nh england help address backlog current adult gender clinic topic without controversy divided area medicine charlie meet doctor suspended relation work trans teen lawyer working legal challenge behalf 14yearold waiting year first appointment nh charlie explores high court judgement regarding teenager ’ ability consent taking hormone blocker meet teenager changed mind detransitioned find happened;1

column1: 2382;2382;The Instagram Effect;None;How Instagram became the dominant force it is today
column5: The Instagram Effect;How Instagram became the dominant force it is today
column6: told by those on the inside.;The story of how Instagram became the dominant force it is today
column7: told by former staff and insiders and through powerful testimony from users who have been negatively impacted.;"In just ten years
column8: Instagram has gained over a billion users worldwide
column9: shaping culture
column10: trends and the way we live our lives. But its impact on society is increasingly being questioned as governments step up efforts to regulate social media networks.

column1: This is the first documentary to examine the app’s effects on users since whistleblower Frances Haugen disclosed internal company research proving Facebook
column3: was aware of Instagram’s role in exacerbating issues around body image and self-harm for younger users. Meta says the research shows the majority of its users have a positive experience on the platform.

column1: Haugen and a number of former Instagram and Facebook insiders
column2: many speaking on camera for the first time
column3: speak candidly about life inside the company. They reveal details of pivotal moments
column4: such as Facebook’s acquisition of Instagram in 2012
column5: and explain how these decisions shaped Instagram and its values.

column1: The power of the platform is also explored through revealing testimonies from three British users: Lauren
column2: Chenade and Abby. With unflinching honesty
column3: they describe how their lives have been impacted by the app. Lauren was on Instagram for 13 hours per day and found herself increasingly struggling with an eating disorder. Chenade decided to get a Brazilian butt lift
column4: one of the most dangerous cosmetic surgeries in the world
column5: and promote it to her Instagram followers
column6: only to regret her decision soon after. Meanwhile
column7: home-schooled Abby turned to Instagram for solace and found herself sucked into anti-recovery communities who promote self-harm.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains upsetting scenes.;2022;60;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bm7qb4.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bm7qb4.jpg;ten year instagram gained billion user worldwide shaping culture trend way live life impact society increasingly questioned government step effort regulate social medium network first documentary examine app ’ effect user since whistleblower france haugen disclosed internal company research proving facebook known meta aware instagram ’ role exacerbating issue around body image selfharm younger user meta say research show majority user positive experience platform haugen number former instagram facebook insider many speaking camera first time speak candidly life inside company reveal detail pivotal moment facebook ’ acquisition instagram 2012 explain decision shaped instagram value power platform also explored revealing testimony three british user lauren chenade abby unflinching honesty describe life impacted app lauren instagram 13 hour per day found increasingly struggling eating disorder chenade decided get brazilian butt lift one dangerous cosmetic surgery world promote instagram follower regret decision soon meanwhile homeschooled abby turned instagram solace found sucked antirecovery community promote selfharm;1

column1: 2383;2383;2 Tone: The Sound of Coventry;None;The story of 2 Tone which exploded from Coventry in 1979 with a musical message of unity.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09x1nwz.jpg;BBC
column4: 2 Tone: The Sound of Coventry;The story of 2 Tone which exploded from Coventry in 1979 with a musical message of unity.;The story of how 2 Tone
column5: a record label from Coventry went on to have a global impact. The brainchild of Jerry Dammers saw dance music with a message dominate the charts from 1979.;"Using music
column6: archive and new interviews this is the story of 2 Tone – a unique musical phenomenon that exploded out of Coventry in the summer of 1979.  2 Tone not only dominated the charts and got the nation dancing to a ska beat
column7: it played a vital part in the movement against racism in Britain and beyond. Including a rare interview with Jerry Dammers
column8: the architect of 2 Tone
column9: and contributions from other key players
column10: the film explores the music style and ethos of the genre
column11: and charts the remarkable story of how this independent ‘do it yourself’ record label from Coventry
column12: went on to have a global impact and a unique place in popular music. 2 Tone’s distinctive look and sound
column13: heavily influenced by 1960s Jamaica
column14: was the brainchild of Jerry Dammers
column15: founder and keyboard player of The Specials. Along with fellow Coventry band The Selecter
column16: The Specials spearheaded 2 Tone from their hometown. The record label also went on to launch the careers of other bands too including Madness and The Beat.

column1: Jerry Dammers reveals how he came up with the ideas behind the 2 Tone revolution. Calling for unity at a time of growing racial tension in the UK
column2: this was music with a message
column3: featuring multiracial bands. With the unlikely blend of Jamaican ska and punk rock
column4: the film explores how a brand-new musical genre came seemingly out of nowhere and went mainstream overnight as legions of fans adopted the rude boy/girl  image and propelled the bands up the charts. It also considers why Coventry was the perfect place for the movement to begin. But it wasn’t just about the message – it was about fun
column5: and live gigs renowned for their energy. The last 2 Tone release
column6: ‘Nelson Mandela’ by The Special AKA  saw Jerry Dammers'  anti-racist message go onto a global stage and was in his words
column7: ‘the culmination of 2 Tone’.

column1: The film also hears from Jerry’s bandmate in The Specials
column2: Neville Staple;  Pauline Black and Neol Davies of The Selecter
column3: proud Coventrian and one time Special’s manager Pete Waterman and 2 Tone fan and film director Gurinder Chadha. Recalling significant rehearsals
column5: Neville Staple and Neol Davies reminisce together in the original Coventry locations which have long since changed use; The Locarno
column6: one-time hub of Coventry nightlife and scene of raucous gigs is now the Central Library.
