column4: Catching a Predator;The inside story of the investigation into Manchester male rapist Reynhard Sinaga.;The inside story of the investigation into serial male rapist Reynhard Sinaga - the biggest rape case in British legal history.;"In 2020
column5: it was made public that Reynhard Sinaga had been prosecuted for 159 counts of rape and other sexual offences
column6: against 48 men. But police found evidence relating to more than 200 victims
column7: many of whom remain unidentified.

column1: With exclusive access to Greater Manchester Police's 2017-19 investigation
column2: this film tells the story of serial male rapist Sinaga’s conviction - the biggest rape case in British legal history. From his flat on Princess Street
column4: mature student Reynhard Sinaga would target lone men who’d been on a night out and invite them into his home
column5: with the offer of somewhere to have a drink or to call a taxi. But instead
column6: once they were inside
column7: he would drug
column8: assault and rape them
column9: recording the attacks and collecting personal belongings as ‘trophies’ from his victims.

column1: Investigators found evidence of more than 200 victims
column2: and many had no recollection of being abused until a police officer knocked on their door to tell them they’d been attacked and filmed. Some of these men still have not been identified. He had been offending for a decade.

column1: As evidence of the horrific scale of Sinaga's offending was uncovered
column2: this film tells the detailed inside story of how detectives pieced together an unprecedented prosecution.

column1: And one of Sinaga’s victims
column2: speaking in the film for the very first time
column3: waives his right to anonymity to break the silence that surrounds male rape. His powerful testimony contributes to an important national conversation in the UK
column4: where sexual violence against men remains one of the most underreported crimes.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains upsetting scenes.;2021;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09xgppl.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09xgppl.jpg;2020 made public reynhard sinaga prosecuted 159 count rape sexual offence 48 men police found evidence relating 200 victim many remain unidentified exclusive access greater manchester police 201719 investigation film tell story serial male rapist sinaga ’ conviction biggest rape case british legal history flat princess street manchester mature student reynhard sinaga would target lone men ’ night invite home offer somewhere drink call taxi instead inside would drug assault rape recording attack collecting personal belonging ‘ trophy ’ victim investigator found evidence 200 victim many recollection abused police officer knocked door tell ’ attacked filmed men still identified offending decade evidence horrific scale sinagas offending uncovered film tell detailed inside story detective pieced together unprecedented prosecution one sinaga ’ victim speaking film first time waif right anonymity break silence surround male rape powerful testimony contributes important national conversation uk sexual violence men remains one underreported crime;1

column6: the former CEO of legendary rap music label Death Row Records
column7: was recently sentenced to 28 years imprisonment for manslaughter in a long line of violent crimes not typically associated with a highly successful record executive.

column1: 2386;2386;Return to the Bonfire;None;"Return to the Bonfire meets the people who build and live the traditions of bonfire night
;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09tzcdh.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Return to the Bonfire;Return to the Bonfire meets the people who build and live the traditions of bonfire night

;Return to the Bonfire combines voices of people from the Greater Shankill area to articulate a wide variety of different perspectives during a pivotal year for the community.  ;For Northern Ireland’s Unionists the 11th and 12th of July are a time of bonfires and parades and two days of the year of huge cultural and political significance.

column2: a documentary was filmed for BBC Northern Ireland in Springmartin and Highfield in the Greater Shankill area of Belfast. The Bonfire followed the building of a traditional bonfire by young people
column3: hearing from both them and the older members of the community about their lives. It is remembered by many as an authentic portrayal of life in a working class Unionist community here.

column1: Now in 2021
column2: Return to the Bonfire takes us back to the Unionist heartland of the Greater Shankill area to see what changes have come to the area. In Highfield
column3: the old bonfire field is now a state-of-the-art football pitch
column4: and mixed marriages are now commonplace. Yet while change has undoubtedly come
column5: unionist culture and politics remain central to many people’s lives. We see how the building of the ‘boney’ is still a crucial rite of passage for the young men of the area and watch as NI centenary celebrations are enjoyed
column6: despite uncertainty about the future. Further down the Shankill Road
column7: there are strongly-held views on peace building between unionist and nationalist communities as well as the controversial Northern Ireland Protocol.

column1: Last summer

2388;2388;Nowhere to Run: Abused by our Coach;None;Charlie Webster sets out to find her old friends who were abused by their running coach.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09w572w.jpg;BBC
column4: Nowhere to Run: Abused by our Coach;Charlie Webster sets out to find her old friends who were abused by their running coach.;After Charlie Webster was abused by her coach she never spoke to her friends in her running club again. Then years on an email sets her on a journey back to her past to find them.;"Charlie Webster is a broadcaster and journalist. She’s covered the world’s biggest sporting events. But there is one story she’s never been able to tell.

column1: When she was 12
column2: Charlie joined an all-girls running group in Sheffield. Running became her passion and escape
column3: and the girls in her running group were her best friends. It was a dream.

column1: But all that time their sports coach was abusing her. She never spoke to any of her friends about what was happening to her.
'It became my own secret that I pushed really far down
column2: but I carried it with me everywhere'.

column1: When Charlie was 19
column2: their coach was arrested and convicted. He was sent to prison for 10 years.

column1: And it was only then that she realised she wasn’t the only one he’d abused No-one had ever spoken to Charlie about it – not the police
She left Sheffield and didn’t speak to any of her friends again. To this day she doesn’t know what they went through. She has no idea who spoke up
column2: or who else was abused by their coach.

column1: Now she wants to find out. She’s finally ready to talk to them – but she doesn’t know if they’ll talk to her.

Charlie’s journey to find the friends she left behind all those years ago reveals a compelling personal story – of a tight-knit group of teenagers pushed apart by a predator who operated in plain sight. As Charlie finds each member of her old running group
column2: she discovers what happened to them. Each discovery reveals a different side to their collective story. The more friends Charlie finds
column3: the more she is able to piece back her past to really understand what happened to her.

column1: But there is another question that needs answering – how was this allowed to happen?
As she digs deeper into her own past
column2: Charlie wants to find out if what happened to her and her friends could happen again. She wants to know how young athletes are protected now.

column1: What she discovers is that abuse is still happening today – and the system is still failing young athletes
column2: in exactly the same way.  And that is something Charlie is determined to stop.

column1: Finding the friend who spoke out
column3: brings Charlie the final answers she’s been searching for.

column1: And bringing the friends back together who haven’t spoken in decades
column2: enables them to find the support and friendship that was taken from them all those years ago";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains upsetting scenes.;2021;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09w572w.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09w572w.jpg;charlie webster broadcaster journalist ’ covered world ’ biggest sporting event one story ’ never able tell 12 charlie joined allgirls running group sheffield running became passion escape girl running group best friend dream time sport coach abusing never spoke friend happening became secret pushed really far carried everywhere charlie 19 coach arrested convicted sent prison 10 year realised ’ one ’ abused noone ever spoken charlie – police athletics club – noone left sheffield ’ speak friend day ’ know went idea spoke else abused coach want find ’ finally ready talk – ’ know ’ talk charlie ’ journey find friend left behind year ago reveals compelling personal story – tightknit group teenager pushed apart predator operated plain sight charlie find member old running group discovers happened discovery reveals different side collective story friend charlie find able piece back past really understand happened another question need answering – allowed happen dig deeper past charlie want find happened friend could happen want know young athlete protected discovers abuse still happening today – system still failing young athlete exactly way something charlie determined stop finding friend spoke whose testimony convicted coach brings charlie final answer ’ searching bringing friend back together ’ spoken decade enables find support friendship taken year ago;11

column9: modern hymn writer Keith remains a little-known creative force. He and his wife Kristyn’s mission is to spread the word of God through song.

column1: Born and bred in Lisburn and Belfast respectively
column2: the couple have for years split their time between their homes in Northern Ireland and Nashville
column3: while performing and touring across multiple continents in between. Raising their young family while travelling the world meant that life was hectic for the Gettys
column4: but the Covid pandemic of 2020 impacted their gruelling workload as well as their faith mission. Now based on the north coast until lockdown restrictions lift
column5: the many prestigious venues - from the Grand Ole Opry to the Royal Albert Hall - in which the couple routinely perform remain beyond reach.

column1: Rather than idly sitting out the pandemic
column2: Keith and Kristyn are busier than ever
column3: adapting their approach to their music and reinventing their business to continue to engage with their community and their fans. We find out about Keith and Kristyn’s motivations
column5: their faith and the experiences that have brought them so far in their careers

column3: a remarkable achievement. A few weeks later
column4: he faltered at the Paralympics. Rather than the victory lap expected
column5: he was beaten and afterwards was ungracious about the loss.

column1: The following months saw Pistorius change. He became involved with a different crowd
column2: whilst growing infatuated with guns and paranoid about security. At this point
column4: the start of a whirlwind romance on the surface that would soon end with him murdering her.

column1: In the witness stand

column3: the judge calls Pistorius a 'very poor witness'. The verdict of culpable homicide (the equivalent of manslaughter) is overturned on appeal and upgraded to murder. His sentence is increased from five to six years – and then on a further appeal increased to 15 years. column1: 2398;2398;Princess Margaret: The Rebel Royal;Series 1: 2. Castaway;Following Princess Margaret and Anthony Armstrong-Jones at the start of their married life;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p077l0nj.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 2. Castaway;Following Princess Margaret and Anthony Armstrong-Jones at the start of their married life;Intimate series profiling Princess Margaret. The second film finds Princess Margaret and Anthony Armstrong-Jones at the start of their married life in the early 1960s.;"The second film in this intimate portrait finds Princess Margaret and her husband Anthony Armstrong-Jones at the start of their married life in the early 1960s. At home with celebrities and artists
column6: they are riding the wave of a cultural and sexual revolution that is transforming Britain.

column2: they set off on an official royal tour of the United States. From California to small-town Arizona
column3: the royal couple promote Britain by day and party by night. They attend a dinner with Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton in a world where Hollywood royalty increasingly competes with the real thing. In Britain
column4: the press starts to ask if the extravagant royal tour is a good way to spend public money. The mystique of monarchy is being increasingly undermined by the emergence of a more open and egalitarian society.

column1: In the years that follow
column2: Anthony Armstrong-Jones begins to withdraw from royal duties and the couple lead increasingly separate lives. Press speculation about the state of their marriage intensifies. In the 1970s Margaret retreats more and more to the Caribbean island of Mustique in an attempt to secure a private life. In an era of celebrity gossip and the telephoto lens
column3: her relationship with a younger man and beach parties with rock stars like Mick Jagger lead to ever more press interest. As Britain lurches from one economic crisis to the next
column4: Margaret's Caribbean lifestyle becomes the lightning rod for republican attacks on the monarchy.

column2: Margaret reflects changing attitudes sweeping the country and gets a divorce. The rebel royal is now increasingly eclipsed by a new generation of princesses. But in her own way
column3: Princess Margaret helped pave the way for them and for the monarchy of the 21st century.

column1: 2400;2400;Ian Wright: Home Truths;None;Ian Wright investigates the effects of growing up in a psychologically violent home.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09h8x9r.jpg;BBC
column4: Ian Wright: Home Truths;Ian Wright investigates the effects of growing up in a psychologically violent home.;Footballer Ian Wright shares his own story and investigates what effect growing up in a psychologically abusive and violent home has on children in the UK.;"Ex-footballer Ian Wright investigates the effect growing up in a psychologically abusive and violent home has on children in the UK. In the last year
column5: 1.6 million women experienced domestic abuse
column6: and in 90% of domestic abuse cases there is a child present. As well as coming to terms with his own experience
column7: Ian sets out to understand the impact this kind of childhood can have on kids growing up now and on the adults they will become.

column1: After returning to his childhood home for the first time in 50 years to revisit his past
column2: Ian decides to travel across the UK to meet other people who have experienced domestic abuse in their childhoods
column3: as well as to meet professionals to talk through his own trauma. Ian discovers how things have changed since he grew up in the 1970s
column4: and he finds out how children are supported in the UK today by visiting his former primary school and observing local and charity-led initiatives.

column1: In the final leg of his journey
column2: Ian visits a charity that works with people at risk of committing
column4: domestic abuse and meets a man who is on a course to help him understand and change his behaviour. Ian discovers how abuse can become a dangerous cycle and emotionally reveals that he is now able to begin to forgive his mother and move on from the past. Upon reflection
column5: he concludes that 'abuse creates a vicious cycle - it’s up to all of us to stop it'.";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains upsetting scenes.;2021;58;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09h8x9r.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09h8x9r.jpg;exfootballer ian wright investigates effect growing psychologically abusive violent home child uk last year 16 million woman experienced domestic abuse 90 domestic abuse case child present well coming term experience ian set understand impact kind childhood kid growing adult become returning childhood home first time 50 year revisit past ian decides travel across uk meet people experienced domestic abuse childhood well meet professional talk trauma ian discovers thing changed since grew 1970s find child supported uk today visiting former primary school observing local charityled initiative final leg journey ian visit charity work people risk committing already committed domestic abuse meet man course help understand change behaviour ian discovers abuse become dangerous cycle emotionally reveals able begin forgive mother move past upon reflection concludes abuse creates vicious cycle ’ u stop;4

column1: 2401;2401;The Man Who Used HIV As a Weapon;None;The shocking accounts of five men who were abused by Daryll Rowe.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k0627.jpg;BBC
column4: The Man Who Used HIV As a Weapon;The shocking accounts of five men who were abused by Daryll Rowe.;The shocking accounts of five men who were abused by Daryll Rowe - the first ever person in the UK to be convicted after deliberately infecting men with HIV.;"This powerful documentary tells the intimate and shocking accounts of five men who were abused by Daryll Rowe - the first ever person in the UK to be convicted after deliberately infecting men with HIV. The men in this film have waived their anonymity to speak publicly for the first time. Some have never told their families. And all have the same burning question: Why did he do it?

column1: These multiple perspectives build a gripping account of how
column3: Daryll Rowe set out on a dangerous
column4: nationwide campaign to trick men into having unprotected sex with him. We hear first-hand how he would lie about his HIV status
column5: sabotage condoms and later send abusive text messages taunting them with the virus: ‘You have HIV. Lol.’ A total of 24 men reported him to the police
column6: but nobody knows how many others Daryll Rowe slept with.

column1: Through candid and revealing testimonies
column2: we not only explore the devastating effect of psychological abuse
column3: but also the resilience of ordinary people. Alongside the men
column4: we follow Daryll Rowe’s foster mother
column5: Jacqui
column6: as she tries to come to terms with - and to understand - her son’s crimes. But there is only one person who really has the answer: Daryll Rowe himself. Are we any closer to finding out why he did it? In a tense final showdown we speak to him in an attempt to understand and provide answers for those affected.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and some upsetting scenes.;2019;48;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07k0627.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07k0627.jpg;powerful documentary tell intimate shocking account five men abused daryll rowe first ever person uk convicted deliberately infecting men hiv men film waived anonymity speak publicly first time never told family burning question multiple perspective build gripping account 18 month daryll rowe set dangerous nationwide campaign trick men unprotected sex hear firsthand would lie hiv status sabotage condom later send abusive text message taunting virus ‘ hiv lol ’ total 24 men reported police nobody know many others daryll rowe slept candid revealing testimony explore devastating effect psychological abuse also resilience ordinary people alongside men follow daryll rowe ’ foster mother jacqui try come term understand son ’ crime one person really answer daryll rowe closer finding tense final showdown speak attempt understand provide answer affected;1

Inside Justice meet with a former detective superintendent who says there could be a link between Linda and convicted double murderer Christopher Halliwell.;"Documentary following the work of Inside Justice as they investigate an alleged miscarriage of justice. Glyn Razzell was convicted of murdering his wife Linda in 2003. Her body has never been found and Glyn has always protested his innocence. Led by Louise Shorter
column6: Inside Justice experts in forensic science
column7: policing and law re-examine the case to see if there is any new evidence that could challenge the conviction.

column1: In this episode
column2: Louise digs further into a potential new line of enquiry. She meets with a former detective superintendent who says there could be a link between Linda and convicted double murderer Christopher Halliwell
column3: who killed two women in the Swindon area. Could Linda have been another one of his victims? She also arranges for Glyn Razzell to take a polygraph test in prison while Inside Justice experts pore over the forensic evidence that was so crucial in Glyn's conviction. His wife Linda's blood was found in the boot of the car her estranged husband was driving on that day. Glyn has always maintained the blood was planted by Linda
column4: and that she staged her own disappearance. Will the experts agree this is a possibility or is the conviction sound?";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2018;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p06zfd0b.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p06zfd0b.jpg;documentary following work inside justice investigate alleged miscarriage justice glyn razzell convicted murdering wife linda 2003 body never found glyn always protested innocence led louise shorter inside justice expert forensic science policing law reexamine case see new evidence could challenge conviction episode louise dig potential new line enquiry meet former detective superintendent say could link linda convicted double murderer christopher halliwell killed two woman swindon area could linda another one victim also arranges glyn razzell take polygraph test prison inside justice expert pore forensic evidence crucial glyns conviction wife lindas blood found boot car estranged husband driving day glyn always maintained blood planted linda staged disappearance expert agree possibility conviction sound;11

column1: Irish whiskey is now enjoying a 21st-century renaissance
column2: with the fastest-growing spirit sales in the world. Once a global player
column3: whose industrial success was almost forgotten
column4: it is a drink with a chequered past.

column1: Ulster and Northern Ireland are at the heart of this story - from the Kingdom of Dalriada and the poitin masters of Donegal
column2: to Northern Ireland’s 21st-century pioneers currently resurrecting the brands and blends once counted among the most famous whiskeys in the world.

column1: Though Belfast’s industrial golden age is more often associated with shipbuilding and linen production
column2: Mark and Fionnan reveal just how significant a role whiskey had in the growth of Belfast.

column1: The film uncovers forgotten links between Ulster’s whiskey makers and those of Scotland
column2: revealing just how much Scotland’s whisky story owes to the north of Ireland
column3: and looking back to a time when Irish whiskey exports outsold Scotch by three to one.

column1: Graphic designer Mark’s fascination with branding and advertising opens a door on our industrial past
column2: as he discovers just how much the story of whiskey connects with the history and heritage of the Ulster-Scots.

column4: Go Back To Where You Came From;Reha Kansara explores what it feels like to be told to ‘go home’ and themes of identity.;Reporter Reha Kansara travels to parts of the UK to speak to three different people on what it feels like to be told to ‘go home’ and explores themes of belonging and identity.;"Discussions about racism and racist behaviours are more urgent now than they have ever been. BBC reporter
column5: Reha Kansara explores issues of belonging and identity through a specific type of racial abuse
column6: one that tells people to go back to where they came from. But for the people who are born and raised in the UK
column7: where exactly are they expected to go back to?

column1: She speaks to three people from Glasgow
column2: Cardiff and London about their experiences of being told to go back home
column3: how it affected their lives and how conversations about race have made them think about where they belong.

column1: As part of her journey
column2: Reha starts with her parents and their lived experiences as immigrants who arrived in the UK in the early 70’s from Uganda and Kenya.

column1: Aisha is born and raised in Scotland and has a YouTube channel. She says people assume she’s not from Scotland on an almost daily basis and that getting angry is not the solution to engage with racists.

Zubair filmed a man in a supermarket who was abusive when he told him to go back to where he came from. The video went viral and made national news. He shows Reha the parts of Cardiff where he grew up and says he’s proud to be British.
Naomi is a student based in London and of Nigerian heritage. Her popularity on TikTok means that she is subjected to racial abuse on an almost daily basis and is regularly told to

We also hear from lawyer and author Dr Shola Mos-Shogbamimu who talks about how our lived experiences can shape who we are and provides a helpful explanation of ‘white privilege’.";Documentary;BBC THREE;False;2020;20;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08qy6dv.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08qy6dv.jpg;discussion racism racist behaviour urgent ever bbc reporter reha kansara explores issue belonging identity specific type racial abuse one tell people go back came people born raised uk exactly expected go back speaks three people glasgow cardiff london experience told go back home affected life conversation race made think belong part journey reha start parent lived experience immigrant arrived uk early 70 ’ uganda kenya aisha born raised scotland youtube channel say people assume ’ scotland almost daily basis getting angry solution engage racist zubair filmed man supermarket abusive told go back came video went viral made national news show reha part cardiff grew say ’ proud british naomi student based london nigerian heritage popularity tiktok mean subjected racial abuse almost daily basis regularly told ‘ go back home ’ also hear lawyer author dr shola mosshogbamimu talk lived experience shape provides helpful explanation ‘ white privilege ’;18

column13: Warwickshire. Throughout her short life
column14: Gemma’s mother had fought with social services and the medical profession to get a diagnosis for the learning disability that Gemma so clearly had. Despite numerous assessments
column15: the relevant authorities decided that she was able to live an independent life without any support.

column1: Beginning with her vicious murder
column2: Gemma: My Murder tells the story of her short life from her struggles with school to her determination to live independently like any other young person. Through her mother
column5: Nikki

column8: we discover a lively
column9: loving
column10: if challenging young woman who adored children and loved pop music. Aged 25
column11: Gemma moved into her own flat and her family were pleased to see that she had some new friends. But her learning difficulties left her vulnerable to exploitation by this group who befriended her
column12: taking her money
column13: using her flat to store illegal drugs and coercing her into shoplifting on their behalf. Powerless to intervene
column14: and with no help from the authorities
column15: Gemma’s family and friends could only stand by as
column16: unknown to them
column17: her five “friends” mistreated Gemma
column18: leading to her brutal murder in the middle of the night. Almost a decade later

column1: 2410;2410;True North;Series 13: The Girl with the Colourful Leg;Amputee model Bernadette’s inspiring journey to the final of Miss Northern Ireland 2021.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b4q2jv.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 13: The Girl with the Colourful Leg;Amputee model Bernadette’s inspiring journey to the final of Miss Northern Ireland 2021.;Charity ambassador
column6: model and actress Bernadette Hagans celebrates the 'inclusion revolution' and makes history as the first amputee to take part in Miss Northern Ireland 2021.;"In 2018
column7: Bernadette Hagans from Belfast was diagnosed with synovial sarcoma
column8: a very rare cancer which develops in cells around joints and tendons. Her right leg was amputated from the knee down
column9: and she had to learn to walk again using a prosthetic limb. Despite this
column10: she felt lucky to be given a chance to live and a week after being discharged from hospital
column11: was signed as a model.

column1: The Girl with the Colourful Leg follows Bernadette
column3: as she takes part in a fashion shoot for Elle magazine and makes history as the first amputee to compete in the final of Miss Northern Ireland. The programme also hears in her own words the ways her diagnosis has changed her for the better and how she now views her 'robot foot' as a piece of art
column4: customising it and regularly changing its colour with the help of a vinyl car wrapping company.

column1: As soon as Bernadette was diagnosed
column2: she decided to tell her story to try to help other young people and families who might be in a similar position. She recorded a video showing her reaction to her diagnosis and since then
column3: her positive social media posts and pictures of her colourful prosthetic customisations have gained her a worldwide following.

column1: Now a charity ambassador as well as a model and actress
column2: Bernadette feels part of the 'inclusion revolution' and is the first amputee to take part in the annual Miss Northern Ireland competition. column1: 2411;2411;PSNI – 20 Years on the Frontline;None;Stephen Nolan looks back at the first 20 years of the PSNI. ;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bjdgzx.jpg;BBC
column4: PSNI – 20 Years on the Frontline;Stephen Nolan looks back at the first 20 years of the PSNI. ;Stephen Nolan looks back at some of the newsworthy
column5: controversial and
column6: at times
column7: shocking events that have marked the first 20 years of the PSNI. ;"In November 2001 the Police Service of Northern Ireland was formed against a backdrop of sectarian hatred
column8: civic distrust and the first glimmers of hope fuelled by the Good Friday Agreement. Stephen Nolan looks back at some of the newsworthy
column9: controversial and
column10: at times
column11: shocking events that have marked the first 20 years of the PSNI. He talks to members of the force who have served in both its junior and senior ranks
column12: and to those who support or challenge the current service.

column1: The transition from the old force to the new was shrouded in controversy. Charges of betrayal both of the RUC as a force and of the hundreds of former officers who had been killed in the Troubles marked its inception. Other changes included a different name and insignia for the new service; affirmative action that would ensure a demographic balance between Protestant and Catholic officers in its ranks; and the abolition of the RUC Special Branch – at that time
column2: one of the world’s most experienced counter-terrorism agencies.

column1: Stephen talks to the architects of the new force. Sir Chris Patten outlines the political context
column3: the last chief constable of the RUC and the first chief constable of the PSNI
column4: gives a first hand account about the transition. Officers
column5: both former and present
column6: chart the establishment of the new service and critics of the force tell Stephen of their concerns.

column1: The clear and primary objective of all these reforms was to create a new police service that would be acceptable to all sections of the community in Northern Ireland. After 20 years
column2: Stephen Nolan examines how far the force has come on its road to acceptance.";Documentary;BBC ONE NORTHERN IRELAND;Contains upsetting scenes.;2022;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bjdgzx.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bjdgzx.jpg;november 2001 police service northern ireland formed backdrop sectarian hatred civic distrust first glimmer hope fuelled good friday agreement stephen nolan look back newsworthy controversial time shocking event marked first 20 year psni talk member force served junior senior rank support challenge current service transition old force new shrouded controversy charge betrayal ruc force hundred former officer killed trouble marked inception change included different name insignia new service affirmative action would ensure demographic balance protestant catholic officer rank abolition ruc special branch – time one world ’ experienced counterterrorism agency stephen talk architect new force sir chris patten outline political context sir ronnie flanaghan last chief constable ruc first chief constable psni give first hand account transition officer former present chart establishment new service critic force tell stephen concern clear primary objective reform create new police service would acceptable section community northern ireland 20 year stephen nolan examines far force come road acceptance;1

column1: 2412;2412;I Am A Men's Rights Activist;None;Ex porn-star and activist Philip delves into the controversy behind men’s rights.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p089l3h0.jpg;BBC
column4: I Am A Mens Rights Activist;Ex porn-star and activist Philip delves into the controversy behind men’s rights.;Journalist Alvaro Alvarez travels with former porn-star and men’s rights activist Philipp Tanzer to a Conference on Men’s Issues
column5: shedding light on the controversial movement.;"“I think as a men’s rights activist you are constantly being silenced”.

column1: Philipp Tanzer is a former gay porn actor who now works as a hairdresser
column2: artist and gallery owner in the Scottish Highlands.

column1: He has been involved in the men’s rights movement for over 2 years
column2: first attending the International Conference on Men’s Issues in London in 2018. It’s a summit where men and women who believe men are at a disadvantage in modern society convene to share their thoughts and a common ground.

column1: Intrigued by the concept and the issues surrounding it
column2: BBC journalist Alvaro Alvarez travelled with Philipp to the same Conference
column3: this time in Chicago in August of last year
column4: in an attempt to get under the skin of this movement and ultimately Philipp’s investment and fascination with it.

column1: For Alvaro
column2: confronted with a confusing setting where amongst other things domestic violence towards women is being downplayed by university professors; conversely Philipp is openly captivated
column3: yet it soon emerges there is more to his own back story than meets the eye.

column1: As part of his journey Philipp also meets with Graham Goulden
column2: a retired police officer and Chief Investigator with over 30-years’ experience
column3: who now works as a violence prevention trainer. Having had numerous heated exchanges on social media
column4: Philipp and Graham agree to meet in person to talk through their alternate stances when it comes to men’s rights and their role in society.

column1: We also hear from Tracie Farrell
column2: a Research Associate with the Knowledge Media Institute
column4: who through her work has been delving into what has become known as the ‘manosphere’
column5: a platform evolving within society where it is becoming easier to have a misogynistic opinion and vocalise it.

column1: It goes against most logical thinking
column2: but are we really starting to ‘flip the narrative’ so that women hold the power and men are subjugated by it?

column1: 2417;2417;For Folk’s Sake: Morris Dancing and Me;None;Richard Macer asks what can save the male Morris dancer from extinction. The answer
column5: For Folk’s Sake: Morris Dancing and Me;Richard Macer asks what can save the male Morris dancer from extinction. The answer
column6: women;What can save the male Morris dancer from extinction? Richard Macer infiltrates the endangered world of bells
column7: beer and beards to discover an unlikely saviour in the form of women.;"What’s the best way to save the ageing breed of male Morris dancer from extinction? Richard Macer infiltrates the endangered world of bells
column8: beer and beards to discover an unlikely saviour of this ancient masculine tradition in the form of women.

column1: The Morris Ring
column2: the oldest Morris organisation in the country
column3: has voted to admit women dancers for the first time with the hope that its member sides - as the teams are called - might stem the tide of declining numbers.  But there are hardliners who believe females will dilute the very essence of what makes men’s Morris great.  So
column4: is Morris better when danced just by men or are women and mixed sides just as good?

column1: During this journey
column2: Macer is invited to join his local side the Manchester Morris Men
column3: where the average age is over 70.  Macer might represent an injection of youth to this team but does he have the talent to perform at one of the biggest festivals in the Morris Ring calendar?

column1: What emerges during a long hot summer of folk dance is a bitter conflict as one of Britain’s most enduring traditions tries to reconcile itself to the modern world of gender equality.  It also becomes a fascinating meditation on the nature of masculinity in a society in thrall to the idea of political correctness. And there is a personal development too for Macer
column2: which sends his journey off in an unexpected direction.";Documentary;BBC FOUR;False;2019;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p074tkhh.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p074tkhh.jpg;’ best way save ageing breed male morris dancer extinction richard macer infiltrates endangered world bell beer beard discover unlikely saviour ancient masculine tradition form woman morris ring oldest morris organisation country voted admit woman dancer first time hope member side team called might stem tide declining number hardliner believe female dilute essence make men ’ morris great morris better danced men woman mixed side good journey macer invited join local side manchester morris men average age 70 macer might represent injection youth team talent perform one biggest festival morris ring calendar emerges long hot summer folk dance bitter conflict one britain ’ enduring tradition try reconcile modern world gender equality also becomes fascinating meditation nature masculinity society thrall idea political correctness personal development macer sends journey unexpected direction;11

column4: TikTok Queen at 16;Documentary following 16-year-old TikTok sensation Kristen Scott.;Documentary following TikTok sensation Kristen Scott. Kristen has just turned 16 and is now legally allowed to leave school to pursue her social media influencing career full-time.;"TikTok sensation Kristen Scott has just turned 16
column5: which is a big deal for every teenage girl
column6: but for Kristen it presents a life-changing choice: she is now legally allowed to leave school to pursue her social media influencing career full-time.

column1: Her posts range from silly dances and impressive singing to more serious issues like mental health and body positivity. With a following of 735
column3: she continues to build her social media presence as she balances brand deals and legal contracts with her normal life as a teenager.

column1: Integral to Kristen’s fledgling career is her mum
column2: Elizabeth. Trying to find a balance between protecting her daughter
column3: supporting her and getting pigeon-holed as a ‘momager’
column4: Elizabeth offers an alternative perspective on the impact of having a social media star in the family.

column1: Industry experts Suhit Amin and Aundrea Worsley offer a glimpse into the up-and-coming but lucrative industry of social media marketing
column2: providing a better understanding of what kind of career Kristen could potentially have if she works hard and plays her cards right.

column1: However
column2: it's not all glamour as Kristen is bullied
column4: for her social media. Does she have thick enough skin to make it as an influencer
column5: or will the hate and pressures make her rethink her choice?

column1: Kristen also openly discusses how lonely this career sometimes is and how Covid-19 has exacerbated this feeling of disconnection. However
column2: there is light at the end of the tunnel as a potential new manager offers her a spot in a Creator House
column3: where she will live with other influencers as they wake up

column1: Is Kristen ready to move away from her supportive parents to dive in the deep end of being a full-time influencer? Is this a viable career for someone who is only 16?

Ben Zand speaks to friends and acquaintances to try and unravel who he really is.;"Ben Zand hears from the people Kanye West grew up with

column4: one of the top five rappers of all time. The producer-turned-performer

column8: many who were already outraged by his declaration that 400 years of slavery ""sounds like a choice"".

column1: 2422;2422;How Police Missed the Grindr Killer;None;Documentary examining the police investigation into serial killer Stephen Port.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0bbbz8j.jpg;BBC
column4: How Police Missed the Grindr Killer;Documentary examining the police investigation into serial killer Stephen Port.;Documentary examining the police investigation into Stephen Port
column5: who murdered four young gay men in east London within 15 months.;"Stephen Port date-raped and murdered four young gay men in east London within 15 months and dumped all four bodies within a few hundred metres of each other. Yet Barking and Dagenham police failed to link the deaths until weeks after the fourth one.

column1: The film tells the story through eyes of the families of Port's victims
column2: unpicking how the police failed to properly investigate each of the deaths in turn. The police's assumptions that these young gay men had died from self-inflicted overdoses of chemsex drugs allowed Port to continue raping and killing innocent young men.

column1: Some of the victims' families have accused the police of institutional homophobia and asked if officers would have investigated more thoroughly
column2: had four young women turned up dead within such a small radius. The Met Police have referred themselves to the Independent Police Complaints Commission over their handling of the case.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and upsetting scenes.;2017;46;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0bbbz8j.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0bbbz8j.jpg;stephen port dateraped murdered four young gay men east london within 15 month dumped four body within hundred metre yet barking dagenham police failed link death week fourth one film tell story eye family port victim unpicking police failed properly investigate death turn police assumption young gay men died selfinflicted overdoses chemsex drug allowed port continue raping killing innocent young men victim family accused police institutional homophobia asked officer would investigated thoroughly four young woman turned dead within small radius met police referred independent police complaint commission handling case;1

column1: 2423;2423;Is This Coercive Control?;None;A group of people come together to try to understand what constitutes coercive control.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08vwtvn.jpg;BBC
column4: Is This Coercive Control?;A group of people come together to try to understand what constitutes coercive control.;Journalist and presenter Ellie Flynn brings together a group of 20 young people aged 18-25 for a social experiment
column5: to see if they understand what constitutes coercive control.;"Please note that the filming for this programme took place prior to Covid-19 restrictions.

column1: Coercive control is a pattern of behaviour by an abuser to harm
column2: punish or frighten their victim. It’s been illegal since 2015
column3: but would we be able to spot it if we saw it happening?

column1: To find out
column2: journalist Ellie Flynn brings together 20 people aged 18-25 from across the UK to explore if they know what coercive control actually is. Over two days
column3: the group watches a specially-written drama telling the story of the relationship between Rachel and Alex. As the drama progresses
column4: it becomes clear that there is a variety of different perceptions of the events in the story. Some think that what they are being shown amounts to normal behaviour in a relationship
column5: while others believe that a line is being crossed.

column1: At each stage of the process
column2: the group has the chance to vote on whether they think there is anything wrong with the actions of Rachel or Alex. They are invited to come to their own conclusions on what they see
column3: and must decide in a final ballot if what they have witnessed constitutes a crime.

column1: We find out how many believe a crime has been committed. But how many are convinced that they know what that crime actually is?
Finally
column2: the group hears from barrister Clare Ciborowska
column3: who analyses the events in Rachel and Alex’s story. She explains the law and reveals the answer to the key question posed by the programme – is this coercive control?";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2020;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p08vwtvn.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p08vwtvn.jpg;please note filming programme took place prior covid19 restriction coercive control pattern behaviour abuser harm punish frighten victim ’ illegal since 2015 would able spot saw happening find journalist ellie flynn brings together 20 people aged 1825 across uk explore know coercive control actually two day group watch speciallywritten drama telling story relationship rachel alex drama progress becomes clear variety different perception event story think shown amount normal behaviour relationship others believe line crossed stage process group chance vote whether think anything wrong action rachel alex invited come conclusion see must decide final ballot witnessed constitutes crime find many believe crime committed many convinced know crime actually finally group hears barrister clare ciborowska analysis event rachel alex ’ story explains law reveals answer key question posed programme – coercive control;11

column5: Datings Dangerous Secrets;When a date goes wrong
column6: what happens when you report sexual assault to a dating app?;How safe is your dating app? Linda Adey is investigating what happens when a date goes wrong and you want to report sexual assault to a dating app.;"While dating apps like Tinder
column7: Bumble and Hinge now play a major role in many young Brits' love lives
column8: a rising number of sexual assault cases have also been reported which happened after meeting someone on an app. Reporter Linda Adey investigates the safety of the most popular dating apps in Britain. She asks whether providing background checks for all users might be one way to improve safety on the most popular apps.

column1: Linda also explores the complaints processes of dating apps. She meets 26-year-old Bex
column2: who tried to report her Tinder date
column3: who she claims sexually assaulted her during a date. She ended up being banned by Tinder
column4: who took months to respond to her initial complaint. According to a survey carried out for the BBC
column5: 47% of people who responded and had used a dating app were not happy with the way their complaint was handled. Linda Adey meets a young woman
column6: Sasha
column7: who claims she was raped twice after meeting a date. Sasha couldn't report the incident because her Tinder date blocked her
column8: which meant all records of their connection on the app were deleted.

column1: According to a new survey carried out for the BBC
column2: 33% of dating app users who responded have experienced either harassment or abuse by someone they met via a dating app. The survey includes women and men aged 18-35 years old.

column1: The investigation also looks into the latest police data. More than 6
column2: 000 people have reported offences linked to dating apps between 2017 and 2021. One in five were sexual offences. The police data is supported by the National Crime Agency's latest statistics from March 2021. They found that cases have increased over the past four years
column3: and 83% of the victims were female. But the true number of cases could be higher: according to the Office for National Statistics
column4: fewer than 16% of sexual assaults are reported to the police.

column1: In very rare cases
column2: a date ends tragically. Linda Adey meets the mum of 26-year-old Katherine from Wales. After Katherine met her new partner on Plenty of Fish
column3: she was stabbed 33 times by someone who turned out to be a dangerous and violent offender. column8: he begins to wonder if we can ever overthrow the legacy it continues to exert over our lives today.;"In this episode
column9: Darren examines his own social mobility. Can he ever fully transition from his working-class past to the middle-class present he currently enjoys? Why should it matter where he is from? And why does his past continue to impact his present?

column1: Using an experiment conceived by Yale University in America
column2: Darren tests the theory that you can recognise a person’s social class by just seven words
column3: visits the further education college he once attended to give a masterclass
column5: Lauriston Castle in Edinburgh
column6: to compare his two worlds.

column1: Keen to experience what life might be like in the past
column2: Darren tries his hand at being a butler with a man who has served everyone from royalty and politicians
column3: to opera singers and Russian oligarchs.

column1: Later
column2: while toasting marshmallows over a campfire
column3: he meets a young traveller in a Bedford van far older than she is to discuss two burning questions: what is freedom
column4: and can social class ever be completely ignored?

column1: Up in Elgin
column2: Darren meets two pigeon-fanciers who show him how pigeons can become a way of life and unwittingly unlock a magic key in Darren’s mind. Coming full circle

column1: With 15 million people in England alone living with a long-term condition
column3: it's no surprise chronic illness influencers on social media are attracting huge followings. But
column5: so have accusations of fakery. Can the accusers be right? Are some influencers faking illnesses for fame
column6: money and attention?

column1: As someone who is disabled
column4: is horrified by the thought of people faking it - but she's equally horrified to see sick people being disbelieved.

column1: In this film

column3: who defined the condition Munchausen's by Internet to describe people who fake illnesses online.

column7: Texas. Convicted of committing a capital murder in 2004
column8: he was sentenced to death. His victim Pablo Castro
column9: a Mexican immigrant convenience store worker with young children
column10: was left for dead from fatal stab wounds as the former US Marine
column11: went on the run to Mexico. Protected by a Mexican Cartel for four years
column12: Ramirez was eventually caught in an FBI sting on the US border four years later. His capture ended years of torment for Pablo Castro's traumatised children. When John Henry Ramirez's trial commenced in December 2008
column13: his accomplices Christina Chavez and Angela Rodriguez had already been sentenced to 25 years and life respectively for their parts in the robbery and murder.

column1: 2433;2433;David Wilson's Crime Files;Series 2: 10. Ethics of Policing;Criminologist David Wilson asks whether the ends justify the means when solving crime.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p09s5cxk.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 2: 10. Ethics of Policing;Criminologist David Wilson asks whether the ends justify the means when solving crime.;Criminologist David Wilson explores some of the ethical quandaries that plague our criminal justice system - is there a line that police shouldn’t cross when hunting the bad guy?;"Criminologist Professor David Wilson presents the second series of talk show Crime Files. In this episode
column6: David and guests discuss the complex ethical issues that face our police today and ask whether the ends justify the means when solving crime.

column1: Investigative journalist Fiona Walker travels to the small town of Winchburgh in West Lothian to examine the century-old case of two murdered children. She recounts the unique way in which the bodies had been preserved and how two eminent pathologists from Edinburgh helped crack the case by deducing the identities of the two young boys. However
column2: Fiona is about to find out all is not what it seems in this horrendous case.

column1: Fiona joins David in the studio to show him some documents that put the whole investigation into an unflattering light. These documents are personal recollections from one of the pathologists who helped solve the case and raise some major ethical questions about the medical practices used back then and what part consent played.

David’s next guest is former deputy chief constable and SPA board member Tom Halpin. He and David look at more modern police practices that raise potential ethical concerns; specifically the issue of stop and search. David questions whether Scotland’s implementation may be going too far and whether bias profiling plays any part in it. Native Glaswegian Tom also recounts his own personal experience with stop and search as a young man.
David’s final guest is former undercover officer for the serious crime squad Simon McLean. He speaks about his recently published memoir
column3: which recounts his early years on the force and how he often found himself pushed into the grey areas of policing. Simon gives us a unique glimpse of the turmoil caused when the rules are stretched to the limit
column4: where plain clothes officers must infiltrate and suppress the very worst among us - the dealers
column5: the shooters and the gangsters. He explains that it is a job for those who are willing to do what is required
column6: and for him that is the officers who fall into The Ten Percent.";Documentary;BBC SCOTLAND;False;2021;28;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p09s5cxk.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p09s5cxk.jpg;criminologist professor david wilson present second series talk show crime file episode david guest discus complex ethical issue face police today ask whether end justify mean solving crime investigative journalist fiona walker travel small town winchburgh west lothian examine centuryold case two murdered child recount unique way body preserved two eminent pathologist edinburgh helped crack case deducing identity two young boy however fiona find seems horrendous case fiona join david studio show document put whole investigation unflattering light document personal recollection one pathologist helped solve case raise major ethical question medical practice used back part consent played david ’ next guest former deputy chief constable spa board member tom halpin david look modern police practice raise potential ethical concern specifically issue stop search david question whether scotland ’ implementation may going far whether bias profiling play part native glaswegian tom also recount personal experience stop search young man david ’ final guest former undercover officer serious crime squad simon mclean speaks recently published memoir ten percent recount early year force often found pushed grey area policing simon give u unique glimpse turmoil caused rule stretched limit plain clothes officer must infiltrate suppress worst among u dealer shooter gangster explains job willing required officer fall ten percent;11

column4: When Nudes Are Stolen;Former glamour model Jess Davies uncovers the hidden trade in nude photographs.;Former glamour model Jess Davies uncovers the hidden trade in nude photographs.;"When Jess Davies started glamour modelling at age 18
column5: she had no idea that she would be opened up to online abuse
column6: trolling and
column7: bizarrely
column8: having her images used by catfish who target men around the world. Now the lads mags have closed and Jess has decided not to do topless shoots anymore
column9: but images of her are all over the internet. She has no control over how they are used or what for.

column1: Over the years Jess has received hundreds
column3: of messages from men telling her they’ve been speaking to someone using her pictures. It’s Jess who bears the brunt of their frustration and anger when victims realise they’ve been conned. She has never been able to get to the bottom of why this happens
column4: but in this film she finally finds out. It can be traced back to a collection of underground forums
column5: websites and groups dedicated to packaging up nude and topless photos to sell in online marketplaces. In these forums
column6: revenge porn
column7: nudes and leaked photos from Only Fans are traded and sold. Eventually
column8: Jess manages to find her own ‘pack’ – photos of her are being sold in exchange for a $15 Amazon gift card.

column1: The film explores a broader online culture in which people have no concerns about sharing and trading peoples’ intimate photos
column2: and give little consideration to whether the pictures were taken consensually.

column1: Jess begins to realise just how massive an impact the trading and misuse of photos of her has had on how she feels about herself and her real-life relationships. Now she is determined to reclaim control over her own body

column4: Mark Walters in the Footsteps of Andrew Watson;Mark Walters looks back at his time with Rangers FC and discovers Andrew Watson's story.;Former Rangers player Mark Walters looks back at the racism he experienced while playing for the club. He also uncovers black footballing pioneer Andrew Watson
column5: who captained Scotland in 1881.;"Former Rangers player Mark Walters looks back at his career with the Glasgow club to assess the racism he faced while playing for them. Watching harrowing footage of his early matches
column6: he vividly describes the visceral atmosphere as he was targeted by opposition fans. In a candid conversation with Graeme Souness
column7: the player-manager who brought him to Ibrox
column8: Mark reveals the inner resilience that got him through those tough games and reflects on how unconscious bias in TV commentary affects the way black footballers are perceived today.

column1: Mark also finds out about early black footballing pioneers in Scotland

column6: drawing on what they already know about the death of Mamie Stuart in 1919.;"Not a great deal is known about the murky
column7: itinerant life of George Shotton. One certainty is that by the time of his death in 1958
column8: he had managed to get away with the murder of his first wife
column9: Mamie
column10: in 1919. But did Shotton go on to kill again?

column1: Shotton was a naval engineer who wed Mamie Stuart in 1918
column2: despite already being a married man
column3: only to be caught and convicted of bigamy two years later. Though suspected of Mamie’s disappearance around this time – not least because of a trunk full of her possessions found dropped off at a Swansea hotel – he managed to evade conviction. It wasn’t until 1961
column4: when divers discovered human remains in a cave near Caswell Bay
column5: that he was posthumously sentenced for the crime.

column1: The case that the investigative team are looking at in conjunction with Mamie’s death is a 1934 incident known as the Brighton Trunk Murder
column2: in which a dismembered body was found split between two trunks in train stations in Brighton and London. Given the similarities between this murder and that of Mamie Stuart
column3: the team believes that Shotton could be a prime suspect for this murder too. column1: Rappers have long mined their lives for inspiration to create and promote their music
column3: some of the biggest artists stand accused of participating in the lawlessness their music describes. Raising the stakes is the 24-hour connectivity of social media
column4: a world where the importance of record sales has been surpassed by streams and likes.

column1: Louis spends time with a number of artists achieving success through self-promotion on social media – from those playing out fierce rivalries online to those live-streaming their often violent and chaotic lifestyles. column2: this content has also drawn the attention of the authorities
column3: who see it as evidence of criminals engaging in 'illegal gang activity'.

column7: immigration and race.;How Barack Obama tried to reshape America. The last episode begins with Obama's decision to launch the special operation into Pakistan
column8: to catch Osama Bin Laden.;"The last instalment of this definitive account of Obama's presidency tells how Obama got re-elected for a second term and tried to tackle America's most intractable social problems - guns
column9: immigration and race.

column1: Episode four begins with president Obama's decision to launch the special operation into Pakistan
column2: to catch Osama Bin Laden. Former CIA director Leon Panetta describes how Obama decides to go ahead despite odds no better than 50:50 and the strong misgivings of top advisors.

column1: As his re-election campaign gears up
column2: Obama has to make a tough choice on contraception - whether to side with the Catholic bishops
column3: or health secretary Kathleen Sebelius and feminist activists. Obama chooses the women
column4: and they contribute to his convincing election victory.

column1: But soon after his re-election
column2: America is shocked by the Sandy Hook massacre - 20 children are shot dead in a Connecticut school. The families of the victims and senior advisor Valerie Jarrett recall the president's attempts to strengthen gun legislation
column3: but they are defeated by the gun lobby.

column1: Obama's other ambitious reforms fared no better. Cecilia Munoz and Valerie Jarrett reveal how Obama worked with allies in Congress to create a bipartisan consensus on immigration but is defeated by the Republicans. The president can move forward only through executive action.
The background of the first black president is different from most African Americans'. Raised in Hawaii by white grandparents
column2: Obama initially downplays racial issues but the shooting of black teenager Trayvon Martin provokes him to speak out. When Ferguson
column4: becomes a flashpoint of conflict between police and African Americans

column5: Til Kingdom Come: Trump
column6: Faith and Money;Documentary about an unusual philanthropic relationship that links Kentucky with Israel.;Documentary about the close ties between a group of pastors in Kentucky and Israel's foremost philanthropic organisation that sheds light on US foreign policy in the Middle East during the Trump era.;"Millions of American evangelicals are praying for the state of Israel. Among them are the Binghams
column7: a dynasty of Kentucky pastors
column8: and their evangelical congregants in an impoverished coal mining town. They donate sacrificially to Israel’s foremost philanthropic organisation
column9: the International Fellowship of Christians and Jews
column10: because they fervently believe the Jews are crucial to Jesus’s return.

column1: This film traces this unusual relationship
column2: from rural Kentucky to the halls of government in Washington
column3: through the moving of the American Embassy in Jerusalem to the annexation plan for the West Bank.

column1: 2454;2454;The Man Who Took on a Mansion;None;One man’s quest to transform one of the most majestic and historic mansions in north Wales;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b6csq1.jpg;BBC
column4: The Man Who Took on a Mansion;One man’s quest to transform one of the most majestic and historic mansions in north Wales;The story of one man who risked it all on the dream of returning a magnificent Grade I listed mansion in north Wales to its former glory.;"Plas Glynllifon is a spectacular Grade I listed mansion on the outskirts of Caernarfon
column5: north Wales. Built in the 1830s
column6: it has an incredible history
column7: including hosting Prince Charles’s investiture ball. Its story took a new twist in 2017
column8: when after years of languishing on the market and falling into serious disrepair
column9: Plas Glynllifon finally found a new owner. Paul Williams fell instantly in love with the place and after buying it
column10: he began a quest to return it to its former glory.

column1: For over four years
column2: we follow the multimillion-pound renovation as Paul sets out to transform the mansion from dilapidated state to 5-star hotel. But it all costs
column3: and with time and finances running out fast
column4: Paul finds himself in a race to complete Glynllifon’s transformation before the dream is lost.";Documentary;BBC ONE WALES;False;2021;39;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b6csq1.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b6csq1.jpg;plas glynllifon spectacular grade listed mansion outskirt caernarfon north wale built 1830s incredible history including hosting prince charles ’ investiture ball story took new twist 2017 year languishing market falling serious disrepair plas glynllifon finally found new owner paul williams fell instantly love place buying began quest return former glory four year follow multimillionpound renovation paul set transform mansion dilapidated state 5star hotel cost time finance running fast paul find race complete glynllifon ’ transformation dream lost;11

column1: 2455;2455;The Cameron Years;Series 1: 2. The Best Is Yet to Come;Examining David Cameron's leadership between 2005 and the 2015 election.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07n85gf.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 2. The Best Is Yet to Come;Examining David Cameron's leadership between 2005 and the 2015 election.;Examining David Cameron's leadership
column6: from his rise to the top of the Conservative Party in 2005 to his 'sweetest victory' at the 2015 election.;"With unprecedented access to David Cameron himself
column7: and drawing on the testimony of leading allies and critics from his close team
column8: party and coalition partners
column9: this second programme explores the former prime minister’s legacy as a leader
column10: from his rise to the top of the Conservative Party in 2005 to his ‘sweetest victory’ in the 2015 general election.

column1: We begin at a moment of crisis for the Conservative Party
column2: after three successive general election defeats. We investigate how Cameron and his small group of supporters sought radically to shift the party’s direction of travel
column5: he managed to become leader in the teeth of opposition from the party’s traditional right wing
column6: his veteran opponent David Davis and accusations of past drug use.

column1: The film then investigates David Cameron’s programme to reshape his party and the opposition he faced in doing so. Environmentalism
column2: social justice and international aid - prioritising these made the Conservatives appear more electable but also ran the risk of alienating their powerful old guard. Two crises
column4: threatened to destabilise everything Cameron had achieved. First
column5: we explore the extent to which the 2008 financial crisis forced a fundamental rethink of 'modern
column6: compassionate Conservatism' in a new political landscape that demanded tough economic measures. Secondly
column7: we turn to the death of David Cameron’s firstborn son
column8: Ivan
column9: and its impact on Cameron as he wrestled with his personal grief in the public gaze.

column1: The general election in 2010 was Cameron’s greatest test yet
column2: and a hurdle at which he fell short. The film explores how
column3: having failed to win an outright majority
column4: David Cameron persuaded his party to join in a coalition with the Liberal Democrats. In the Rose Garden
column5: Cameron and his new political comrade Nick Clegg suggested that a new era of political compromise was beginning
column6: but did the coalition stir up resentment among backbenchers who felt marginalised by the new arrangement?

column1: The film turns to the first major tests of David Cameron’s leadership. First
column2: examining how the implementation of austerity
column3: masterminded by his close ally George Osborne
column4: saw the start of long-lasting public outrage and sowed the seeds of coalition division over the introduction of increased tuition fees. Secondly
column5: questioning Cameron’s response to the Libyan Civil War - whether his decision to intervene was the right one
column6: and whether he was experienced to lead the country in war.

column1: Finally
column2: the programme tackles the three great challenges of Cameron’s first term: the passage of gay marriage legislation in 2013
column3: which was simultaneously the high point of Cameron’s 'compassionate' social agenda
column4: but also the nadir of his relationship with the party and grassroots; the Scottish referendum in 2014
column5: which saw Cameron’s government come dangerously close to presiding over the break-up of the Union; and the general election in 2015
column6: in which David Cameron led his party to a victory that defied the polls
column7: but at the expense of his coalition partners
column8: the Liberal Democrats.

column1: We leave David Cameron in 2015
column2: at the height of his powers. Had his journey to this point set in motion political events and personal blindspots that would
column4: usher him out of office just over one year later?";Documentary;BBC ONE;Contains some upsetting column5: TV
column6: Amazing Hotels: Life Beyond the Lobby
column7: Series 4: 6. The Lanesborough
column8: London;Monica Galetti and Giles Coren visit London's most expensive hotel
column9: the Lanesborough.;Monica Galetti and Giles Coren visit London's most expensive and exclusive hotel
column10: the Lanesborough. It's the first time the hotel has allowed anyone behind the scenes.;"Monica Galetti and Giles Coren visit London's most expensive and exclusive hotel
column11: the Lanesborough. It's the first time the hotel has allowed anyone behind the scenes.

column1: The hotel is set discreetly in a grand and historic building on London’s Hyde Park Corner. Its suites
column4: are often rented for months at a time
column5: and even the cheapest rooms come with a dedicated butler. Giles and Monica discover a friendly staff that makes staying here feel like home
column6: and no request is too big.";Documentary;BBC TWO;False;2022;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p0b5546g.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p0b5546g.jpg;monica galetti giles coren visit london expensive exclusive hotel lanesborough first time hotel allowed anyone behind scene hotel set discreetly grand historic building london ’ hyde park corner suite costing £27000 night often rented month time even cheapest room come dedicated butler giles monica discover friendly staff make staying feel like home request big;13

column1: 2457;2457;Nudes4Sale;None;Ellie Flynn investigates people making money from selling their nude photos and videos.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p08dlbyq.jpg;BBC
column4: Nudes4Sale;Ellie Flynn investigates people making money from selling their nude photos and videos.;Reporter Ellie Flynn investigates how thousands of ordinary people and teenagers all across the world are making money from selling their own nude photos and videos.;"In an age where social media is absolutely everywhere there is a new growing trend: #Nudes4Sale.

column1: This phenomenon has been growing quietly for the past three years
column2: but is now creeping into the mainstream. Reporter Ellie Flynn investigates how thousands of ordinary people and teenagers all across the world are making money from selling their own nude photos and videos.

column1: But how many people creating content for these sites are actually underage
column2: and should the sites themselves be doing more to protect underage and vulnerable contributors?

column1: Ellie meets Hannah
column3: who has been selling explicit content of herself since she was 16. Hannah set up an account on a site called OnlyFans using a fake ID. She was reported for being under 18 and kicked off the site but managed to set up a new profile and continue selling nudes.

column1: Lauren
column3: is one of the top-ranked Only Fans creators in the world. She has over 2
column5: 000 followers on Instagram. In one month alone
column6: Lauren earned a jaw-dropping £37
column7: 000 - a figure she says is going up every month.

column1: But not everyone is making a decent living. Some vulnerable people find themselves using sites like these to help put a roof over their heads. Sasha is 20 and earns a few hundred pounds a month on OnlyFans. She uses sex toys
column2: collaborates with other performers and has even had requests to make videos of herself going to the toilet for £50-£60. Sasha has a history of mental health issues and turns to the local council to help her find suitable accommodation when she decides to leave home. But the council can’t help
column3: and Sasha finds herself effectively homeless. She is left thinking about what she might have to do to put a roof over her head
column4: and with sites like OnlyFans at her fingertips
column5: that thought could be scary.

2458;2458;Surviving Helmand;None;Inspiring documentary on Helmand told through four emotional testimonies.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p0b1wsql.jpg;BBC
column4: Surviving Helmand;Inspiring documentary on Helmand told through four emotional testimonies.;Inspiring documentary on the war in Afghanistan told through emotional testimonies of three Welsh soldiers and a bereaved mother.;"Four inspirational people deeply affected by the conflict in Afghanistan - two soldiers who overcame the deep psychological impact of their experiences
column5: one who lost a leg
column6: and a bereaved
column7: campaigning mother - tell their extraordinary stories of anguish
column8: despair and recovery
column9: reveal how they coped with the consequences and have strived to help others. This is their story of surviving Helmand.

column1: At the height of the war in 2009 and 2010
column2: the biggest threat to the soldiers were Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) – increasingly sophisticated and devastating homemade bombs planted by the Taliban. Activated by pressure from above or a command wire
column3: they became the single largest cause of fatalities and injuries
column4: and an effective psychological terror weapon.

column1: Geraint (Gez) Jones from Wrexham joined the Royal Welsh Regiment looking for adventure. But this was not what he had signed up for. The IEDs were hard to detect and a constant threat. Gez saw what they could do to soldiers and their families. When the war was over
column2: he felt like a failure and started drinking and using drugs. Geraint recovered after he left the army
column3: focusing on physical exercise and his love of the outdoors
column4: wrote a best-selling book based on his experiences and has forged a successful career as a podcaster and writer of historical fiction.

column1: Steve Owen from Cardigan was another who signed up looking for adventure. But in 2010
column2: Steve’s Jackal vehicle hit an IED. He ended up having his leg amputated as a result of chronic pain from his injuries. This would be the beginning of a new life for Steve and his family. Just four months after his amputation
column3: Steve succeeded in completing a 26-mile sponsored walk. Now with three children and a happy marriage
column4: he is embarking on an even more ambitious marathon to raise funds for Woody’s Lodge
column5: a charity that supports veterans of the armed forces and emergency services
column6: where he works as project manager.

column1: Most challenging of all for families back home was the loss of a loved one. Sarah Adams from Cwmbran was proud when her young son James Prosser joined the army. James drove a Warrior Infantry Fighting Vehicle at the height of the IED attacks
column3: the news that Sarah feared most arrived one morning. An IED had blown up the Warrior James was driving
column4: and he had died from his injuries. With the war still raging
column5: James's mother felt she needed to go to Camp Bastion
column6: where James had died
column7: to get some resolution of her grief. Sarah flew to Camp Bastion in June 2012
column8: three years after her son’s death there.

column1: Hugh Keir from the village of Crynant near Neath was a sniper in the 3rd Battalion Parachute Regiment. He was trapped in the siege of Musa Qala and at the mercy of daily Taliban bombardments. Like many veterans
column2: it took years for Hugh to get help for the deep psychological impact of his experiences. As part of his recovery
column3: Hugh started a podcast and a rugby team - the FuBars - to help others.
