2459;2459;Olly Alexander: Growing up Gay;None;Olly Alexander explores the mental health issues faced by members of the LGBT+ community.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07k32vd.jpg;BBC, iPlayer, TV, Olly Alexander: Growing up Gay;Olly Alexander explores the mental health issues faced by members of the LGBT+ community.;Documentary in which Years and Years frontman Olly Alexander explores the mental health issues faced by members of the LGBT+ community.;Recent figures show that more than 40 per cent of LGBT+ people will experience a significant mental health problem
column2: compared to around 25 per cent of the whole population
column3: and are more than twice as likely to have attempted suicide.

column1: In this eye-opening film
column2: young pop culture icon Olly Alexander explores why the gay community is more vulnerable to mental health issues
column3: as he opens up about his own long-term battles with depression. As the outspoken frontman of British band Years and Years
column4: Olly is a powerful voice on mental health
column5: bullying and LGBT+ rights. He has broken taboos with music videos that celebrate queer identities and spoken openly about his own sexuality as well as his ongoing struggles with anxiety.

column1: In the film Olly joins young people on their journeys battling issues that parallel his own - from homophobic bullying to eating and anxiety disorders - and along the way he asks what can be done to address them.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language and some upsetting scenes.;2017;60;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07k32vd.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07k32vd.jpg;recent figure show 40 per cent lgbt people experience significant mental health problem compared around 25 per cent whole population twice likely attempted suicide eyeopening film young pop culture icon olly alexander explores gay community vulnerable mental health issue open longterm battle depression outspoken frontman british band year year olly powerful voice mental health bullying lgbt right broken taboo music video celebrate queer identity spoken openly sexuality well ongoing struggle anxiety film olly join young people journey battling issue parallel homophobic bullying eating anxiety disorder along way asks done address;1

2460;2460;Work It: Body Confidence Stories;Series 1: 4. Matt and Sarah;Student Matt ditches the booze and Tourette’s sufferer Sarah is exercising in public.;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p07jjdb0.jpg;BBC
column5: Series 1: 4. Matt and Sarah;Student Matt ditches the booze and Tourette’s sufferer Sarah is exercising in public.;Student Matt attempts to ditch his boozy lifestyle and man boobs for a healthy lean body
column6: and Sarah who has Tourette’s
column7: wants the confidence to work out in public.;"In this episode
column8: Work It trainer and Body building Champion Jay tells the story of how his love for the extreme things in life left him a double amputee after motorbike accident. 3 months in a coma and every bone in the right side of his body broken Jay’s brave recovery is when he found his purpose in life
column9: to work out and train others.

column1: The trainers meet Sarah who has Tourette’s Syndrome and wants to gain the confidence to work out in public and increase her core strength
column2: and boozy student Matt needs a life check from the trainers.

column1: Sarah
column2: who’s most common tic is to meow
column3: tells the story of how she’s has been told to leave gyms in the past when she has uncontrollably ticked. Kelechi’s mindfulness approach is the perfect fit to help Sarah in techniques which help keep her mind elsewhere
column4: combined with uplifting her self-assurance and improving her core strength. The personal trainers are gob-smacked by Matt’s revelations about his student lifestyle in one day he can get through over 4000 calories just in alcohol! Esmée takes no prisoners and quickly puts Matt to work in the gym. He wants to ditch the drinking and lose his ‘dad bod’ but he’ll need will power and grit to stick to the programme that Esmée has set.";Documentary;BBC THREE;Contains some strong language.;2019;20;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p07jjdb0.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p07jjdb0.jpg;episode work trainer body building champion jay tell story love extreme thing life left double amputee motorbike accident 3 month coma every bone right side body broken jay ’ brave recovery found purpose life work train others trainer meet sarah tourette ’ syndrome want gain confidence work public increase core strength boozy student matt need life check trainer sarah ’ common tic meow tell story ’ told leave gym past uncontrollably ticked kelechi ’ mindfulness approach perfect fit help sarah technique help keep mind elsewhere combined uplifting selfassurance improving core strength personal trainer gobsmacked matt ’ revelation student lifestyle one day get 4000 calorie alcohol esmée take prisoner quickly put matt work gym want ditch drinking lose ‘ dad bod ’ ’ need power grit stick programme esmée set;1

column1: 2461;2461;House of Saud: A Family at War;Series 1: Episode 3;What does the future hold for Saudi Arabia and the rest of the world?;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/{recipe}/p097cb0p.jpg;BBC
column4: House of Saud: A Family at War
column5: Series 1: Episode 3;What does the future hold for Saudi Arabia and the rest of the world?;Documentary series. The House of Saud is now facing a moment of unprecedented instability. This episode looks at how the family stays in power.;"The House of Saud
column6: rulers of the modern kingdom for nearly a century
column7: are now facing a moment of unprecedented instability. This episode looks at how the family stays in power.

column1: The film features some of those who have worked for Saudi princes. They describe how the wealth allowed lives of privilege and pleasure out of the spotlight. But the growth of social media has meant Saudis are getting increasing insight into the behaviour of their rulers
The uniquely generous social contract that has existed in the kingdom for decades has protected and bolstered the House of Saud
column2: yet this is changing. Facing a demographic time-bomb of a hugely young population and an economy beset by low oil prices
column3: the new ruler Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman has embarked on an unprecedented programme of social and economic reform. Allowing women to drive and relaxing rules on the male guardianship system
column4: his modernising agenda has pleased many. At the same time
column5: his government has recently introduced strict anti-terror laws and is conducting what many consider to be a crackdown on any critics. This month
column6: a leading a group of UN experts attacked the kingdom's behaviour as a 'persecution of human rights defenders'.

column1: The film also features information security experts who believe that the Saudi government uses sophisticated methods to monitor social media in order to suppress dissent and internal criticism of the regime.
With this crucially important country facing a historic crossroads
column2: the programme asks what the future holds for Saudi Arabia and the rest of the world.";Documentary;BBC TWO;Contains some upsetting scenes.;2018;59;documentaries;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/352x198/p097cb0p.jpg;https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1200x675/p097cb0p.jpg;house saud ruler modern kingdom nearly century facing moment unprecedented instability episode look family stay power film feature worked saudi prince describe wealth allowed life privilege pleasure spotlight growth social medium meant saudi getting increasing insight behaviour ruler including transgression uniquely generous social contract existed kingdom decade protected bolstered house saud yet changing facing demographic timebomb hugely young population economy beset low oil price new ruler crown prince mohammed bin salman embarked unprecedented programme social economic reform allowing woman drive relaxing rule male guardianship system modernising agenda pleased many time government recently introduced strict antiterror law conducting many consider crackdown critic month leading group un expert attacked kingdom behaviour persecution human right defender film also feature information security expert believe saudi government us sophisticated method monitor social medium order suppress dissent internal criticism regime crucially important country facing historic crossroad programme asks future hold saudi arabia rest world;1

column4: Israel and Iran: The Hidden War;Jiyar Gol heads to Israel on the trail of half a ton of missing Iranian secret documents.;The BBC's Jiyar Gol travels to Israel on the trail of half a ton of missing Iranian secret documents.;For years
column5: Israel and Iran have been involved in an escalating hidden war
column6: a conflict played out in the shadows
column7: on land
column8: air and sea
column9: with tit-for-tat attacks that avoided open clashes. But they are now becoming more conspicuous - with Iran's nuclear programme a major flashpoint. Iran's leaders say they have no plans to build nuclear weapons - but Israel claims otherwise. Numerous explosions in Iran's nuclear and missile facilities have been blamed by former Iranian officials on Israel's Foreign intelligence service
column10: Mossad. column4: Flint;The untold story of the one of the worst man-made disasters in American history.;Documentary filmed over five years exploring the untold story of the man-made disaster that continues to haunt America. Narrated by Alec Baldwin.;"Flint is the birthplace of General Motors and was once one of the most prosperous cities in the world. However
column5: in the 1980s
column6: the automobile industry in Flint collapsed
column7: costing thousands of jobs and beginning a grim economic decline.

column1: Against this backdrop
column2: Rick Snyder rose to power on a promise to run government like a business. As Michigan’s governor
column3: he stripped Flint’s city council of its power
column4: and his administrators raised water prices to balance the books. They then forced the city to use water from the Flint River in order to save more money. Almost immediately
column5: it became clear something was wrong. In many homes the water turned brown
column6: with residents reporting an increase in illness and rashes. At the last remaining General Motors assembly plant in Flint
column7: car parts began to rust.

column1: Despite growing protests
column2: the government insisted the water was perfectly safe. When Scotland-based film-maker Anthony Baxter arrived on the scene
column3: he found Flint residents taking matters into their own hands
column4: pulling together in a remarkable community effort to get at the truth. Hundreds of volunteers took part in a city-wide testing of Flint’s water. Rock band promoter and mother of three Melissa Mays helped lead the effort in partnership with decorated scientist Marc Edwards. Professor Edwards concluded that Flint was the site of a man-made health disaster. Because state officials didn’t treat the river water properly to prevent corrosion
column5: it had eaten away at Flint’s old lead pipes
column6: unleashing lead particles through the drinking water supply. For more than a year
column7: lead had been finding its way into the bloodstreams of more than 10
column8: 000 of the city's children.

column1: Narrated by Alec Baldwin
column2: this documentary explores the untold story of the man-made disaster that continues to haunt America to this day.
